questions.text: Which class of hypovolemic shock, according to Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) guidelines, is characterised by the absence of urine output?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Class IV

Explanation:

  • According to the Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS), in the classes of hypovolemic shock, class IV is characterised by the absence of urine output.

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 5 cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the staging, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) cT3N1M0

Explanation:

According to the TNM Staging of Breast Cancer, the staging in the given case is cT3N1M0.

  • cT3: Clinically, the tumor is greater than 5 cm.
  • N1: Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes are involved.
  • M0: No evidence of distant metastasis.

Stage

Description

Tumor size (T)

TX

Primary tumor cannot be assessed

T0

No evidence of primary tumor

Tis

Carcinoma in situ (DCIS, LCIS, or Paget's disease)

T1

Tumor ≤ 2 cm

T1mi

Tumor ≤ 1 mm

T1a

Tumor > 1 mm but ≤ 5 mm

T1b

Tumor > 5 mm but ≤ 10 mm

T1c

Tumor > 10 mm but ≤ 20 mm

T2

Tumor > 2 cm but ≤ 5 cm

T3

Tumor > 5 cm

T4

Tumor of any size with direct extension to chest wall or skin

T4a

Extension to the chest wall

T4b

Ulceration or skin nodules

T4c

Both T4a and T4b

T4d

Inflammatory breast cancer

Node (N)

NX

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastases to movable ipsilateral level I, II axillary lymph nodes

N2

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or clinically apparent internal mammary nodes

N2a

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes that are clinically fixed or matted

N2b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes without axillary lymph node involvement

N3

Metastasis to axillary lymph nodes or infraclavicular nodes, or to supraclavicular nodes

N3a

Metastasis to infraclavicular nodes

N3b

Metastasis to internal mammary nodes

N3c

Metastasis to supraclavicular nodes

Metastasis (M)

MX

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

 

Stage Grouping

  • Stage 0: Tis N0 M0
  • Stage IA: T1/T1mi N0 M0
  • Stage IB: T0 N1mi M0; T1/T1mi N1mi M0
  • Stage IIA: T0 N1 M0; T1 N1 M0; T2 N0 M0
  • Stage IIB: T2 N1 M0; T3 N0 M0
  • Stage IIIA: T0 N2 M0; T1 N2 M0; T2 N2 M0; T3 N1 M0
  • Stage IIIB: T3 N2 M0
  • Stage IIIC: T4 N0 M0; T4 N1 M0; T4 N2 M0; Any T N3 M0
  • Stage IV: Any T Any N M1

questions.text: Genetic testing for BRCA 1/BRCA 2 is indicated for all of the following except:

choices.text: Breast cancer diagnosed in a postmenopausal female >50 years of age

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Breast cancer diagnosed in a postmenopausal female >50 years of age

Explanation:

  • Genetic Testing for BRCA1/BRCA2 Mutations is generally not routinely indicated for women who are diagnosed with breast cancer after the age of 50.

Indications

  • An individual at any age with a known pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant in a cancer susceptibility gene within the family
  • Breast cancer diagnosed age ≤50 years
  • TNBC (Triple-Negative Breast Cancer) diagnosed age ≤60 years (Option D ruled out)
  • Two breast cancer primaries (Option C ruled out)
  • Breast cancer at any age with one or more relative with breast cancer diagnosed ≤50 years, invasive ovarian cancer, male breast cancer, pancreatic cancer, high-grade or metastatic prostate cancer
  • Breast cancer at any age with two or more affected relatives
  • Male breast cancer (Option B ruled out)
  • An individual with a personal or family history of ≥3 of the following:
    • Breast cancer, sarcoma, adrenocortical carcinoma, brain tumour, leukaemia
    • Colon cancer, endometrial cancer, thyroid cancer, kidney cancer, dermatological manifestations, macrocephaly or hamartomatous polyps of the gastrointestinal tract
    • Lobular breast cancer, diffuse gastric cancer
    • Breast cancer, gastrointestinal cancer or hamartomatous polyps, ovarian sex chord tumours, pancreatic cancer, testicular Sertoli cell tumours or childhood skin pigmentation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best preferred investigation for Neuroendocrine Tumors (NETs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PET

Explanation:

The investigation of choice for the localization of Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (PNETs) is SRS (somatostatin receptor scintigraphy).

  • They are derived from pleuripotent stem cells.
  • Classified as functional and non-functional PNETs
  • Subtypes:
    • Insulinoma (most common functional PNET)
    • Gastrinoma (most common functional and malignant PNET)
    • Non-functional tumors
    • VIPoma
    • Glucagonoma
    • Somatostatinoma
    • Carcinoid
    • ACTHoma
    • GRFoma
  • It is symptomatic and diagnosed at an early stage.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Laboratory measurement of active substances or its by products.
    • PET (Positron Emission Tomography)/CT: Preferred investigation for NETs nowadays. (Option D)
      • Tracer: 68Gallium (68Ga)-labeled somatostatin analogs
    • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS) is used for the localization of NETs. (IOC).
      • All Neuroendocrine tumors express Somatostatin receptors except Insulinoma.
      • It is not used nowadays. (Option B ruled out)

 

USG (ultrasound) (Option A) is not the best choice for pancreatic NETs because the pancreas is deep in the abdomen, making it hard to visualize. It is useful for detecting large masses but is less sensitive for smaller tumors or those without distinct features.

MRI (Option C) is useful for pancreatic tumors and liver metastases but lacks the functional detail of SRS. SRS is the gold standard for detecting somatostatin receptor-positive NETs.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient presents with hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Renal angiomyolipoma

Explanation:

  • The presence of hematuria and a neovascular mass in the left kidney on a CT scan suggests a benign renal tumor, likely Renal Angiomyolipoma (AML).

Arise from
  • Perivascular epithelioid cells

Types
  • Sporadic AMLs: Present in the 4th-6th decades, typically small, solitary, and slow-growing.
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Present earlier (3rd-4th decades), larger, multiple, bilateral, and tend to grow.

Symptoms

  • Abdominal or flank pain, hematuria, hypertension, anemia.
  • Impaired kidney function, usually due to hemorrhage (severe complication).
  • Wunderlich syndrome: Nontraumatic kidney hemorrhage.

Risk Factors for AML Complications
  • Pregnancy: Increased risk of hemorrhage
  • TSC-associated AMLs: Higher risk of CKD and ESKD
  • Epithelioid AMLs: Potential for malignant transformation, metastasis, and local recurrence.

 

Risk factors for hemorrhage:

  • AML size (>6 cm)
  • Increased vascularity
  • Large intralesional aneurysms (>5 mm)
  • Exophytic growth pattern.

Histology

Circular blood vessels, muscles, and fat; perivascular epithelioid cells with dense eosinophilic cytoplasm and mitotic figures.

Diagnosis
  • CT: (Investigation of choice) Presence of intralesional fat and neovascular mass.
  • USG: Appears as hyperechoic
  • Immunocytochemical analysis: Differentiates AML from RCC, using markers like HMB-45 and melan-A.

Treatment
  • Observation (tumors <4 cm)
  • Nephron-Sparing Surgery(Partial nephrectomy) (larger tumors or those with a high risk of bleeding)
  • Angioembolization (acute hemorrhage).
  • Medications (mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and sirolimus).

 

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) (Option A) is a malignant tumor of the kidney that appears as a solid, heterogeneous mass with irregular borders and necrosis. While it shows neovascularization, it lacks the fat component and distinct vascular pattern of angiomyolipomas (AMLs). The presence of these benign features suggests AML, not RCC.

 

Renal oncocytoma (Option B) is a benign tumor that typically appears as a well-defined, solid mass with homogeneous enhancement and sometimes a central scar on CT or MRI. It lacks the neovascular pattern and fat component seen in AMLs. Oncocytomas have less vascularity, making them unlikely in this case.

 

Renal cysts (Option D) is a fluid-filled, non-enhancing structure with smooth walls on imaging. It lacks vascularity and neovascularization. A renal cyst doesn't cause hematuria or present as a neovascular mass, making it unlikely in this case.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman after thyroidectomy comes to you for a 2nd opinion for further treatment of papillary thyroid cancer. What would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Radioiodine scan

Explanation:

  • After thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer, a radioiodine scan (I-131) is recommended to detect any remaining thyroid tissue or metastasis, as papillary thyroid cancer is often Radioactive Iodine (RAI)-avid (capable of absorbing and concentrating radioactive iodine).

Roles:

  • Remnant Ablation: Destruction of any remaining benign thyroid tissue following a total or subtotal thyroidectomy.
  • Adjuvant Therapy: Additional treatment post-surgery to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence.
  • Treatment of Known Disease: Targeting and destroying residual cancer cells or recurrent structural or biochemical disease.

Radioactive Iodine Ablation (RAI):

  • Isotope Used: Iodine-131 (Half-Life: 8 Days)
  • Emission:
    • Beta Rays: 90% of emissions; targeted treatment of the thyroid gland while sparing surrounding tissues.
    • Gamma Rays: 10% of emissions; used for imaging and also responsible for side effects.
  • Applications: Primarily for Differentiated Thyroid Cancer (DTC) like Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma (PTC) and Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma (FTC).
  • Side Effects: (Dose-Dependent): Sialadenitis, nasolacrimal duct obstruction, transient swelling, infertility, secondary malignancies (e.g., leukemia)

Indications

Contraindications
  • Differentiated thyroid cancers
    • E.g., Papillary thyroid carcinoma
    • Follicular thyroid carcinoma
    • Hurthle cell carcinoma
  • Tumor size >2cm
  • One or more risk factors
  • Obvious extrathyroidal extension
  • >45 years of age
  • Lymph node and distant metastasis
  • Poorly differentiated thyroid cancers
    • E.g., Medullary thyroid carcinoma
    • Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma
  • Pregnancy & Breastfeeding (Absolute contraindications)
  • Vomiting & Diarrhea (Relative contraindications)

 

Radiotherapy (Option A) is not the standard follow-up after thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid cancer (PTC). RAI therapy is preferred as it targets thyroid tissue, while radiotherapy is reserved for advanced cases or metastasis. RAI is more effective than radiotherapy for treating remaining thyroid cells or metastasis.

Chemotherapy (Option B):Papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) is not treated with chemotherapy, as it doesn't respond well. RAI is the standard treatment, while chemotherapy is used for more aggressive cancers like anaplastic thyroid cancer.

Wait and watch (Option D) approach may be used in low-risk cases of papillary thyroid cancer (PTC) if the tumor is small, localized, and has been fully removed. However, after thyroidectomy, a radioiodine scan (RAI) is typically done to check for remaining tissue or metastases, even in low-risk cases.

questions.text: A 17-year-old woman with no comorbidities presents with numbness and paraesthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no history of smoking or history of other illnesses. She mentions the episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Raynaud’s phenomenon

Explanation:

  • The scenario of a young woman experiencing numbness, paresthesia, and bluish discoloration of the fingers during cold stress or excessive stress, with no comorbidities, smoking history, or other illnesses, is most likely diagnosed as Raynaud's Phenomenon.

Category

Description

Definition

It is characterized by episodic reduction in blood flow, typically in the fingers, triggered by cold exposure or stress.

Clinical Features
  • Pallor: Skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow.
  • Cyanosis: Skin turns blue or purple due to deoxygenation of blood.
  • Rubor: Skin turns red as blood flow returns, often with swelling and tingling.
  • Cold Sensitivity: Cold, numb fingers.
  • Pain: Pain during the cyanotic phase.
  • Swelling and Tingling: Occurs in the rubor phase.

Types
  • Primary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Disease):
    • Occurs without underlying disease.
    • More common and has a better prognosis.
  • Secondary Raynaud Phenomenon (Raynaud Syndrome):
    • Occurs due to an underlying condition (e.g., scleroderma, lupus).
    • Often more severe.

Management
  • Lifestyle Modifications: Avoid cold exposure, stress reduction, and smoking cessation.
  • Medications: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine), alpha-blockers (e.g., prazosin), and other vasodilators.
  • Avoidance of Triggers: Avoid cold, beta-blockers, and caffeine.
  • Advanced Treatments: Surgical sympathectomy for severe cases.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical Presentation and History: Based on symptoms and triggers.
  • Nailfold Capillaroscopy: To examine capillary changes.
  • Blood Tests: To identify underlying autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.

Sequence of events in Raynaud’s phenomenon:

  • Pallor: The initial phase where the skin becomes pale or white due to reduced blood flow and vasospasm.
  • Cyanosis: Followed by a blue or purple colour due to continued reduced blood flow and lack of oxygen.
  • Rubor: The final phase is where the skin turns red as blood flow returns and the area warms up.

 

Buerger’s disease (thromboangiitis obliterans) (Option A) is an inflammatory condition affecting small and medium-sized arteries and veins, leading to clot formation and reduced blood flow. It is most commonly seen in young male smokers and is characterized by painful ischemia, ulceration, or gangrene of the fingers or toes. This diagnosis is unlikely due to the absence of smoking history, risk factors, and ulcerative symptoms.

 

Atherosclerosis (Option B) is the buildup of fatty plaques in arteries, often seen in older individuals with risk factors like smoking, high cholesterol, hypertension, and diabetes. This diagnosis is unlikely for the young woman, as she has no comorbidities or risk factors, and atherosclerosis typically presents with chronic symptoms such as pain or claudication, rather than intermittent symptoms triggered by cold or stress.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA) (Option D) affects large arteries in people over 50, causing headaches, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and vision issues.

questions.text: All of the following are anterior mediastinal tumors except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lymphoma

Explanation:

  • Lymphoma is a tumor of the middle mediastinum, not the anterior mediastinum.

Tumors of mediastinum

Anterior mediastinum

Middle mediastinum

Posterior mediastinum
  • Thymomas (Option D ruled out)
  • Thymic carcinomas
  • Thymic cyst
  • Germ cell tumors (Option C ruled out)
  • Lymphomas
  • Parathyroid adenomas (Option A ruled out)
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Fibroma
  • Lymphomas (Option B)
  • Tumors of the heart and great vessels
  • Tumours of the trachea, mainstem bronchi, and oesophagus
  • Aortic pathologies such as aortic aneurysm, abscess, or dissection.
  • Pericardial cysts
  • Bronchogenic cysts
  • Neuroenteric cyst
  • Mesothelial cyst
  • Pheochromocytoma

 
  • Neurilemomas (schwannomas)
  • Neurofibromas
  • Ganglioneuromas
  • Ganglioneuroblastomas
  • Neuroblastomas
  • Pheochromocytomas

questions.text: A chronic-alcoholic presents to the emergency room with acute pain in the abdomen in the epigastric region radiating to the back with nausea, anorexia, and occasional vomiting. Investigations showed elevated amylase levels (3 times) and total count. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute pancreatitis

Explanation:

The scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with epigastric abdominal pain radiating to the back, along with nausea, anorexia, occasional vomiting, and elevated amylase levels and total count, is indicative of Acute Pancreatitis.

Clinical Diagnosis (Requires 2 of 3):

  • Abdominal pain is strongly suggestive of acute pancreatitis. (Option B)
  • Serum amylase and/or lipase (more specific) level at least 3 times the upper limit of normal. (Option B)
  • Imaging findings characteristic of acute pancreatitis.

X-ray Features
  • Sentinel loop sign:
    • Dilated loop of small intestine near the inflamed pancreas due to localized ileus.
    • Significance: Early indicator of acute pancreatitis on X-ray.

Sentinel loop sign
  • Colon cut-off sign:
    • Abrupt termination of gas in the colon at the splenic flexure, with collapsed distal colon loops.
    • Significance: Suggests localized pancreatic inflammation, causing colonic spasm as an indirect sign of acute pancreatitis

Investigations of Choice:

  • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT): Primary tool for assessing pancreatic necrosis, peripancreatic inflammation, fluid collections, and complications.
    • Most reliable for staging and detecting complications.
    • May underestimate necrosis if done in the first 24 hours.

Morphological Types (Revised Atlanta Classification 2008):

  • Interstitial oedematous pancreatitis: Mild form with pancreatic oedema and swelling but no necrosis.
  • Necrotising pancreatitis: Severe form involving pancreatic parenchymal necrosis, associated with higher morbidity and mortality.

 

Acute hepatitis (Option A) is liver inflammation, often caused by viral infections, alcohol, or toxins, with symptoms like jaundice, fatigue, dark urine, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST). This diagnosis is unlikely for the patient, as her symptoms of epigastric pain, elevated amylase, and the absence of jaundice or liver enzyme elevation point more toward pancreatitis.

Acute Cholecystitis (Option C), caused by gallstones, presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea, with ultrasound showing gallstones or thickened walls. However, the patient's epigastric pain and elevated amylase suggest pancreatitis, not cholecystitis.

Acute appendicitis (Option D) presents with right lower quadrant pain, fever, elevated white blood cell count, and pain that starts around the umbilicus, shifting to the lower right abdomen. In this case, the patient has epigastric pain and elevated amylase, making appendicitis unlikely, as it doesn’t typically affect amylase levels.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for the chronic alcoholic patient’s presentation with confusion, aphasia, unstable gait, and symptoms related to Wernicke’s encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Vit B1

  • The scenario of a chronic alcoholic patient exhibiting confusion, aphasia, unstable gait, and signs of Wernicke's encephalopathy suggests vitamin B1 deficiency, which can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome (Cerebral Beri-Beri).

Clinical Manifestations

Wernicke Encephalopathy:

  • Symptoms: Ophthalmoplegia, nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia, global confusion.

Korsakoff Psychosis:

  • Symptoms: Anterograde and retrograde amnesia, sensory agnosia, and confabulation.

Causes of Thiamine Deficiency in Alcoholics
  • Increased thiamine requirements due to alcohol consumption. Alcohol is a source of empty calories.
  • Inhibition of intestinal thiamine absorption by alcohol.

Metabolic Implications
  • Impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.
  • Accumulation of pyruvate and lactate in the blood.
  • Potential for life-threatening lactic acidosis.

Vit C (Option B) is also known as ascorbic acid. Its deficiency results in scurvy, bleeding gums, impaired healing, bone weakness and anaemia.

Vit D (Option C) is essential for calcium homeostasis and bone health; its deficiency leads to rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

Vit B3 (Option D) is also known as niacin. Its deficiency causes pellagra, characterised by the "4 D's": dermatitis, dementia, diarrhoea, and can be fatal (Death).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis?

choices.text: Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles
USG is the gold standard investigation for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Caused by hypertrophy of longitudinal muscles

Explanation:

  • Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) is caused by the hypertrophy of the circular muscles of the pylorus, not the longitudinal muscles.

Clinical Presentation
  • Typical onset: 3 to 6 weeks of age
  • Symptoms:
    • Projectile, non-bilious vomiting (Option A ruled out)
    • Visible gastric peristalsis
    • Palpable "olive-like" mass in the abdomen (hypertrophied pylorus), best felt from the left side
      • Test feed: Gastric peristalsis is seen passing from left to right across the abdomen, and in a relaxed (feeding) baby, the pyloric ‘tumor’ is palpable as an ‘olive’ in the right upper quadrant.
    • Dyselectrolytemias-
      • Hypochloremia
      • Hypokalemia due to persistent vomiting
      • Metabolic alkalosis. (Option D ruled out)

Ultrasound (Gold Standard)

(Option C ruled out)
  • Characteristic "doughnut sign" indicating thickened pyloric muscle
  • Diagnostic criteria:
    • Pyloric muscle thickness ≥ 4 mm
    • Pyloric canal length > 14 mm
    • "Cervix sign" on long-axis view
    • "Target sign" on short-axis view

Barium Meal (Less Common)

Can assist in diagnosis but is less accurate than ultrasound, it reveals:

  • "String sign": Thin streak of contrast through narrowed pylorus
  • "Railroad track sign": Two thin lines of contrast indicating mild narrowing
  • "Double track sign": Similar to railroad track sign, indicating thickened muscle

questions.text: A 28-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast. Which of the following is the most likely cause of acute mastitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Crack in the nipple

Explanation:

The most likely cause of Acute Mastitis is crack in the nipple.

  • It refers to infammation of the breast tissue.
  • It can occur in lactating (more common) as well as non-lactating women.
  • It occurs during the first month of breastfeeding.
  • It is caused by a local infection (due to cracks and fissures in the nipples).
  • Organisms: Staphylococcus aureus (more common), Streptococci
  • Clinical features:
    • Erythematous and painful breast
    • Fever
    • Single or multiple abscesses (Staphylococci)
    • Cellulitis (Streptococci)
  • Management:
    • Antibiotics
    • Continued milk expression from the breast.

 

Breast engorgement (Option A) causes swelling and discomfort but doesn’t lead to infection or mastitis unless complications like blocked ducts or nipple damage occur. It also lacks the fever and redness seen in mastitis.

Hormonal influence (Option B), such as those during pregnancy or menstruation, can cause breast tenderness and swelling, but they don't directly lead to acute mastitis. While hormonal fluctuations may contribute to conditions like engorgement, they don't cause the infection or inflammation seen in mastitis.

Absence of lactation (Option C), or insufficient milk supply, may cause discomfort or engorgement but is not linked to acute mastitis. Mastitis usually occurs in breastfeeding women due to milk stasis, blocked ducts, or nipple trauma, which allow bacteria to enter. If a mother isn't lactating, mastitis is unlikely unless there's an unrelated infection.

questions.text: Which lymph node is most commonly involved in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pelvic

Explanation:

  • Prostate Cancer primarily spreads to regional pelvic lymph nodes, including the external and internal iliac nodes, before metastasizing to other areas.
  • Most common malignant tumor in men over the age of 65 years.
  • Most common among Afro-American

Risk factor

  • Advanced age
  • High-fat diet

Protective factors

(Mnemonic: LESA)

  • Lycopene
  • Vitamin E
  • Selenium
  • Vitamin A

Pathology

  • Most common site- peripheral zone (75%) > transitional zone (15%) > central zone (10%)
  • Most common histological type is adenocarcinoma
  • Most common genetic alteration seen in CA prostate- hypermethylation of GSTP1 (Glutathione transferase promoter region 1) located on chromosome 11.
  • 70-80% of the cases.
  • Microscopy: small, crowded, absent basal layer, lack of branching

Clinical features
  • Commonly asymptomatic.
  • Bladder outlet obstruction.
  • Haematuria
  • Pelvic pain, back pain, arthritic pain in sacroiliac joint-features of secondaries
  • On per rectal examination: hard, nodular, irregular often with loss of median groove.

Routes of spread
  • Most common route of spread- haematogenous (skeletal metastases: pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae)
  • Lymphatic: Internal iliac, external iliac lymph nodes, retroperitoneal lymph nodes, mediastinal nodes and occasionally the supraclavicular nodes.

Investigations

  • DRE (Digital Rectal Exam): Physical examination; detects nodules but limited in early-stage
  • PSA (prostate-specific antigen) Test: Measures PSA levels; elevated levels suggest cancer
  • TRUS (Transrectal Ultrasound): Imaging with rectal probe; detects abnormalities
  • mpMRI (Multiparametric MRI): Advanced imaging; superior for staging and capsular spread
  • Prostate Biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis; tissue sampling for cancer cells

Management

  • Active Surveillance: For low-risk cases; regular monitoring
  • Radical Prostatectomy: Surgery for localized cancer; potentially curative
  • Radiation Therapy: High-energy rays; external or brachytherapy
  • Hormone Therapy: Reduces/block testosterone; for advanced/metastatic cases
  • Chemotherapy: Systemic drug treatment; for advanced/metastatic cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the following image?

choices.text: Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Staphylococcus aureus is the causative organism

Explanation:

  • The given image depicts Fournier's Gangrene, which results from a polymicrobial infection involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, rather than solely Staphylococcus aureus

Fournier's Gangrene

Definition

Necrotizing infection of the soft tissues in the perineum, external genitalia, and perianal region, akin to necrotizing fasciitis.

Causative Organisms

Mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic bacteria in a fulminating inflammation of the subcutaneous tissues. (Option A)

Clinical Presentation
  • Symptoms: Intense pain in the genitalia, progressing through five phases:
    • Prodromal Phase: Fever and lethargy.
    • Early Pain Phase: Intense pain, possible edema, pruritus.
    • Progressive Phase: Increased pain, erythema.
    • Crepitation Phase: Dusky skin with subcutaneous crepitation.
    • Gangrene Phase: Gangrene with purulent discharge.
  • Pain may decrease as gangrene progresses.
  • Severity ranges from localized tenderness to septic shock.

Risk Factors
  • Peripheral vascular disease
  • Diabetes mellitus (Option B ruled out)
  • Malnutrition
  • Alcoholism
  • Immunocompromised states.

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation supported by imaging or lab findings.

Management

Initial Treatment:

  • Fluid resuscitation.
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Surgical debridement of necrotic tissue.

Additional Measures:

  • Daily rounds (high rates mortality and morbidity) (Option C ruled out)
  • Urinary and fecal diversion to prevent wound contamination.
  • Intensive monitoring for sepsis.
  • Wound review and vacuum-assisted dressing.
  • Skin grafting post-infection control.

 

The testes remain unaffected (Option D) in this condition as they have the dual blood supply.

questions.text: What type of hernia is a funicular hernia? Direct inguinal hernia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Indirect inguinal hernia

Explanation:

  • Funicular hernia is a type of indirect Inguinal Hernia.

Feature

Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Direct Inguinal Hernia

(Option A ruled out)

Common in

Young adults

Elderly

Course

It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring.

Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle

Relation to Spermatic Cord

Anterolateral to the spermatic cord

Posterior to the spermatic cord

Location of Neck of Sac

Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle.

Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels

Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Relation to Scrotum

Descends into the scrotum

Does not Descend

Types
  • Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal
  • Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis (Option B)
  • Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia

 

 

—

 

Femoral hernia (Option C) occurs when abdominal contents push through the femoral canal, located below the inguinal ligament, and is more common in women due to a wider pelvis. It differs from funicular or inguinal hernias as it is not associated with the inguinal canal and carries a higher risk of complications like incarceration or strangulation.

Umbilical hernia (Option D) occurs when part of the intestine or abdominal tissue protrudes near the navel. It is more common in infants but can affect adults, often due to obesity or increased intra-abdominal pressure. Unlike inguinal hernias, it is not related to the inguinal canal or processus vaginalis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of anorectal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intersphincteric

Explanation:

  • The intersphincteric type is the most common form of Anorectal Fistula (Fistula-in-Ano).
  • A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Classifications:

  • Low-level fistulas open into the anal canal below the internal ring.
  • High-level fistulas open into the anal canal at or above the internal ring.
  • Simple fistula without extensions
  • Complex fistula with extensions.

Parks classification:

Type 1

Inter- sphincteric (most common, 70%) (Option A)

Type 2

Trans- sphincteric (25%) (Option B ruled out)

Type 3

Supra- sphincteric (4%) (Option C ruled out)

Type 4

Extra- sphincteric (1%) (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after sustaining an RTA and injury to the lower chest. On presentation, the patient is stable, and vitals are normal. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct ANswer: A) eFAST

Explanation:

In the scenario of an RTA with a stable patient, normal vitals, and clear lung fields, the most appropriate next step would be an extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (eFAST).

  • It is a rapid bedside ultrasound to detect life-threatening injuries in trauma patients, focusing on the chest and abdomen.
  • It assesses the pericardium, pleural spaces, and abdominal cavity for air or fluid.
  • If clear lung fields rule out pneumothorax or hemothorax, eFAST helps detect other bleeding sources, like intraperitoneal bleeding.

FAST (Focused Abdominal Sonography for Trauma) and eFAST (Extended FAST)

  • Purpose: Assess for free fluid in the abdominal cavity, thoracic cavities, and pericardium. (Option A)
  • Nature of Injury: Not used to determine the specific nature or extent of injury.
  • Advantages: (Option A)
    • Rapid, reproducible, portable, and non-invasive bedside test.
    • Can be performed simultaneously with resuscitation.
    • Accurate at detecting >100 mL of free blood.
  • Limitations:
    • Operator-dependent and may be unreliable in obese patients or when the bowel is full of gas.
    • Low sensitivity (29–35%) for detecting hollow viscus or solid organ injuries without haemoperitoneum.
    • Unreliable for excluding injuries in penetrating trauma.
    • Requires repeat or supplementary investigations if needed.
    • Unreliable for assessing retroperitoneum.

 

Tube thoracostomy (Option B) is used for pneumothorax or hemothorax, but since the chest radiography shows clear lung fields, it’s not needed at this point.

CECT chest (Option C) and abdomen (Option D) are more invasive imaging options. Since the chest radiography is clear and the patient is stable, eFAST is a quicker, non-invasive first step to assess for other injuries, such as abdominal or retroperitoneal bleeding, before considering further imaging.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low-grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Transurethral resection of the tumor

Explanation:

In the case of a 2x2 cm bladder mass indicative of low-grade transitional cell carcinoma, the preferred initial treatment is Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor (TURBT).

  • It is the initial management of bladder tumours for accurate staging. (Option A)
  • It is performed using a cystoscope inserted through the urethra to remove the tumor from the bladder.
  • It allows for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes (tumor is removed and sent for histopathological examination).
  • Large tumours: Standard fractionated resection of the entire tumour (tumour base with deep muscle).
  • Small tumors (<3 cm): En bloc resection of the entire tumour (solitary tumor)
  • The following details should be recorded to enable accurate risk stratification:
    • Size of the primary tumour
    • Number of tumours
    • Nodular or papillary features
    • Presence of CIS
    • Completeness of visual resection.
  • Mapping biopsies (if CIS suspected): Taken from trigone, bladder dome and the right, left, anterior and posterior bladder wall.

Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

 

Resection with ileal conduit (Option B) involves removing the entire bladder and creating a urinary diversion using the ileum. It is typically reserved for invasive or high-grade bladder cancer, not low-grade transitional cell carcinoma, where transurethral resection is the ideal treatment.

Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction (Option C) is typically reserved for invasive bladder cancer or select cases of localized low-grade tumors in favorable locations. However, for most low-grade, non-muscle invasive bladder cancers, transurethral resection (TURBT) is the preferred initial treatment.

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Option D), given before the main treatment, is typically used for muscle-invasive bladder cancer or high-risk cases. For low-grade, non-muscle invasive tumors, TURBT is the initial treatment, with chemotherapy considered only if there is recurrence or progression.

questions.text: Which of the following will have unilateral hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Retrocaval ureter

Explanation:

  • Retrocaval ureter is one of the causes of unilateral Hydronephrosis (HN).
    • It is an aseptic dilatation of pelvicalyceal system due to partial or intermittent obstruction to the outflow of urine.

Causes:

Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis

Extramural Causes:

  • Advanced Malignancies
    • Colorectal cancer
    • Carcinoma cervix
    • Carcinoma Prostate
  • Retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Retrocaval Ureter (Option D)

Congenital Causes:

  • Posterior Urethral Valve (Option B ruled out)
  • Urethral atresia (Option A ruled out)

Intramural Causes:

  • PUJ Obstruction
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric Stricture
  • Urothelial tumor

Acquired Causes:

  • Bladder neck stenosis
  • BPH (Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia) (Option C ruled out)
  • CA Prostate
  • Urethral strictures

Intraluminal Causes:

  • Stone
  • Papillary Slough
  • Due to:
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Sickle cell anemia

 

Clinical features:

Unilateral Hydronephrosis

Bilateral Hydronephrosis
  • Congenital PUJ obstruction and calculus are the most common causes
  • Male to Female ratio 2:1
  • Right side kidney is affected more commonly

 

From lower urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain
  • Features of bladder outlet obstruction—frequency, hesitancy, poor stream
  • Kidneys are not palpable if renal failure develops early
  • Dull aching loin pain with dragging sensation or heaviness
  • Mass in the loin which moves with respiration
  • Dietl's crisis (Intermittent Hydronephrosis): Swelling in the loin after acute renal colic, disappears after passing a large volume of urine
  • Dysuria, haematuria. If infected, fever and tenderness in the renal angle

From bilateral upper urinary tract obstruction:

  • Loin pain, mass in the loin, attacks of renal colic
  • In severe cases, features of renal failure like oliguria, edema, and hiccoughs may be present

questions.text: A 44-year-old lady presents to the hospital with a ballotable flank mass. The mass measures 4 cm on CT imaging. Urine examination shows malignant cells. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Partial nephrectomy

Explanation:

  • A 4 cm ballotable flank mass with a CT scan showing a hyper-enhancing solid renal mass suggests Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC), with partial nephrectomy being the preferred treatment for tumors smaller than 4 cm.

Management

RCCs are radio and chemo-resistant.

Surgical Management:

Partial Nephrectomy: Involves removing only the tumor while preserving the remainder of the kidney. (Option A)

Indications:

  • T1 Disease(<7cm)
  • Restricted to poles
  • RCC in solitary functioning kidney

Radical Nephrectomy: Involves removal of the kidney with Gerota’s fascia, para-aortic nodes, and ureter up to the pelvic brim. (Option C ruled out)

Indications: Larger tumors or when partial nephrectomy is not feasible

Ablative Techniques

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) and Cryoablation: Involve destroying the tumor using extreme temperatures.

Indications:

  • Patients who are not surgical candidates
  • Patients with small tumors(T1a lesions) (usually <4 cm).

Systemic Therapy

(For advanced/ metastatic disease)

Targeted Therapy

  • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib)
  • mTOR inhibitors (e.g., everolimus)

Immunotherapy: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (e.g., nivolumab)

 

Partial nephrectomy + Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Option B): Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is typically used for muscle-invasive or high-risk RCC, which isn't the case here. With a 4 cm localized tumor, RCC generally doesn't respond well to chemotherapy, and partial nephrectomy alone is sufficient.

Radical nephrectomy + Postoperative radiotherapy (Option D): Postoperative radiotherapy is not typically used for RCC due to its resistance to radiation. Radical nephrectomy is reserved for larger or invasive tumors, while partial nephrectomy is preferred for this smaller 4 cm tumor to preserve kidney function.

questions.text: A soldier arrives at a referral hospital 24 hours after experiencing a shrapnel injury to his right thigh caused by a high-speed projectile. He expresses significant discomfort at the site of the wound. Upon examination, there is evidence of crepitus. Which of the following microorganisms is the probable culprit behind his current state?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Clostridium perfringens

Explanation:

  • The soldier's shrapnel injury to his right thigh, accompanied by significant discomfort, crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues), suggests Gas Gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

A rapidly progressive, potentially fatal condition characterized by widespread necrosis of muscles and soft-tissue destruction, often due to late-presenting missile wounds or crushing injuries.

Cause

Clostridium perfringens (Option D)

Incubation period

<24 hours but ranges from 1 hour to 6 weeks

Sources and predisposing factors
  • Contaminated soil and feces.
  • Wounds with necrotic or foreign material.
  • Crush wounds, road traffic accidents, amputations.
  • Anaerobic environments in the wound.

Common sites of infection
  • Adductor region of the lower limb and buttocks.
  • Subscapular region in the upper limb.

Clinical features
  • Severe pain with limb swelling rapidly increases in severity.
  • Serosanguineous discharge.
  • Skin turns brown to blue-black with hemorrhagic bullae.
  • Sweet, sticky odor & Soft-tissue crepitus (presence of gas in the tissues).

Complication

  • Septicaemia, toxemia, renal failure, liver failure.
  • Circulatory failure, DIC, secondary infections.
  • Death occurs in critically ill patients.

Investigation

  • X-ray: Gas in soft tissues.
  • Gram stain & blood culture: Large Gram-positive bacilli without neutrophils.
  • Biochemical profile: Metabolic acidosis, renal failure.
  • Peripheral blood smear: Haemolysis.
  • CT scan for chest or abdominal wounds.

Treatment

  • High-dose intravenous penicillin and clindamycin, along with 3rd generation cephalosporins, are given intravenously.
  • Polyvalent antiserums given intravenously.
  • All dead tissues are excised, and debridement is performed until healthy tissue bleeds.
  • Amputation done in severe cases
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

Prevention

  • Proper debridement of devitalized crushed wounds.
  • Devitalized wounds should not be sutured.
  • Adequate cleaning of wounds with H₂O₂ and normal saline.
  • Penicillin - As a prophylactic antibiotic.

Image

 

Clostridium septicum (Option A) causes spontaneous, non-traumatic gas gangrene and is associated with conditions like colorectal cancer or immunocompromised states, whereas Clostridium perfringens is more commonly linked to gas gangrene in traumatic injuries.

Clostridioides difficile (Option B) is primarily linked to antibiotic-associated diarrhea and colitis, not gas gangrene, and does not produce the gas or tissue necrosis seen in traumatic injuries.

Clostridium novyi (Option C) is a less common cause of gas gangrene, typically associated with specific conditions like soil or animal-related injuries, and is unlikely to be the cause of a shrapnel wound.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the qSOFA score components?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lactate dehydrogenase

Explanation:

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is not part of the components used in the qSOFA (quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) Score.

  • It is a simplified, rapid assessment scale developed as an easier alternative to the more complex SOFA score, which requires laboratory tests.
  • The Third International Consensus Definition of Sepsis recommends using qSOFA to identify patients with sepsis (higher risk of death, prolonged ICU stay, and increased need for ICU admission).
  • Components:
    • Respiratory rate ≥22 (Option A ruled out)
    • Altered mental status (Option C ruled out)
    • Systolic blood pressure ≤100 mm Hg. (Option D ruled out)
  • Interpretation: qSOFA ≥2 (with a concern for infection) is associated with a significantly greater risk of death or prolonged ICU stay.

questions.text: Inhalational induction of choice in children is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sevoflurane
 

Explanation:

  • The preferred method for inducing anesthesia through inhalation in children is Sevoflurane.

 

Sevoflurane

Properties

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated ether with low blood solubility (λb/g 0.65), allowing for rapid induction and emergence.

Its non-pungency makes it suitable for inhalation induction, especially in pediatric patients. It is used with conventional vaporizers.

Uses

Ideal for smooth and rapid inhalation induction, particularly in daycare procedures (4-8% concentration with nitrous oxide and oxygen).

It is commonly used for both pediatric and adult anesthesia.

C/I

Should be avoided in cases of severe hypovolemia, susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia, and intracranial hypertension.

Systemic Effects

Cardiovascular

Mild myocardial depression with slight reduction in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. It causes minimal heart rate increase and may prolong the QT interval.

Hepatic

Decreases portal vein flow but increases hepatic artery flow, maintaining overall hepatic perfusion.

Renal

Slightly decreases renal blood flow but has no known association with significant renal toxicity.

Compound A, a degradation product of sevoflurane, is nephrotoxic in animals but has no known adverse effects on humans.

Neuromuscular

Provides adequate muscle relaxation for intubation but is often combined with other agents or muscle relaxants.

Cerebral

Slight increases in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and intracranial pressure. High concentrations may impair CBF autoregulation. Seizures have not been reported.

Respiratory

Depresses respiration and helps reverse bronchospasm. Thus agent of choice in asthmatics.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common side effect induced by cisplatin chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - GI symptoms

  • Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are the most common side effects associated with Cisplatin (platinum-containing chemotherapy drug) treatment, including symptoms like nausea, vomiting, and loss of appetite.
  • Mechanism of action: It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing their growth and division.

  • Uses: It is widely used in the treatment of various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, bladder cancer, and carcinoma cervix (in combination with other drugs or radiation therapy).
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Nephrotoxicity
    • Ototoxicity
    • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting)
    • Progressive peripheral motor and sensory neuropathy
    • Myelosuppression (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia
    • Electrolyte disturbances (hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, and hypophosphatemia)
    • Hyperuricemia, hemolytic anemia, and cardiac abnormalities are rare side effects.
    • Anaphylactic-like reactions (facial edema, bronchoconstriction, tachycardia, and hypotension).

Neuropathy (Option B) is characterised by nerve damage and resulting in symptoms like numbness, tingling, and weakness, which is a known side effect of cisplatin. However, it is not the most common side effect.

Cardiotoxicity (Option C): While cisplatin can have cardiovascular side effects, such as abnormal heart rhythms and changes in blood pressure, cardiotoxicity is not typically the most common side effect of cisplatin.

Myopathy (Option D) refers to muscle-related side effects, including muscle weakness or pain. Although cisplatin can lead to myopathy, it is not the most common side effect.

questions.text: Which of the following is most suitable for intravenous regional anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lidocaine

Explanation:

  • The most suitable local anesthetic for intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), commonly known as Bier's block, is Lidocaine.

 

Intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA):

Indications
  • Suitable for minor surgical procedures on the upper or lower extremities (hand surgeries, forearm procedures, and foot surgeries).
  • Used when general anesthesia is not necessary and for patients with contraindications to other forms of anesthesia.

Anesthetic Agents
  • Commonly used local anesthetics include
    • Lidocaine (most frequent)
    • Prilocaine

Procedure Steps
  • Tourniquet Application: Apply a tourniquet to the proximal part of the extremity to prevent blood flow and keep the local anesthetic localized.
  • Venous Access: Establish intravenous access in the selected limb.
  • Administration of Anesthetic agent: Inject the local anesthetic into the IV line, typically in a volume of 40-50 mL.

Tourniquet Management

  • The tourniquet should be inflated to a pressure that is approximately 50 mmHg above systolic blood pressure.
  • It is typically safe to keep the tourniquet inflated for 30-60 minutes; prolonged inflation can increase the risk of complications.

Advantages
  • Provides effective analgesia with minimal systemic absorption.
  • Allows for a bloodless surgical field.
  • Quick onset of action and ease of administration.

Disadvantages and Complications
  • Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) Can occur if the local anesthetic enters the systemic circulation.
  • Tourniquet Pain
  • Nerve Damage

Contraindications
  • Infection at the injection site or over the tourniquet.
  • Severe peripheral vascular disease.
  • Patient refusal or inability to cooperate.

 

Lipid Emulsion Therapy
  • Used as a treatment for Local anesthesia systemic toxicity, acts by sequestering the local anesthetic from circulation and mitigating toxic effects.
  • Administer a 20% lipid emulsion intravenously if toxicity occurs.

 

Bupivacaine (Option A): is the most cardiotoxic drug and it should never be administered intravenously.

Mepivacaine (Option B): has the same anesthetic potency as lidocaine but also has a milder dilating ability, leading to a longer duration of anesthesia without a vasoconstrictor.

Procaine (Option C): can be used as an alternative if allergic to lignocaine. It can cause methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: A patient in the ICU with an endotracheal tube now needs a tracheostomy tube. Which type of tube will you use?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cuffed tracheostomy tube

Explanation:

  • Cuffed tracheostomy tubes are commonly used for patients who require mechanical ventilation or have an increased risk of aspiration.
  • The cuff creates a seal around the trachea, preventing air leaks and minimizing the risk of aspiration of secretions, food, or other materials into the lungs.

 

Uncuffed tracheostomy tube (Option A):

  • An uncuffed tracheostomy tube has no inflatable cup.
  • These are most commonly used in the neonatal population or for patients who can manage their own secretions.
  • These allow airway clearance but don't protect from aspiration.

Metallic tracheostomy tube (Option C):

  • A 2-3 inch long curved metal or plastic tube placed in a surgically created opening in the trachea to keep it open.
  • It is indicated in case of obstruction in the upper airway
  • Establishes and maintains a secure airway when it is unsafe to do so via the mouth or nose, in cases of severe facial, head, or neck injuries, for bronchial hygiene and secretion removal, and to provide airway protection in patients with neuromuscular disorders.

Endotracheal tube (Option D):

  • It is made of polyvinyl chloride.
  • The main indication is to secure a definitive airway when there is the inability to maintain airway patency, inability to protect the air against aspiration, failure to ventilate, failure to oxygenate, and anticipation of a deteriorating course leading to respiratory failure.

questions.text: Resistance of the tube shown below is primarily because of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Diameter

Explanation:

  • Airway resistance (R) in the endotracheal tube is because of diameter.
  • Resistance is directly proportional to viscosity and length and inversely proportional to the radius (r^4) according to the Hagen Poiseuille law.

 

The ETT size is described in terms of internal diameter:

Age

Internal Diameter

length

Term-Neonate

3 mm (uncuffed)

9 cm

1 Year Old

4 mm (uncuffed)

10 cm

Child (>1 Year)

Age/4 + 4 mm (uncuffed)

Age/2 + 12 cm

Adult

> 7 mm

18-22 cm

 

  • The cuff is positioned 3-4 cm above the carina and 2-2.5 cm below the glottis.
  • Murphy's eye is a side hole at the tip, which allows continued ventilation if the end abuts the tracheal wall.

questions.text: Which is the least commonly used graft for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intercostal artery

Explanation:

The intercostal artery is the least commonly used graft in Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) due to its limited availability and potential complications, with the long saphenous vein, internal mammary artery, and radial artery being preferred options.

  • It is a procedure done by using a vascular graft for bypassing the blocked site of arteries and allowing the flow of blood to the heart muscles.
  • Indications:
    • Triple vessel stenosis
    • Left main stem stenosis
    • Chronic stable angina
    • Angina with persistent chest pain
    • >70% blockage of coronary vessels

Classification of Vascular grafts:

  • Bioprosthetic grafts
    • LIMA (Left Internal Mammary Artery) (Option B ruled out)
    • Long saphenous vein: Most commonly used in infra-inguinal surgeries due to small and medium-sized vessels. (Option A ruled out)
  • Synthetic grafts
    • Dacron: Most commonly used synthetic graft in supra inguinal surgeries due to large vessels.
    • Polyurethane
    • ePTFE (expanded polytetrafluoroethylene)

 

Most preferred graft for CABG is LIMA , but the Long saphenous vein is more commonly used due to its extra length and it is easy to handle.

 

Radial artery (Option D) is a commonly used graft in CABG, offering comparable long-term patency to the internal mammary artery and is particularly useful for smaller coronary arteries. It’s a good alternative to vein grafts, but requires careful harvesting and postoperative monitoring for complications.

questions.text:
In a 45-year-old patient undergoing a preoperative assessment for a surgical procedure, which classification of Mallampati score is assigned based on the following description:

Hard palate, soft palate, uvula, tip of the uvula, and tonsil pillars are visible. No oropharyngeal structures are obstructing the view.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Grade I

Explanation:

  • In the scenario described, the entire soft palate, uvula, pillars, and tonsillar region can be seen without any obstruction.
  • The correct classification is Grade I. This indicates an optimal airway visualization and ease of intubation.

 

The Mallampati classification is used to predict the ease of intubation based on the visibility of pharyngeal structures during mouth opening and tongue protrusion.

Mallampati Classification:

(Mnemonic - PUSH - Pillars, Uvula, Soft palate, Hard palate)

  • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, soft palate, and hard palate are visualized.
  • Class II: The base of the uvula, soft palate, and hard palate are visualized. (Option B)
  • Class III: Soft palate and hard palate are visualized. (Option C)
  • Class IV: Hard palate only is visualized. (Option D)
  • Class 0: Any part of the epiglottis is visible (easy laryngoscopy with difficult airway management)

questions.text: Which of the following is the recommended treatment for the condition shown in the image, where the size of the stone is 1.5 cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ureteroscopy

Explanation:

  • A 2 mm stone in the ureter is managed by ureteroscopy, a minimally invasive procedure that uses a flexible tube inserted through the urethra and bladder to remove or fragment stones smaller than 2 cm.

Conservative management of Renal Stones:

  • Indications
    • Upto 5 mm in size
    • Non dilated ureter
    • Stone located in the lower third of the ureter
    • Progressive downward movement on repeated scan
  • Increased fluid intake to promote diuresis and stone passage
  • Medical expulsive therapy (MET)
    • Involves the use of alpha-blocker medications (e.g., tamsulosin) or calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine)
    • Helps to relax the ureter smooth muscle, facilitating the spontaneous passage of the stone
    • Typically recommended for stones up to 10 mm in size.
  • Intervention (if the stone fails to pass or symptoms worsen)
    • Ureteroscopic stone extraction (Option B)
      • It allows fragmentation and removal of stones smaller than 2 cm from the ureter or kidney.
      • Avoided in <5 years
    • ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) (Option C ruled out)
      • Radiolucent or radiopaque renal or ureteric stones less than 2 cm in diameter
      • Stones located in the renal pelvis, upper, or middle ureter
      • Patients with normal renal function and no severe hydronephrosis
    • Percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) (Option A ruled out)
      • To extract stones from the kidney through a dilated tract.
      • For stones larger than 2 cm.
  • Regular follow-up with imaging to monitor stone location and size

 

ESWL (Option C): is incorrect because while ESWL can be considered for renal or proximal ureteric stones <2 cm, its effectiveness drops as the stone approaches 1.5 cm and especially in mid/distal ureter where targeting is more difficult.

 

Wait and Watch (Option D) can be appropriate for stones smaller than 5 mm that are not causing significant symptoms, ureteroscopy is recommended when a stone is causing discomfort or complications. A 2 cm stone can be removed or fragmented quickly through ureteroscopy, making it a more proactive and effective treatment option.

questions.text: What is the appropriate antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is the antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose (symptoms include dilated pupils and slurred speech).
  • Mechanism: It is a specific benzodiazepine receptor antagonist that works by competitively binding to the same receptors in the brain that Benzodiazepines target, effectively reversing their effects (sedative and respiratory-depressant effects of benzodiazepines), preventing life-threatening complications of overdose.

Flurazepam (Option B) is not an antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose; it is actually a Benzodiazepine medication itself, used to treat insomnia. It would not counteract the effects of other Benzodiazepines.

Barbiturates (Option C) are a separate class of drugs that act as central nervous system depressants. They have a different mechanism of action compared to Benzodiazepines, and they are not considered antidotes for Benzodiazepine overdose.

Buspirone (Option D) is an anxiolytic medication, but it does not function as an antidote for Benzodiazepine overdose. It has a distinct mechanism of action and is used for long-term treatment of anxiety disorders.

questions.text: What is the initial management approach for urinary symptoms in a patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tamsulosin

Explanation:

  • The initial treatment for a patient with Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) is Tamsulosin, an α-1 blocker.

Management

Medical Management
  • 1st line management: ⍺ 1 Blocker
    • Prazosin
    • Terazosin
    • Silodosin
    • Most commonly used: Tamsulosin (⍺ 1A selective Blocker) (Option B)
  • 2nd line: 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors
    • Finasteride (Option C ruled out)
    • Dutasteride
    • Triptorelin pamoate
  • Combination treatment with ⍺ 1 Blocker and 5 𝛼 Reductase inhibitors are used in large prostate.

Surgical Management
  • Indications:
    • No improvement in medical management.
    • Acute retention of urine
    • Chronic urinary retention with residual urine of more than 200 ml.
    • Complications like hydroureter, hydronephrosis, stone formation, recurrent infection, and gross haematuria
  • Surgeries:
    • Gold standard- TURP (Trans urethral resection of prostate). (Option A ruled out)
    • Trans urethral incision of prostate (TUIP)
    • Open prostatectomy procedures

 

Acute management in urinary retention: urethral catheterization and if it fails - suprapubic cystostomy (SPC).

Observation (Option D) may be suitable for mild, asymptomatic BPH cases that don’t significantly affect quality of life, with regular monitoring and lifestyle changes. However, if symptoms worsen, medications like Tamsulosin are typically recommended, as observation alone is not the standard initial treatment for urinary symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about nephroblastoma except:

choices.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by surgery
Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Most common intra-abdominal malignancy in children

Explanation:

  • Nephroblastoma, or Wilms Tumor, is the most common primary renal malignancy in childhood and the 2nd most common intraabdominal malignancy (neuroblastoma being the most common) in children, typically affecting those aged 2 to 5 years.

Cause

Caused by mutations in WT1 and WT2 genes on chromosome 11.

Associated syndromes

  • Denys-Drash Syndrome (DDS): A rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in the WT1 gene, characterized by a triad of Wilms' tumor, nephrotic syndrome due to diffuse mesangial sclerosis, and male pseudohermaphroditism
  • WAGR Syndrome: A rare genetic condition caused by a deletion on chromosome 11p13, leading to a combination of Wilms' tumor, aniridia (absence of the iris), genitourinary abnormalities, and intellectual disability.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS): A genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, increased tumor risk, macroglossia, abdominal wall defects, and hemihyperplasia, often due to abnormalities on chromosome 11p15.5.
  • Perlman Syndrome: A rare genetic disorder characterized by overgrowth, developmental delay, intellectual disability, distinctive facial features, and an increased risk of Wilms' tumor, often caused by mutations in the DIS3L2 gene.

Clinical Presentation
  • Most common malignant pediatric renal tumor.

Triad:

  • Asymptomatic abdominal mass (MC presentation)
  • Fever (disappears after tumor resection)
  • Hematuria (Gross/Microscopic)

Rarely: Pain

Investigations

USG- Primary investigation

CECT- Investigation of choice.

MRI - For better soft tissue visualization.

Treatment

Chemotherapy followed by surgery. (Option A ruled out)

Multimodal approach

  • Surgery: Radical nephrectomy or nephron-sparing surgery
  • Chemotherapy: VCD regimen

Vincristine, Cyclophosphamide, Dactinomycin/Doxorubicin

  • Radiation therapy: For higher stages or unfavorable histology

Staging

I. Disease confined to the kidney and completely resectable

II. Tumor extends beyond the kidney but can be excised completely

Ill. Residual disease after resection with positive lymph nodes and massive spillage

IV. Blood-borne metastasis

V. Bilateral disease

Prognosis

Most important Prognostic Factor - Histology > Stage

Metastasis

Mainly through a hematogenous route into: (Option C ruled out)

  • Lungs (MC) (Option B ruled out)
  • Liver
  • Bones (Rarely)

questions.text: A female patient complains of swelling and pain in her great toe. Her uric acid level is found to be high. A drug that reduces uric acid levels is prescribed. Which of the following enzymes should the drug inhibit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Xanthine oxidase

  • Xanthine oxidase, involved in Purine Metabolism by converting purines to uric acid in the liver, is targeted by medications like allopurinol and febuxostat to lower uric acid levels in the treatment of gout and hyperuricemia.

Urease (Option A) breaks down urea, unrelated to uric acid metabolism.

Homogentisate oxidase (Option B) relates to phenylalanine and tyrosine metabolism, not uric acid.

Lysyl oxidase (Option C) is involved in collagen and elastin cross-linking, unrelated to uric acid metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the mechanism of action of labetalol?

choices.text: Directly acts as arterial vasodilator resulting in indirect effect tachycardia
Blocks both alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors
Primarily acts as a vasodilator with little effect on arterioles
Decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as a relaxant for vascular smooth muscles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Blocks both alpha and beta-adrenergic receptors

  • Labetalol is a non-selective beta-blocker and an alpha-blocker that blocks both beta- and alpha-adrenergic receptors.
  • It reduces sympathetic nervous system activity, leading to decreased heart rate, decreased contractility, and vasodilation.
  • It reduces the effects of epinephrine and norepinephrine on the heart, decreasing heart rate and contractility (beta-blocker).
  • It reduces arterial resistance by causing dilation of the blood vessels, leading to decrease in blood pressure (alpha-1 blocker).
  • It is the drug of choice for hypertension in pregnancy.

Non selective 𝛃1 + 𝛃2 blocker

Cardioselective 𝛃1 blocker

Without ISA

With ISA

With ɑ blocking activity

 

  • Metoprolol
  • Esmolol
  • Atenolol
  • Bisoprolol
  • Acebutolol
  • Betaxolol
  • Nebivolol
  • Propranolol
  • Sotalol
  • Timolol
  • Pindolol
  • Celiprolol
  • Oxprenolol
  • Penbutolol
  • Pindolol
  • Bopindolol
  • Labetalol
  • Carvedilol

ISA: intrinsic sympathomimetic action

Directly acts as an arterial vasodilator, resulting in indirect effect tachycardia (Option A): Labetalol primarily acts as a non-selective beta-blocker and alpha-blocker. Its vasodilatory effect is mainly due to its blockade of alpha-adrenergic receptors, leading to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscle resulting in decreased systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

Primarily acts as a vasodilator with little effect on arterioles (Option C): Labetalol acts as both a beta-blocker and an alpha-blocker, causing vasodilation in both arteries and arterioles. Its alpha-blocking activity leads to arteriolar dilation, while its beta-blocking activity contributes to arterial vasodilation.

Decreases peripheral vascular resistance by directly acting as a relaxant for vascular smooth muscles (Option D): Labetalol decreases peripheral vascular resistance, but it does so indirectly by blocking both alpha-adrenergic receptors and beta-adrenergic receptors, resulting in reduced vasoconstrictor effects of catecholamines such as norepinephrine and epinephrine. This results in vasodilation and decreased peripheral vascular resistance. It does not directly act as a relaxant for vascular smooth muscles.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, when a constriction is detected at the esophageal junction approximately 25 cm from the incisor, what is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arch of aorta

Explanation:

  • The constriction at the esophageal junction, about 25 cm from the incisor, is likely caused by the arch of the aorta, where the Esophagus passes behind the aorta and left main bronchus, leading to a physiological narrowing.

Physical Narrowing

  • The esophagus has three relatively narrow sections, with endoscopic measurements from the incisors.
  • They are:
    • Cricopharyngeus muscle (upper oesophageal sphincter)
    • Where the left main bronchus and aorta cross the oesophagus
    • Esophagogastric junction (lower oesophageal sphincter).

 

Inferior vena cava (Option A) runs parallel to the aorta in the abdomen and does not cross the esophagus in the thoracic cavity, so it does not cause constriction at the esophageal junction.

Right bronchus (Option C) crosses the esophagus lower in the thoracic cavity and does not cause constriction at the 25 cm level, where the esophagus is more closely related to the left bronchus and arch of the aorta.

Diaphragmatic opening (Option D) is located around 40 cm from the incisors, lower than the 25 cm mark, and is not involved in constriction at this level.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the surgical OPD with a painless left inguinal reducible mass. On examination cough impulse is positive. After further investigations, the patient is diagnosed with an inguinal hernia. What is the surgical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hernioplasty

Explanation:

  • Hernioplasty is the preferred surgical approach for Inguinal Hernia in adults, involving the repair of the hernia with synthetic mesh to strengthen the abdominal wall and prevent recurrence.

Management of Inguinal Hernia

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy:
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates. (Option A ruled out)
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh (preferred in adults). (Option B)
    • Indications:
      • Direct hernia
      • Recurrent hernia, Re-recurrent hernia
      • lncisional hernia
      • Old age
      • Hernia with weak abdominal muscle tone
      • Sliding hernia.
  • Herniorrhaphy:
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures
    • Techniques:

Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates.

 

Shouldice Repair: involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

 

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

 

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair: Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery. It is a a tension-free, simple, fat, polypropylene mesh repair for inguinal hernia. (Option A)

 

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair:
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

 

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair

 

Wait and watch (Option C) may be considered for small, asymptomatic hernias in low-risk patients, but in this case, surgical intervention is recommended to prevent complications like incarceration or strangulation, as inguinal hernias do not resolve on their own.

Emergency laparotomy (Option D) is reserved for incarcerated or strangulated hernias with compromised blood supply or bowel obstruction, not necessary for this reducible and painless hernia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was prescribed a diuretic by a doctor to manage hypertension. Which of the following diuretic acts on the site 'A' is marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Hydrochlorothiazide

  • Site A is DCT (distal convoluted tubule), at which Hydrochlorothiazide (thiazide diuretic) acts by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron, leading to increased excretion of sodium, chloride, and water.

Classification of Diuretics

Class & Drugs

Mechanism of action

Clinical uses

Side effects

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

  • Acetazolamide (Option C)
  • Methazolamide

Inhibit carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the proximal tubule, decreasing bicarbonate reabsorption

Glaucoma, Altitude sickness

Metabolic acidosis, Hypokalemia

Loop diuretics

  • Furosemide (Option A)
  • Bumetanide

Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle

Acute pulmonary edema, Chronic heart failure, Hypercalcemia
  • Hypokalemia, Ototoxicity, Metabolic alkalosis,
  • Hyperglycemia,
  • Hyperuricemia

Thiazide diuretics

  • Hydrochlorothiazide (Option B)
  • Chlorthalidone

Inhibit sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule

Hypertension, Edema
  • Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia,
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia

Potassium-sparing

  • Spironolactone
  • Amiloride

Inhibit sodium channels in the distal nephron or block aldosterone receptors

Heart failure, Hyperaldosteronism

Hyperkalemia, Gynecomastia (for Spironolactone)

Osmotic diuretics

  • Mannitol (Option D)
  • Glycerin

Increase osmolarity of the glomerular filtrate, inhibiting water reabsorption.

Cerebral oedema, Acute glaucoma

Dehydration, Electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: A homosexual man presents with painful defecation and a protruding mass from the anal canal. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the anus. What is the appropriate course of action for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Combined chemoradiation

Explanation:

  • Combined chemoradiation, involving chemotherapy (fluorouracil and mitomycin C) and radiation, is the standard treatment for localized squamous cell carcinoma of the anus, preserving anal function and improving local control and survival.

Anal Canal Carcinoma

Risk factors
  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) Infection: Strongly linked to anal canal cancer, particularly high-risk subtypes (16, 18, 31, 33)
  • Anal Intraepithelial Neoplasia (AIN): A precancerous condition significantly increases the risk of progression to anal canal cancer, especially from AIN II or III.
  • Immunosuppression (e.g., HIV-positive, transplant recipients)
  • Sexual Practices: Anal intercourse increases HPV transmission risk.
  • History of Other Genital Neoplasia: Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) or cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN)
  • Extensive Anogenital Condylomata: The presence of extensive anal warts linked to HPV infection

Clinical features
  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Palpable Mass
  • Pruritus (Itching)
  • Discharge
  • Incontinence
  • Fistulation (anterior tumour extension in women can create a fistula between the anus and vagina).
  • Appearance:
    • Anal margin tumours: Often resemble malignant ulcers with raised, hardened edges.
    • Anal canal tumours: Typically palpable as irregular, hardened, and tender ulcerated areas.
  • Lymph Node Involvement: Enlarged lymph nodes in the perirectal or groin regions may indicate cancer spread.

Investigations

  • Biopsy from the Anal Region: The primary diagnostic test to confirm the presence of carcinoma.
  • FNAC of Inguinal Nod (assess metastasis).
  • USG Abdomen (check for any spread of the disease).
  • MRI of the Perineum (assess the extent of the tumour).
  • Proctosigmoidoscopy: Assess the upper extent of the tumour within the anal canal.

Management

  • Chemoradiation (Nigro regimen): The preferred treatment modality for carcinoma of the anal canal. (Option C)
    • Chemotherapy Drugs: Commonly used drugs include 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), bleomycin, vincristine, and adriamycin.
    • Radiotherapy: Often used alone in advanced cases where the tumour is not resectable.
  • Surgical Interventions:
    • Abdominoperineal Resection (APR) with Colostomy: For persistent or recurrent disease after combined modality therapy (CMT), or for cases where the tumor does not respond to chemoradiation. (Option B ruled out)
    • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy: Involves using 5-FU, cisplatin, and mitomycin C before surgery to shrink the tumour.

 

Chemotherapy (Option A) alone is not the primary treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the anus; chemoradiation is preferred for better local control and survival.

Wide local excision (Option D) is not the standard treatment for anal cancer, as chemoradiation is more effective in preserving function and reducing recurrence. Surgery is only considered if chemoradiation fails.

questions.text: A psychiatrist prescribes lithium for a patient who is diagnosed with bipolar disorder. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding lithium?

choices.text: Lithium is teratogenic if given to pregnant females
Lithium toxicity is exacerbated with thiazide
Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels
Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hemodialysis is not useful in lithium overdose

  • Hemodialysis is useful in Lithium overdose. Hemodialysis can effectively treat severe lithium toxicity, as it can rapidly remove lithium from the bloodstream.

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect (Option A) when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

Lithium toxicity is exacerbated with thiazide (Option B): Thiazide diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, can increase the serum levels of lithium by decreasing its renal clearance, leading to toxicity, manifesting with symptoms such as tremors, confusion, and renal failure.

Lithium can decrease thyroid hormone levels (Option C), resulting in hypothyroidism by decreasing the synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones. Patients who are taking lithium should have their thyroid function monitored regularly.
