questions.text: Four friends are planning a trip to Ladakh. During their stay, one of them began experiencing headaches, nausea, dizziness, and fatigue. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Acetazolamide

  • The chest tightness, shortness of breath, and altered sensorium at high altitude suggest mountain sickness, and Acetazolamide (carbonic acid anhydrase inhibitor) is the drug that provides relief.

Mechanism in mountain sickness:

  • Inhibits kidney carbonic anhydrase.
  • Increases urine bicarbonate ions excretion → Metabolic acidosis.
  • Counteracts respiratory alkalosis from high altitude hyperventilation.
  • Improves oxygenation and alleviates AMS symptoms.

Sumatriptan (Option A) is a 5-HT1B/1D Agonist (triptan) and is used for the treatment of migraine and cluster headaches. It won’t help in relieving mountain sickness symptoms.

Promethazine (Option B) is a first-generation antihistamine that acts on the basal ganglia and has anticholinergic properties. It is used for its antiemetic and anti-motion sickness properties. It won’t help in mountain sickness.

Scopolamine (Option C), or Hyoscine, is a medication with anticholinergic properties. It is used as a truth serum and is the drug of choice for prophylaxis of motion sickness. It won’t help in mountain sickness.

questions.text: Which of these drugs stimulates PPAR-alpha?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Gemfibrozil

  • Gemfibrozil is a fibrate (fibric acid derivative) that acts as a PPAR - alpha agonist (Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha agonist).

Class

Fibrate or PPAR-α agonist

Mechanism of action

Activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPAR-α), leading to the following effects:

  • Reduce triglyceride production
  • Elevate high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol levels
  • Decrease hepatic triglyceride synthesis

Uses

Hyperlipidemia

Adverse effects

  • GI side effects (nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea)
  • Myopathy, especially when used with statins
  • Hepatotoxicity (elevated liver enzymes)
  • Renal dysfunction
  • Gallbladder disease
  • Contraindicated in children and pregnancy

Ezetimibe (Option B) is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that blocks dietary cholesterol absorption in the small intestine via PCIL1 transporter protein interference. It is used with statins for primary hypercholesterolemia.

Colestipol (Option C) is a bile acid sequestrant that binds to bile acids in the intestine, preventing their reabsorption and promoting their excretion in the feces. They are used in adjunct with statin therapy.

Simvastatin (Option D) is an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor (statin) that works by inhibiting the production of cholesterol in the liver.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with increased cough, breathlessness, and decreased exercise capacity. Chest X-ray shows pulmonary fibrosis. Which drug can be administered in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Pirfenidone

  • Pirfenidone is the correct answer, as it is an antifibrotic agent approved for treating Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF).

Management of Interstitial lung disease

Disease

Treatment

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Pirfenidone + Nintedanib

Nonspecific interstitial pneumonitis

Prednisolone + cyclophosphamide or rituximab

Desquamative interstitial pneumonitis

Corticosteroids or Cytotoxic agents (Azathioprine)

Bronchodilators may be used

Cryptogenic organising pneumonia

Corticosteroids

Cyclophosphamide or Rituximab can be used alternatively

Hamman-Rich syndrome

Mechanical ventilation

Bortezomib (Option A) is a proteasome inhibitor for treating multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma.

Roflumilast (Option B) is a phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Imatinib (Option C) is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs).

questions.text: A patient who was in excruciating pain all over his body was taken to the hospital. In recent years, he has experienced these incidents frequently. When exercising vigorously, the ache begins. Anemia was detected on blood examination along with elongated RBC as opposed to concave ones. It was determined that he had sickle cell anemia. What substitution takes place in sickle cell anemia?

choices.text: Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 6th position
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 6th position
Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 5th position
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 5th position

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 6th position

Explanation:

  • In sickle cell anemia, a single-point mutation in the beta-globin gene causes glutamic acid to be substituted with valine at the 6th position of the beta-globin chain

 

Pathophysiology of Sickle cell anemia:

 

HbS Polymerisation: (Option B)

  • A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the β-globin gene results in the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the sixth position in the β-globin chain.
  • This mutation leads to the formation of mutated hemoglobin (HbS).
  • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
  • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocyte, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.

​​​​​​​Vaso-occlusion:

  • Sickled erythrocytes impair blood flow and aggregate with neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells, causing stasis.
  • Leads to ischemia-reperfusion (I-R) injury.
     

Endothelial Dysfunction:

  • Oxygenated Hb (Fe²⁺) depletes endothelial nitric oxide (NO), forming nitrate (NO₃⁻) and methemoglobin (Fe³⁺).
  • Free radicals are generated by NADPH oxidase, xanthine oxidase (XO), and uncoupled endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) contribute to endothelial damage and dysfunction.
  • Methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) breaks down, releasing cell-free heme, which is a major erythrocyte damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP).
     

Sterile Inflammation:

  • Cell-free heme or ischemia-reperfusion injury triggers sterile inflammation by:
    • Generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
    • Activating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4).
    • Inducing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs).
    • Releasing DAMPs, DNA, and other unidentified factors.
  • This activates the inflammasome pathway, releasing IL-1β.
  • Sterile inflammation enhances the adhesiveness of neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells.
  • This creates a cycle that promotes further vaso-occlusion.

Option A,C and D is not the pathology of Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most appropriate to be used for the treatment of diarrhea in a patient who was treated for colorectal carcinoma with 5-fluorouracil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Loperamide

  • Loperamide is the most appropriate to be used for the treatment of diarrhea in a patient who was treated for colorectal carcinoma with 5-fluorouracil.
  • 5-fluorouracil, an antimetabolite chemotherapy drug, can cause gastrointestinal toxicity, including diarrhea, as a side effect.
  • Loperamide, an antidiarrheal medication, works by reducing intestinal motility and enhancing water and electrolyte absorption in the intestine, leading to firmer stools. Thus, it is the most suitable drug for this case.

Ciprofloxacin (Option A) is an antibiotic that is used to treat bacterial infections, including diarrhea-causing pathogens. However, in this given case, the cause is most likely due to the GI toxic effects of 5-FU. Therefore, the use of an antibiotic would be inappropriate.

Atropine (Option C) is an anticholinergic agent that can be used to treat dysentery and diverticulitis. It is not helpful in this case since the cause is most likely due to the GI toxic effects of 5-FU.

Ornidazole (Option D) is an antimicrobial drug used to treat protozoal and anaerobic bacterial infections. However, in this given case, the cause is most likely due to the GI toxic effects of 5-FU. Therefor, thee use of an antibiotic would be inappropriate.

questions.text: Among the options provided, which pairing correctly matches the trauma patients brought to the casualty?

choices.text: Penetrating injury to eustachian tube - CSF otorrhea
Penetrating injury to eye - Battle sign

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Gaze palsy - Mid brain lesion

Explanation:

  • Gaze palsy, a difficulty in eye movement, can result from damage to structures in the midbrain, such as the third cranial nerve nucleus and paramedian pontine reticular formation.

 

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) - Pin point pupil (Option A): EDH causes a dilated, non-reactive pupil due to pressure on the oculomotor nerve (CN III), while pinpoint pupils are more associated with opioid overdose or pontine lesions.

Penetrating injury to eustachian tube - CSF otorrhea (Option B): Penetrating injury to the eustachian tube may cause complications but not CSF otorrhea, which is typically linked to basilar skull fractures and injury to the temporal bone.

Penetrating injury to eye - Battle sign (Option C): Battle sign, bruising behind the ear, is associated with basilar skull fractures, not penetrating eye injuries, which present with hyphema, corneal damage, or visual disturbances.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Granisteron + dexamethasone + aprepitant

  • Chemotherapy can trigger the release of chemicals like serotonin and substance P, which activate the vomiting centre in the brain, and this can be treated with a combination of granisetron + dexamethasone + aprepitant.

First-line therapies (include any of or a combination of)

Drugs

Mechanism of Action

Granisetron or Ondansetron

They are 5-HT3 receptor antagonist, which blocks receptors in the gut and brain stimulated by serotonin released during chemotherapy, reducing nausea and preventing vomiting.

Dexamethasone

A corticosteroid with anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects, it reduces gastrointestinal inflammation and suppresses the release of chemicals in the brain that trigger nausea and vomiting.

Aprepitant

It is a substance P/neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor antagonist that works by blocking NK1 receptors, inhibiting the action of substance P (a neurotransmitter involved in triggering nausea and vomiting).

This medication is often used in combination with others as it targets different pathways in the development of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), offering a more comprehensive approach to prevention and management. This combination therapy is particularly effective in preventing both acute and delayed CINV.

Doxylamine + domperidone + aprepitant (Option A): Doxylamine is primarily an antihistamine used for morning sickness in pregnant women and is not commonly used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. Domperidone is a medication used to treat nausea and vomiting but is not the first-line treatment for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Prochlorperazine + metoclopramide + domperidone (Option B): Prochlorperazine is an antipsychotic medication used to treat schizophrenia and other psychiatric disorders. While it can be used to treat nausea and vomiting, it is not a first-line treatment for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

Dexamethasone + metoclopramide + domperidone (Option C): Dexamethasone and metoclopramide can be used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting; they are not first-line treatments. Additionally, the addition of domperidone is not typically recommended for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: What are the consequences of a deficiency in Vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Xerophthalmia

  • Xerophthalmia is a condition associated with severe vitamin A deficiency.
  • Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy eyes and vision.

Vitamin A Deficiency Manifestations :

 

1. Ocular manifestations :

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the most significant preventable cause of blindness, especially in children below 5 in developing countries.
  • Early Signs:
    • Loss of sensitivity to green light.
    • Difficulty adapting to dim light.
    • Night blindness.
  • Prolonged Deficiency:
    • Xerophthalmia:
      1. Dry, thick, keratinized conjunctiva and cornea. If untreated, it leads to corneal ulceration and ultimately results in blindness due to the formation of opaque scar tissue.
      2. WHO grading of xerophthalmia:

XN
  • Night blindness.

X1
  • X1A: Conjunctival xerosis.
  • X1B: Bitot spots.

X2
  • Corneal xerosis.

X3
  • X3A: Corneal ulceration, less than one-third.
  • X3B: Corneal ulceration, more than one-third.

XS
  • Corneal scar.

XF
  • Xerophthalmic fundus.

 

  • Bitot's Spots: Grayish-white triangular plaques firmly adherent to the conjunctiva.
  • Keratomalacia: When xerophthalmia persists for a longer time, it progresses to keratomalacia (corneal softening)
     

2) Immune Function:

  • Deficiency increases susceptibility to infections.
  • Infection reduces retinol-binding protein synthesis, lowering vitamin A levels and impairing immune responses.

 

3) Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions:

  • Follicular Hyperkeratosis (Phrynoderma): Causes rough skin due to hyperkeratinization of the follicular epithelium.
  • Keratinizing Metaplasia: Affects respiratory, gastrointestinal, and genitourinary tracts.
  • Epithelium is atrophied.

 

4) Other General Manifestation :

  • Growth retardation due to defective synthesis of chondroitin sulfate.
  • Decreased protein synthesis.

 

Beri-beri (Option A) is a condition caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy, cardiovascular problems, and impaired mental function.

Pellagra (Option B) is a condition caused by niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency causes Pellagra is characterized by the "4 Ds" - dermatitis (skin inflammation), diarrhea, dementia (mental confusion), and death if left untreated.

Neuropathy (Option D) refers to nerve damage, which can have various causes, such as diabetes, alcohol abuse, certain medications, and vitamin deficiencies. Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with neuropathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about p43?

choices.text: It increases telomere length in the liver
It retains the telomerase enzyme in the nucleus

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) It retains the telomerase enzyme in the nucleus

  • Telomerase is an enzyme that adds DNA repeats (nucleotides) to the ends of chromosomes, preventing them from shortening during DNA replication.
  • p43 has been shown to play a role in regulating telomerase activity.
  • It helps retain telomerase in the nucleus, which can act on telomeres, thus maintaining their length and contributing to cellular lifespan.
  • By retaining telomerase in the nucleus, p43 helps regulate the balance between cell proliferation and senescence or cell cycle arrest.

 

It increases telomere length in the liver (Option A) Telomere lengthening in the liver is not attributed to p43. Telomeres shorten with cell division, and telomerase, not p43, maintains or lengthens them in specific cells, including stem cells and some cancer cells.

It synthesizes RNA (Option B) While p43 regulates gene expression, it is not directly involved in RNA synthesis. RNA polymerases primarily carry out RNA synthesis.

It stabilizes RNA (Option C)p43 can indirectly affect RNA levels through gene regulation, p43 does not stabilize RNA molecules.

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed an infection. Blood analysis revealed neutropenia. Which of the following drugs is likely to be effective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Filgrastim

  • Filgrastim is likely to be effective for neutropenia in a patient on anti-cancer therapy.

Class

Recombinant human G-CSF (Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor)

Mechanism of action

  • Stimulates colony-forming unit (CFU) granulocytes to increase neutrophil production.
  • Enhances phagocytic and cytotoxic activities of neutrophils.

Uses

  • To treat severe neutropenia (after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, high-dose cancer chemotherapy, congenital neutropenias, and patients with AIDS receiving zidovudine)
  • Used in patients undergoing peripheral blood stem cell collection for stem cell transplantation.

Romiplostim (Option A) is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that binds to thrombopoietin receptors on bone marrow megakaryocytes and stimulates the production of platelets. It is used to treat thrombocytopenia.

Oprelvekin (Option B) binds to thrombopoietin receptors on bone marrow megakaryocytes, stimulates the production of megakaryocytes, and is used to treat thrombocytopenia.

Epoetin alfa (Option D), also known as Erythropoietin, is produced by peritubular cells of the kidney and is essential for normal erythropoiesis. It stimulates red blood cell production and is ineffective in treating neutropenia.

questions.text: A farmer sprayed a chemical in the pool which causes inhibition of complex-III of the electron transport chain. Identify the inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Antimycin

Explanation:

  • Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome b-c1 complex) of the electron transport chain. It interrupts the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, thereby inhibiting the flow of electrons through this complex.

 

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone (Option A)

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

Complex I

(NADH dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex I to ubiquinone​

 

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone) (Option B)

Carboxin

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A (Option D)

BAL

Complex III

Cytochrome bc1 complex

 

Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to Cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−) (Option C)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

Complex IV

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

 

Prevents electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen​

Oligomycin

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

 

 

Blocks the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis​

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

 

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn’t block respiration entirely.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFREF)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Metoprolol

Multiple large-scale clinical trials have shown that Metoprolol (a second-generation/ cardioselective 𝛃-blocker) reduces mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFREF).

  • It is more potent in blocking 𝛃1-receptor (cardiac muscle) than 𝛃2-receptor (bronchial muscles).
  • It is used as secondary prophylaxis for myocardial infarction (to prevent reinfarction and arrhythmias) and to treat hypertension, angina, and heart failure.

Side effects of beta-blockers:

Cardiac side effects

Extracardiac side effects
  • Withdrawal can lead to the precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Negative chronotropic effects include the development of sinus bradycardia and heart block.
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction.

 
  • Increased airway resistance (contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm).
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • Masking of the hypoglycemic signs (tachycardia).
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

 

Furosemide (Option B) and Torsemide (Option C) are loop diuretics commonly used in heart failure to reduce fluid buildup and relieve symptoms. While they provide symptomatic benefits, they do not improve mortality. These drugs are widely used in acute decompensated heart failure.

Prazosin (Option D) is an alpha-blocker that is used primarily to treat high blood pressure and benign prostatic hyperplasia, but it is not recommended for the management of heart failure and has not been shown to reduce mortality in HFREF patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female undergoes emergency laparotomy for perforation peritonitis. Which of the following is the surest sign of wound dehiscence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Copious sero-sanguinous discharge

Explanation:

The surest sign of Wound Dehiscence following emergency laparotomy is copious serosanguinous discharge, typically occurring around day 6 post-op, indicating a burst abdomen and requiring urgent laparotomy management.

Definition

Disruption of any or all of the layers in a wound.

Occurrence

Up to 3% of abdominal wounds; most commonly occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days.

Types

 
  1. Partial dehiscence: Involves only the skin and subcutaneous fat.
  2. Complete dehiscence: Involves the fascial layer and may include evisceration (extrusion of abdominal viscera).

Risk Factors

General:

  • Malnourishment
  • Diabetes
  • Obesity
  • Renal failure
  • Jaundice
  • Sepsis
  • Cancer
  • Treatment with steroids
  • Emergency surgery

Local:

  • Inadequate or poor closure of wound or closure of a wound under tension
  • Poor local wound healing
  • Increased intra-abdominal pressure

Clinical Presentation
  • Pinkish serosanguinous discharge (salmon-coloured fluid), (Option A)
  • Possible evisceration,
  • Popping sensation during straining or coughing.

Treatment

  • Partial dehiscence (without evisceration): Prompt reclosure of the fascia is generally advised.
  • Complete dehiscence with evisceration:
    • Requires urgent reoperation.
    • Tension suturing is done.
    • Protect eviscerated bowel with moist towels; handle carefully to prevent injury.
    • Antibiotic therapy; fluid management.

 

Rebound tenderness (Option B) refers to pain that is felt when pressure is released from the abdomen, often indicating peritoneal irritation or inflammation, typically seen in conditions like peritonitis. While rebound tenderness could suggest a complication (such as ongoing infection or intra-abdominal issues), it is not specific to wound dehiscence.

Hemorrhage (Option C): Although significant bleeding can occur after surgery, hemorrhage is not a typical feature of wound dehiscence. Hemorrhage can be caused by vessel injury, clotting issues, or inadequate hemostasis at the surgical site, but it's not directly linked to the reopening of the wound itself.

Hypotension (Option D) may occur due to various factors like shock, blood loss, or infection. While hypotension can be a result of complications following surgery, it is a general sign of systemic distress rather than a specific sign of wound dehiscence. The cause of hypotension needs to be identified through further clinical investigation.

questions.text: Cholera is known to cause diarrhea through its interaction with specific receptors in the human body. Which of the following is known to make it easier for cholera toxin to enter the body through the intestinal mucosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) GM1 ganglioside:

  • Cholera toxin is produced by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae and is responsible for causing the characteristic symptoms of cholera, including severe diarrhea. Cholera toxin enters the body through the intestinal mucosa and interacts with specific receptors on the surface of intestinal cells.
  • The receptor that facilitates the entry of cholera toxin into the body is the GM1 ganglioside receptor. GM1 ganglioside is a glycosphingolipid, a type of molecule found in the lipid bilayer of cell membranes. Cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside on the surface of intestinal cells, which triggers the toxin to be internalized into the cell through endocytosis. Once inside the cell, the toxin can exert its effects, leading to the disruption of ion transport and fluid balance, ultimately causing severe diarrhea.

 

GLUT1 (Glucose Transporter 1) (Option A) is a protein responsible for transporting glucose across cell membranes.

GM2 ganglioside (Option B) is a type of glycosphingolipid, it is not the receptor specifically associated with cholera toxin binding and entry into intestinal cells.

Cephalin (Option C) is a type of phospholipid and is not known to be directly involved in the interaction between cholera toxin and intestinal cells.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old woman who experienced nausea and vomiting after being involved in a road traffic accident, and was brought to the emergency room unconscious, based on the findings of the NCCT brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Extradural hemorrhage

Explanation:

  • The likely diagnosis for a woman presenting with nausea and vomiting after a road traffic accident, and NCCT head showing a lens-shaped or biconvex hematoma between the inner surface of the skull and the outer layer of the dura mater, is Extradural Hemorrhage (Epidural Hemorrhage).

Aspect

Epidural Hematoma (EDH)

(Option A)

Subdural Hematoma (SDH)

(Option B ruled out)

Mechanism
  • Rupture of an artery, often the middle meningeal artery, usually due to a skull fracture, commonly in the temporal bone.

Two contexts:

  • High-energy injury: Rupture of cortical surface vessels.
  • Low-energy injury: Venous bleeding, common in older adults on anticoagulants.

Clinical Presentation
  • Classic: Transient loss of consciousness, lucid interval, rapid neurological decline.
  • Headaches are common.
  • Brain compression signs: Contralateral hemiparesis, reduced consciousness, ipsilateral pupillary dilation.
  • Variable presentation depending on injury severity and timing.
  • Signs of raised intracranial pressure: Headache, reduced consciousness, focal neurological deficits.

CT Appearance

Lentiform (lens-shaped or biconvex) hyperdense lesion between the skull and the brain.

 

Diffuse concave hyperdense (acute), isodense (subacute), or hypodense (chronic) crescent-shaped lesions over the brain surface, often crossing suture lines.

 

Management

Neurosurgical emergency; requires immediate evacuation, usually by craniotomy.

Depends on size, location, and clinical status:

1. Large or worsening hematomas: Urgent evacuation by craniotomy or craniectomy.

2. Smaller, stable bleeds: Conservative management initially, with surgery if needed.

Summary

EDH often follows a predictable course with a lucid interval.

SDH has a more variable presentation and distinct CT appearance.

 

Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (Option C) involves bleeding within the brain tissue, appearing as a high-density, irregular mass on NCCT. It is commonly associated with hypertension or stroke, not trauma. While unconsciousness may suggest a severe injury, the imaging would not show the "lens-shaped" hematoma seen in extradural hemorrhage.

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (Option D) involves bleeding between the brain and arachnoid mater, often from a ruptured aneurysm. On NCCT, it appears as diffuse blood in the sulci. While trauma and unconsciousness may raise suspicion, it doesn't show the biconvex hematoma seen in extradural hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to feeding difficulties, vomiting, and failure to thrive. The child's history reveals that the infant was born full-term and had a normal birth weight. On physical examination, the infant appears jaundiced, and the liver is palpable below the costal margin. Oil drop Cataracts are also noted on eye examination. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of galactose in the blood and urine. Based on these clinical findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) GALT (Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase) deficiency

Explanation:

  • GALT deficiency, also known as galactosemia, is a genetic disorder that impairs the ability to metabolize galactose properly. Galactose is a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

 

Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option A)
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis

Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,

Severe mental retardation

Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)

Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens

Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

 

G6PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency (Option A) is a genetic disorder that leads to a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase, which is important for protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.

ALDH (Aldehyde dehydrogenase) deficiency (Option C) is associated with a condition called alcohol-induced flushing, where individuals who carry certain genetic variants of the aldehyde dehydrogenase enzyme experience facial flushing and other symptoms when they consume alcohol.

PKU (Phenylalanine hydroxylase) deficiency (Option D) is a genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting phenylalanine to tyrosine.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Local excision and biopsy

Explanation:

  • The patient's whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months, combined with a history of tobacco chewing, suggests Oral Submucous Fibrosis (OSMF), and local excision with biopsy is crucial to confirm the diagnosis and rule out malignancy or dysplasia.

 

It is a progressive condition involving deep fibrosis in the oral mucosa, characterized by fibrous bands and considered a precancerous lesion.

Cause
  • Hypersensitivity to tobacco, betel nut, chilli, areca nut, vitamin deficiencies, localised collagen disorders.
  • Leads to alteration of collagen metabolism causing juxtaepithelial progressive inflammatory fibrosis of the submucosa.
  • This leads to atrophy and dysplasia.

Clinical features

  • Common in Asians
  • Males and females are equally affected.
  • Soreness in the mouth more during meals
  • Burning, also more while eating
  • Vesicular eruptions
  • Trismus
  • Difficulty in protruding tongue
  • Fibrosis and scarring
  • Ankylosing glossitis

 

Management

  • Cessation of causative factors(tobacco, chilli, areca nut)
  • Oral hygiene
  • Dexamethasone local injections
  • Hydrocortisone
  • HCG submucosal injection
  • Vitamin and iron supplementation
  • Surgical excision with graft
  • Stem cell therapy

 

Avoid smoking + Wait and watch (Option B) overlooks the lesion's severity and potential malignancy risk. Waiting without biopsy could delay diagnosis and treatment, worsening the condition.

Steroidal Injection (Option C) helps manage inflammation in OSMF but is not the initial step. A biopsy is needed first to confirm the diagnosis and rule out malignancy before considering steroid treatment.

Sclerotherapy (Option D) is used for vascular conditions, not OSMF. It is not the recommended initial treatment for diagnosing or managing OSMF. A biopsy is necessary first to confirm the diagnosis and assess the lesion.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness, which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Myasthenia gravis:

  • Myasthenia Gravis is a neuromuscular junction disease characterized by ptosis and muscle weakness that worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. Symptoms are relieved by anti-choline esterase, such as neostigmine.

Pathophysiology

Autoimmune disease is caused by antibodies targeting acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

Disruption in neuromuscular transmission occurs through:

  • Blockage of acetylcholine receptors.
  • Complement-mediated inflammation leads to:
    • Reduced receptor count.
    • Damage to the end plate.

Clinical features
  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms:

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Diagnosis

Tensilon (edrophonium) Test

  • This involves the injection of Edrophonium (a short-acting anticholinesterase agent) into individuals with a deficiency of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Steps: 2 mg i.v. Edrophonium → Observe for any adverse reactions → If no adverse reactions occur after 30–60 seconds, the remaining 8 mg is injected.
  • If muscle strength improves after the administration of edrophonium, it indicates the presence of Myasthenia Gravis.

Management

Anticholinesterase agents (inhibit the breakdown of ACh by acetylcholinesterase and increase presynaptic levels of ACh, allowing for muscle contraction).

  • Pyridostigmine (drug of choice)
  • Neostigmine
  • Ambenonium

Huntington's chorea (Option B) is characterised by involuntary jerking movements and a decline in cognitive and psychiatric function. No ptosis or improvement with neostigmine.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option C) is characterised by progressive muscle weakness and atrophy. It has a mix of upper neuron and lower neuron signs in its presentation. Though ptosis may be seen, No improvement with neostigmine is seen.

External ophthalmoplegia (Option D) is characterised by paralysis or weakness of the muscles that control eye movement, resulting in diplopia. No improvement with neostigmine is seen.

questions.text: A newborn infant is brought to the clinic with jaundice and a white, punctate, and scattered opacity in the central lens. The condition is consistent with Oil drop cataract. Which of the following metabolic disorders is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Galactosemia

Explanation:

  • The most likely metabolic disorder responsible for the presentation of oil drop cataract in a newborn infant with jaundice and lens opacities is Galactosemia.
  • GALT deficiency, also known as galactosemia, is a genetic disorder that impairs the ability to metabolize galactose properly. Galactose is a sugar found in milk and other dairy products.

 

Galactose-1-phosphate Uridyltransferase (GALT) Deficiency
  • Severely deficient in individuals with Classic Galactosemia in which galactose-1-phosphate and, therefore, galactose accumulate. (Option A)
  • It Is an inborn error of metabolism

Accumulation
  • Accumulated galactose is shunted into side pathways like galactitol production. Aldose reductase catalyzes it.
  • Galactose-1 phosphate accumulates in the liver, inhibiting galactokinase and glycogen phosphorylase, leading to hypoglycemia.

Bilirubin

Reduced bilirubin uptake and conjugation, increasing unconjugated bilirubin in blood

Symptoms

  • Hypoglycemia, Hypophosphatemia, Hyperuricemia, Lactic acidosis
  • Hepatomegaly, Jaundice,
  • Severe mental retardation
  • Galactosuria (galactose excreted in urine)
  • Oil drop Cataracts from dulcitol accumulation in the lens, reversible cataract
  • Tubular damage and generalized aminoaciduria

Diagnosis

  • Clinical manifestations (e.g., congenital cataract), presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels
  • Prenatal diagnosis via amniocentesis
  • Detection of heterozygous parents by elevated galactose levels after a galactose load

Complications in untreated cases

  • E. coli sepsis,
  • Fanconi syndrome
  • Feeding problems,
  • Failure to thrive,
  • Hepatocellular damage,
  • Bleeding

Treatment

Withdrawal of galactose and lactose from the diet.

GALT deficiency is a part of the newborn screening panel

 

Phenylketonuria (PKU) (Option A) is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This leads to the buildup of phenylalanine in the body. It can lead to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and other neurological problems if left untreated.

Maple syrup urine disease (Option B) is a metabolic disorder that affects the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine). It can cause neurological symptoms and a characteristic sweet odor to the urine.

Wilson's disease (Option D) is a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to copper accumulation primarily in the liver and brain. It can cause various neurological and hepatic symptoms.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of dicumarol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Inhibits vitamin K dependent Clotting factors

  • Dicumarol (also known as Bishydroxycoumarin) inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, including factors II, VII, IX, and X.
  • It inhibits the enzyme VKOR (vitamin K epoxide reductase).
  • It has poor gastrointestinal tolerance.
  • It's not preferred now.

Activates antithrombin III (Option A): Heparin is an indirect thrombin inhibitor that activates antithrombin III activity to inhibit thrombin indirectly. Dicumarol does not activate antithrombin III.

Inhibits tissue plasminogen activator (Option C): Epsilon Amino-Caproic Acid (EACA) is an anti-fibrinolytic drug that inhibits tissue plasminogen activator and is used as an antidote for fibrinolytic. Dicumarol does not inhibit the action of the tissue plasminogen activator.

Inhibitor of factor Xa (Option D): Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, Edoxaban, and Betrixaban are direct inhibitors of factor Xa. They are used in the treatment of DVT (deep vein thrombosis). Dicumarol does not directly inhibit factor Xa. Instead, it indirectly inhibits the production of factor Xa by inhibiting the production of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.

questions.text: Oxaloacetate is produced from which of the following amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Aspartate

Explanation:

  • Aspartate is the amino acid that contributes to the production of oxaloacetate through transamination reactions in the citric acid cycle.

 

Aspartic Acid (Aspartate):

  • Isolation and Characteristics:
    • Aspartic acid (Asp) was first isolated by Kreusler in 1869.
    • It is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid, meaning it can be synthesized by the body and can be converted to glucose.
  • Transamination and TCA Cycle:
    • Aspartate undergoes transamination to produce oxaloacetate, a key intermediate that initiates the TCA (Krebs) cycle.
    • The enzyme Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST), which requires PLP (pyridoxal phosphate) as a coenzyme, transfers the amino group of aspartate to α-ketoglutarate, forming oxaloacetate and glutamate.
    • Reaction: Aspartate+α-Ketoglutarate→AST/PLPOxaloacetate+Glutamate

Clinical Significance of AST:

    • AST levels are clinically important: Elevated AST is seen in conditions like cardiac ischemia and hepatic diseases (such as liver damage or hepatitis).
  • Malate-Aspartate Shuttle: Transfers cytoplasmic NADH into the mitochondria for oxidation in the electron transport chain, contributing to ATP production.
  • Role in the Urea Cycle: Donating its alpha-amino group to form urea, which is excreted in urine.
  • Glucogenic Pathway:
    • The carbon skeleton of aspartate can also be converted to fumarate, which enters the glucogenic pathway, contributing to glucose synthesis.
    • Reaction:
      Citrulline+Aspartate→Arginine+Fumarate
  • Synthesis of Purines and Pyrimidines:
    • Synthesis of purines: contributing the 1st nitrogen and 6th NH2 group.
    • Pyrimidine synthesis: Its entire structure is incorporated into the pyrimidine ring, contributing the 1st nitrogen and carbons 4, 5, 6.

 

Alanine (Option A) can be involved in the glucose-alanine cycle and can be converted into pyruvate, not oxaloacetate.

Lysine (Option B) is an essential amino acid, and it is not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate.

Leucine (Option C) is also not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate. It is primarily involved in protein synthesis and can be catabolized to generate acetyl-CoA, which can then enter the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old smoker presents with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea. His BP is 190/110 mmHg, and heart rate is 105 bpm. What is the initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Control Blood pressure

Explanation:

  • The case scenario of a smoker presenting with severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back, shortness of breath, and mild nausea, along with a BP of 190/110 mmHg and heart rate of 105 bpm, is likely experiencing Aortic Dissection, where the initial management focuses on BP control.

It occurs when a defect or a flap occurs in the aorta, resulting in blood tracking into aortic tissues, splitting the medial layer, and creating a false lumen.

Clinical features
  • Sudden onset of severe, tearing chest, radiating to the interscapular region
  • Renal pain and renal failure
  • Paraplegia
  • Syncope
  • Weakness
  • Hypotension or shock

Investigations

  • Stable Patient: CT angiography is the standard investigation of choice.
  • Unstable Patients (SBP<100 mm of HG, HR>100 bpm): TEE (TransEsophageal Echocardiography) (preferred investigation of choice)
  • MRI can also be done if CT is unequivocal.
  • Chest x-ray reveals widening of mediastinum along with left-sided pleural effusion

TEE of an aortic dissection within the descending part

Management

Initial Management: Initial management of all types of aortic dissection includes:

  • Blood pressure control (which is usually high at presentation) (Option A)
  • Strict pain management,
  • Prompt referral for specialist management

Surgical Management

Type A (or type I and II) dissections

Type B (or type III) dissections

Those involving the ascending aorta usually require surgical intervention.

  • Synthetic graft if needed
  • Anastomosis

 

Endovascular stenting of type A dissections.

Initial management:

  • Antihypertensive drugs
  • Monitoring on an acute care unit

 

Complicated cases: If pain worsens, fails to resolve, or malperfusion signs appear (e.g., organ, limb, or neurological symptoms)

  • Percutaneous endovascular stents
  • Surgery (rarely used)

 

Urgent surgery (Option B): Although surgery is often required for aortic dissection, blood pressure control is the initial and most critical step before surgery. Stabilizing the patient with medications like labetalol helps reduce the force on the aorta, preventing further dissection or rupture. Surgery would follow once the patient is stabilized.

Wait and watch (Option C) is not an option for aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention. Delaying treatment with a "wait and watch" approach can lead to life-threatening complications, such as rupture or organ failure.

Blood transfusion (Option D) may be necessary if there is significant blood loss, but it is not the first line of management for aortic dissection. The priority is stabilizing the patient with blood pressure control to minimize the risk of further dissection or rupture before considering other interventions like a transfusion.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension is given the drug ‘X’. Identify ‘X’?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Aliskiren

The drug marked ‘X’ is Aliskiren.

  • Class: Renin inhibitor
  • Mechanism: It works by inhibiting renin, blocking the production of angiotensin I, and lowering blood pressure.
  • Use: Treatment of hypertension.

Captopril (Option A) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. It inhibits the activity of ACE (an enzyme responsible for converting angiotensin I into angiotensin II), reducing the production of angiotensin II (vasoconstrictor). This results in vasodilation decreased peripheral resistance, and lower blood pressure. It is commonly used for the treatment of hypertension and heart failure.

Spironolactone (Option B) is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone receptor antagonist. It binds to the aldosterone receptors (kidneys and other tissues) and inhibits the effects of aldosterone, promoting sodium and water excretion while retaining potassium, leading to diuresis. It is used in the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, and certain hormonal disorders.

Losartan (Option D) is an angiotensin II receptor antagonist targeting the angiotensin II type 1 (AT1) receptors. It selectively blocks these receptors, preventing the binding of angiotensin II resulting in vasodilation and a decrease in peripheral resistance and blood pressure. It is commonly prescribed for the management of hypertension and heart failure.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infection. You notice the following finding in his CT. What is the likely condition indicated by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Horseshoe kidney

Explanation:

  • The patient, who presents with hematuria and recurrent urinary tract infections, is diagnosed with Horseshoe Kidney, as indicated by a CT abdomen revealing the fusion of the two kidneys at their lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure.

Horseshoe Kidney

It is a congenital condition in which the two kidneys are fused at the lower ends, forming a U-shaped structure.

Cause

  • During fetal development the kidneys fuse at their lower poles, forming a U-shaped structure.
  • This fusion results in the inferior mesenteric artery preventing the ascent of the isthmus of the kidney to its normal position in the abdomen, leading to an abnormal location lower in the abdomen.

Clinical Features
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Pain: due to obstruction or renal stones.
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Hematuria
  • Rovsing's syndrome: Hyperextension of the spine- nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain.

Investigation

  • CT Angiography (CT Angio): This is the investigation of choice for diagnosing a horseshoe kidney, as it allows for detailed visualization of the renal anatomy, the abnormal vascular supply, and associated complications.

CT Abdomen showing Horseshoe kidney

  • Contrast-Enhanced CT (CECT): Used when CT Angio is not available
  • Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP) - characteristic findings include:
    • Medial Orientation of Calyces: Referred to as the "Hand Joining Sign."
    • High Insertion of Ureters with Anterior Transposition: This creates a "Flower Vase" appearance of the ureters.

 

 

Management

  • Asymptomatic Patients: Typically do not require treatment, but should be monitored periodically.
  • Symptomatic Patients:
    • UPJ Obstruction: Surgical intervention such as pyeloplasty
    • Kidney Stones: Management may include conservative measures like increased fluid intake, medical therapy, or surgical removal
    • UTIs: Treated with antibiotics, and preventive measures may be considered if infections are recurrent.
    • Isthmus Management: The isthmus of the horseshoe kidney should not be divided surgically as it contains functional renal tissue.
    • Pregnancy Considerations: A horseshoe kidney can lead to dystocia (difficult labor) due to the kidney's abnormal position.

 

Polycystic kidney disease (Option A) is a genetic disorder with multiple fluid-filled cysts causing kidney enlargement. CT imaging shows round or oval cysts, but no kidney fusion. The CT scan in this case, showing fused kidneys, is inconsistent with PKD.

 

Hydronephrosis (Option C) is caused by urinary tract blockage, leading to kidney swelling. CT shows dilated renal pelvis and calyces, but no kidney fusion. The CT scan here shows fused kidneys, indicating horseshoe kidney, not hydronephrosis.

 

Pancake kidney (Option D) is a rare congenital anomaly where the kidneys fuse into a flattened, disc-like shape. On CT, it appears as a flattened mass lower in the abdomen, unlike the U-shaped fusion seen in horseshoe kidney. This case shows a U-shaped fusion, indicating horseshoe kidney, not pancake kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following minerals is best known for insulin secretion stabilisation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Zinc

Explanation:

  • Zinc is an essential trace mineral that plays a crucial role in numerous biological processes, including insulin secretion and stabilization. It is involved in the synthesis, storage, and release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells. Zinc also helps in maintaining the structure and stability of insulin molecules.

Zinc:

Dietary Sources

Grains, beans, nuts, cheese, meat, shellfish.

Therapeutic Use

Zinc reduces copper absorption in Wilson’s disease.

Zinc-Dependent Enzymes
  • Carboxypeptidase
  • Carbonic anhydrase
  • Alkaline phosphatase
  • Lactate dehydrogenase
  • Ethanol dehydrogenase
  • Glutamate dehydrogenase
  • RNA polymerase (required for protein biosynthesis)

Functions
  • Antioxidant RoleExtracellular superoxide dismutase is zinc-dependent, contributing to zinc’s antioxidant properties.
  • Insulin and ZincZinc stabilizes insulin in beta cells of the pancreas but is not present in released insulin.
  • Taste Sensation Gusten, a zinc-containing protein in saliva, is important for taste sensation.

Deficiency Manifestations
  • Poor wound healing
  • Skin lesions, hyperkeratosis, dermatitis, alopecia
  • Impaired spermatogenesis
  • Reduced T and B lymphocyte numbers, impaired macrophage function
  • Psychiatric disorders: depression, dementia, and cognitive decline (e.g., Alzheimer's)

Acrodermatitis Enteropathica
  • Acrodermatitis (inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers, etc.)
  • Diarrhea, alopecia, ophthalmoplegia, hypogonadism

Toxicity Manifestations
  • Chronic Toxicity: Gastric ulcers, pancreatitis, anemia, nausea, vomiting, pulmonary fibrosis
  • Acute Toxicity: Fever, excessive salivation, headache, anemia

 

Cadmium (Option A) is a toxic heavy metal that can have detrimental effects on health, including disrupting various physiological processes.

Copper (Option B) is an essential trace mineral that plays a role in various bodily functions, including the formation of red blood cells and maintaining connective tissues. While it is involved in several enzymatic reactions.

Iron (Option C) is vital for oxygen transport in the blood and is a key component of hemoglobin.

questions.text: What type of graft is used when a patient undergoes skin grafting following a road traffic accident in which the graft is harvested from the patient's own body?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autograft

Explanation:

  • The graft harvested from the patient's own body is called an autograft.

Types of Grafts

 

Graft Type

Source

Advantages

Disadvantages

Autograft

(Option A)

Tissue from one site to another on the same individual

No risk of immune rejection; high success rate

Requires a donor site, additional morbidity

Allograft

(Option C ruled out)

Tissue from another individual of the same species

Availability of larger tissue amounts

Risk of immune rejection; needs immunosuppression

Xenograft

(Option B ruled out)

Tissue from a different species (e.g., pig to human)

Readily available; used as temporary grafts

High risk of immune rejection; often temporary

Isograft

(Option D ruled out)

Tissue between genetically identical individuals

No risk of immune rejection due to genetic identity

Limited availability; specific to identical twins
  • Concordant Xenograft:
    • Xenograft between closely related species.
    • Compatibility: Better immune compatibility; lower risk of hyperacute rejection.
    • Example: Primate to human (e.g., baboon to human).
  • Discordant Xenograft:
    • Xenograft between distantly related species.
    • Compatibility: Poor immune compatibility; high risk of hyperacute rejection.
    • Example: Pig to human.

questions.text: In which organelle is DNA present?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Mitochondria

Explanation:

  • DNA is present in the mitochondria, which are double-membraned organelles found in the cells of most eukaryotic organisms. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a small circular molecule separate from the nuclear DNA. It carries genetic information essential for the functioning of mitochondria and plays a crucial role in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Lysosome (Option B) are membrane-bound organelles containing enzymes responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials and substances. Their primary function is related to digestion and waste disposal within the cell.

Endoplasmic Reticulum (Option C) is an organelle involved in the synthesis, folding, modification, and transport of proteins and lipids. The ER is composed of membranous structures and is mainly responsible for the manufacturing and transportation of molecules within the cell.

Cytoplasm (Option D) is the gel-like substance found inside the cell, which includes various organelles and is the site of many cellular processes. The cytoplasm contains various molecules and structures necessary for cell function, DNA is not present in the cytoplasm. DNA is primarily found within the nucleus of eukaryotic cells, where it houses the genetic information required for cell function and development.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve.

choices.text: Drug C is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is as efficacious as drug D
Drug D is more potent than drug C

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Drug B is the most efficacious

  • Drug B is the most efficacious because it exhibits the highest plateau on the dose-response curve.

Efficacy is the maximal effect a drug can produce

  • The higher the Vmax, the higher the efficacy.

Potency is the amount of drug required to produce a given effect

  • The lower the drug dose needed, the higher the potency.

Both are independent of each other;

  • Efficacious drugs can have high or low potency and vice versa.

Drug C is the most potent (Option A): Potency determined by EC50 value, inversely proportional, so Drug C is not the most potent.

Drug C is as efficacious as Drug D (Option C): EC50 value affects potency, not efficacy, so Drug C is not equally efficacious as Drug D.

Drug D is more potent than Drug C (Option D): Potency is determined by EC50 value, so Drug D is not necessarily more potent than Drug C.

questions.text: Please determine the instrument provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Linear stapler

Explanation:

The instrument shown in the image is a Linear Stapler.

  • It consists of a handle, shaft, anvil, and stapling cartridge.
  • Uses:
    • Side to side anastomoses.
    • Ends are closed by transverse staple.
    • To close the bowel either completely or partially.

 

 

Skin stapler (Option B) is used for closing skin wounds, not internal tissues, and does not create the straight-line closure typical of a linear stapler.

 

Circular stapler, also called EEA stapler (End to End Anastomosis) (Option C) is used for anastomosis of tubular structures like the bowel or blood vessels, creating a circular stapling line. It is not suitable for straight-line stapling, which is the function of a linear stapler.

 

 

Curved stapler (Option D) is used for hard-to-reach areas, typically in the gastrointestinal tract, but like the circular stapler, it does not create a straight-line closure, which is the purpose of a linear stapler.

questions.text: Which drug elicits the following response on blood pressure and heart rate, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Norepinephrine

  • The image illustrates an elevation in arterial blood pressure and a reduction in heart rate, which are effects associated with Norepinephrine, which increases systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure and causes reflex bradycardia.

Description

Norepinephrine, or noradrenaline, is a sympathomimetic drug used primarily as a vasopressor.

Mechanism of Action (MOA)

It acts on α1 and β1 adrenergic receptors and has some affinity for alpha-2 receptors.

  • Activation of α1 receptors causes vasoconstriction, increasing peripheral resistance and blood pressure.
  • Activation of β1 receptors increases heart rate and myocardial contractility.

Uses
  • Treatment of acute hypotension (e.g., septic shock, cardiogenic shock).
  • Cardiac arrest.

Side effects
  • Cardiovascular: Arrhythmias, bradycardia, hypertension.
  • CNS: Anxiety, headache, tremor.
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting.
  • Respiratory: Respiratory difficulty, dyspnea.
  • Metabolic: Hyperglycemia, lactic acidosis.

Contraindications
  • Peripheral vascular thrombosis (risk of ischemia).
  • During anesthesia with cyclopropane or halothane (due to the risk of arrhythmias).
  • Hypotension is due to blood volume deficits (hypovolemia) until an adequate fluid replacement.

Isoproterenol (Option B) is a sympathomimetic drug that causes beta-2 mediated vasodilation and leads to a decrease in mean blood pressure and increased heart rate.

Epinephrine (Option C) increases heart rate and blood pressure at lower doses by stimulating beta-1 adrenergic receptors in the heart, but at higher doses, there is a rise in blood pressure, but later beta-2 action predominates and leads to a decrease in blood pressure (biphasic reaction).

Dopamine (Option D) can increase or decrease blood pressure and heart rate depending on the dose and the type of receptors it stimulates. At low doses, it stimulates mainly dopaminergic receptors in the kidneys, causing vasodilation and increasing renal blood flow. At the same time, at higher doses, it can also stimulate alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, increasing blood pressure.

questions.text: Hormone-sensitive lipase is activated by all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D) Insulin

Explanation:

  • Insulin inhibits the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase
  • Hormone-sensitive lipase is present in the adipose tissues which breaks down fats stored in the adipose tissue to FA + glycerol during fasting and starvation. Since it breaks fats, it is considered a catabolic enzyme. It is activated by the catabolic hormone like glucagon and inhibited by the anabolic hormone insulin.

 

Peripheral lipolysis:

  • It is a process in which triacylglycerols are hydrolyzed into free fatty acids (FFA) and glycerol.
  • This process is mediated by hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL).
  • This process occurs in adipose tissue
  • The lipase acts on triacylglycerols and converts them into diacylglycerol, the preferred substrate for HSL.

  • The glycerol released from the adipose tissue is transported to the liver and participates in glycolysis or gluconeogenesis.
  • Free fatty acids bind to albumin and are transported to muscles, where they are activated into their CoA derivatives and oxidized in mitochondria for ATP.

 

Regulation:

  • HSL is activated when phosphorylated with Protein kinase A, which in turn is dependent on cAMP produced in the adipocyte when catecholamines activate adenylyl cyclase.
  • Insulin dephosphorylates HSL and inactivates it.(Option D)
  • The counter-regulatory hormones of insulin, such as glucagon (Option A), epinephrine (Option B), and cortisol, stimulate the activity of HSL.

 

ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) (Option C) While cortisol plays a role in metabolism, it does not directly activate hormone-sensitive lipase. Instead, cortisol can indirectly influence lipid metabolism by affecting other regulatory pathways.

questions.text: A man came with complaints of recurrent discharge and pain due to lesions around the anus for 3 years. A diagnosis of fistula-in-ano is made. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MRI

Explanation:

  • The gold standard investigation in Fistula-in-Ano is MRI.

Fistula-in-Ano

A chronic abnormal communication between the anorectal lumen (internal opening) and an external opening on the skin of the perineum, buttock, or, rarely, the vagina in women.

Causes

  • Idiopathic/Cryptoglandular: The most common cause, often associated with prior anorectal sepsis.
  • Associated Conditions:
    • Crohn’s disease
    • Tuberculosis
    • Lymphogranuloma venereum
    • Actinomycosis
    • Rectal duplication
    • Foreign bodies
    • Malignancy (rare, can develop within a longstanding fistula)

Clinical features
  • Intermittent purulent discharge: This may be bloody and purulent. Discomfort typically increases until the pus discharges, providing temporary relief.
  • Previous history of Anorectal abscess
  • Passage of flatus or faeces: Through the external opening, (indicative of a rectal rather than an anal internal opening).

Investigation

  • MRI: Maps the fistula tunnel and provides detailed images of the sphincter muscle and pelvic floor structures. (Investigation of choice) (Option D)
  • Endoscopic Ultrasound: It uses high-frequency sound waves to identify the fistula, sphincter muscles, and surrounding tissues.
  • Fistulography: An X-ray procedure using injected contrast to visualize the anal fistula tunnel. (1st investigation) (Option A ruled out)
  • Examination Under Anesthesia: Allows for thorough evaluation of the fistula tunnel and identification of potential complications.
  • Fistula Probe: A specialized instrument is inserted through the fistula to identify the fistula tunnel.
  • Anoscopy: A small endoscope is used to visualize the anal canal for assessment of fistulas during anoscopy.

Management:

Fistulotomy

  • Opening the fistula tract to heal by secondary intention.
  • Used for intersphincteric and trans-sphincteric fistula involving <30% of external sphincter; not for anterior fistula in women.

Fistulectomy

  • Removal of the fistula using diathermy cautery for better visualization of anatomy.
  • Effective for understanding the fistula's anatomy and extensions.

Setons

  • Materials are inserted into the fistula tract for drainage or gradual cutting.
  • Loose setons promote drainage; tight/cutting setons cut through muscle over time.

Advancement Flaps

  • Closing the internal opening with a flap of anorectal mucosa is used when the sphincter complex is not extensively indurated.
  • Effective for certain fistula configurations.

 

USG (Ultrasonography) (Option B) is useful for assessing superficial fistulas but is limited in evaluating deep or complex ones, lacking the detailed imaging of surrounding structures that MRI provides.

CECT (Contrast Enhanced Computed Tomography) (Option B) is less ideal for fistula-in-ano due to lower soft tissue contrast compared to MRI, which provides superior detail and accuracy in evaluating fistula anatomy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Probenecid

  • Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that increases the excretion of uric acid in urine by blocking the reabsorption of uric acid in the renal tubules.

Uricosuric drugs

Mechanism

Inhibit OAPT transporter/ URAT-1 in kidney ⇒ Inhibits reabsorption ⇒ Increase excretion of uric acid

Drugs

1. Probenecid:

  • Side effects: diarrhoea, hypersensitivity, uric acid stones
  • Contraindication: nephrolithiasis, renal failure
  • Precaution: take plenty of oral fluids
  • Concomitant colchicine or NSAIDs indicated in attack of gout

2. Sulphinpyrazole:

  • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug
  • Recommended in both acute and chronic gout

3. Benzbromarone:

  • Safe in renal failure
  • Contraindication – Liver diseases

4. Lesinurad

 

Drugs for acute attack of gout

DOC- NSAIDS (All types)

  • Except for aspirin and paracetamol
  • Anti-inflammatory

Colchicine (spindle poison) (Option A)

 
  • MOA: microtubule inhibitor
  • Used in acute attacks of gout and familial Mediterranean fever and is also the DOC for karyotyping

Corticosteroids
  • Intra articular injections, avoid oral route
  • Immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory

 

Drugs for chronic gout

Xanthine oxidase inhibitors

  • Allopurinol (DOC) (Option D)
  • Oxipurinol
  • Febuxostat (Option B)

MOA: Blocks xanthine oxidase enzyme → Inhibits the conversion of hypoxanthine to uric acid in the liver.

Uric acid oxidase enzyme

  • Pegloticase
  • Rasburicase

MOA: Uric acid is converted to allantoin and excreted in urine

Uricosuric agents

  • Probenecid (OptionC)
  • Benzbromaron
  • Sulfinpyrazone
  • Lesinurad

MOA: Inhibit OATP transporter/URAT-1 in the kidney → inhibits reabsorption of uric acid → increased excretion of uric acid.

(OATP - Organic anion transport protein, URAT-1 - Uric acid transporter)

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented to a psychiatrist with symptoms of low mood, loss of interest, loss of appetite, and difficulty sleeping for 2 months. The psychiatrist makes the diagnosis of a major depressive disorder. Which drug is best for the disorder, as mentioned earlier?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Fluoxetine

  • Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI).
  • SSRIs are recommended as a first-line treatment for major depressive disorder due to their efficacy in alleviating depressive symptoms.
  • It works by increasing the availability of serotonin in the brain, which can help improve mood, appetite, and sleep patterns.

Buspirone (Option A) is an anxiolytic primarily used for generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). It lacks significant antidepressant efficacy.

Lithium (Option B) Primarily used as a mood stabiliser for bipolar disorder and to augment antidepressants in treatment-resistant depression. It is not a first-line treatment for unipolar MDD.

Divalproex (Option D) is a mood stabiliser used in bipolar disorder and epilepsy. Not effective as a primary treatment for MDD.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption is admitted to the hospital with features of confusion, vision loss and an unsteady gait. He is unable to remember the most recent incidents. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Thiamine

  • Chronic alcohol consumption can cause thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency due to poor intake and absorption, leading to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, characterised by confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confabulation, and amnesia.

Feature

Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Korsakoff Syndrome

Onset

Acute

Chronic often follows Wernicke's

Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C) (Option A): Ascorbic acid deficiency leads to scurvy, characterised by weakness, joint pain, bleeding gums, and skin changes.

Retinol (Vitamin A) (Option B) Retinol deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, and vision-related issues.

Folate (Vitamin B9) (Option D) Folate deficiency can cause megaloblastic anaemia and neural tube defects in pregnant women.

questions.text: Which antidepressant would you recommend for a 38-year-old professor experiencing depression who is concerned about potential sexual dysfunction as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Bupropion

  • Bupropion is least likely to cause sexual dysfunction compared to other antidepressants.
  • As a dopamine-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (DNRI), it increases dopamine and norepinephrine levels without affecting serotonin, unlike SSRIs and SNRIs, which often cause sexual dysfunction by raising serotonin levels.
  • Bupropion may even improve sexual function in some cases.

Escitalopram (Option B) is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that works by increasing serotonin levels in the brain, which can improve mood but can also cause sexual dysfunction as a side effect. In some studies, up to 60% of patients taking SSRIs reported sexual dysfunction as a side effect.

Venlafaxine (Option C) is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) that works by increasing the levels of both serotonin and norepinephrine in the brain, which can improve mood but can also cause sexual dysfunction as a side effect. Studies have shown that up to 30% of patients taking SNRIs reported sexual dysfunction as a side effect.

Fluoxetine (Option D) is an SSRI antidepressant commonly prescribed for depression and anxiety disorders. While it can cause sexual dysfunction, it is less likely than SSRIs like paroxetine or sertraline. Its long half-life may prolong its effects on sexual function, making it less suitable for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: Which mental functions are examined in the Mental State Examination (100-7)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Concentration

  • The Mental State Examination (MSE) often uses the 100-7 test to assess concentration. In this test, the patient is asked to subtract 7 from 100 and subtract 7 from each resulting number for one minute. The number of correct responses is recorded.
  • Concentration, defined as the ability to focus and maintain attention on a task, can also be evaluated in the MSE through activities such as counting backwards or reciting the months of the year in reverse order.

Mental Status Examination (MSE):

  • The Mental Status Examination (MSE) is the psychiatric counterpart to a physical examination used in the rest of medicine.
  • It examines all aspects of mental functioning and identifies signs and symptoms indicative of mental illness. It provides a “snapshot” of the patient’s mental state at the time of the assessment.
  • Cognitive evaluation in MSE is usually done in the form of a Mini-Mental Status Examination (MMSE).

Aspects of MSE:

General description:
  • Appearance and behaviour
  • Motor activity Speech

Emotional state:
  • Mood: subjective experience of patient’s internal and sustained emotional state
  • Affect: expression of mood (that appears to the clinician)

Thinking:
  • Thought content
  • Thought process
  • Perceptual disturbances

Cognition (higher mental function): most commonly evaluated by Mini-Mental Status Examination (MMSE)
  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention & calculation
  • Memory (immediate, recent & long term)
  • Abstract reasoning
  • Insight & Judgement

Judgment (Option A) refers to a person's ability to make sound decisions and choices. It involves considering multiple options, weighing the pros and cons, and deciding based on reason and logic. Judgment can be assessed in the MSE by asking the patient to solve a hypothetical problem, such as what they would do if they found a stamped envelope on the street.

Language (Option B) refers to a person's ability to communicate effectively using spoken or written words. Language can be assessed in the MSE by asking the patient to name objects, repeat phrases, describe a picture, or write a sentence.

Orientation (Option C) refers to people’s awareness of their surroundings and place in time and space. Orientation can be assessed in the MSE by asking the patient to state their name, the date, location, and the reason for their hospitalisation.

questions.text: What is the predominant manifestation experienced with cannabis consumption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers C - Dream-like state

  • The predominant manifestation of cannabis consumption is a dream-like state characterised by altered perception, euphoria, and detachment from reality. Cannabis primarily affects the central nervous system, inducing a state of relaxation and altered sensory experiences.

Cannabis

Aspect

Description

Composition
  • Over 400 compounds
  • Includes cannabinoids, flavonoids, and terpenoids
  • Primary psychoactive component: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)

Forms
  • Dried plant material (marijuana)
  • Bhang (Derived from dried leaves)
  • Ganja (derived from flowering stem)
  • Hashish (concentrated resin)
  • Oils and extracts (Hash oil)
  • Edibles
  • Topical preparations

Receptors
  • CB1 and CB2 (G-protein coupled receptors- Gi subtype)

Methods of Use
  • Smoking (most common)
  • Vaporizing
  • Oral ingestion
  • Sublingual administration
  • Topical application

Clinical Features of Intoxication
  • Tachycardia
  • Conjunctival injection
  • Anxiety or euphoria
  • Slowness of time
  • Impaired cognition and motor coordination
  • Dry mouth
  • Increased appetite
  • Nystagmus
  • Postural hypotension
  • Delirium (especially at high doses)

Onset and Duration of Effects
  • Smoking: Rapid onset (minutes), duration 2-3 hours
  • Oral ingestion: Delayed onset (30-90 minutes), duration 4-12 hours

Anxiety (Option A). While some people may experience anxiety or paranoia after using cannabis, this is not the most common symptom. In fact, some strains of cannabis are known for their calming and anxiety-reducing effects.

Depressed mood (Option B). Cannabis can have mood-altering effects, but a depressed mood is not the most common symptom. In some cases, cannabis may actually improve mood and alleviate symptoms of depression.

Decreased appetite (Option D). Cannabis is known for causing "the munchies," or an increase in appetite rather than a decrease. While some strains may have more appetite-suppressing effects, this is not the most common symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following does not suggest a medical cause of mental illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Auditory hallucination

  • Auditory hallucinations are more commonly associated with psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders rather than medical causes of mental illness.
  • While medical causes (e.g., delirium and neurological disorders) can occasionally produce hallucinations, visual or tactile hallucinations are more indicative of a medical etiology than auditory hallucinations.

Elderly age (Option A): Mental illnesses in older adults are more likely to have a medical or organic cause (e.g., dementia, delirium, or metabolic abnormalities).

Loss of consciousness (Option B) suggests possible neurological issues such as epilepsy, head trauma, or other medical conditions causing altered mental states.

Acute onset (Option D): Rapid onset of psychiatric symptoms strongly suggests a medical cause, such as delirium, stroke, or infection.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a middle-aged man who visits the psychiatry OPD claiming that he has been hearing voices from aliens instructing him to harm his family members for the last seven months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Schizophrenia

The patient's presentation of auditory hallucinations (hearing voices from aliens instructing harm) persisting for seven months strongly suggests schizophrenia. Key diagnostic features include:

  • Hallucinations: Perception of voices in the absence of external stimuli, a hallmark of schizophrenia.
  • Duration: Symptoms persisting for more than six months are required for a diagnosis of schizophrenia, as per DSM-5 criteria.
  • Content of hallucinations: The bizarre and threatening nature of the auditory hallucinations aligns with the psychotic features commonly seen in schizophrenia.

Types of Schizophrenia:

Type of Schizophrenia

Characteristics

Paranoid Schizophrenia

  • Characterised by delusions and hallucinations.
  • Individuals may have a fixed belief that others are out to harm them, often leading to mistrust and vigilance.
  • Cognitive functions usually remain intact, while emotional responses may be inappropriate.

Catatonic Schizophrenia

 

Characterised by three or more of the following symptoms:

  • Motor immobility ( stupor)
  • Excessive, odd movement (stereotypies or mannerisms)
  • Waxy flexibility (bending like a wax candle)
  • Extreme negativism (resisting instructions or maintaining rigidity)
  • Unusual postures (bizarre posturing, catalepsy)
  • Echolalia or echopraxia (Mimicking speech or movements)

Disorganised (Hebephrenic) Schizophrenia
  • Involves disorganised speech and behavior.
  • Inappropriate emotional responses and poor functioning.
  • Typically associated with a poorer prognosis.

Residual Schizophrenia
  • History of schizophrenia with delusions and hallucinations (in the past 1 year) with lingering negative symptoms but minimal or no positive symptoms at present.
  • No prominent delusions or hallucinations
  • Individuals may exhibit social withdrawal and reduced emotional expression.

Simple Schizophrenia

Involves prominent negative symptoms

Undifferentiated Schizophrenia

Diagnosis for patients who do not fit into other categories presenting a mix of symptoms.

Mania (Option A) involves elevated mood, grandiosity, and hyperactivity but does not typically present with persistent hallucinations instructing harm.

Delusional Disorder (Option B) involves non-bizarre delusions without prominent hallucinations. Persistent auditory hallucinations exclude this diagnosis.

Brief Psychotic Disorder (Option D) involves psychotic symptoms lasting less than one month, ruling it out in this case where symptoms have persisted for seven months.

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of heme synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
