Correct Option: C) δ Amino-Levulinic Acid synthase (ALA Synthase)

Explanation:

  • This enzyme catalyzes the formation of ALA from glycine and succinyl-CoA. It is the rate-limiting enzyme of the heme synthesis pathway. Its activity is tightly regulated by feedback inhibition by heme itself.

 

 

Heme Synthesis:

Step

Reaction

Enzyme

Key Points

1

Succinyl CoA + Glycine → Delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)

ALA Synthase (Option C)

Mitochondria

Rate-limiting step; requires pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor

ALA Dehydratase (Option B)

Cytoplasm

It involves removal of 2 molecules of water; the enzyme contains zinc and is inhibited by lead

4 PBG → Hydroxymethylbilane (HMB)

Uroporphyrinogen Decarboxylase

Protoporphyrinogen Oxidase

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with CAD comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, height of 182 cm, weight of 85 kg, and a BMI of 25 kg/m². Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 95 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration of 19.3 μmol/L (N=5–15). Serum lipid concentrations are within the normal range. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Cystathionine beta synthase

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario CAD patient with high homocysteine levels is suggestive of homocystinuria caused by Cystathionine beta synthase deficiency is associated with homocystinuria.

 

Homocystinuria:

  • A genetic disorder characterized by elevated levels of homocysteine in the blood. The clinical manifestations of homocystinuria can include cardiovascular issues (such as early-onset atherosclerosis), skeletal abnormalities, intellectual disabilities, and other systemic complications. The patient in the question has an elevated homocysteine concentration, which is characteristic of homocystinuria.

 

Types of Homocystinuria:

 

Type 1 vs Type 2 Homocystinuria:

Feature

Type - I Homocystinuria

Type - II Homocystinuria

Enzyme Deficiency

Cystathionine beta-synthase

Methionine synthase

Metabolic Pathway Affected

Homocysteine to cystathionine

Homocysteine to methionine

Elevated Metabolites

Homocysteine and methionine

Homocysteine and elevated levels of methionine

Biochemical Diagnosis
  • Low levels of cysteine.
  • High levels of methionine.
  • High levels of cysteine.
  • Low levels of methionine.

Treatment
  • Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation; low-methionine diet; cysteine supplementation

Vitamin B12 and folate supplementation; low-methionine diet

 

Homogentisate oxidase (Option A) deficiency leads to alkaptonuria, a condition characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, causing darkening of urine and connective tissue.

Cystathionine gamma synthase (Option C) deficiency is not a well-known enzyme deficiency associated with a specific clinical disorder. Cystathionine gamma synthase is involved in the transsulfuration pathway, converting cystathionine to cysteine.

HGPRTase (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase) (Option D) deficiency is seen in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by neurological and behavioral abnormalities, along with uric acid overproduction leading to gout.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy who accompanied his father to a fish farming region in his hometown accidentally consumes a white odourless chemical. He was under some medication and post-meal he developed toxicity of the drug. Which of the following toxin is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Antimycin A

Antimycin A is commonly used in fish farming as a piscicide (a chemical toxic to fish) to selectively remove undesirable fish species. It is a colorless to white crystalline compound and is relatively odorless.

  • It is a potent respiratory chain uncoupler. When consumed, it inhibits cellular respiration.
  • It is a mitochondrial toxin that inhibits Complex III of the electron transport chain.
  • This inhibition leads to decreased ATP production and increased oxidative stress.
  • This can amplify the toxicity of some medications- especially those metabolized via oxidative pathways (e.g. anticonvulsants, antibiotics, or chemotherapeutics).

Alkyl guanides (Option A) are a broad class of compounds, some of which can be toxic, but not specifically associated with fish farming or the described scenario. Also, they aren't primarily known for causing drug toxicity by interfering with metabolism in the same direct way as Antimycin A.

BAL (British Anti-Lewisite; Dimercaprol) (Option B): This is a chelating agent, not a toxin, and is used as an antidote for heavy metal poisoning.

Strychnine (Option D): It's a plant-derived neurotoxin (not used in fish farming). It causes convulsions via spinal inhibition of glycine, not mitochondrial toxicity. It does not primarily cause drug toxicity by interfering with drug metabolism in the way Antimycin A does. Its symptoms would be distinctly neurological, not primarily drug accumulation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female came to the emergency department with a bleeding condition and dental caries. Which vitamin supplementation from the list below would be best for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Vitamin K

Explanation:

  • Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting and proper wound healing.

Vitamin K:

  • Fat-soluble vitamin that acts as a coenzyme or prosthetic group for gamma-carboxylase.
  • Calcium-dependent proteins that rely on Vitamin K:
    • Clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.
    • Anticoagulant factors like protein C and S.
    • Osteocalcin (promotes bone mineralization by depositing calcium).
  • Forms of Vitamin K:
    • Phylloquinone (K1): Found in green vegetables, this form has an isoprenoid side chain with 20 carbons.
    • Menaquinones (K2): Synthesized by intestinal bacteria, these have varying side chain lengths and an isoprenoid side chain containing 30 carbons, which is lipid soluble. (Option B)
    • Menadione (K3): A synthetic form which is water-soluble. Menadione and menadione diacetate can be metabolized into phylloquinone.
  • Vitamin K exists in two forms: Epoxide and Hydroquinone form.
  • Functions:
    • Blood Clotting.
    • Bone Health - Carboxylating glutamate to glutamic acid in proteins like osteocalcin is involved in bone mineralization.

 

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine) (Option A) is important for converting food into energy and maintaining proper nerve function..

Vitamin B9 (Folate (Option B) is crucial for cell division and DNA synthesis. It is particularly important during pregnancy and for overall cell growth. Deficiency in folate can lead to anemia

Vitamin D (Option C) is important for maintaining bone health, immune function, and overall well-being. It helps the body absorb calcium and phosphorus from the intestines. Vitamin D deficiency can lead to weakened bones and rickets.

questions.text: In all types of shock, which of the following is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reduced tissue perfusion

Explanation:

  • Reduced tissue perfusion, a hallmark of all Shock types, results in inadequate oxygen and nutrient delivery, leading to organ dysfunction.
    • It is defined as a systemic state of low tissue perfusion which is inadequate for normal cellular respiration. (Option A)

Classification

Type of Shock

Mechanism

Examples

Hypovolemic Shock

Reduced circulating blood volume

Hemorrhage, Dehydration

Cardiogenic Shock

Failure of the cardiac pump

Myocardial Infarction, Cardiac Dysrhythmias

Obstructive Shock

Mechanical obstruction of cardiac filling

Cardiac Tamponade, Tension Pneumothorax

Distributive Shock

Systemic vasodilation leading to organ hypoperfusion

Septic Shock, Anaphylactic Shock

Endocrine Shock

Combination of hypovolemic, cardiogenic, or distributive shock mechanisms

Addisonian Crisis, Myxedema Coma

 

Increased peripheral resistance (Option B) may occur in some shock types (e.g., hypovolemic, cardiogenic) as compensation to maintain blood pressure, but it's not universal. In septic shock, peripheral resistance is often decreased due to vasodilation.

Decreased respiratory rate (Option C) may occur in certain shock types (e.g., neurogenic, severe hypovolemic), but increased respiratory rate (tachypnea) is more common as the body compensates for low oxygen levels, making it not universal in all shock types.

Cold clammy skin (Option D) occurs in some shock types (e.g., hypovolemic, cardiogenic) due to vasoconstriction, but not in all. In septic shock, skin may be warm and flushed due to vasodilation.

questions.text: A female was diagnosed with lead poisoning. What is the probable enzyme defect responsible for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) ALA dehydratase

Explanation:

Lead poisoning can lead to acquired porphyria by inhibiting 3 enzymes of the heme synthesis pathway:

Enzyme inhibited

Features

ALA dehydratase (Primarily inhibited)

ALA elevation

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase

Coproporphyrin elevation

Ferrochelatase

Elevated Zinc protoporphyrin levels (Most sensitive marker)

 

ALA synthase (Option A) is an enzyme involved in the first step of heme synthesis, where delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is formed.

Heme synthase (Option C), also known as ferrochelatase, is involved in the final step of heme synthesis, where ferrous iron is inserted into protoporphyrin IX to form heme.

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase (Option D) is an enzyme involved in the conversion of coproporphyrinogen III to protoporphyrinogen IX in the heme synthesis pathway

questions.text: Which of the following procedures has the highest risk of causing the recurrence of duodenal ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Highly selective vagotomy

Explanation:

  • Highly Selective Vagotomy (also known as Parietal Cell Vagotomy or Proximal Gastric Vagotomy) has the highest risk of causing the recurrence of duodenal ulcers.
  • It is the procedure that best preserves the vagal innervation of the gastric antrum and pylorus.
  • It divides only the vagus nerves supplying the acid-producing portion of the stomach within the corpus and fundus, so there is no need for routine drainage procedures.

 

Characteristic

Truncal Vagotomy

(Option C ruled out)

Truncal Vagotomy with Antrectomy

(Option D ruled out)

Selective Vagotomy

(Option A ruled out)

Highly Selective Vagotomy

(Option B)

Nerves Divided

Left and right vagus above hepatic and celiac branches

Truncal vagotomy plus removal of the antrum

Main right and left vagus distal to celiac and hepatic branches

Only nerves to the acid-producing portion (all branches to the fundus and body) of the stomach

Drainage Procedure

Usually required

Not applicable

Required

Not required

Acid Reduction

~50%

~85%

<50%

Variable

Ulcer Recurrence

2-7%

1%

5-10%

2-10%%

Significant side effects

10-20%

10-20%

10-20%

<5%

questions.text: In which of the following locations can cardiolipin be found?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Inner mitochondrial membrane

  • Cardiolipin is a distinctive phospholipid abundant in the inner mitochondrial membrane. It plays a role in the structural integrity of the mitochondria and is involved in several mitochondrial functions, including electron transport chain activity.

Cardiolipin:

Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane

Function:

  • Optimal function of numerous enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism.
  • Stabilizes the respiratory chain complexes and supercomplexes

Synthesis:

  • Unique dimeric structure consisting of four fatty acid chains
  • Synthesized in the mitochondria from phosphatidylglycerol and cytidine diphosphate-diacylglycerol (CDP-DAG)

Outer mitochondrial membrane (Option A) primarily consists of phospholipids like phosphatidylcholine and phosphatidylethanolamine.

Option C - Cytosol: Cardiolipin is not found in the cytosol. It is mainly confined to the mitochondrial membrane.

Mitochondrial matrix (Option D) Cardiolipin is primarily located in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not a major component of the mitochondrial matrix.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has limited hip movement and complains of pain and discomfort in the hip region. Which of the following tests is done to identify flexion deformity at the hip?
questions.solution:
Correct option: A) Thomas test

Explanation:

  • This test is used to assess the presence of hip flexion contracture and to measure hip extension.
  • If the patient has a hip flexion contracture, the contralateral knee will rise off the examination table when the hip on the affected side is extended.

 

Thomas Test :

  • Thomas Test is a clinical examination used to assess hip flexion contracture (tightness of the hip flexors), particularly the iliopsoas muscle. It helps detect hip flexor tightness or shortening which may be contributing to lower back or hip pain. The test is especially useful in diagnosing conditions such as iliopsoas syndrome or hip joint stiffness.

Steps in Thomas Test:

  1. Position the Patient:
  2. Flex the Contralateral Hip:
  3. Assess the Involved Hip: While the opposite leg is held in flexion, observe the position of the involved leg (the leg lying flat on the table).
  4. Evaluate Knee Flexion
    • Positive Thomas Test: The involved leg rises off the table or the knee remains flexed. This suggests hip flexor contracture (tightness of the iliopsoas or other hip flexors), which may limit the ability of the patient to fully extend the hip.
    • Negative Thomas Test: The involved leg remains flat on the table, with little to no knee flexion, indicating that there is no significant hip flexor tightness.

 

Telescopy (Option C) Identifies hip instability by moving the patient's leg in circular motion, observing abnormal hip joint movement, confirmed by visible and palpable greater trochanter displacement.

Lasegue test (Option B) Identifies lumbar radiculopathy or sciatica by lifting the patient's straight leg while lying flat, pain indicating nerve root compression.

McMurray test (Option D) Assesses knee meniscal tears by bending, twisting, and extending the patient's knee, pain or "click" suggests tear.

questions.text: A patient is referred to a higher center with the diagnosis of fracture. On examination, the forearm pulses were not palpable. An upper arm X-ray was done, which is given below. Which artery is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Brachial artery

Explanation:

  • The brachial artery is a major artery in the upper arm and runs along the anterior aspect of the upper arm. It is the main blood vessel that supplies blood to the arm. The brachial artery divides into the radial and ulnar arteries in the elbow region.
  • An injury to the brachial artery can result in reduced blood flow to the entire arm, including the forearm and hand. This can cause a reduction or absence of pulses in the upper arm.

Radial artery (Option A): While an injury to the radial artery can result in reduced blood flow to the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand, it would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

Ulnar artery (Option B): Like the radial artery, an injury to the ulnar artery can result in reduced blood flow to the medial aspect of the forearm and hand but would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

Anterior interosseous artery (Option D): An injury to the anterior interosseous artery can result in reduced blood flow to the muscles in the anterior compartment of the forearm but would not affect the pulses in the upper arm.

questions.text: What type of displacement is most likely observed in a 60-year-old female patient who presents with pain and swelling in her left wrist after falling on an outstretched hand, and exhibits a dinner fork deformity upon examination?

choices.text: Proximal and ventral displacement of radius
Supination and dorsal displacement of radius
Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna
Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Supination and dorsal displacement of radius

Explanation:.

  • In a Colles' fracture, the distal fragment of the radius is displaced dorsally. At the same time, the wrist is tilted towards the palm of the hand, resulting in the characteristic dinner fork deformity..

Displacement of Radius that may be seen in Colles’ fracture:

  • Dorsal shift
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Lateral shift
  • Lateral tilt
  • Supination
  • Proximal shift

Diagnosis is done by X-ray. The most common is Dorsal tilt.

Best test to identify colles fracture - styloid process test.

Styloid Process Test:

  • Normally the radial styloid process is distal to the ulnar styloid process.
  • In Colles fracture - both radial and ulnar styloid processes are at the same level.
  • Most reliable clinical sign.

Management of a Colles' fracture:

  • Closed reduction and below elbow POP cast- “Handshake cast”: Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement).

 

Complications

  • Stiffness of fingers - most common
  • Malunion - next common complication
  • Median nerve - most common nerve injured.
    • One of the very common causes of Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Extensor pollicis longus - most common tendon injured.

 

Proximal and ventral displacement of radius (Option A) is reverse colle’s fracture, this would result in a deformity that appears opposite to the dinner fork deformity, with the wrist being angled downwards.

Proximal and dorsal displacement of ulna (Option C) distal radius fracture would not typically result in displacement of the ulna.

Proximal and ventral displacement of ulna (Option D) is also incorrect as this would result in a deformity that appears opposite to the dinner fork deformity, with the wrist angled upwards.

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the marked structure correspond?

choices.text: At the junction of L1 & L2
At the junction of L2 & L3
At the junction of T12 & L1
At the junction of L3 & L4

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) At the junction of L3 & L4

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the umbilicus which lies at the junction of L3 & L4. The umbilicus is located at the level of the intervertebral disc between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, the ureters, and the descending colon.

Abdominal planes -

Position of Umbilicus:

  • The position of the umbilicus varies depending on the individual's body shape and size, but it is typically located at the level of the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) or the intervertebral disc between L4 and L5.
  • It is situated in the center of the abdomen, approximately halfway between the xiphoid process at the bottom of the sternum and the pubic symphysis.

 

At the junction of L1 & L2 (Option A): Associated structures at this level include the spinal cord, the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the renal arteries and veins, and the ureters.

At the junction of L2 & L3 (Option B): Associated structures at this level include the inferior vena cava, the renal veins, the gonadal arteries and veins, and the ascending colon.

At the junction of T12 & L1 (Option C): Associated structures at this level include the aorta, the inferior vena cava, the celiac trunk, the superior mesenteric artery, and the renal arteries

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient after an injury presented with a deformity as shown in the image. Which nerve will be damaged in the given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Radial Nerve

Explanation:

  • In the given scenario, the image displaying wrist drop and a fracture of the shaft of the humerus is indicative of damage to the radial nerve

Nerve

Root origin

Common causes

Features

Radial

C5-T1
  • Compression in axilla (crutches, "Saturday night palsy")
  • Midshaft fracture of humerus
  • Repetitive pronation/supination (screwdriver use, "finger drop")

Above elbow injury:

  • Loss of sensation over posterior arm/forearm and dorsal hand
  • Wrist drop (loss of elbow, wrist, and finger extension)
  • Decreased grip strength (wrist extension necessary for maximal action of flexors)

Below elbow injury:

  • Distal paresthesias without wrist drop

Midshaft fracture:

  • Tricep function and posterior arm sensation spared

 

Ulnar Nerve (Option A): The ulnar nerve mainly innervates forearm and hand muscles for wrist flexion and finger abduction. It's not typically involved in wrist drop.

Median Nerve (Option C): The median nerve innervates specific forearm muscles and the hand's anterior compartment but isn't heavily involved in wrist extension, the main problem in the image.

Musculocutaneous Nerve (Option D): The musculocutaneous nerve mainly innervates the anterior arm muscles, like the biceps brachii, aiding in elbow flexion, not wrist extension.

questions.text: A person who had a road traffic accident presented to ER with injury to bulbar urethra. What can be the location of collection of the urine due to this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Anterior abdominal wall

Explanation:

  • The bulbar urethra is a part of the male urethra located just before the penile urethra. An injury to the bulbar urethra can lead to a urethral rupture, allowing urine to leak into the surrounding tissues. In the case of bulbar urethral rupture, the urine extravasates to
    • Superficial perineal pouch
    • Scrotum
    • Penile region
    • Anterior abdominal wall

Extravasation of Urine:

  • Due to rupture of spongy urethra below the perineal membrane causes urine to accumulate in – superficial extravasation.
    • If Buck's fascia is intact, extravasation of blood and urine confined to penile shaft.
    • If Buck's fascia is disrupted:
      • Superficial perineal pouch
      • Scrotum
      • Around penis
      • Lower part of anterior abdominal wall
  • Urine cannot escape to:
    • Deep perineal pouch (because of perineal membrane)
    • Ischiorectal fossa (because of Colles' fascia)
    • Thigh (fascia lata)
  • Due to rupture of membranous urethra above the perineal membrane causes urine to accumulate in – deep extravasation.
    • Deep perineal pouch
    • Extraperitoneal space
    • Space of Retzius (space around bladder and prostate)
    • Superficial perineal space if perineal membrane also ruptured

 

Inguinal pouch (Option A): The inguinal pouch is not a typical location for urine collection. It is an area in the groin region, and urine collection there wouldn't be directly related to a bulbar urethral injury.

Peritoneal cavity (Option B): The peritoneal cavity is the abdominal cavity where various organs are located. It is not a common location for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. Leakage of urine into the peritoneal cavity could result in a condition known as urinoma, but this is not the primary location of urine collection in cases of bulbar urethral injury.

Ischiorectal fossa (Option C): The ischiorectal fossa is situated in the pelvic region, but it is not a usual site for urine collection due to a bulbar urethral injury. This fossa contains fat and connective tissue and is not directly connected to the urinary system.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male was climbing the stair, suddenly he fell & an iron nail hit on his neck. After the injury, the patient is having a hard time shrugging his shoulders and he is having difficulty turning his head. This might be due to an injury to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Spinal accessory Nerve

Explanation:

  • The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) is responsible for innervating the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles.
  • In this scenario, the patient's difficulty in shrugging his shoulders and turning his head suggests an issue with the spinal accessory nerve, which controls these muscles.
  • The injury caused by the nail hitting his neck could have damaged or impinged the spinal accessory nerve, leading to these symptoms.

Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI):

  • Supplies: Sternomastoid muscle and Trapezius muscle
  • Enter the cranial cavity by foramen magnum and exit by jugular foramen.
  • Spinal accessory nerve is a content of the occipital triangle
  • If damaged it will lead to difficulty in shrugging the shoulder (trapezius muscle affected)

 

Deltoid Muscle (Option B): The symptoms described are not directly related to the function of the deltoid muscle, which is responsible for shoulder abduction.

Sternocleidomastoid Muscle (Option C): Sternocleidomastoid muscle is involved in head and neck movements such as rotation and tilting, it is not responsible for shoulder shrugging.

Long Thoracic Nerve (Option D): Damage to the long thoracic nerve can lead to scapular "winging," where the scapula protrudes outward from the back due to weakened serratus anterior muscle.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 17-year-old male patient who visits the clinic with a painless lump on the outer side of his left knee, as depicted in the radiograph provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Osteochondroma

Explanation:

  • The radiograph shows a well-defined bony protuberance arising from the metaphysis of the distal femur, which is consistent with an osteochondroma.

 

Osteochondroma:

  • Benign cartilaginous neoplasms arising from physeal cartilage beneath the periosteum.
  • Growth via enchondral ossification, similar to normal bone development.
  • More common in males, usually appearing during adolescence.
  • Affects long bones, especially the femur and humerus.

Clinical Presentation

  • Usually presents as a painless mass.
  • Symptoms may include:
    • Formation of a bursa due to friction.
    • Activity-related discomfort.
  • Rare symptoms:
    • Neuropathic pain from nerve compression.
    • Sudden pain due to fracture.

Osteochondroma: X-ray, Treatment, and Complications

 

X-ray Appearance

  • Bony protuberance with distinct edges.
  • Widened host bone cortex extending into the osteochondroma.
  • Features may include:
    • Thin outer cortex, cancellous structure.
    • Pedunculated (cauliflower-like) or sessile base.
    • Pedunculated types grow away from joints, toward the diaphysis.

 

 

MRI to assess the cartilage cap thickness

  • Reserved for cases where malignant transformation is suspected.

 

 

Biopsy to rule out malignancy

  • Indicated without symptoms such as pain or rapid growth.

 

Treatment

  • Asymptomatic osteochondromas: No treatment required. (Option B)
  • Excision indicated for:
    • Large lesions causing pressure.
    • Concern for malignant transformation in adults.

 

Complications

Complication

Description

Painful bursa formation

Due to friction over the osteochondroma.

Activity-related discomfort

General discomfort with movement.

Nerve compression

Rare, may cause neuropathic symptoms.

Fracture

Uncommon, results in sudden pain.

Malignant transformation

Rare progression to chondrosarcoma, more likely with a cartilage cap >1.5 cm.

 

  • Malignant transformation risk factors:
    • Large cartilage cap (>1.5 cm on MRI).
    • Osteochondroma location: More common in the trunk, rare in extremities.
    • Risk Factors: Increased size or new pain after skeletal maturity, especially in Multiple Osteochondromas.

Enchondroma (Option A) are benign cartilaginous tumors that typically arise within the medullary canal of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur. They are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally on radiographs.

 

Chondroblastoma (Option B) are rare benign bone tumors that arise in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the proximal humerus or femur. On X-ray, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis.

 

Giant Cell Tumor (Option D) are benign bone tumors that typically arise in the epiphysis of long bones, such as the distal femur or proximal tibia. They may cause pain and swelling and erode adjacent bone, resulting in pathologic fractures. On radiographs, giant cell tumors appear as lytic lesions with a "soap bubble" appearance.

questions.text: An elderly patient with the presented deformity was brought to the outpatient department (OPD). What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Rheumatoid Arthritis

Explanation:

  • The image provided shows a deformity of the hand with ulnar deviation of the fingers, which is a classic finding in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). It is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. It is characterized by synovial membrane inflammation, which lines the joint space, leading to progressive cartilage and bone destruction.

 

Clinical features of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Symmetrical polyarthritis, polysynovitis with soft-tissue swelling- Pain and morning stiffness in multiple joints usually lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • Generalized myopathy or neuropathy, tiredness, and loss of weight.
  • As the disease progresses, joint deformity, joint instability, and tendon rupture.

 

Joints affected

Common
  • MP joints of the hand
  • PIP joints of fingers
  • Wrists, knees, elbows, ankles

Less common
  • Hip joint
  • Temporo-mandibular joint
  • Spares sacroiliac joint and distal inter phalangeal joints.

 

Deformities in Rheumatoid arthritis
Hand
  • Ulnar deviation of the hand
  • Swan neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity

Elbow: Flexion deformity
Knee
  • Valgus deformity
Ankle: Equinus deformity
Foot
  • Hallux valgus
  • Hammer toe

 

Extra-articular manifestations of Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Vasculitis
  • Rheumatoid nodules- Subcutaneous, over bony prominences, in the synovium, on tendons, in the sclera, and the viscera. Size is increased by methotrexate.
  • Serositis
  • Felty's syndrome: Severe splenomegaly + neutropenia + RA. (Option A)

 

Rickets (Option A) is a condition that results from the deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphorus, leading to poor bone mineralization. It commonly presents with bowing of the legs, delayed growth, and softening of the skull bones.

Osteomalacia (Option B) is a condition that results from the deficiency of vitamin D or calcium, leading to the softening of bones, most commonly seen in adults. It commonly presents with bone pain, muscle weakness, and fractures.

Osteoarthritis (Option C) is a degenerative joint disease that primarily affects the articular cartilage. It commonly presents with joint pain, stiffness, and limited range of motion.

questions.text: Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Rape victim

  • Medical termination of pregnancy can be done upto 24 weeks in case of rape victims.

The MTP Act 1971 and The MTP Act Amendments 2021:

 

MTP Act 1971

The MTP Amendment Act 2021

Indications (Contraceptive failure)
  • Only applies to married women.
  • Unmarried women are also covered

Gestational Age Limit
  • 20 weeks for all indications
  • 24 weeks for rape survivors.
  • Beyond 24 weeks for substantial fetal abnormalities

Medical practitioner opinions required before termination
  • One RMP till 12 weeks
  • Two RMPs till 20 weeks
  • One RMP till 20 weeks
  • Two RMPS 20-24 weeks
  • Medical Board approval after 24 weeks

Breach of the woman's confidentiality
  • Fine up to Rs 1000
  • Fine and/or Imprisonment of 1 year.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female, who works as a maid complained of knee pain and swelling. Which of the following area gets damaged in Housemaid’s knee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B (Prepatellar bursa)

Explanation:

  • The correct answer is option b (Prepatellar bursa), as housemaid's knee involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa due to repeated kneeling or trauma to the front of the knee.
  • Housemaid's knee, also known as prepatellar bursitis, involves inflammation of the prepatellar bursa.
  • The prepatellar bursa is located just in front of the patella (kneecap) and can become inflamed due to repetitive kneeling or trauma to the area.
  • This condition is often seen in individuals who perform activities that involve prolonged kneeling, such as housemaids or carpet layers.

Bursa Around Knee:

  • Suprapatellar bursa: Deep to quadriceps femoris. Communicates with knee joint.
  • Prepatellar bursa: Lies over the superficial surface of patella.
  • Housemaid’s knee – Prepatellar bursitis.
  • Infrapatellar bursa: Lies over patellar ligament.
  • Clergyman’s knee – Infrapatellar bursitis.
  • Anserine bursa: Lies between tibial collateral ligament and tendons of sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus.

 

A (Option A): The suprapatellar bursa is located above the patella (kneecap) and helps reduce friction between the femur (thigh bone) and the quadriceps tendon. This bursa is not commonly associated with housemaid's knee.

C (Option C): The infrapatellar bursa is located below the patella, between the patellar ligament and the tibia (shin bone). It helps reduce friction during knee movements. Inflammation of this bursa is known as "clergyman's knee" or "Clergyman's bursitis," which is caused by excessive kneeling and friction.

D (Option D): The pes anserine bursa is located on the inner side of the knee, just below the joint. It is situated between the tendons of the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles and the underlying tibia. Inflammation of this bursa can lead to pes anserine bursitis, which typically presents as pain and tenderness on the inner side of the knee. This condition is not directly related to housemaid's knee.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with painful swelling in the index finger around the proximal phalanx. An X-ray was done, and it is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Enchondroma

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a radiolucent (dark) lesion with stippled (small, white, calcified) areas in the proximal phalanx of the finger.
  • Chondroma is a benign tumour of hyaline cartilage that occurs in bones of endochondral origin.
  • Tumours can arise within the medullary cavity, called enchondromas or on the bone surface, where they are called juxtacortical chondromas.
  • It is the most common type of benign bone tumor of the phalanges of the hand and is usually seen in 10 to 30 years of age.
  • Both Maffucci syndrome and Ollier’s disease are characterised by multiple enchondromas (not solitary).
  • Treatment: Curettage with wall cauterization.

 

 

Osteosarcoma (Option A) is a malignant bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults' metaphyseal region of long bones. On an X-ray, it usually appears as a mixed radiolucent-radiopaque lesion with a sunburst pattern.

 

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option A) The main causes are folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Peripheral blood shows hypersegmented neutrophils and macroovalocytes as early changes. Bone marrow is hypercellular, with numerous megaloblasts and giant metamyelocytes.

 

Ewing's Sarcoma (Option B) is a malignant bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults' diaphyseal region of long bones. On an X-ray, it usually appears as a permeative lesion with onion peel appearance.

 

Osteoclastoma (Option C), or giant cell tumor, is a benign bone tumor more commonly seen in young adults with epiphysis of long bones. An X-ray shows an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis and a typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: A doctor was summoned as a public witness to appear and record his evidence in court. What is correct about this witness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Expert witness

  • An expert witness is someone who possesses specialized knowledge, skills, or expertise in a particular field that is relevant to the case.
  • In the given scenario, a doctor is summoned as a witness.
  • If the doctor's testimony is related to their medical expertise and is meant to provide insight and explanation to the court on medical matters, then they would be considered an expert witness.

Oral evidence (Option A): Oral evidence refers to the testimony or statements provided by witnesses verbally in court.

Common witness (Option B): The scenario doesn't provide enough information to suggest that the doctor in question is a common witness.

Hostile witness (Option D): A hostile witness is a term used to describe a witness who is uncooperative or openly antagonistic towards the party that called them to testify.

questions.text: A 80-year-old woman slipped and fell in the bathroom, experiencing pain and an inability to walk due to a left hip injury, without any prior osteoarthritis history, and with an observation of a shortened and externally rotated left lower limb according to X-ray findings, how would you plan to manage her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Hemiarthroplasty

Explanation:

  • The X-ray image provided shows a left hip fracture. This patient is an elderly female who fell and is unable to walk, with shortened, externally rotated lower limb which is suggestive of displaced fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • A hemiarthroplasty is the most appropriate option for this patient. It involves replacing the femoral head and neck with a prosthetic implant. This procedure is generally preferred for older patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, which the X-ray image indicates.

 

 

Internal Fixation with Cancellous Screws (Option A) This option may be suitable for certain types of hip fractures, but it may not be appropriate for displaced femoral neck fractures, which are more common in the elderly.

Meyer's Operation (Option B) It involves cutting and repositioning the femur to correct the deformity. This option may not be suitable for elderly patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, as it is a more invasive procedure.

McMurray's Osteotomy (Option D) It involves cutting the femur to correct the deformity. This option may not be suitable for elderly patients with displaced femoral neck fractures, as it is a more invasive procedure.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female who had the extraction of her 3rd molar tooth reported loss of sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and floor of the mouth. Which nerve is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lingual Nerve:

Explanation:

  • The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3). It provides sensory innervation to the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and the floor of the mouth. Damage to the lingual nerve during the extraction of the 3rd molar tooth (also known as a wisdom tooth) can result in loss of sensation in these areas.

Sensory supply of tongue 

 

Anterior two-thirds of tongue-derived from 1st arch

Posterior one-third of tongue-from 3rd  arch

From the epiglottis-from 4th arch

General sensory

Lingual nerve

Glossopharyngeal nerve

Internal laryngeal branch of superior laryngeal nerve (vagus)

Special sensory

Except circumvallate papillae by chorda tympani (facial nerve)

Including circumvallate papillae by glossopharyngeal nerve

Internal laryngeal branch of superior laryngeal nerve (vagus)

 

Glossopharyngeal Nerve (Option B): The glossopharyngeal nerve (IX) conveys taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue, not the anterior 2/3rd or floor of the mouth.

Spinal Accessory Nerve (Option C): The spinal accessory nerve (XI) mainly controls head and shoulder movements. It's unrelated to tongue or mouth floor sensation.

Chorda Tympani Nerve (Option D): The chorda tympani nerve conveys taste sensations from the front two-thirds of the tongue and regulates salivary glands. Not connected to mouth floor sensation. Damage usually from middle ear surgery, not molar extraction.

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Cadaveric spasm

  • Cadaveric spasm (instantaneous rigor) is a rare postmortem phenomenon where the muscles stiffen immediately at the time of death without passing through the usual phase of primary muscular relaxation seen in typical rigor mortis.

Key Features:

  • Immediate onset: Occurs at the moment of death.
  • Muscle groups affected: Usually involves small muscle groups, especially the hands and fingers.
  • Violent deaths: Often associated with sudden, traumatic, or violent deaths.
  • Emotional stress: Common in situations involving intense nervous tension before death, like drowning, suicides, or combat situations.
  • Clenched fist: A classic sign, often seen when the deceased was holding an object firmly at death (e.g., weapon or grass in homicide).

Rigor mortis (Option A): Involves a gradual stiffening of muscles, typically starting 2-6 hours after death, with a period of primary relaxation beforehand.

Livor mortis (Option B): Postmortem lividity, where blood settles due to gravity, causing purple discoloration.

Algor mortis (Option D): Is the cooling of the body after death.

questions.text: Which bone is most likely to be fractured in an injury to the anatomical snuff box?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scaphoid

Explanation:

  • The anatomical snuff box is a triangular depression located on the radial aspect of the dorsum (back) of the hand.
  • It is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles.
  • Fractures within the anatomical snuff box are commonly associated with falls onto an outstretched hand, particularly with the wrist extended.
  • The most fractured bone in this region is the scaphoid bone, also known as the navicular bone.

Anatomical snuff box/Radial fossa: Triangular hollow visible on the lateral aspect of the wrist when the thumb is fully extended.

Boundaries:

  • Anterolateral: Extensor pollicis brevis, Abductor pollicis longus
  • Posteromedial: Extensor pollicis longus
  • Roof:
    • Dorsal cutaneous branch of radial nerve: Found in the skin and subcutaneous tissue of anatomical snuff box.
    • Cephalic vein: Arises from dorsal venous network of hand and crosses anatomical snuff box to travel to the anterolateral aspect of forearm.

Contents

  • Radial Artery: Crosses the floor of the anatomical snuff box.

Tenderness in the anatomical snuff box following a fall on an outstretched hand strongly suggests a scaphoid fracture, as the scaphoid bone lies in the floor of the anatomical snuff box. This type of fracture is common and can have complications due to poor blood supply.

 

Lunar (lunate) bone (Option B):  The lunate bone, found in the wrist joint, rarely fractures in injuries to the anatomical snuff box and isn't usually part of its formation.

Cuboid bone (Option C): The cuboid bone is one of the tarsal bones located in the foot. It is not related to the anatomical snuff box or the wrist region.

Trapezius (Option D): The trapezius is a large muscle located in the upper back and neck area. It is not a bone and is not related to the anatomical snuff box or wrist injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old factory worker was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting and blurring of vision after he consumed local spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Fomepizole

Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase.

  • Alcohol dehydrogenase catalyses the oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. Alcohol dehydrogenase also catalyses the initial steps in the metabolism of ethylene glycol and methanol to their toxic metabolites.

Features or symptoms of methanol poisoning:

  • Gastrointestinal Distress: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea are common symptoms associated with methanol poisoning.
  • Neurological Symptoms: Methanol toxicity affects the central nervous system and can lead to symptoms such as headache, dizziness, confusion, disorientation, agitation, and seizures.
  • Visual Impairment: Methanol poisoning can cause visual disturbances, including blurred vision, double vision, or complete loss of vision. This is due to the toxic effect of methanol on the optic nerve.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Methanol is metabolized in the body to formic acid and formaldehyde, which can lead to metabolic acidosis—a disturbance in the body's acid-base balance. Symptoms of metabolic acidosis include rapid breathing, increased heart rate, and fatigue.
  • Respiratory Distress: Severe cases of methanol poisoning may result in respiratory distress, difficulty breathing, and lung damage.

questions.text: The given finding is associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Trisomy 21

Explanation:

  • Trisomy 21, commonly known as Down syndrome, results from an extra copy of chromosome 21. People with Down syndrome often have distinct facial features, intellectual disabilities, and certain medical problems. Approximately half of individuals with Down syndrome have a single transverse palmar crease, making this the correct answer. The simian crease is relatively common in Down syndrome.

Down's syndrome, caused by trisomy 21, is associated with multiple systemic manifestations due to the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21.

  • This is due to meiotic nondisjunction in either maternal or paternal gamete.
  • Occurs at a frequency of 1:800 to 1:1000 newborns.

The overexpression of genes located on chromosome 21 contributes to the clinical features.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis:

General Features:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Flat facial profile, upward-slanting eyes with epicanthic folds, oblique palpebral fissure (visible when eyes are open).
  • Small nose with flat nasal bridge
  • Narrow palate, small teeth, and furrowed, protruding tongue
  • Significant hypotonia
  • Small, brachycephalic skull with flat occiput, and small, dysplastic ears
  • Short, broad hands with clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the middle phalanx of the fifth finger)
  • Simian crease on the palm
  • A wide gap between the first and second toes (sandal gap)

Comorbidities

  • Congenital Heart Disease: 40% of children have congenital heart defects, primarily endocardial cushion defects (40-60% of cases) - AVSD, VSD, ASD, PDA, TOF. Early cardiac evaluation is crucial.
  • Gastrointestinal Malformations: 12% have atresias, especially duodenal atresia. There is an increased risk of annular pancreas and Hirschsprung disease.
  • Ophthalmic Problems: Increased risk of cataracts, nystagmus, strabismus, and visual acuity issues. Regular eye evaluations are advised from infancy onward.
  • Hearing Defects: 40-60% experience conductive hearing loss, often due to serous otitis media in the first year. Routine hearing assessments are recommended before 6 months of age and annually.
  • Thyroid Dysfunction: Hypothyroidism occurs in 13-54% of patients.
  • Atlanto-occipital Subluxation: Incidence ranges from 10-30%. A lateral neck radiograph is recommended.
  • Physical Growth: Linear growth is typically slower, and children may become obese with age. Muscle tone often improves, but regular monitoring of height and weight is necessary.
  • Malignancies: Increased risk of lymphoproliferative disorders, such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, acute myeloid leukemia, myelodysplasia, and transient lymphoproliferative syndrome.
  • Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease: The APP gene, located on chromosome 21, plays a significant role in amyloid plaque formation, a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.

 

Trisomy 13 (Option A): Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, results from an extra chromosome 13, leading to severe developmental issues and congenital abnormalities. While hand anomalies are common, a simian crease isn't typically present.

Klinefelter's syndrome (Option C): Klinefelter's syndrome in males with an extra X chromosome (XXY) leads to male hypogonadism and physical differences, but it's not usually linked to a simian crease.

Trisomy 18 (Option D): Trisomy 18, or Edwards syndrome, stems from an extra chromosome 18, leading to severe developmental delays, intellectual disabilities, and congenital anomalies. While hand abnormalities may occur, a simian crease isn't a defining trait.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level shown by the arrow in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) L4-L5

Explanation:

  • If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.

 

L2-L3 (Option A): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

L5-S1 (Option C): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.

L3-L4 (Option D): This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presented with swelling due to a collection of blood around the eyes after sustaining a head injury. Which structural attachment is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aponeurosis attachment

Explanation:

  • When a person sustains a head injury, especially around the eyes, blood can collect in the surrounding tissues due to ruptured blood vessels. The blood can accumulate in the subcutaneous space, causing swelling. The structural attachment that can contribute to this condition is the aponeurosis attachment.

The scalp is made up of five layers:

  1. Skin-hairy and has numerous sweat glands and sebaceous glands
  2. Superficial fascia (Connective tissue)-provides a medium for vessels and nerves to pass to the skin
  3. Deep fascia in the form of the epicranial aponeurosis or galea aponeurotica with the occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar tissue-provides passage for emissary veins connecting extracranial veins to intracranial venous sinuses
  5. Pericranium

 

Periosteum (Option B): The periosteum is a tough connective tissue layer on bone surfaces. It aids in bone health but isn't directly linked to swelling around the eyes from head injuries.

Cellulitis (Option C): Cellulitis, a bacterial skin infection, doesn't typically lead to blood collection and swelling post-head injury.

None of the above (Option D): The correct answer is A. Aponeurosis attachment, as explained above. Therefore, the option "None of the above" is not the correct answer in this context

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom associated with chronic cocaine abuse?

choices.text: Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating.
Hallucination of insects crawling on the skin (formication).

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Dilated pupils, rapid pulse and sweating.

Seen in acute cocaine poisoning

  • Mechanism of action of cocaine: Inhibits the synaptic reuptake of Epinephrine, Norepinephrine, Dopamine, Serotonin.
  • All these substances will increase synaptic cleft.This will cause Sympathomimetic Toxidrome

Chronic Cocaine Abuse: Cocainism, Cocainomania or Cocainophagia

  • Tolerance for high doses
  • Rush (When excited) and crash (when depressed)

Triad of cocaine abuse:

  • Nasal / Palatal perforation
  • Black tongue and teeth
  • Gangrene of periphery (Nose tip, ear lobule)

Cocaine bugs is aka Magnan symptom or formication: This is tactile hallucination. It seems like insects, mice or rats are crawling on skin.

Treatment:

  • Antidote: Amyl nitrite to control heart rate and BP
  • Supportive and Symptomatic treatment
  • Fatal dose: Around 1g

questions.text: Which co-transporter is primarily responsible for facilitating glucose absorption across the basolateral membrane of an enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) GLUT2

Explanation:

  • Glucose Transporter Type 2 (GLUT2) is a protein that helps with glucose transport across cell membranes. In the small intestine, GLUT2 is found on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes (intestinal cells), where it facilitates the transport of glucose from these cells into the bloodstream.

 

Transporter

Tissue Location

Functions

GLUT 1

Brain, kidney, colon, placenta, erythrocytes

Facilitates glucose uptake

GLUT 2 (Option B)

Liver, pancreatic β cells, small intestine, kidney

Enables rapid glucose uptake or release

GLUT 3

Brain, kidney, placenta

Assists in glucose uptake

GLUT 4

Heart and skeletal muscle, adipose tissue

Mediates insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

GLUT 5

Small intestine

Facilitates fructose absorption

SGLT 1

Small intestine and kidney

Actively transports glucose against a concentration gradient

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a swelling below the ear and complains of pain in the lobule of the ear. The patient also reports difficulty in completely closing the left eye and experiences trouble while eating food. What nerve is most likely to be damaged in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Facial nerve

Explanation:

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) controls facial expressions, including eye closure and smiling. Damage to it can cause weakness or paralysis in these muscles. Additionally, it regulates muscles for eating and swallowing, which aligns with the patient's eating difficulties.

External Ear consists of two main parts:

  • Pinna (Auricle)
  • External Auditory Meatus

Aspects

Auricle (Pinna)

External Auditory Meatus

Composition

Elastic cartilage, except lobule (fibrofatty tissue)
  • Cartilaginous part (Outer 1/3) with hair and ceruminous glands
  • Bony part (Inner 2/3), with thin skin continuous with the tympanic membrane, lacks hair and glands.

Parts
  • Concha (Depression leading to the external meatus)
  • Helix (Prominent rim with anterior and posterior limbs)
  • Antihelix (Parallel ridge to the helix)
  • Tragus & Antitragus (Separated by inter-tragic notch)
  • Cymba Conchae (Above crus of helix)
  • Lobule (Soft, fleshy part below antitragus)

Nerve Supply

Lateral Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve (C2, C3)
  • Upper two-thirds: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Concha: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) (Alderman’s Nerve)

 

Medial Surface

  • Lower third: Great auricular nerve
  • Upper two-thirds: Lesser occipital nerve (C2)
  • Roof & Anterior Wall: Auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3)
  • Floor & Posterior Wall: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X)

 

Clinical Relevance

McEwen’s triangle (Cymba Conchae)

  • It is a surgical landmark on the temporal bone to locate the mastoid antrum.

Furuncles (cartilaginous part) susceptible to infections

 

 

 

Greater Auricular nerve (Option A): Damage to this nerve might result in altered sensation around the ear, but it wouldn't explain the symptoms mentioned in the case.

Auriculotemporal nerve (Option B): provides sensation to the external ear and part of the scalp. However, it doesn't control facial movement, eye closure, or eating functions.

Vagus nerve (Option D): While damage to the vagus nerve might cause some difficulties in swallowing and speech, it would not explain the specific symptoms of facial muscle weakness, inability to close the eye, or earlobe pain described in the case.

questions.text: The court summons a member of the public who witnessed the incident to provide testimony and document their account. What kind of evidence does the witness offer to the court?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Oral evidence

  • “All statements which the court permits or requires to be made before it by a witness, in relation to matters of fact under inquiry, such statements are called as oral evidence".
  • Hence anything which is spoken or expressed by the mouth of a witness who is called for trial in the Court is referred to as oral evidence.
  • Oral evidence is a type of direct evidence.
  • Oral evidence must, in all cases be direct.
  • If it refers to a fact which could be seen, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he saw it
  • If it refers to a fact which could be heard, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he heard it.
  • If it refers to a fact that could be perceived in any other sense or in any other manner, it must be the evidence of a witness who says he perceived it in that sense or in that manner.

Hearsay evidence (Option B): Hearsay evidence refers to a testimony that is provided by a witness and is not based on any personal communication.

Subpoena (Option C): Subpoena is a formal written order that requires a person to appear before a court, or other legal proceedings and testify, or produce documentation.

Circumstantial evidence (Option D): Circumstantial evidence is evidence of facts that the court can draw conclusions from.

questions.text: A 45-year-old person presents to the outpatient department with a 6-month history of increased urine output and increased water intake. On investigation, the following results are obtained: HbA1C - 5.5%, Blood glucose - 80 mg/dL, Postprandial glucose - 130 mg/dL, and decreased urine osmolarity. What would be the most probable diagnosis for this given condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Diabetes Insipidius

Explanation:

In diabetes insipidus, the kidney’s inability to concentrate urine leads to large volumes of dilute urine (Polyuria).

Polydipsia means excessive thirst because the body tries to compensate for high fluid loss by increasing thirst to encourage more fluid intake.

  • Diabetes insipidus is a condition in which there is the absence of or poor response to anti-diuretic hormone (ADH).
  • This results in reduced distal tubule and collecting duct permeability to water.
  • This causes the kidneys to excrete large amounts of dilute urine that clinically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Low urine osmolality (<600 mosm/L) in association with high plasma osmolality {>300 mosm/L}
  • Water deprivation test → differentiates psychogenic polydipsia from DI
  • The vasopressin response test → to differentiate central DI and nephrogenic DI
    • An increase in urine osmolality by >50% of the baseline indicates Central DI

 

DM (Diabetes Mellitus) (Option A): This option is unlikely because the HbA1C level of 5.5% and the blood glucose levels are within the normal range (HbA1C < 6.5% and blood glucose < 126 mg/dL for diagnosis of diabetes).

Conn's Disease (Option C): Primary Hyperaldosteronism - This condition is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands, leading to high blood pressure and low blood potassium levels.

Addison's Disease (Option D): Adrenal Insufficiency - This condition involves the adrenal glands not producing enough cortisol and, in some cases, aldosterone. Symptoms often include fatigue, weight loss, and low blood pressure.

questions.text: All of the following changes occur in chronic starvation except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hyperthermia

Chronic Starvation causes the development of the following changes:

  • Loss of well-being, hunger, and hunger pains.
  • Mental and physical lethargy and easy fatigue.
  • Progressive loss of weight which is rapid in the first six months.
  • Polyuria
  • Increasing wasting, the body weight is reduced by about 40% of the normal.
  • Pigmentation and anaemia
  • Hypothermia and not Hyperthermia; peripheral vascular stasis in cold and hypotension
  • Extreme lethargy, gross mental retardation and loss of self-respect
  • Oedema, first in the feet and lower limbs
  • Reduced resistance to infection causing diarrhoea, dysentery, tuberculosis, etc.

questions.text: In the adjacent graph, plateau phase represents which one of the following properties?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Plasticity

Explanation:

  • The given graph is cystometrogram (CMG).
  • Cystometry is the procedure to study the relationship between the bladder volume and pressure.
  • A CMG is a test that measures the pressure inside the bladder as it fills with fluid.
  • It helps assess the bladder's function and its ability to store and release urine.
  • Plateau Phase:
    • The plateau phase of the cystometrogram, where the pressure remains relatively constant despite increasing volume, can be explained by the bladder's ability to stretch and accommodate increasing volumes of urine.
    • This is a result of the unique properties of the bladder's smooth muscle.
    • Law of Laplace:
      • According to the Law of Laplace, for a spherical viscus (like the bladder), the pressure (P) inside the bladder is related to the wall tension (T) and the radius (r) of the bladder.
      • The relationship is given by P=2T/r. As the bladder fills, the radius increases, which helps keep the pressure relatively low despite the increased volume.
  • Plasticity: Plasticity refers to the ability of the bladder's smooth muscle to undergo prolonged changes in length (stretch) without a significant increase in pressure. This allows the bladder to store larger volumes of urine without a significant rise in pressure.

 

Elasticity (Option A): Elasticity is the property of a material to return to its original shape after being stretched or deformed. This option is incorrect.

Contractility (Option C): Contractility is the fundamental property of muscle tissue that enables it to contract when stimulated. This option is incorrect.

Automaticity (Option D): Automaticity refers to the ability of certain cells (such as cardiac pacemaker cells) to spontaneously generate electrical impulses without external stimulation. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: In which poisoning is cherry red hypostasis seen on post-mortem examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - CO Poisoning

Carbon monoxide poisoning causes cherry red discoloration of the skin, mucus membranes, conjunctiva, nail beds, areas of hypostasis, blood tissues and internal organs.

  • This coloration changes to dark green and then to brown as decomposition starts to occur.

Post-mortem changes associated with Carbon monoxide poisoning are:

  • Cherry-pink lividity: One of the classic signs of carbon monoxide poisoning is the development of cherry-pink lividity on the skin. This occurs due to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, a stable complex formed when carbon monoxide binds to hemoglobin, resulting in a bright pink or cherry-red coloration of the skin.
  • Discoloration of internal organs: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause discoloration of internal organs. The organs may appear bright red due to the presence of carboxyhemoglobin.
  • Pulmonary congestion and edema: Carbon monoxide can lead to congestion and fluid accumulation in the lungs, resulting in pulmonary congestion and edema. This can be observed during postmortem examination as fluid-filled lungs with frothy fluid.
  • Macroscopic changes in the brain: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause macroscopic changes in the brain. The brain may appear swollen and congested, and the white matter can show pink discoloration.

Hydrogen Sulphide (Option B): poisoning causes a rotten egg smell in the victim. The general signs of asphyxia are present along with signs of changing of the blood and viscera colour to greenish-purple and not cherry-red.

Yellow Phosphorus (Option C):is a potent hepatotoxin. Post-mortem findings include garlicky odour along with icterus of the body due to liver failure as a part of multiple organ failure which causes the death of the victim.

Hydrogen cyanide (Option D): is an extremely lethal poison. Post-mortem findings of hydrogen cyanide poisoning include glistening and prominent dilated pupils, frothy mouth, brick-red blood and cheeks due to impaired oxygenation of the tissues. The internal organs may be oedematous due to congestion.

questions.text: According to the law, nothing is an offense if a person is of an unsound mind and is not able to understand that the nature and consequences of his/her act are wrong. Which rule of insanity applies in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Mc Naughton's rule

  • McNaughton's rules state that "Nothing is an offense done by a person who is incapable of knowing that he is doing is wrong due to mental illness".
  • The rules of insanity in forensic medicine are primarily governed by the McNaughten Rules (1843), which establish the legal criteria for determining criminal responsibility in cases involving mental illness.

McNaughten Rules (Key Principles):

  • Presumption of Sanity: Every individual is presumed sane unless proven otherwise.
  • Defect of Reason: The accused must suffer from a severe mental disease causing a defect of reason.
  • Inability to Understand the Nature of the Act: The individual must be unable to understand the nature and quality of the act they were committing.
  • Inability to Distinguish Right from Wrong: The person must be incapable of understanding that the act was wrong due to their mental condition.

Durham's Rule (Option A): states that a criminal cannot be convicted of a crime if the act was a result of a mental disease or defect the criminal had at the time of the incident.

Curren's Rule (Option C): An accused person will not be criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

Irresistible impulse rule (Option D): According to the Irresistible Impulse rule in jurisdictions defendants typically must present sufficient evidence to prove the existence of mental illness and that the mental illness caused the inability to control one's actions or conform one's conduct to the law.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Bruner gland

Explanation:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn. (Option C ruled out)
    • Presence of submucous Brunner's gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland (mucus secreting glands - to protect from stomach acids).

 

Interstitial cells of kajal (Option B): They are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features that send long, multiply branched processes into the intestinal smooth muscle, generating the basal electrical rhythm (BER). This option is incorrect.

Peyer’s patches (Option D): They are lymphoid tissues especially in terminal 25 cm of the ileum. This option is incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the type of homicide:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Burking

Burking is a type of homicide caused by smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

  • In this method, the attacker kneels or sits on the chest of the victim and closes the victim's mouth and nose with his or her hands.
  • Traumatic asphyxia occurs due to respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest.
  • This prevents normal respiratory movements from happening.

There are a few types of homicide that involve similar methods or characteristics to burking.

  • Suffocation: Suffocation involves depriving a person of oxygen by covering their airways, often by using a hand, pillow, plastic bag, or other objects.
  • Smothering: Smothering is a type of suffocation where the perpetrator covers the victim's nose and mouth, blocking their ability to breathe.
  • Strangulation: Although not exactly the same as burking, strangulation involves applying pressure to the neck, either manually or using a ligature
  • Choking: Choking occurs when an object or material obstructs the airway, preventing the person from breathing properly.

Mugging (Option A): is a method of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow. The attacker usually attacks from behind.

Garrotting (Option C): is a method of strangulation caused by a ligature being thrown around the neck and quickly tightening it.

Bansdola (Option D): is a method of strangulation that uses two bamboo sticks.

questions.text: Which of the following functions is NOT attributed to the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Bile salts secretion

Explanation:

  • Bile salts are produced in the liver and stored in the gallbladder. They are released into the small intestine when needed to aid in the digestion and absorption of fats.
  • Bile salts emulsify large fat molecules, breaking them down into smaller droplets, which increases the efficiency of fat digestion by enzymes.

 

Functions of intestinal epithelium:

Paneth cells

  • Specialised immune cells found in the intestinal crypts of Lieberkuhn, primarily in the small intestine.
  • They are known for secreting antimicrobial peptides, such as defensins and lysozymes, which help protect the gut against infections.

 

Goblet cells (Option C ruled out)

  • Goblet cells are specialised epithelial cells throughout the intestines that secrete mucus.
  • This mucus forms a protective layer over the epithelial surface, safeguarding the intestinal lining from mechanical and chemical damage.

 

Enteroendocrine cells

  • Enteroendocrine cells are scattered throughout the gastrointestinal tract and produce hormones like serotonin, gastrin, and cholecystokinin.
  • These hormones are involved in digestion, appetite regulation, and gut motility.

 

Enterocytes (Option A ruled out)

  • Enterocytes are the absorptive cells lining the intestinal villi that absorb nutrients such as carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, and minerals.

 

Exocrine cells

  • These cells in the mucosa of the small intestine secrete mucus, peptidase, sucrase, maltase, lactase, lipase, and enterokinase.

questions.text: Who is responsible for handling the investigation in the case of a custodial death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Judicial magistrate

  • Section 176 (l) of the Code of Criminal Procedure (CrPC) states that if a person in custody dies or disappears or a woman is raped in custody, the Judicial Magistrate (Executive Magistrate) has the power to order an inquiry.

Conditions for Magistrate inquest:

  • A - Death in Asylum
  • B - Death in hostels
  • C - Custodial death/rape
  • D - Dowry death
  • E - Exhumation

Police Inquest

Magistrate Inquest

174 CrPC

176 CrPC

Most common inquest in India

Best Inquest

 

Type of magistrate Inquest:

Judicial

Executive
  • In the court of law (for conducting trial)
  • Appointed by high court
  • In maintaining law & Order in the society
  • Appointed by state Govt.
  • Designated as District Magistrate (DM)

 

Following govt officials can be appointed as executive magistrate:

  • District Collector
  • Tehsildar
  • RDO
  • Deputy collector

questions.text: Kartagener syndrome is associated with defects in which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Cilia

Explanation:

  • Kartagener Syndrome, also known as Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD), is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects the cilia. It is characterized by chronic productive cough and recurrent infections of upper and lower respiratory tract.

 

Aspects

Details

Triad
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Situs inversus

Pathophysiology
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance → recurrent infections.
  • Embryonic nodal cilia dysfunction → situs inversus.

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent sinus and respiratory tract infections
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Nasal polyps
  • Otitis media with hearing loss
  • Male infertility (immotile sperm)
  • Female subfertility (impaired fallopian tube cilia)
  • Neonatal respiratory distress

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient underwent an endoscopic examination of the gastrointestinal tract due to recurrent abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. Identify the arrow-marked structure in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brunner's Gland

Explanation:

  • The given histology slide is of duodenum.
  • Identification points:
    • Wall made up of four layers.
    • Mucosa – presence of numerous broad villi lined by simple columnar epithelium with microvilli and goblet cells.
    • Presence of crypts of lieberkuhn
    • Presence of submucous Brunner’s gland.
  • The marked structure by the arrow is of Brunner's gland.

Histology:

Feature

Duodenum

Jejunum

Ileum

Villi

Present

Present

Present

Brunner's Glands

Present

Absent

Absent

Peyer's Patches

Absent

Absent

Present

 

Intestinal Cells of Kajal (Option B): Incorrect term (likely a misinterpretation of interstitial cells of Cajal, which regulate gut motility).

Crypts of Lieberkühn (Option C): Present in the duodenum but are located in the mucosa, whereas Brunner’s glands are in the submucosa.

Peyer’s Patch (Option D): Found in the ileum, not the duodenum.

questions.text: The first heart sound coincides with which phase of cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: option C) Isovolumetric contraction

Explanation:

  • The first heart sound, also known as S1, is a low-pitched sound that occurs due to the closure of the atrioventricular valve during the beginning of isovolumetric contraction.

Phases of cardiac cycle-

Phase

Sub-Phase

Key Events

Systole

Isovolumetric Contraction (Option C)
  • Ventricles begin to contract
  • Ranges from closure of AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) till opening of semilunar valves.
  • First heart sound appears.
  • No blood volume change in ventricles

 

Ventricular Ejection
  • Has 2 phases- Rapid ejection phase and Reduced ejection phase.
  • Ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary pressure
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves open
  • Blood ejected into aorta and pulmonary artery (Option B ruled out)
  • Ventricular volume decreases
  • Ends with the closure of the aortic valve.

Diastole

Isovolumetric Relaxation (Option D ruled out)
  • Ventricles relax
  • Ventricular pressure drops
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves close
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
  • Second heart sounds appears.
  • Ends with the opening of AV valves.

 

Rapid Filling
  • AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) open
  • Blood flows rapidly from atria to ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases rapidly
  • Third heart sound appears.

 

Diastasis
  • Blood flow from atria to ventricles slows
  • No change in the atrial and ventricular pressure.
  • Ventricular volume increases slowly

 

Atrial Systole
  • Atria contract
  • Additional blood pushed into ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases slightly
  • End-diastolic volume (EDV) reached
  • Fourth heart sound is produced.

 

Rapid atrial filling (Option A): It occurs during diastole, after the semilunar valves close (end of systole). This phase is unrelated to the first heart sound (S1) production, as the AV valves are open during this time.

questions.text: Which change is least likely to occur among a group of colleagues taking an excursion to a high-altitude mountain region?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Increase PaO2

Explanation:

  • PaO2 is the least likely to happen during an excursion to a high-altitude mountain region. At higher altitudes, the partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) decreases due to the lower atmospheric pressure. This can lead to a hypoxia, where there's a reduced availability of oxygen for the body's cells and tissues.

 

Changes during Acclimatization in high altitudes

Respiratory
  • At high altitudes, lower oxygen levels stimulate peripheral chemoreceptors, increasing pulmonary ventilation. (Option D ruled out)
  • This leads to enhanced CO2 removal, causing respiratory alkalosis.
  • Kidneys respond by excreting more bicarbonate to stabilize blood pH, causing a sustained increase in ventilation and supporting prolonged acclimatization.

Haematological
  • At high altitudes, lower PO2 boosts erythropoietin production, increasing red blood cell count. (Option B ruled out)
  • This also raises 2,3-diphosphoglycerate (2,3-DPG) levels in red blood cells.
  • Initially, alkalosis shifts the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to the left but increased 2,3-DPG shifts it to the right, improving oxygen release to tissues.

Cardiovascular
  • Hypoxia activates the sympathoadrenal axis, increasing heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure.
  • Increased cardiac output leads to an increase in blood flow, and hypoxia causes vasodilation in the systemic circulation, further contributing to increased blood flow and oxygen supply to the tissues.

Tissue
  • In acclimatization, skeletal muscles undergo several changes, including an increase in the number of capillaries and mitochondria and an increase in myoglobin content. (Option C ruled out)
  • Further, chemicals released from the hypoxic tissues stimulate angiogenesis.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in pediatric patients with Diabetic Ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option D) Cerebral edema

Explanation:

In pediatric patients with Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), the most common cause of death is cerebral edema, a rare but life-threatening complication.

Other Complications:

  • Cognitive impairment
  • Venous thrombosis
  • Pancreatic enzyme elevations
  • Acute kidney injury
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Rhabdomyolysis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Multiple organ dysfunction syndrome
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  • Sepsis

questions.text: The presence of a prominent 'v' wave of jugular venous pulse is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Tricuspid regurgitation

Explanation:

  • In a jugular venous examination, the presence of a prominent 'V' wave in the jugular venous pulse can be indicative of tricuspid regurgitation. Tricuspid regurgitation is a valvular heart condition where the tricuspid valve does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward from the right ventricle to the right atrium during systole. This regurgitant flow leads to an increased 'V' wave in the jugular venous pulse.

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

 

Wave

Details

Abnormalities

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

Prominent a Wave: Tricuspid stenosis (Option C ruled out), right ventricular hypertrophy, pulmonary hypertension.

Absent a Wave: Atrial fibrillation (Option D ruled out)

Cannon a Wave: Atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve

 

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

-

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

Steep x Descent: Constrictive pericarditis, cardiac tamponade.

 

v wave
