  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

Prominent v Wave: Tricuspid regurgitation (Option A)

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

Steep y Descent: Rapid ventricular filling due to high atrial pressure.

 

Absent y Descent: Obstruction to ventricular filling (severe hypertrophic cardiomyopathy) (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal constituent of serum osmolality?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Sodium

Explanation:

  • The combined presence of sodium and chloride accounts for approximately 90% of plasma osmolality. Out of a total of 295 mOsm/kg H2O, sodium chloride contributes around 270 mOsm, while the remaining 20 mOsm is attributed to urea, glucose, protein, and other ions such as potassium and calcium.
  • Whenever Na+ moves from one compartment to the other, Cl- also moves to maintain electroneutrality, mainly contributing to osmolality.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding creatinine clearance?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option C) Greater than inulin clearance

Explanation:

  • Creatinine clearance is greater than inulin clearance because of the tubular secretion of creatinine in addition to filtration. This makes creatinine clearance a practical but slightly imprecise measure of GFR.
  • Creatinine is partially secreted and never reabsorbed by the renal tubules, which can result in an overestimation of GFR.
  • Inulin is a freely filterable substance, neither endogenously secreted by the body nor reabsorbed by the nephron.

 

Types of Clearance Measurements:

Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: The involvement of which of the following results in the given condition below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lymphatics

  • The image shows massive swelling of the lower limb with skin thickening and folds, characteristic of elephantiasis.

  • Elephantiasis results from lymphatic obstruction, leading to chronic lymphedema and fibrosis.

  • The most common cause is lymphatic filariasis due to Wuchereria bancrofti infection.

  • Non-infectious causes include congenital lymphedema, malignancy, and post-surgical lymphatic damage.

Lymphedema and Elephantiasis

Feature

Lymphedema (Elephantiasis)

Cause

Lymphatic obstruction (Filariasis, malignancy, surgery, congenital defects)

Appearance

Massive swelling, skin thickening, warty texture

Stages

1. Pitting edema (early) 2. Non-pitting edema (late) 3. Fibrosis & skin changes (severe)

Complications

Skin infections, ulceration, restricted mobility

Diagnosis

Clinical examination, ultrasound, lymphoscintigraphy

Treatment

Limb elevation, compression therapy, antibiotics for infections, diethylcarbamazine (for filariasis)

Arteries (Option A): Incorrect because arterial disease causes ischemia, pain, and ulceration, not massive swelling.

Vein (Option B): Incorrect because venous insufficiency leads to varicose veins and stasis ulcers, not elephantiasis.

DVT (Option D): Incorrect because deep vein thrombosis (DVT) presents with acute unilateral swelling, pain, and erythema, not chronic massive lymphedema.

questions.text: Hand washing during COVID-19 is what level of prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Primary prevention

Explanation:

  • Handwashing during COVID-19 is a form of primary prevention because it aims to prevent the onset of illness by reducing the risk of infection.
  • Primary prevention involves actions taken to prevent the occurrence of disease or injury before it happens, and hand hygiene is an effective strategy to reduce transmission of the virus.

 

Primordial prevention (Option A): is incorrect because primordial prevention focuses on preventing the emergence of risk factors for disease, such as promoting healthy behaviors in early childhood or ensuring access to a healthy environment. Handwashing is a more immediate preventive measure rather than an early-stage intervention.

Secondary prevention (Option C): is incorrect because secondary prevention focuses on early detection and screening for disease, as well as early intervention to reduce the severity or complications of an already established disease. Handwashing prevents disease transmission, not early disease detection.

Tertiary prevention (Option D): is incorrect because tertiary prevention deals with the management and rehabilitation of individuals with already established diseases to prevent further complications and improve quality of life. Handwashing is not related to disease management but to prevention.

questions.text: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Primary prevention

Explanation:

  • The government's plan to outline tobacco control laws is considered primary prevention because the laws are intended to prevent the initiation of tobacco use and thereby reduce the risk of diseases associated with tobacco use, such as cancer, heart disease, and respiratory conditions.
  • Primary prevention focuses on reducing risk factors before any disease or injury occurs. Tobacco control laws aim to prevent the onset of smoking-related health problems by discouraging the use of tobacco.

 

Primordial prevention (Option A): is incorrect because primordial prevention focuses on preventing the development of risk factors in the first place, like promoting a healthy environment or addressing social determinants. While tobacco control laws aim to prevent smoking, they are more specifically aimed at reducing existing risk factors (tobacco use), making primary prevention a more accurate term.

Secondary prevention (Option C): is incorrect because secondary prevention focuses on early detection and intervention after the risk factors have been established. Tobacco control laws, however, aim to prevent the risk factor (tobacco use) from even emerging.

Tertiary prevention (Option D): is incorrect because tertiary prevention deals with management and rehabilitation of individuals who already have diseases or conditions, which is not the focus of tobacco control laws. These laws are intended to prevent the occurrence of tobacco-related diseases in the first place.

questions.text: A baby presents to the OPD; the image below shows the findings. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer D - Capillary Hemangioma:

  • The images show a bright red, raised, well-demarcated lesion commonly seen in infants.

  • Capillary hemangiomas (strawberry hemangiomas) are benign vascular tumors that typically appear after birth, grow rapidly, and regress spontaneously.

  • They are superficial hemangiomas composed of proliferating endothelial cells.

  • Commonly occur on the face, scalp, trunk, or extremities.

  • Most resolve by 5–7 years of age without treatment.

Infantile Hemangioma (Capillary Hemangioma)

Feature

Capillary Hemangioma

Cause

Proliferation of immature endothelial cells

Appearance

Bright red, raised lesion with a well-demarcated border

Onset

Appears within first few weeks after birth

Growth Pattern

Rapid growth for months, then gradual involution

Resolution

90% regress by 5–7 years of age

Treatment

Observation, propranolol (if complications occur)

Portwine stain (Option A): Incorrect because port-wine stains (nevus flammeus) are flat, non-proliferative vascular malformations that do not regress.

Cavernous hemangioma (Option B): Incorrect because cavernous hemangiomas are deeper, bluish, and less well-defined.

Naevus simplex (Option C): Incorrect because naevus simplex ("salmon patch") is a flat, pink-red blanching lesion commonly seen on the forehead and nape of the neck.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a known case of ovarian cancer presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dermatomyositis

  • The patient presents with proximal muscle weakness (difficulty in climbing stairs, standing from a chair, and combing hair).

  • The image shows a heliotrope rash or shawl sign, which are characteristic skin findings in dermatomyositis.

  • Dermatomyositis is often paraneoplastic, commonly associated with ovarian cancer.

Dermatomyositis

Feature

Dermatomyositis

Cause

Autoimmune inflammatory myopathy, often paraneoplastic

Muscle Weakness

Symmetrical, proximal muscle weakness

Characteristic Rashes

Heliotrope rash (around eyes)

 

Gottron’s papules

 

Shawl sign

 

V-sign

 

Mechanic’s hand

 

Holster sign

 

Paraneoplastic Association

Ovarian, lung, breast, and gastric cancers

Diagnosis

Elevated CPK, anti-Mi-2, anti-Jo-1, muscle biopsy

Treatment

Corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, cancer screening

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option A): Incorrect because SLE presents with malar rash, arthritis, and systemic involvement, but not prominent muscle weakness.

Systemic sclerosis (Option C): Incorrect because systemic sclerosis causes skin tightening, Raynaud's phenomenon, and esophageal dysmotility, not proximal muscle weakness.

Cushing syndrome (Option D): Incorrect because Cushing’s causes proximal weakness due to steroid myopathy, but lacks the classic skin rash seen in dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces of both arms. Punctate pitting was noted on examining the nails. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Psoriasis

  • The patient presents with erythematous plaques with silvery scales over the extensor surfaces, which is classic for psoriasis.

  • Nail pitting is a characteristic feature of psoriatic nail involvement.

Psoriasis

Feature

Psoriasis

Common Sites

Extensor surfaces (elbows, knees), scalp, lower back

Lesion Type

Well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales

Koebner Phenomenon

Lesions appear at sites of trauma

Nail Changes

Pitting, onycholysis, oil-drop sign

Treatment

Topical steroids, vitamin D analogs, systemic biologics in severe cases

Signs in Psoriasis

Sign

Description

Candle-Grease Sign

Silvery-white, shiny scales appear on scraping.

Last Häutchen Sign

Thin transparent membrane seen after scale removal.

Auspitz Sign

Pinpoint bleeding after removing the last membrane.

Koebner Phenomenon

Psoriatic lesions appear at sites of trauma.

Woronoff Ring

Pale ring around healing psoriatic plaques.

Lichen planus (Option B): Incorrect because lichen planus presents with purple, pruritic, polygonal papules and Wickham striae, not silvery scales.

Eczema (Option C): Incorrect because eczema involves flexural surfaces and is associated with intense pruritus and weeping lesions.

Pityriasis rosea (Option D): Incorrect because it presents with a herald patch followed by a Christmas-tree distribution of lesions, not thick silvery scales.

questions.text: A patient presented with itchy lesions, as shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Lichen Planus

  • The image shows multiple violaceous, polygonal, pruritic papules predominantly on the lower extremities, which is characteristic of lichen planus.

  • The presence of Wickham striae (fine white reticulations) supports the diagnosis.

Lichen Planus

Feature

Lichen Planus

Etiology

Autoimmune, drug-induced (ACE inhibitors, NSAIDs), Hepatitis C association

Clinical Features

Purple, pruritic, polygonal, planar papules

Common Sites

Wrists, ankles, oral mucosa, nails

Koebner Phenomenon

Lesions at sites of trauma

Wickham Striae

Fine white lacy network over papules

Nail Changes

Longitudinal ridging, nail thinning

Treatment

Topical steroids, antihistamines, systemic therapy in severe cases

Scabies (Option A): Incorrect because scabies presents with burrows, interdigital involvement, and nocturnal itching.

Psoriasis (Option C): Incorrect because psoriasis has silvery scales on erythematous plaques, usually on extensor surfaces.

Warts (Option D): Incorrect because warts are hyperkeratotic papules caused by HPV, without pruritus or Wickham striae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old truck driver with a history of multiple sex partners presented to the dermatological department, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer A - Secondary Syphilis

  • The image shows bilateral, non-pruritic, reddish-brown maculopapular lesions on the palms, characteristic of secondary syphilis.
  • The patient's history of multiple sex partners increases the likelihood of Treponema pallidum infection.
  • Associated systemic signs include lymphadenopathy, fever, and mucous membrane involvement.

Secondary Syphilis

Feature

Secondary Syphilis

Etiology

Treponema pallidum (spirochete)

Transmission

Sexual contact, vertical transmission

Clinical Features

Maculopapular rash on palms/soles, condylomata lata, lymphadenopathy

Systemic Symptoms

Fever, malaise, sore throat

Diagnosis

Serology (VDRL, RPR, FTA-ABS, TPPA)

Treatment

Benzathine penicillin G (single dose IM)

 

 

Lichen Planus (Option B): Incorrect because lichen planus has violaceous, polygonal papules with Wickham striae, not palmoplantar rash.

Scabies (Option C): Incorrect because scabies presents with burrows in interdigital spaces with severe nocturnal pruritus.

Psoriasis (Option D): Incorrect because palmoplantar psoriasis has silvery scales and well-defined plaques rather than a diffuse maculopapular rash.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhoea and alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Zinc

  • Zinc deficiency leads to poor wound healing, dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to its role in cell division, immune function, and tissue repair.

  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica (a genetic disorder of zinc absorption) presents with periorificial and acral dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia.

  • Zinc is crucial for collagen synthesis, immune function, and enzyme activity, making its deficiency detrimental to healing.

Zinc Deficiency

Feature

Zinc Deficiency

Causes

Poor diet, malabsorption (Crohn’s, celiac), chronic diarrhea, alcoholism

Clinical Features

Poor wound healing, dermatitis, alopecia, diarrhea, immune dysfunction

Dermatological Signs

Eczematous plaques, periorificial dermatitis, nail dystrophy

Diagnosis

Low serum zinc, clinical presentation

Treatment

Zinc supplementation (oral zinc sulfate)

Iron (Option A): Incorrect because iron deficiency causes anemia, fatigue, koilonychia, and glossitis, not dermatitis and diarrhea.

Calcium (Option B): Incorrect because calcium deficiency leads to tetany, muscle spasms, and osteomalacia, not alopecia or poor wound healing.

Magnesium (Option C): Incorrect because magnesium deficiency causes neuromuscular excitability, tremors, and cardiac arrhythmias, not dermatitis or alopecia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with the following skin lesions characterized by red and scaly patches. The patient also complains of a painful and swollen finger joint. On examination, the finger joint appears inflamed and tender to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Psoriatic Arthritis

  • The image shows dactylitis (sausage digit), which is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

  • The patient has red and scaly skin lesions, suggesting psoriasis.

  • Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, affecting small and large joints, with dactylitis, enthesitis, and nail changes.

  • Dactylitis is a hallmark feature of PsA, caused by inflammation of both tendons and joints.

Psoriatic Arthritis

Feature

Psoriatic Arthritis

Etiology

Autoimmune, associated with HLA-B27

Joint Involvement

Asymmetrical, affects DIP, PIP, and spine

Key Features

Dactylitis (sausage digit), enthesitis, nail pitting, onycholysis

Skin Lesions

Psoriasis (scaly plaques on extensor surfaces)

Diagnosis

CASPAR criteria, RF negative, elevated ESR/CRP

Treatment

NSAIDs, DMARDs (Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine), Biologics (TNF-α inhibitors)

Pseudo gout (Option B): Incorrect because pseudo gout presents with acute monoarthritis (e.g., knee) due to calcium pyrophosphate deposition, but does not cause dactylitis or skin lesions.

Osteoarthritis (Option C): Incorrect because OA affects weight-bearing joints, spares DIP, and lacks systemic inflammation like psoriasis.

Reactive Arthritis (Option D): Incorrect because reactive arthritis follows an infection (e.g., GI or GU) and presents with conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis (Reiter’s syndrome), but lacks dactylitis and psoriasis.

questions.text: Infant mortality rate is typically stated as a rate per how many live births.?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1000

Explanation:

  • Infant mortality rate (IMR) is typically expressed as the number of deaths of infants (under 1 year) per 1,000 live births in a given year. It is a key indicator of the overall health and well-being of a population, reflecting factors such as access to healthcare, nutrition, and living conditions.

 

100 (Option A): is incorrect because infant mortality rate is not expressed per 100 live births, but per 1,000 live births.

10,000 (Option C): is incorrect because the IMR is not expressed per 10,000 live births. The standard convention is per 1,000 live births.

1,00,000 (Option D): is incorrect because the infant mortality rate is generally not expressed per 1,00,000 live births. It is commonly presented per 1,000 live births to maintain consistency and comparability.

questions.text: According to WHO, what proportions of GNP should be spent on health services?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 5%

Explanation:

  • The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that 5% of a country's Gross National Product (GNP) should be spent on health services.
  • This target is suggested to ensure that countries can provide adequate healthcare services, improve public health infrastructure, and address healthcare needs of the population.

 

2% (Option A): is incorrect because the WHO's recommendation is higher than 2%. The figure of 2% is often lower than the minimum threshold suggested by the WHO.

2.5% (Option B): is incorrect because the WHO recommends 5% and not 2.5% for a more optimal investment in the health sector.

3.5% (Option C): is incorrect because, although it’s a reasonable figure for some countries, the WHO’s recommendation is 5%, which is slightly higher.

questions.text: School health program is under:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) PHC

Explanation:

  • The School Health Program in India is typically managed and implemented under Primary Health Centres (PHCs).
  • These centers provide basic healthcare services to communities, including children in schools, through regular health check-ups, immunizations, and health education.
  • The PHCs serve as the main hub for delivering health services to the school-aged population.

 

CHC (Option B): is incorrect because Community Health Centres (CHCs) focus on more specialized and advanced healthcare services than PHCs. They are not the primary location for managing the School Health Program.

DH (Option C): is incorrect because District Hospitals (DH) focus on providing specialized healthcare and emergency services rather than delivering primary health services in schools.

Health and Wellness Centres (Option D): While Health and Wellness Centres are part of the National Health Mission and offer comprehensive healthcare services, the School Health Program is more closely associated with PHCs for primary healthcare services in the school setting.

questions.text: Which of the following should not be included in the school health service?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Doctor on premises

Explanation:

  • While it is important for schools to have access to healthcare services, having a doctor on premises is not a mandatory requirement for School Health Services.
  • In many schools, a school health program is run by a nurse or a trained health worker, with doctors available for consultations when needed.
  • The focus of school health services is on preventive care, routine health screenings, and maintaining health records. Having a doctor on-site is not a necessary component, as healthcare professionals can also be consulted through local health centers or clinics.

 

Education of handicapped children (Option A): is incorrect because education of handicapped children is typically part of the school's inclusive education program, which is not directly linked to the medical services provided by the school health service, but is a separate educational initiative.

Dental and eye health services (Option C): is incorrect because dental and eye health services are a key component of the school health service program, focusing on the prevention and treatment of common conditions like cavities, vision problems, and other health issues in children.

School health records (Option D): is incorrect because maintaining school health records is an essential part of the school health service to monitor and track the health status, vaccinations, and any medical issues of students, ensuring proper care and follow-up when necessary.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. CT head imaging reveals multiple calcified parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is the correct approach to management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Continue antiepileptics

Explanation:

Seizures due to calcified neurocysticercosis should be managed with long-term antiepileptic therapy (e.g., levetiracetam, phenytoin, or valproate). Antiparasitic drugs are not needed for calcified lesions.

  • Multiple calcified parenchymal cysts on CT head are characteristic of neurocysticercosis (NCC) in the inactive (calcified) stage.
  • Seizures in calcified NCC are caused by gliotic scarring rather than active infection, so the primary treatment is antiepileptic therapy.
  • Antiparasitic drugs (Albendazole, Praziquantel) are ineffective in the calcified stage and can worsen inflammation.
  • Steroids are used only if perilesional edema is present, but they do not alter the course of calcified cysts.
  • The combination of albendazole and praziquantel is recommended for effective treatment of multiple viable cysts (>2 cysts).

 

Treatment of Neurocysticercosis

  1. Seizure Management: Anticonvulsant therapy is initiated upon seizure presentation. Stop if follow-up imaging shows resolution and no seizures for 24 months.
  2. Anthelmintic Therapy: Depends on the lesion stage.
  3. Cystic Lesions Treatment:
    • Albendazole: Drug of choice for parenchymal neurocysticercosis (15 mg/kg daily for 10-14 days). Recommended for 1-2 parenchymal cysts.
    • Praziquantel: Alternative option (50 mg/kg in 3 divided doses daily for 10 days).
    • Albendazole + Praziquantel: For >2 viable cysts (Praziquantel: 50 mg/kg/day for 10-14 days).
    • Prednisolone: 10 mg three times daily for 14 days, starting 1 day before albendazole or praziquantel. Given to suppress the inflammation during the natural course of the disease.
  4. Stages of Cysts:
    • Viable Cysts: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Vesicular & Colloidal Stages: Treated with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Granulonodular Stage: Some experts recommend treatment.
    • Calcified Lesions: Do not require treatment with anticysticidal therapy.
    • Small, Solitary Cerebral Cysts: Often resolve without treatment.
  5. Operative Intervention: Indicated for hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea for 3 days. He reports consuming raw fish prior to symptom onset. He is hemodynamically stable, and stool examination reveals no pus cells. Culture grows on Wagatsuma agar. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Vibrio parahaemolyticus

Explanation:

  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic Gram-negative bacterium associated with seafood consumption, particularly raw fish or shellfish.
  • It causes self-limited gastroenteritis with watery diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.
  • It grows on Wagatsuma agar, a selective medium used to detect Kanagawa-positive strains producing hemolysin.

 

Vibrio parahaemolyticus Infection

Pathophysiology

  • Infection Routes:
    • Ingestion → Gastroenteritis.
    • Wound exposure → Localized infection.
    • Severe cases → Spreads to blood (esp. in immunocompromised).
  • Virulence Factors:
    • Thermostable Direct Hemolysin (TDH) – Pore-forming toxin, unclear mechanism.
    • Type 3 secretion system – Similar to other Gram-negative bacteria.
  • Most cases are self-limiting enteritis.

 

Evaluation

  • Gold standard: Stool culture on TCBS agar.
  • Additional tests: Blood/wound cultures if sepsis/wound infection suspected.

 

Treatment & Management

  • Supportive care: IV fluids, electrolyte correction.
  • Antibiotics (for severe cases):
    • Gastroenteritis: Doxycycline.
    • Wound infections: Doxycycline or minocycline.
    • Severe infections/sepsis: Add 3rd-gen cephalosporin.

 

Vibrio cholerae (Option A): Vibrio cholerae causes profuse watery diarrhea ("rice-water stools") due to cholera toxin-mediated chloride secretion. It does not typically cause fever or abdominal pain and does not grow on Wagatsuma agar.

  • Thiosulfate-Citrate-Bile Salts-Sucrose (TCBS) Agar:
    • Differentiates between sucrose fermenters (like Vibrio cholerae) and non-sucrose fermenters (such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus).
    • Vibrio cholerae produces yellow colonies due to sucrose fermentation.

 

Salmonella typhi (Option B): Salmonella typhi causes typhoid fever, characterized by stepwise fever, constipation or "pea-soup" diarrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly. It does not grow on Wagatsuma agar.

Shigella sonnei (Option C): Shigella sonnei causes bacillary dysentery, characterized by fever, abdominal cramps, and bloody/mucoid diarrhea with pus cells. The stool in this case lacks pus cells, ruling out Shigella.

questions.text: Which culture medium is used to distinguish lactose fermenters from non-lactose fermenters?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) MacConkey agar

Explanation:

  • MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium used to isolate and distinguish Gram-negative enteric bacteria based on lactose fermentation.
  • This is a selective and differential medium that indicates lactose fermentation.
    • Lactose fermenters (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella, Enterobacter) → Pink colonies due to acid production.
    • Non-lactose fermenters (e.g., Salmonella, Shigella, Proteus) → Colorless colonies due to lack of acid production.

 

MacConkey Agar with Lactose fermenting and Non-Lactose fermenting colonies

 

Bile salt agar (Option A): This medium is used for the isolation of enteric bacteria, particularly Salmonella and Shigella, but does not specifically differentiate lactose fermenters from non-fermenters.

Thayer-Martin agar (Option B): This is a selective medium containing antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, trimethoprim) used for the isolation of Neisseria species (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Neisseria meningitidis).

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Option C): This medium is used for fungal cultures, particularly Candida, Aspergillus, and dermatophytes, and does not differentiate lactose fermentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with multiple sexual partners presents with a palmoplantar rash. On examination, he has mucocutaneous papules on the scrotum and lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Secondary syphilis

Explanation:

  • Secondary syphilis is the second stage of syphilis, which occurs if primary syphilis is left untreated. It typically presents a few weeks to several months after the initial chancre has healed. This stage is marked by systemic manifestations and can affect multiple organ systems.

Clinical Features:

1. Rash: The most characteristic feature is a diffuse, non-pruritic rash that can appear anywhere on the body. It often presents as reddish-brown spots (macules) and may also include raised lesions (papules). The rash is polymorphous, non-infectious, and never vesicular

2. Mucous Membrane Lesion- Condylomata Lata: These are broad, wart-like lesions that can appear in moist areas, such as the oral cavity, genital region, and perineum. They are highly infectious.The oral features of secondary syphilis can be painless or painful erythematous lesions, grayish-white mucous patches, or irregular linear erosions termed snail track ulcers

3. Moth eaten alopecia-nonscarring, patchy hair loss with a "moth-eaten" appearance, most commonly affecting the scalp. It is considered a pathognomonic sign of the disease but can also affect other hair-bearing areas.

4. Blushke olendroff sign-The Buschke-Ollendorff sign in secondary syphilis and cutaneous vasculitis involves deep dermal tenderness when pressing on lesions, such as syphilitic papules, with a pinhead.

5. Lymphadenopathy: Generalized painless lymphadenopathy,characteristic epitrochlear node involvement

6. Systemic Symptoms: Patients may experience flu-like symptoms, including mild fever, malaise, and fatigue.

7. Rarely, secondary syphilis can lead to neurological symptoms or ocular involvement, though this is more common in tertiary syphilis.

Diagnosis: Serological Testing:

  1. Non-Treponemal Tests: RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) and VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) are used for screening. These tests detect nonspecific antibodies and can be positive in other conditions.
  2. Treponemal Tests: FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) confirms the diagnosis by detecting antibodies specific to Treponema pallidum.

Treatment:

  • The standard treatment for secondary syphilis is Benzathine penicillin G. Dosage: 2.4 million units intramuscularly in a single dose.
  • For those allergic to penicillin, alternatives such as doxycycline or tetracycline can be used.

Complications: If left untreated, secondary syphilis can progress to the latent stage and eventually tertiary syphilis, which can lead to serious complications, including cardiovascular, neurological, and systemic damage.

 

Psoriasis (Option A): Psoriasis presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales, commonly on the extensor surfaces (elbows, knees). It is not associated with mucocutaneous lesions or lymphadenopathy.

Primary syphilis (Option C): Primary syphilis presents as a painless genital chancre without systemic symptoms. The rash and mucosal lesions seen in this case are characteristic of secondary syphilis, not primary.

Tertiary syphilis (Option D): Tertiary syphilis occurs years after untreated infection and presents with gummas (granulomatous lesions), neurosyphilis, or cardiovascular complications. The rash and lymphadenopathy seen here are more indicative of secondary syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites invade the skin directly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schistosoma mansoni

Explanation:

  • Schistosoma species (including S. mansoni, S. haematobium, and S. japonicum) penetrate human skin directly when a person comes in contact with contaminated freshwater containing cercariae (infective larval stage). This leads to swimmer’s itch followed by systemic schistosomiasis.

 

Schistosoma (Blood Fluke):

Species

  • Schistosoma haematobium (Africa, Near East, Middle East, India)
  • Schistosoma mansoni (Africa, South America)
  • Schistosoma japonicum (China, Japan, Far East)

Habitat

  • S. haematobium: Veins of vesical and pelvic plexuses
  • S. mansoni: Inferior mesenteric vein
  • S. japonicum: Superior mesenteric vein

Definitive Host

Man

Intermediate Host

Snail

Mode of Infection

Skin penetration by cercaria

Infective form

Cercaria larva

Eggs

Has characteristic lateral spine.

Larva

Has following stages:

  • Miracida
  • Sporocysts
  • Cercaria: Has elongated ovoid body and forked tail.

Adult worm
  • Sexes are separate.
  • Has 2 muscular suckers: Oral and ventral sucker
  • Gynecophoric canal begins behind the ventral sucker, where the female worm is held.

 

Life Cycle:

 

Clonorchis sinensis (Option B): This liver fluke is transmitted through ingestion of raw or undercooked freshwater fish containing metacercariae, not by direct skin penetration. It causes biliary tract infections and is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

Wuchereria bancrofti (Option C): This filarial parasite is transmitted by mosquito bites, not by direct skin penetration. It causes lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis) due to obstruction of lymphatic vessels.

Diphyllobothrium latum (Option D): This tapeworm is acquired through ingestion of raw freshwater fish containing plerocercoid larvae, not through skin penetration. It can cause vitamin B12 deficiency leading to megaloblastic anemia.

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Wilson & Blair medium

Explanation:

  • Wilson & Blair medium is a selective agar used specifically for the isolation and identification of Salmonella species, particularly Salmonella typhi. This medium contains brilliant green, which inhibits the growth of most bacteria except for Salmonella, and helps in the selective growth of this organism while also aiding in its identification through distinctive colony characteristics.

 

PLET medium (Option A): This medium is used for the isolation of Listeria monocytogenes, not Salmonella.

BCYE medium (Option B): Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar is used for the isolation of Legionella species, not Salmonella.

Stuart's medium (Option D): This is a transport medium used for the transport of specimens, particularly for maintaining the viability of pathogens, but it is not used for the isolation of Salmonella.

questions.text: A cattle farmer presented with a lesion on the arm as shown below. Gram staining showed gram-positive rods as shown below. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bacillus anthracis

Explanation:

The clinical presentation of a lesion on the arm, especially in a cattle farmer, raises suspicion for anthrax, which is caused by Bacillus anthracis. Bacillus anthracis is a gram-positive, spore-forming rod. The bacterium can form spores that can survive in the environment for long periods. Infection in humans can occur through contact with infected animals or animal products, such as wool, hides, or meat, or through a wound contaminated with spores.

  • The presentation of a black necrotic lesion (eschar) surrounded by swelling and secondary vesicles is characteristic of cutaneous anthrax, which occurs when Bacillus anthracis spores enter through damaged skin. MO
  • Commonly seen in dock workers carrying hides and skins on their bare backs. Also known as Hide-Porter’s disease.

 

Name

Microscopy

Features

a. Bacillus Anthracis

Bacillus anthracis appears as large (3-10 µm x 1-1.6 µm), rectangular, rod-shaped bacteria (“box-car appearance”), often arranged in chains. It is Gram-positive.

It is

 

 

Blood Culture Morphology:

Characteristic

Description

Blood Agar
  • Large (2 to 5 mm), grey, flat, non-hemolytic colonies with irregular margins- giving a frosted glass appearance.
  • Tenacious consistency firmly adheres to agar.
  • "Medusa head" appearance under microscope.

Agar with Penicillin
  • Susceptible to penicillin.
  • Grows large, spherical cells in 3-6 hours on media with 0.05-0.50 units of penicillin/ml.
  • Forms "string of pearls" chains.

Gelatin Liquefaction

 

 

 

 
  • Obligate aerobe.
  • More growth and energy production at the surface.
  • Liquefaction starts from the top, resembling an "inverted fir tree".

PLET Medium

 

 
  • Contains polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, and thallous acetate in heart infusion agar (PLET)
  • Selective for isolating B. anthracis from samples with other spore-forming bacilli.

Serology

 

 

 
  • Ascoli's Thermoprecipitin Test: Detects anthrax antigens in tissue extracts.
  • DFA: Detects antibodies against B. anthracis; confirms presence via cell wall polysaccharide and capsule antigens.

Laboratory Safety Note
  • High risk of infection from spores.
  • Caution is advised when handling B.anthracis isolates.

 

Bacillus cereus (Option A): Although it is also a gram-positive rod, it is not associated with anthrax and usually causes foodborne illnesses or opportunistic infections.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option C): This is a gram-negative rod and is usually associated with infections in immunocompromised individuals, burns, or wounds, but it is not associated with anthrax.

Brucella abortus (Option D): This is a gram-negative bacterium that causes brucellosis, which can also affect farmers but typically presents with fever, joint pain, and more systemic symptoms rather than localized lesions like anthrax.

questions.text: In the context of a national public health initiative aimed at addressing anemia, which of the following programs follows the "6x6x6 strategy"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anemia Mukt Bharat

Explanation:

The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) program, launched by the Government of India, aims to reduce anemia among women, children, and adolescents. The "6x6x6 strategy" refers to a set of actions designed to address anemia, focusing on:

  • 6 target age groups (children aged 6-59 months, adolescent girls, pregnant women, lactating mothers, women of reproductive age, and men)
  • 6 interventions (Iron and Folic Acid supplementation, deworming, malaria control, nutrition improvement, managing hemorrhage during childbirth, and controlling hookworm)
  • 6 delivery platforms (school-based programs, anganwadis, health centers, etc.)

 

Poshan Abhiyan (Option B): is incorrect because the Poshan Abhiyan (National Nutrition Mission) focuses on improving the nutritional status of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers but does not specifically follow the "6x6x6 strategy" related to anemia.

Kishori Shakti Yojana (Option C): is incorrect because the Kishori Shakti Yojana focuses on the empowerment of adolescent girls, providing them with life skills training, but it does not follow the "6x6x6 strategy" for addressing anemia.

None of these (Option D): is incorrect because Anemia Mukt Bharat (Option A) clearly follows the "6x6x6 strategy" for anemia control.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization is done by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hydrogen peroxide

Explanation:

  • Plasma sterilization is a method of sterilizing medical instruments and other equipment by using hydrogen peroxide in a low-pressure environment. The hydrogen peroxide is vaporized and then subjected to a plasma field, which generates highly reactive ions and free radicals that effectively kill microorganisms.

 

Risk category

Recommended method

Medical device/Equipment

1. Critical device (high risk): Items that enter a normally sterile site.

Sterilisation

  • If heat resistant: Hot air oven or autoclave
  • If heat-sensitive: Ionising radiation or ethylene oxide or plasma sterilisation.

Surgical instruments, implants/prostheses, rigid endoscopes, syringes, needles, CuT, Urinary catheter

2. Semi-critical device (intermediate risk):

Items in contact with mucous membranes or body fluids.

High-level disinfection (HLD):

Such as glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, formaldehyde and hydrogen peroxide.

Respiratory equipment, non-invasive flexible endoscopes, bedpans, urine bottles

 

3. Non-critical (low-risk)

Items in contact with intact skin.

Intermediate or Low-level disinfection (ILD or LLD):

Such as phenols, chlorhexidine, isopropyl alcohol, povidone-iodine, etc

 

Patient items include blood pressure cuffs, ECG electrodes, thermometer and stethoscopes.

 

Environmental surfaces include computers, bed rails, food utensils, bedside tables, patient furniture and floor.

 

Ethylene oxide (Option A): This is used for gas sterilization, but it is not associated with plasma sterilization. It is effective for sterilizing heat- and moisture-sensitive items.

Gamma rays (Option B): Gamma radiation is used in radiation sterilization, which is another method of sterilization, but it is not related to plasma sterilization.

Ultraviolet radiation (Option D): UV radiation is effective for surface sterilization but does not penetrate materials deeply enough for plasma sterilization.

questions.text: Which of the following dimorphic fungi causes subcutaneous mycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sporothrix schenckii

Explanation:

Sporotrichosis

Causative agent

Dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.

 

Epidemiology

Common in gardeners, forest workers, and manual labourers.

 

Route of transmission

Minor trauma or thorn prick.

Clinical features
  • Chronic infection affects cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue.
  • Lesions form at sites of minor trauma or thorn pricks, starting as nodules.
  • Nodules ulcerate and necrose; infection spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis: Secondary ulcers on lymph nodes; lymphatics become hardened and cord-like.
  • Systemic dissemination: Can affect bones, joints, and meninges.

Specimens

Aspiration from nodules and biopsy material.

 

Diagnosis

 

Microscopy:

  • KOH mounts or histopathological sections stained by methenamine silver stain show asteroid bodies (Splendore hoeppli phenomenon)
  • Yeast phase: Cigar-shaped cells.

 

Culture: Thin septate hyphae with flower-like clusters of small conidia; pear-shaped conidia in rosette-like clusters in mycelial phase.

 

Serological tests: Helpful for extracutaneous or systemic infections.

 

Treatment

 

Medications:

  • Itraconazole
  • Terbinafine
  • Amphotericin B: For disseminated infection

Cryotherapy.

 

Dimorphic Fungus

  • Have the ability to convert between two specific morphologic forms, yeast and hyphae.

Types:

  • Thermally dimorphic fungi:
    • Converts between hyphae (22–25°C) and yeast (37°C), based on the temperature
    • Thermally dimorphic fungi infect humans and other mammals
    • Conversion to yeast within healthy and immunocompromised mammalian hosts is essential for virulence (Option B)
    • Eg. Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Coccidioides immitis and posadasii, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and lutzii, Sporothrix schenckii, Talaromyces marneffei, Emmonsia spp., Lacazia loboi.
  • Nonthermal dimorphic fungi:
    • Typically infects plants

 

 

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option B): This dimorphic fungus causes histoplasmosis, a respiratory infection, not a subcutaneous mycosis.

Blastomyces dermatitidis (Option C): This is also a dimorphic fungus, but it causes blastomycosis, which primarily affects the lungs, though it can disseminate to skin and other organs, but it's not classified as a subcutaneous mycosis.

Penicillium marneffei (Option D): This dimorphic fungus causes penicilliosis, a systemic infection that can affect the lungs, liver, and lymph nodes, primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It does not typically cause subcutaneous mycosis.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) lgG

Explanation:

  • IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in human serum, constituting about 70-75% of the total immunoglobulin in the bloodstream. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing toxins, opsonizing pathogens, and activating the complement system.

 

IgG

  • Four types – IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, and IgG4
  • It is the main serum immunoglobulin, constituting 80% of total serum antibodies
  • Distribution: Both intravascular and extravascular
  • Only maternal antibody transported across the placenta, providing passive immunity to newborns mop
  • Function:
    • Binds to microorganisms, enhancing their phagocytosis
    • Participates in complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralisation of toxins/viruses
    • Part of chronic inflammation
  • Clinical Application: Used in isoimmunisation for Rh-negative mothers with anti-Rh(D) IgG during delivery.

 

IgM

  • It is a heavy molecule, hence called 'the millionaire molecule.’
  • Structure: Made of five four-peptide subunits; requires a J chain for polymerisation
  • Valency: 10
  • Distribution: Primarily intravascular (80% of IgM)
  • Early Production: First antibody synthesized by the fetus, starting around 20 weeks of gestation
  • Short-Lived: IgM antibodies degrade sooner than IgG
  • Immune Hemolysis: One IgM molecule can induce hemolysis, unlike IgG, which requires 1,000 molecules for similar effect
  • Opsonization Efficiency: 500-1,000 times more effective in opsonization than IgG
  • This is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response, but its concentration in serum is lower than IgG. It is typically the first to respond to infections. (Option B ruled out)

 

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Found primarily in mucosal areas (like respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts), IgA is not present in the highest concentration in serum compared to IgG. (Option C ruled out)
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

 

IgD:

  • IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes
  • Function:
    • Acts as recognition receptors for antigens
    • It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression.

 

IgE:

  • Heat-labile (sensitive to heat)
  • It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism)
  • Mediates Prausnitz-Küstner Reaction
  • Distribution: Primarily found in extravascular spaces
  • Elevated Levels: In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections
  • Function: Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators
  • This is present in very low concentrations in serum. It is primarily associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. (Option D ruled out)

 

Immunoglobulin Functions:

  • IgG: Protects body fluids
  • IgA: Protects body surfaces
  • IgM: Guards the bloodstream
  • IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity
  • IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes

questions.text: The stain used for identifying Cryptococcus is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) India ink stain

Explanation:

  • India ink stain is commonly used for identifying Cryptococcus neoformans, particularly in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The stain highlights the capsule of the Cryptococcus organism, making it appear as a halo around the yeast, which is a characteristic feature of Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Cryptococcus Spp.

Cryptococcus is a true yeast.

Capsule

Polysaccharide capsule - helps in serotyping and protection against phagocytosis.

Serotypes

A, D, AD serotypes - Cryptococcus variety neoformans

B, C serotypes -Cryptococcus variety gattii

Virulence factors
  • Polysaccharide Capsule: The primary virulence factor. It helps the pathogen evade phagocytosis and suppresses the host’s local immune responses, enabling the organism to survive and spread.
  • Melanin Production: Cryptococcus produces melanin via the enzyme phenol oxidase, which contributes to its virulence by protecting the pathogen from oxidative stress and immune defenses.
  • Enzyme Production: The fungus secretes several enzymes, including:
    • Phospholipase: Aids in tissue invasion and damage.
    • Urease: Helps the fungus survive in the host environment by neutralizing acidic conditions, enhancing its ability to colonize and spread.

Risk of infection

Immunocompromised States:

    • HIV/AIDS, cancer, organ transplant recipients, those on immunosuppressive therapies, extremes of age are at higher risk.

Geographic Location:

    • Exposure to environments where Cryptococcus gattii is endemic, such as tropical and subtropical regions

Environmental Exposure:

    • Exposure to bird droppings or decaying wood can increase the likelihood of infection, especially with C. neoformans.

 

Management of cryptococcosis

Microscopy

    • India ink- Demonstrates the capsule, which appears as clear space surrounding the round budding yeast cells
    • Mucicarmine stain: It stains the carminophilic cell wall of C. neoformans

Culture
    • Sabouraud Dextrose Agar, forming smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies.
    • Niger seed agar and bird seed agar: Demonstrates melanin production (brown colored colonies) due to phenol oxidase/laccase enzyme.
    • The ability to grow at 37°C and hydrolyse urea differentiates C. neoformans from non-pathogenic cryptococci

 

Antigen detection tests

Demonstration of the capsular antigen by Precipitation and Latex agglutination test

Treatment

  • Initial Treatment with liposomal Amphotericin B and Flucytosine
  • Maintenance Therapy with Fluconazole for 6-12 months, depending on immune status.
  • Monitoring: Regularly check CSF for fungal clearance, renal function, and electrolytes.
  • Management of Underlying Conditions: Optimize ART to reduce recurrence risk.

 

Albert's stain (Option A): This is used for staining Corynebacterium diphtheriae and is not suitable for identifying Cryptococcus.

Silver stain (Option B): This is typically used for identifying fungal organisms, especially fungal structures like spores and hyphae, but it is not the best stain for Cryptococcus.

Auramine-rhodamine stain (Option D): This is used for detecting mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis) through fluorescent microscopy, not for Cryptococcus.

questions.text: Which of the following is an acid-fast organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mycobacterium avium

Explanation:

  • Mycobacterium avium complex is a nonmotile, non-spore-forming, gram-positive acid-fast bacillus. M. avium complex is a nonchromogen and slow-growing and takes about 10 to 20 days to develop mature colonies.
  • Mycobacterium avium is an acid-fast organism, which means it retains the dye when subjected to an acid wash during the acid-fast staining procedure (e.g., Ziehl-Neelsen stain). This property is due to the high lipid content in the cell wall, particularly the mycolic acids, which makes it resistant to acid decolorization.

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): This is a Gram-positive bacterium but not acid-fast. It does not retain the stain after the acid wash.

Escherichia coli (Option B): This is a Gram-negative bacterium and is not acid-fast. It will not retain the stain in an acid-fast test.

Actinomyces (Option D): This genus includes bacteria that are Gram-positive and typically do not exhibit acid-fast properties.

questions.text: A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

Explanation:

  • A patient previously vaccinated for rabies (within 3–6 months) requires only a booster of two doses of rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3 after a new category 3 exposure. This ensures rapid and sufficient anamnestic immune response without the need for additional interventions like rabies immunoglobulin.

 

Wound cleaning only (Option A): is incorrect because wound cleaning alone is insufficient for managing a category 3 dog bite, even if the patient was vaccinated earlier. Booster doses of the rabies vaccine are essential to maintain protection.

Wound cleaning + rabies vaccine on day 0, 3 & 7 (Option C): is incorrect because a three-dose schedule is unnecessary for previously vaccinated individuals. The recommended booster involves only two doses (day 0 and day 3).

Wound cleaning + IM vaccine + RIG (Option D): is incorrect because rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is only indicated for rabies-naïve patients or those who have not completed prior prophylaxis.

questions.text: In which medical condition is a ground-glass appearance observed on high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Silicosis

  • Silicosis, a progressive occupational interstitial lung disease caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust. On HRCT, silicosis characteristically shows ground-glass opacities, particularly in early stages.
  • The ground-glass appearance on HRCT refers to an imaging pattern in which the lung parenchyma appears hazy due to partial filling of the air spaces with fluid, inflammatory cells, or fibrosis.
  • They appear as hazy areas of increased attenuation in the lung parenchyma without obscuring the underlying bronchial and vascular margins. As the disease progresses, nodular opacities called silicotic nodules develop, typically with an upper lung zone predominance, and may calcify over time, resulting in eggshell calcifications.

Silicosis:

  • Leading cause of Interstitial lung disease (ILD) in India, frequently resulting from occupational exposure in the glassware, mining, quarrying, and construction industries.
  • Manifests after 10-20 years of continuous exposure.
  • Radiological features:
    • The chest radiograph may show profuse military infiltration or consolidation, and there is a characteristic HRCT pattern of ground glass opacitities known as “crazy paving”.
    • Multiple well-circumscribed 3–5 mm nodular opacities predominantly in the mid-and upper zones.
    • Enlargement of the hilar glands with an “egg-shell” pattern of calcification (seen in 20% of cases).
    • As the disease progresses, progressive massive fibrosis (PMF) may develop.

Asbestosis (Option A): Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. The characteristic findings on HRCT include linear opacities that typically have a subpleural and lower lung zone predominance, with fine reticular lines, thick bands, or honeycombing. Ground-glass appearance is not a typical feature of asbestosis.

Anthracosis (Option C): Anthracosis, or coal workers' pneumoconiosis, is caused by the inhalation and deposition of coal dust particles. The primary HRCT finding is the presence of small, rounded opacities, often referred to as coal macules or coal nodules found in the upper lung zones. Ground-glass opacities are not a characteristic feature.

Bagassosis (Option D): Bagassosis is an acute hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of moldy bagasse. While HRCT findings in bagassosis can vary, they typically include centrilobular nodules and air-trapping. While ground-glass opacities may be seen, they are not the predominant or characteristic feature.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - LFT

The Child-Pugh scoring system is used to assess the severity of liver disease, predict prognosis for liver cirrhosis, and determine a patient's eligibility for liver transplantation.

Liver Function Tests (LFTs), which include enzymes like ALT (alanine aminotransferase) and AST (aspartate aminotransferase), are not part of the Child-Pugh scoring system.

The Child-Pugh classification employs using a scoring system that incorporates parameters such as:

  • Bilirubin
  • INR
  • Albumin
  • Ascites
  • Hepatic encephalopathy

Child-Pugh classification

Parameters

1

2

3

Encephalopathy

None

Grade 1-2

(Minimal)

Grade 3-4

(Advanced)

Ascites

None

Mildly controlled

Poorly controlled

Bilirubin (mg/dL) (Option B Ruled Out)

< 2

2 - 3

> 3

Albumin (g/dL) (Option A Ruled Out)

> 3.5

3 - 3.5

< 3.5

INR (Option C Ruled Out)

< 1.7

1.7 - 2.3

> 2.3
  • The Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class is determined by summing the scores for each parameter.
  • The Child-Pugh score has inherent bias related to ascites and encephalopathy, potentially failing to reflect their severity accurately. This limitation is reduced in the MELD scoring system.

Child-Pugh Score

Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class

1-Year Survival Rate

Category A

5-6 (Compensated cirrhosis)

100%

Category B

7-9 (Decompensated cirrhosis)

81%

Category C

> 10

45%

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done, and it showed predominantly lymphocytes, sugar- 50mg, and protein- 3000mg/dl. Cobweb coagulum was noted. Gram-staining was negative. The patient's chest X-ray shows upper lobe involvement with hilar lymph node enlargement.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Tuberculous meningitis

  • The presentation including subacute fever with neck rigidity, characteristic CSF findings (lymphocytic predominance, low sugar, markedly elevated protein), cobweb coagulum formation, and chest X-ray showing upper lobe involvement with hilar lymphadenopathy, which are all classic features of tuberculous meningitis.

  • The negative Gram stain further supports mycobacterial infection rather than typical bacterial pathogens.

Tuberculous Meningitis

Symptoms and Clinical Features:

  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.

  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.

  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.

  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.

  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.

  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.

  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:

  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).

  • High protein content (1–8 g/L).

  • Cobweb Coagulum: Clear fluid in a test tube with a cobweb at the bottom

  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:

  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4–8 weeks, positive in ~50%).

  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10–40%).

  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:

 

  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.

  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions -tuberculoma

Treatment:

  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.

  • Initial drug regimen: isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and pyridoxine.

  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.

  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).

  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

Bacterial meningitis (Option B): Bacterial meningitis typically presents with acute onset (<24-48 hours), neutrophilic predominance in CSF, and positive Gram stain. The subacute presentation and lymphocytic CSF make bacterial meningitis unlikely.

Fungal meningitis (Option C): While fungal meningitis can present with similar CSF findings, including low glucose and high protein, it typically occurs in immunocompromised patients and does not usually present with characteristic upper lobe chest X-ray findings. The presence of pulmonary involvement strongly suggests tuberculosis.

Viral meningitis (Option D): Viral meningitis typically presents with normal to mildly elevated protein levels, normal glucose levels, and absence of cobweb coagulum. The markedly elevated protein (3000mg/dl) and low glucose are inconsistent with viral etiology.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a 2-year-old child gives a history of completing required antenatal vaccinations during her previous pregnancy. Which of the following would you recommend for her current pregnancy?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of TT
Give a booster dose of Td

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Give a booster dose of Td

Explanation:

The Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) vaccine is recommended as a booster dose during pregnancy, especially if the woman has completed the required antenatal vaccinations previously. In India, the current guidelines suggest giving two doses of Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) during pregnancy: one at the start of pregnancy and one between 20 to 26 weeks.

  • Tetanus Toxoid (TT) is part of routine antenatal immunization, but the Td vaccine is recommended if there is a history of prior TT vaccination in previous pregnancies, as it also covers Diphtheria.

 

Give a booster dose of TT (Option A): is not correct in this context, as the current guidelines recommend Td (Tetanus and Diphtheria) for booster doses, not TT.

Give 2 doses of TT (Option C): is incorrect because only a booster dose of Td is needed. Giving 2 doses of TT is not the standard recommendation if the woman has completed required antenatal vaccinations in the previous pregnancy.

Give 2 doses of Td (Option D): is not correct because only 1 dose of Td is recommended for the current pregnancy, not two. The second dose of Td is given between 20-26 weeks of pregnancy if the first dose was given early in the pregnancy.

questions.text: When should a primigravida initiate breastfeeding after a normal delivery of a healthy baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Within 1 hour

Explanation:

For a primigravida (first-time mother) delivering a healthy baby through normal delivery, it is recommended to initiate breastfeeding within 1 hour after birth. Early initiation of breastfeeding is crucial because:

  • It helps in the initiation of milk production.
  • The baby receives the first milk, known as colostrum, which is rich in nutrients and antibodies, providing essential protection against infections.
  • Early breastfeeding also promotes bonding between the mother and the baby.

 

After 1 hour (Option B): is incorrect because, as per guidelines, the baby should begin breastfeeding within the first hour of birth, not after it.

After 4-6 hours (Option C): is incorrect. Delaying breastfeeding for this long can lead to problems like poor milk production and inadequate intake by the baby.

After 24 hours (Option D): is incorrect. Waiting for 24 hours is too long, and early breastfeeding is essential for both maternal and infant health.

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Subarachnoid haemorrhage

  • The presentation of sudden severe headache ("worst headache of my life"), hypertension, and nuchal rigidity, along with the CT scan showing characteristic "Star of Death" appearance due to blood accumulation in basal cisterns, are diagnostic of Subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).
  • This condition occurs when blood accumulates in the subarachnoid space between the brain and the thin tissues covering it, usually due to aneurysm rupture, and carries a 35% mortality rate if untreated.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage- Etiology, Risk factors and Pathophysiology

  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.

  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.

  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).

  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology

  • Age: Most aSAH occurs between ages 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.

  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology

  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):

    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.

    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)

      • Age >60

      • Posterior circulation aneurysms

      • Atherosclerosis

      • Aneurysm size

        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.

        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.

        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.

      • Family history

      • Previous SAH

      • ADPKD

  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):

    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.

    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.

    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.

    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.

    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology

  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.

  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.

    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.

    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

Clinical Presentation

 

  • "Thunderclap headache" - worst headache of life

  • Sudden onset severe headache

  • Vomiting

  • Variable LOC

  • Meningismus

  • Retinal hemorrhages

  • Focal neurologic deficits

  • Nuchal rigidity

Diagnosis

CT Head

  • Non-contrast CT is first-line

  • "Star sign" - blood in basal cisterns

  • Sensitivity: 98-100% in first 12 hours

Lumbar Puncture

  • If CT negative

  • Xanthochromia (takes 12h to develop)

  • Elevated opening pressure

Cluster headache (Option A): Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral pain centered around the eye often described as retro-orbital pain along with associated autonomic symptoms. They typically occur in clusters or cycles and do not present with nuchal rigidity or “Star sign” on CT findings.

Encephalitis (Option C): Encephalitis typically presents with fever, altered mental status, seizures, and focal neurological deficits. The absence of fever and presence of classic SAH findings on CT make encephalitis unlikely.

Meningitis (Option D): While meningitis can present with headache and nuchal rigidity, it typically includes fever and photophobia. The CT findings are not consistent with meningitis. Also, the characteristic "Star of Death" appearance on CT is pathognomonic of SAH.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Rheumatoid arthritis

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation that can extend beyond joints to involve other tissues, including the pleura. When the pleura is involved, the inflammatory process causes damage to blood vessels in the pleural membrane, leading to increased vascular permeability and the leakage of fluid, proteins, and immune cells into the pleural space, resulting in an exudative effusion.

Causes of pleural effusion

Tranudative

Exudative

Both

  • Congestive heart failure (Option A)

  • Cirrhosis

  • Liver failure (Option B)

  • Nephrotic syndrome (Option D)

  • Peritoneal dialysis

  • SVC obstruction

  • Myxedema

  • Urinothorax

  • Malignancies

  • Tuberculosis

  • Pneumonia

  • Esophageal perforation

  • Pancreatic disease

  • Rheumatoid pleuritis (Option C)

  • Collagen vascular diseases:

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Sjögren syndrome

  • Wegener Granulomatosis

Pulmonary embolism

Drugs induced

  • Nitrofurantoin

  • Dantrolene

  • Methysergide

  • Bromocriptine

  • Procarbazine

  • Amiodarone

  • Dasatinib

questions.text: A 26-year-old male with a history of respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks and the weakness is progressive, ascending, and symmetrical in nature. The lower limbs were involved before and gradually the upper limbs were also affected. On examination you note areflexia. Pain and proprioception are preserved. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Guillain-Barré syndrome

  • The patient presents with classic features of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) including antecedent respiratory tract infection, progressive ascending symmetrical weakness, and areflexia. GBS is an autoimmune polyradiculopathy causing patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves. The temporal relationship with infection, pattern of weakness, and preserved sensory function are characteristic of GBS.

Category

Symptoms

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia, neck floppiness
  • Bilateral 7th nerve palsy
  • Bulbar palsy
    • Difficulty in handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
    • A leading cause of death due to pulmonary involvement.
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis
    • Ventilatory support is required in 30% of cases.
    • Increased carbon dioxide levels.

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Proprioception loss
    • Difficulty in climbing stairs
    • Pain in the neck/arm/shoulder is similar to over-exercised muscle
  • Sensory manifestations can occur before or along with motor manifestations.

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Autonomic dysregulation (e.g., orthostatic hypotension, bladder/bowel sparing/transient involvement)
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure, arrhythmias, postural hypotension
  • Reduced heart rate and blood pressure, neurogenic shock.

Myasthenia gravis (Option B): Weakness in myasthenia gravis typically worsens with repeated use of the affected muscles and improves with rest. Additionally, it often affects the muscles of the face and eyes before involving the limbs. The ascending pattern and areflexia are not typical features of myasthenia gravis.

Polymyositis (Option C): Polymyositis presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness primarily affecting the shoulder and hip girdle muscles, making activities like climbing stairs or raising arms above the head difficult. Patients maintain normal reflexes and have no sensory involvement. The absence of proximal muscle pattern, presence of areflexia, and absence of ascending weakness pattern make polymyositis unlikely.

Multiple sclerosis (Option D): Multiple sclerosis typically follows a relapsing-remitting course with scattered neurological manifestations. Common presentations include visual symptoms like optic neuritis and sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and numbness. Patients often demonstrate hyperreflexia rather than areflexia.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Liposomal amphotericin B

  • For the given HIV-positive patient with cryptococcal meningitis, Liposomal amphotericin B is the preferred initial therapy due to its higher efficacy and better penetration into the central nervous system. The treatment regimen consists of liposomal amphotericin B (L-AMB) combined with 5-flucytosine for 2 weeks as induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for 6 weeks as consolidation therapy.

Cryptococcal Meningitis

Common Cause
  • The leading infectious cause of meningitis in AIDS patients is primarily due to Cryptococcus neoformans (C. neoformans); C. gattii accounts for up to 12%.

Clinical Presentation

 
  • Symptoms include fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs.
  • Low incidence of seizures and focal neurological deficits.
  • Kernig’s Sign- Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

CSF Profile
  • It may be normal or show modest elevations in WBC and protein levels.
  • Decreased glucose levels may be observed.
  • Elevated CSF opening pressure is typical.

Diagnosis
  • Identification of organisms via India ink examination of CSF.

 

  • Detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF or blood.
  • Blood cultures for fungi are often positive.
  • The biopsy may be necessary for diagnosing CNS cryptococcoma and to differentiate it from immune reconstitution syndrome.

Induction therapy
  • IV amphotericin B (0.7 mg/kg daily) or liposomal amphotericin (4–6 mg/kg daily) plus flucytosine (25 mg/kg qid) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Monitor renal function to avoid flucytosine toxicity.

Maintenance Therapy
  • Amphotericin should be continued until CSF culture is negative, followed by fluconazole (400 mg/d PO for 8 weeks, then 200 mg/d) until CD4+ T-cell count >200 cells/μL for 6 months.

Vancomycin (Option A): Vancomycin is primarily used to treat bacterial infections, particularly those caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). It has no activity against Cryptococcus neoformans, and would be ineffective in treating cryptococcal meningitis.

High dose fluconazole with flucytosine (Option B): While these antifungal medications are used in cryptococcal meningitis treatment, they are not the optimal initial therapy for severe cases. High-dose fluconazole with flucytosine lacks the rapid fungicidal activity of liposomal amphotericin B and is reserved for maintenance therapy or cases where amphotericin B is contraindicated.

Voriconazole (Option C): Voriconazole is primarily used to treat invasive aspergillosis and other filamentous fungal infections. It is not the drug of choice for cryptococcal meningitis as it has limited evidence for efficacy against Cryptococcus neoformans compared to the standard regimen.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with coarse facial features and gradual enlargement of the hands and feet for the past decade. He has been diagnosed with acromegaly based on elevated levels of IGF-1 and growth hormone that did not suppress after a 75 g glucose challenge test. What drug is recommended for treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Lanreotide depot formulation

  • The clinical manifestations indicate active acromegaly based on typical physical changes and biochemical confirmation. Lanreotide is a somatostatin analog that has high efficacy in controlling GH and IGF-1 levels, as well as its convenient long duration of action.
  • It is administered as a long-acting depot injection and is considered the first line medical therapy for acromegaly. The medication works by binding to somatostatin receptors on the pituitary tumor, effectively reducing GH secretion and consequently normalizing IGF-1 levels.

Management of Acromegaly

Surgical Treatment

Transsphenoidal surgical resection is the preferred treatment, especially for those with GH-secreting adenomas.

Post-Surgery:

  • Improvement in soft tissue swelling and normalization of GH levels typically occur shortly after surgery
  • IGF-1 levels normalize within 3-4 days.
  • There is a 10% recurrence rate of acromegaly years later, and up to 15% of patients may develop hypopituitarism.

Medical therapy

Preferred in medical therapy if curative surgery is not feasible or if GH fails to decrease post resection

  • Somatostatin Receptor Ligands (SRLs):
    • Long-acting injectable forms (octreotide, lanreotide).
    • Normalizes GH and IGF-1 levels in about 50% of patients.
    • Side Effects: GI disturbances, transient nausea, and gallbladder issues.
  • GH receptor antagonist:
    • Pegvisomant blocks peripheral GH receptors, normalizing IGF-1 levels in about 70% of patients, though GH levels remain elevated. It is administered through daily subcutaneous injections and is used for recurrences or poor responses to SRLs.
  • Dopamine Agonists:
    • High doses of cabergoline can provide modest GH suppression.

Radiation Therapy

External beam radiation therapy or stereotactic techniques are considered for patients not achieving biochemical control through surgery or medical therapy.

Terlipressin (Option B): Terlipressin is a synthetic vasopressin analog used primarily for the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome and bleeding esophageal varices. It has no role in the treatment of acromegaly as it does not affect GH secretion or action.

Ketoconazole (Option C): Ketoconazole is an antifungal medication. While it has been used off-label for some endocrine conditions (such as adrenal hypercortisolism), it is not indicated for acromegaly management as it does not affect GH or IGF-1 levels.

Leuprolide (Option D): Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist commonly used for the treatment of conditions such as prostate cancer and endometriosis. It does not have any effect on GH secretion and is therefore not effective in treating acromegaly.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited disorder characterized by abnormal red blood cells that are spherical in shape instead of the normal biconcave disc shape. Elective splenectomy is the primary treatment for Hereditary spherocytosis.
  • In HS, splenectomy is particularly effective because the spleen is the primary site of spherocyte destruction.
