The timing of splenectomy varies with disease severity: severe HS requires elective splenectomy at 4-6 years of age, moderate HS can be delayed until puberty, while mild cases may be managed with folic acid supplementation alone.

Management of Hereditary Spherocytosis (HS)

Splenectomy as Primary Treatment
  • Splenectomy significantly improves anemia by prolonging red cell survival, reducing the need for transfusions, and preventing iron overload and related organ damage.
  • Post splenectomy: Spherocytosis and altered osmotic fragility persist, but reticulocyte counts and erythrocyte lifespan normalize.

Blood Film Changes Post-Splenectomy
  • Features like Howell-Jolly bodies, acanthocytes, target cells, cabot ring and Pappenheimer bodies appear after splenectomy.

 

Indications for Splenectomy
  • Recommended for patients with severe, transfusion-dependent anemia, growth failure, skeletal changes, leg ulcers, or extramedullary hematopoietic tumors.

Timing of Splenectomy:

  • Should be delayed until age 5–9 if possible or at least age 3, to reduce the risk of post-splenectomy sepsis while balancing the increased risk of gallstones in older children.

Laparoscopic Splenectomy
  • Preferred method, with benefits like less discomfort, quicker recovery, and shorter hospital stays. Combined laparoscopic splenectomy and cholecystectomy is an option for patients with symptomatic gallstones.

Partial Splenectomy
  • Used in infants or young children to alleviate anemia while preserving some splenic immune function. It reduces transfusion needs but may eventually require total splenectomy in about half of patients.

Pre- and Post-Splenectomy Care

 

  • Vaccination: Patients should receive vaccines against pneumococcus, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and meningococcus before surgery.
  • Antibiotic Prophylaxis: Use of prophylactic antibiotics post-splenectomy is controversial but recommended by some for at least 5 years or even lifelong.
  • Folic Acid: Continued supplementation (1 mg/day) is recommended to prevent folate deficiency.

G6PD deficiency (Option A): In G6PD deficiency, splenectomy may actually worsen the anemia because the spleen filters and removes damaged red blood cells from the circulation. The primary management involves avoiding oxidative stressors and managing acute hemolytic episodes.

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (Option B): In PNH, there is an abnormality in the complement system, and stem cell transplant is the best curative treatment. Splenectomy is not indicated as the hemolysis is complement-mediated and occurs throughout the circulation.

Hairy cell leukemia (Option D): In hairy cell leukemia, chemotherapy is the standard treatment. Splenectomy may be considered only in cases with massively enlarged spleen or if there is resistance to other treatments, but it is not the preferred initial treatment option.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urine metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Pheochromocytoma

  • The clinical manifestations indicate pheochromocytoma based on the classic triad of symptoms and elevated urinary metanephrines. Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that produces excessive amounts of catecholamines, leading to paroxysmal symptoms including sudden onset headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring elevated levels of urinary metanephrines, which is considered the most sensitive diagnostic test for pheochromocytoma. The episodic nature of symptoms along with documented elevation in blood pressure during these episodes strongly supports this diagnosis.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.

 

  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Addison's disease (Option A): Addison's disease is primary adrenocortical failure and presents with symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. While adrenal crisis can cause symptoms such as headache and sweating, it does not cause an episodic elevation of blood pressure and is characterized by hypotension rather than hypertension. Also elevated metanephrines is not a finding in Addison’s disease.

Renal artery stenosis (Option B): Renal artery stenosis can lead to high blood pressure but does not cause sudden onset headaches, palpitation, and profuse sweating. An elevated 24-hour urine metanephrine is not associated with renal artery stenosis as this condition affects the renovascular system rather than catecholamine production.

Hyperthyroidism (Option D): Hyperthyroidism symptoms include weight loss, increased appetite, tremors, heat intolerance, palpitations, and sweating. However, an elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine is not associated with hyperthyroidism, and the symptoms are typically continuous rather than episodic.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a smoking history presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126mEq/L, AST:62, ALT:56, RBS:112 mg/dl, serum bilirubin of 0.8mg%, and a positive HIV test. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Legionella

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a severe form of pneumonia known as Legionnaires' disease.The presentation includes high-grade fever, cough, confusion, along with hyponatremia and elevated liver enzymes. It is a strict aerobe that is poorly stained with gram stain, explaining the negative gram stain results despite active infection. The patient's immunocompromised status (HIV positive) and age further increase the risk for Legionella infection.

Legionnaires' Disease

General Features
  • Incubation period: 2-10 days
  • Non-specific flu-like symptoms initially
  • Often more severe than typical pneumonia

Clinical Features

 

Respiratory

  • Dry cough
  • Shortness of breath
  • Chest pain

Systemic

  • High fever (102-105°F)
  • Headache
  • Myalgias
  • Fatigue

Gastrointestinal

  • Diarrhea
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Abdominal pain

Diagnosis

Laboratory Tests
  • Blood Analysis- Hyponatremia, Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Urinary Antigen- Most common test, rapid results, detects L. pneumophila serogroup-1
  • Culture- Gold standard, requires special media, takes 3-5 days
  • PCR

Imaging Findings

 
  • Chest X-ray: Focal infiltrates/consolidation, predominantly lower lobes
  • CT: Ground-glass opacities, consolidation, pleural effusions possible
  • Can be multilobar in immunocompromised patients

Treatment

 

Mild-Moderate Disease:

  • Azithromycin 500mg PO daily
  • Levofloxacin 750mg PO daily
  • Clarithromycin 500mg PO BID

Severe Disease:

  • Levofloxacin 750mg IV daily
  • Azithromycin 500mg IV daily
  • Consider combination therapy for severe cases

Streptococcus (Option A): Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, but it typically presents with a productive cough with rust-colored sputum. In this case, the sputum gram stain did not detect any organisms, making Streptococcus less likely. Additionally, the extrapulmonary symptoms are not typical for pneumococcal pneumonia.

Pneumocystis jiroveci (Option C): While the patient is HIV positive, the symptoms described and chest X-ray findings of bilateral infiltrates are not specific to Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia. PJP typically presents with a more gradual onset of dry cough and progressive dyspnea without the characteristic hyponatremia and liver enzyme elevation seen here. Also, chest X-ray shows pneumatoceles or thin-walled cysts and reticular opacities with septal thickening.

Klebsiella (Option D): Klebsiella causes pneumonia in individuals with a history of alcoholism or COPD. While the patient has a smoking history, the clinical presentation (including confusion and diarrhea) is inconsistent with Klebsiella pneumonia infection. Additionally, Klebsiella would typically be visible on gram stain.

questions.text: What is the serial interval?

choices.text: Time taken to develop a Primary case A
Time gap between entry of organism till maximum infectivity
Interval between Primary and secondary case
Time gap between onset till first detection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Interval between Primary and secondary case

Explanation:

  • The serial interval is the time between the onset of symptoms in the primary case (the first infected person) and the onset of symptoms in a secondary case (the person infected by the primary case). It is useful for understanding the transmission dynamics of an infectious disease.

 

Time taken to develop a Primary case (Option A): is incorrect because this refers to the incubation period or the time it takes for symptoms to develop after exposure to the pathogen, not the serial interval.

Time gap between entry of organism till maximum infectivity (Option B): is incorrect. This describes the infectious period or incubation period, not the serial interval.

Time gap between onset till first detection (Option D): is incorrect because this refers to the time to diagnosis or detection time, not the serial interval.

questions.text: Which barrier is the doctor addressing when a male patient expresses concern about potential impotency from the recommended vaccine during a vaccination drive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cultural barrier

Explanation:

  • The concern raised by the male patient regarding impotency due to a vaccine reflects a cultural barrier. This is a belief or misconception rooted in social and cultural influences that may cause hesitation or reluctance toward vaccination, even when scientific evidence supports the vaccine's safety and effectiveness.
  • Cultural barriers can stem from misinformation, myths, and stigmas related to vaccines that may be prevalent in a community or group.

 

Physical barrier (Option A): is incorrect because a physical barrier would refer to an actual, tangible impediment, such as poor access to healthcare facilities, not misconceptions or fears about side effects.

Environmental barrier (Option B): is incorrect as environmental barriers refer to external factors like pollution, poor infrastructure, or geographical challenges that hinder access to healthcare, which is not the case here.

Physiological barrier (Option C): is incorrect because physiological barriers would involve biological factors that prevent proper functioning or access to healthcare, such as allergies or medical conditions, not the cultural beliefs affecting the patient's attitude toward vaccination.

questions.text: Which stage of the demographic cycle has the highest birth and death rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Stage I

Explanation:

In Stage I of the demographic transition model, both birth rates and death rates are high. This stage is typically characterized by:

  • High birth rates due to limited access to contraception, cultural norms favoring large families, and high infant mortality.
  • High death rates due to poor sanitation, limited medical care, and high incidences of disease and famine.

Stage I is generally seen in pre-industrial societies, where population growth is slow and fluctuates due to high mortality rates.

Stage II (Option B): is incorrect because, in Stage II, death rates decline significantly due to improvements in healthcare, sanitation, and nutrition, while birth rates remain high, resulting in rapid population growth.

Stage III (Option C): is incorrect because, in Stage III, birth rates decline as a result of increased access to contraception, women's education, and urbanization, while death rates continue to decline, leading to a slower population growth.

Stage IV (Option D): is incorrect because, in Stage IV, both birth rates and death rates are low, and the population tends to stabilize or grow slowly, as seen in many developed countries today.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. Chest X-ray shows a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- CT-guided biopsy

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a suspicious lung mass requiring tissue diagnosis. CT-guided biopsy is the most appropriate next step given the peripheral location of the mass near the apex of the lung.
  • It is a minimally invasive procedure where a radiologist uses CT imaging to guide the insertion of a needle into the lung mass to obtain a tissue sample for analysis. The procedure provides accurate histopathological information about the nature of the mass, including whether it is cancerous or benign, which is crucial in a patient with significant smoking history and hemoptysis.

Evaluation for Suspected Lung Mass

Non-Invasive Diagnostic Methods

Sputum Cytology
  • Non-invasive initial diagnostic test
  • Most useful for central lesions (Option C Ruled Out)
  • Higher yield in large, proximal tumors
  • Low sensitivity due to high tissue variability

CT Chest
  • Contrast-enhanced
  • Extension to upper abdomen (adrenal level)
  • Sensitivity: 55%, Specificity: 81%
  • Identifies tumor location, extent, and lymph node involvement
  • Lymph node ≥1cm in short axis considered suspicious

PET/PET-CT
  • Higher accuracy than CT (Sensitivity: 80%, Specificity: 88%)
  • Identifies metabolic activity and potential metastases
  • Reduces futile thoracotomies
  • Helpful in identifying recurrence post-therapy

Invasive Staging & Biopsy Methods

CT-Guided Transthoracic Biopsy
  • Preferred for peripheral lesions (Option A)
  • High diagnostic accuracy
  • Minimally Invasive
  • Risk of pneumothorax (especially in emphysematous patients)
  • Contraindicated if high bleeding risk or severe emphysema

EBUS-TBNA
  • CP-EBUS: Real-time sampling of mediastinal/hilar nodes
  • RP-EBUS: For smaller/peripheral lesions
  • Navigation bronchoscopy for mapped approach

Endoscopic-TBNA
  • Samples through esophageal wall
  • Accesses stations 2, 4, 7, 8, 9
  • Sensitivity: 89%, Specificity: 100%

Mediastinoscopy
  • Used after negative needle technique
  • Samples para-tracheal nodes
  • Sensitivity: 78%, Specificity: 100%
  • Mortality risk: 0.08%

VATS/RATS
  • For mediastinal lymph node sampling
  • Full dissection during lung resection
  • Minimally invasive approach

 

Cancer Type

Location

Primary Investigations

Additional Investigations

Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) - Adenocarcinoma

Peripheral/Outer regions of lung
  • CT-guided needle biopsy
  • PET-CT scan
  • Blood tests for tumor markers (CEA)
  • Molecular testing (EGFR, ALK, ROS1)
  • MRI brain (for staging)
  • Pulmonary function tests

NSCLC - Squamous Cell

Central/Main bronchi
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • Chest CT with contrast
  • Sputum cytology
  • Mediastinoscopy
  • Bone scan (if symptoms)
  • PD-L1 testing

Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)

Central regions, rapid spread
  • CT chest/abdomen/pelvis
  • Bronchoscopy
  • Blood tests (ProGRP, NSE)
  • MRI brain (mandatory)
  • Bone marrow biopsy
  • Nuclear medicine scans

Large Cell Carcinoma

Any location
  • PET-CT scan
  • Core needle biopsy
  • Immunohistochemistry
  • Molecular profiling
  • EBUS-TBNA
  • Liquid biopsy

Carcinoid Tumors

Usually central airways
  • Octreotide scan
  • Bronchoscopy with biopsy
  • 24-hour urine 5-HIAA
  • Chromogranin A levels
  • MIBG scan
  • Endoscopic ultrasound

Bronchoscopy (Option A): While bronchoscopy can be useful in evaluating central lesions or endobronchial tumors, it may not be effective for evaluating peripheral lung masses, especially those located near the apex.

Sputum cytology (Option C): Sputum cytology is inexpensive and noninvasive but has a lesser sensitivity than biopsy, especially when there is a clear indication of a suspected lung mass on radiography. The yield for sputum cytology is highest for larger and centrally located tumors such as squamous cell carcinoma and small-cell carcinoma.

Sputum for AFB (Option D): While TB can cause hemoptysis, the appearance of a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex on chest X-ray is inconsistent with the typical presentation of TB and indicates a suspected malignancy for which a tissue diagnosis is more urgently needed.

questions.text: The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom should be
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) >10 sq. ft.

Explanation:

  • The ideal per capita space for students in a classroom is generally recommended to be greater than 10 square feet per student. This allows enough room for each student to sit comfortably and engage in classroom activities without feeling cramped.
  • This standard ensures that classrooms are not overcrowded, promoting a better learning environment.

 

>5 sq. ft. (Option A): is incorrect because this amount of space would be too small for students, making the classroom uncomfortable and impractical for learning.

>15 sq. ft. (Option C): is incorrect because while this would be spacious, it is not always necessary for most classrooms. It could be suitable for larger or more specialized classrooms but is not typically required for all settings.

>20 sq. ft. (Option D): is incorrect because this is even more space than needed for a regular classroom. Though spacious, it may lead to inefficient use of space and resources in most educational settings.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improves as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the probable cause of her headaches?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Pseudotumor cerebri

  • The clinical manifestations such as presence of characteristic headaches that worsen when lying down, papilledema on fundal examination, and the absence of focal neurological deficits indicate pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). This condition is characterized by increased intracranial pressure without any identifiable cause such as a tumor. The patient's use of oral contraceptives is a notable risk factor, as hormonal medications can contribute to the development of this condition.

Pseudotumor Cerebri / Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension

Definition

A disorder associated with elevated CSF pressure without obvious cause, commonly affecting young, obese females

Key Symptoms
  • Headache (worse on waking and with recumbency)
  • Visual disturbances (may be transient)
  • Can occur without visual problems
  • Worse in morning or after lying down
  • Pulsatile tinnitus may be present

Diagnostic Criteria
  • Elevated CSF pressure (>20-25 cm H2O)
  • Normal MRI/MRV findings
  • Normal neurological examination (except for papilledema)
  • Papilledema may be present (but not required for diagnosis)

Initial Treatment
  • Acetazolamide (250-500 mg)
  • Weight loss (if overweight)
  • Serial lumbar punctures may be needed
  • Regular ophthalmologic monitoring

Secondary Treatment
  • Topiramate
  • Other carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • CSF shunting procedures (if needed)
  • Weight loss management programs

Monitoring
  • Regular visual field testing
  • Ophthalmic examination
  • CSF pressure monitoring
  • Weight monitoring
  • Headache diary

Important Considerations
  • Fundoscopic exam should be performed even without overt ophthalmic involvement
  • Consider diagnosis in chronic migraine cases
  • May require long-term management
  • Early intervention is crucial for preventing vision loss

Myasthenia gravis (Option A) primarily presents with muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly affecting ocular and bulbar muscles. The absence of muscle weakness/headache and the presence of papilledema make this diagnosis unlikely.

Temporal arteritis (Option B) typically affects older adults over 50 years and presents with temporal headache, jaw claudication, and scalp tenderness. Also, the patient's presentation of papilledema is not a typical feature of Temporal arteritis.

Chronic migraine (Option C) is characterized by headaches occurring on 15 or more days per month for at least three months. While the timeframe is similar, the presence of papilledema and positional nature of the headache are not typical features of migraine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic tuberculosis was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition?

choices.text: Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

  • Cryptic tuberculosis is a rare and atypical presentation of tuberculosis where there is absence of both tuberculin skin test response (negative) and radiological findings on chest X-ray (negative), despite active Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.
  • The standard diagnostic tools - tuberculin skin test (which measures delayed hypersensitivity response to M. tuberculosis antigens) and chest X-ray (which typically shows parenchymal infiltrates) - may not detect tuberculosis infection in its cryptic form.
  • In its severe form, known as cryptic miliary TB, the condition can lead to pancytopenia and massive hematogenous dissemination, with postmortem findings revealing multiple necrotic, nongranulomatous lesions.

Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray (Option A) indicates a hypersensitivity response to M. tuberculosis without radiological evidence of active disease. This pattern typically suggests latent tuberculosis infection.

Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray (Option B) represents the classical presentation of active pulmonary tuberculosis with both immunological response and radiological changes. In Cryptic tuberculosis, both these findings are absent.

Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray (Option D) suggests active pulmonary disease without measurable immune response, commonly seen in immunocompromised states . While this can occur in some forms of TB, it does not represent cryptic tuberculosis where both tests are characteristically negative.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Gaisböck syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Hypotension

  • Gaisböck syndrome, primarily associated with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), is characterized by polycythemia secondary to chronic hypoxemia. The condition develops when the body responds to chronic hypoxemia by increasing erythropoietin production, leading to erythrocytosis.
  • The patients with this syndrome typically present with elevated blood pressure rather than hypotension, due to the underlying respiratory disease and increased blood viscosity.

Gaisböck syndrome

Key Clinical Features
  • High hematocrit levels
  • Erythrocytosis (Option B Ruled Out)
  • Normal leukocyte counts (Option C Ruled Out)
  • No splenomegaly
  • Hypertension
  • Facial rubor

Patient Characteristics
  • Predominantly affects males
  • Obese and anxious personality (Option D Ruled Out)
  • Often cigarette smokers

Risk Factors
  • Alcoholism
  • Diuretic therapy
  • Physical & Emotional stress
  • Obesity
  • Smoking

Pathophysiological Mechanisms
  • Psychiatric disorders causing chronic stress
  • Volume contraction (diuresis)
  • Hypertension
  • Nocturnal hypoxemia
  • Increased erythropoietin production

Complications
  • Formation of microthrombi
  • Cerebral infarction
  • Vascular disease

Treatment Approach
  • Management of hypertension
  • Weight reduction
  • Smoking cessation
  • Alcohol reduction/cessation
  • Stress management

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Constrictive pericarditis

  • Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pericardium leading to impaired cardiac filling. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of Kussmaul's sign (increased jugular venous distention during inspiration) and absence of murmur.
  • During inspiration, the rigid pericardium prevents normal cardiac expansion, causing exaggerated rise in venous pressure. The condition results from pericardial inflammation and fibrosis, which creates a restrictive envelope around the heart, limiting diastolic filling.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

atigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Aortic regurgitation (Option B) typically presents with a characteristic diastolic murmur, which is absent in this case. Additionally, aortic regurgitation does not cause increased neck vein distention with inspiration.

Tricuspid stenosis (Option C) presents with elevated jugular venous pressure, but also includes a diastolic murmur and does not demonstrate Kussmaul's sign. The jugular venous pressure in tricuspid stenosis remains constant or decreases with inspiration.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (Option D) can cause increased jugular venous pressure but does not demonstrate Kussmaul's sign. While it can cause right-sided heart failure symptoms, the characteristic inspiratory increase in neck vein distention is not a typical feature.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. Chest X-ray showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Cystic fibrosis

  • Cystic fibrosis is identified as the primary diagnosis based on the classical triad of symptoms presented. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum (indicating pulmonary involvement), bronchial wall thickening on chest X-ray, and steatorrhea since birth (indicating pancreatic insufficiency).
  • The condition is characterized by a genetic defect in the CFTR gene affecting chloride channels, resulting in thick secretions in multiple organ systems.

Pathological features of Cystic Fibrosis

Organ System

Pathological Features

Clinical Manifestations

Diagnostic Findings

Respiratory
  • Thick mucus plugging
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic inflammation
  • Submucosal gland hypertrophy
  • Chronic productive cough
  • Recurrent infections
  • Progressive dyspnea
  • Digital clubbing
  • Obstructive pattern on PFTs
  • Bronchiectasis on CT

Pancreatic
  • Duct obstruction
  • Acinar cell destruction
  • Fibrosis
  • Fat replacement
  • Malabsorption
  • Steatorrhea
  • Failure to thrive
  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiency
  • Low fecal elastase
  • Elevated fecal fat
  • Low vitamins A, D, E, K

Sweat Glands
  • Abnormal chloride transport
  • Normal gland structure
  • Salty-tasting skin
  • Heat intolerance
  • Salt depletion
  • Elevated sweat chloride
  • >60 mEq/L diagnostic

Hepatobiliary
  • Bile duct plugging
  • Focal biliary cirrhosis
  • Multilobular cirrhosis
  • Neonatal cholestasis
  • Portal hypertension
  • Gallstones
  • Elevated liver enzymes
  • Ultrasound changes

Hyaline membrane disease (Option A) primarily affects premature infants and presents immediately after birth with respiratory distress. This condition does not manifest with chronic respiratory infections or steatorrhea seen in this 5-year-old child.

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency (Option C) typically presents with progressive emphysema and liver disease but does not cause pancreatic insufficiency leading to steatorrhea.

Malabsorption syndrome (Option D) typically presents with steatorrhea, diarrhea, weight loss & various nutrient deficiencies but does not account for the specific respiratory manifestations present in this case. The combination of respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms points more specifically to cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: In a 60-year-old male, what is the primary etiology typically associated with Cushing's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Pituitary microadenoma

  • Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is most commonly caused by a pituitary microadenoma. This condition is characterized by a benign ACTH-secreting tumor in the pituitary gland, leading to hypercortisolism through increased ACTH production. The excessive ACTH stimulates the adrenal glands to produce higher levels of cortisol, resulting in the classic features of Cushing's syndrome.

Cushing's syndrome- Definition and Causes

Definition:
  • Cushing's syndrome is a collection of symptoms resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of glucocorticoids.
  • Cushing's disease specifically refers to Cushing's syndrome caused by a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.
  • It is relatively rare, but mild cases may be more common, particularly among those with symptoms like central obesity, type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis.

Causes:

Cushing's syndrome can be caused by various factors, categorised as ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

I) ACTH-dependent Cushing's Syndrome accounts for approximately 90% of cases.

  • Cushing's disease (ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma) is the most common cause.
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome occurs when a non-pituitary tumour secretes ACTH.

II) ACTH-independent Cushing's Syndrome constitutes the remaining 10% of cases.

  • Adrenocortical adenoma is the most prevalent cause, accounting for 5–10% of all cases.
  • Rare causes include:
    • Primary bilateral macronodular adrenal hyperplasia (PBMAH)
    • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease (PPNAD)
    • McCune-Albright syndrome

Small-cell lung cancer (Option A) can produce ACTH or ACTH-like substances, resulting in paraneoplastic Cushing's syndrome. However, it is not the most common cause of Cushing's disease in an elderly patient. Small-cell lung cancer typically presents with additional respiratory symptoms and a more rapid onset of hypercortisolism features.

Adrenal tumor (Option B) can cause Cushing's syndrome through autonomous cortisol production by either an adenoma or carcinoma. However, these tumors bypass the pituitary-adrenal axis and typically suppress ACTH levels, unlike the elevated ACTH seen in Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary microadenoma.

Ectopic ACTH syndrome (Option C) occurs when non-pituitary tumors (such as lung, pancreas, or thymus) produce ACTH. While this is a recognized cause of Cushing's syndrome, it is less common than pituitary microadenomas as the primary cause of Cushing's disease in older adults. Ectopic ACTH syndrome typically presents with more rapid onset and severe metabolic derangements.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family reported a previous history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor made a tentative diagnosis based on the clinical symptoms. What would be the most appropriate investigative method to establish a conclusive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C- Sestamibi scan

  • The clinical presentation suggests primary hyperparathyroidism, characterized by the triad of bone pain (from increased bone resorption), abdominal cramps (from hypercalcemia), and neuropsychiatric symptoms (manifesting as abnormal behavior).
  • Sestamibi scan is the preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas, which are the most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism.

Primary Hyperparathyroidism- Lab and Radiological findings

Lab Investigations

Serum calcium levels

Increased

Serum phosphate levels

Decreased

Serum alkaline phosphatase (SAP) levels

Increased

Serum PTH (parathyroid hormone) assay

Elevated PTH

Radiological features

Features

Image

Subperiosteal erosions and terminal resorption in the phalanges (usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side) along with bone demineralisation.

The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).

 

 

Brown tumour or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions in bone from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can lead to bone expansion, accompanied by bleeding and granulation tissue.

Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the parathyroid adenoma.

MRI (Option A) while capable of identifying soft tissue masses, is not the first-line imaging modality for parathyroid adenoma detection. MRI is more expensive, time-consuming, and does not offer any significant advantage over sestamibi scanning for parathyroid imaging.

Ultrasonogram (Option B) can identify parathyroid masses but has limitations in detecting ectopic parathyroid tissue and is highly operator-dependent. It may be used as a complementary imaging technique but is not the most sensitive primary diagnostic tool.

CT scan (Option D) provides detailed anatomical imaging but lacks the functional information provided by sestamibi scanning. While CT may be useful for surgical planning, it is not the initial imaging modality of choice for diagnosing parathyroid adenomas.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Dermatomyositis

  • The patient's presentation of proximal muscle weakness (difficulty with stairs, rising from chair, and hair combing) along with the pathognomonic violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids (heliotrope rash) suggest Dermatomyositis . This inflammatory myopathy typically affects middle-aged individuals and has a combination of muscle and skin involvement.

Dermatomyositis

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.
  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles
  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.

 

  • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin
  • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck
  • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back
  • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh
  • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers

Inclusion body myositis (Option A) primarily affects older people and typically presents with distal muscle weakness and asymmetric involvement. Unlike dermatomyositis, it does not have associated skin manifestations and tends to affect finger flexors and quadriceps preferentially.

Polymyositis (Option C) is an autoimmune inflammatory muscle disease that presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness. However, it lacks the characteristic skin manifestations seen in dermatomyositis, particularly the heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules.

Scleroderma (Option D) is a connective tissue disorder primarily affecting the skin and internal organs. While it can cause muscle weakness, its hallmark features are skin thickening and fibrosis, not the violaceous rash characteristic of dermatomyositis. It also presents with Raynaud's phenomenon and internal organ involvement.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Myasthenia gravis

  • The diagnosis for Myasthenia gravis is supported by the classic presentation of fatigable muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day (diurnal variation), ptosis, and positive response to neostigmine. The improvement with neostigmine, an Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor which increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction, is particularly diagnostic of myasthenia gravis.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Clinical Features
  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia
  • Weakness in oculomotor, pharyngeal, limb, neck extensors
  • Fluctuation and fatigue worse with activity, improved by rest
  • Fatiguability increases as the day passes (diurnal variation)
  • Initial symptoms frequently ocular (diplopia/ptosis)
  • Facial weakness produces "snarling" expression

Physical Examination
  • Eye movements and ptosis
  • Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities
  • Weakness following repetitive muscle activation
  • Normal deep tendon reflexes
  • No sensory abnormalities
  • Symptoms relieved by Anticholinesterases

Diagnostic Tests
  • Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% generalized MG)
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies (in ~40% of AChR-negative cases)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Single-fiber EMG
  • CT or MRI of chest (to evaluate thymus)

Clinical Tests
  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: 2mg + 8mg IV
  • Ice pack test for ptosis
  • Fatigue testing (repeated muscle activation)

Huntington chorea (Option B) is a genetic condition characterized by involuntary movements, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms. It does not present with ptosis or show diurnal variation, nor does it respond to neostigmine.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option C) presents with progressive muscle weakness, but lacks the characteristic diurnal variation seen in myasthenia gravis. ALS does not typically begin with ptosis and shows no improvement with neostigmine.

External ophthalmoplegia (Option D) can cause ptosis but does not demonstrate the distinctive pattern of fatigue and improvement with rest. Additionally, external ophthalmoplegia does not respond to neostigmine and lacks the diurnal variation characteristic of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Study of death in all aspects is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Thanatology

  • Thanatology deals with death in all aspects including somatic, systemic and clinical, and molecular or cellular death.

Thanatology:

  • Death and Dying: Examining the biological, physiological, and medical aspects of death, as well as the experiences, emotions, and psychological processes associated with dying.
  • Bereavement and Grief: Investigating the psychological, emotional, and social responses to the loss of a loved one, including theories of grief, coping mechanisms, and support for individuals experiencing bereavement.
  • End-of-Life Care: Exploring the ethical, legal, and practical considerations surrounding palliative care, hospice care, advance care planning, and the management of pain and symptoms in individuals nearing the end of life.
  • Cultural and Religious Perspectives: Investigating how different cultures, religions, and belief systems understand and approach death, funeral rituals, mourning practices, and concepts of afterlife or spiritual continuity.
  • Social and Legal Aspects: Examining the societal and legal frameworks surrounding death, including issues such as euthanasia, assisted suicide, funeral industry practices, organ donation, and legal rights and responsibilities related to death and dying.

Forensic anthropology (Option B): Forensic anthropology involves the study of human remains. It involves applying the skeletal analysis, descriptive data, body marks, and photographs of the individual together to get to forensic inferences.

Toxicology (Option C): Toxicology is the study of analysing suspect samples for the presence of toxins. It only deals with toxins that can be a cause of death- one aspect of death and not all of them.

Molecular death (Option D): Molecular death is the death of cells and tissues individually. It occurs one to two hours after the stoppage of the vital functions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. On examination, it is found that the patient has conductive hearing loss and the Rinne test results are negative. Additionally, a reddish mass is observed located behind the tympanic membrane. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glomus tumour

Explanation:

  • The symptoms of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus with a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane are consistent with glomus tumor.
  • The negative Rinne test indicates conductive hearing loss is also common in patients with glomus tumours.

 

Glomus tumor (Paraganglioma)

Definition

Tumors originating from the paraganglia are known as paragangliomas, with glomus tumors being a specific type of paraganglioma.

Tumour type

Benign (most common benign tumor of middle ear)

Origin

Paraganglionic cells or glomus bodies .

Prevalence

Commonly seen in middle-aged individuals (40-50 years), with a higher prevalence in females

Types

  1. Glomus tympanicum: Arise from the promontory of the middle ear (tympanic plexus).
  2. Glomus jugulare: Arises from the dome of the jugular bulb (sympathetic plexus covering the jugular vein).

Spread

  • Inferiorly: To the jugular foramen
  • Anteriorly: Invading into the nasopharynx (blockage of eustachian tube)
  • Posteriorly: Invading the mastoid
  • Superiorly: To the posterior and middle cranial fossa (IX-XII cranial nerve palsy)
  • Laterally: To the tympanic membrane (present as a bleeding polyp of the external auditory canal).
  • Medially: Invading the labyrinth and petrous pyramid (dizziness and facial palsy).

 

Clinical manifestations
  • Hearing loss (gradually progressive conductive hearing loss)
  • Pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat like sounds): It is synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Bleeding from ear (profuse bleeding in case of polyp)
  • Dizziness or vertigo and facial paralysis may appear.
  • Symptoms like headache, sweating, palpitation, hypertension, anxiety due to sympathetic excess (catecholamine release)

Histopathology

  • No capsule (locally invasive)
  • HPE reveals Zell Ballen pattern, where epithelioid chief cells and sustentacular supporting cells form clusters (Zell Ballen) encircled by extensive vascular sinusoids.
  • Preoperative biopsy of the tumour is not performed due to the risk of profuse bleeding from its highly vascular thin-walled blood sinusoids and potential injury to the high jugular bulb or aberrant internal carotid artery.

Otoscopy

  • Red reflex through intact tympanic membrane and bulging tympanic membrane (glomus tympanicum).
  • “Rising sun" appearance due to the tumor originating from the floor of middle ear (glomus jugulare).

Diagnosis

  • CECT (IOC) shows erosion of the carotico-jugular spine on the diseased side, known as Phelp’s sign.
  • MRI scan revealed microhemorrhages within the tumor which appear as white and gray dots on MRI, creating a "salt and pepper" appearance.
  • Angiography is used to identify the arteries supplying the tumor.

 

Acute otitis media (Option A): is less likely as it typically presents with ear pain, fever, and fluid or pus in the middle ear.

Chronic otitis media (Option B): may present with conductive hearing loss but is less likely to have a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

Serous otitis media (Option D): may cause conductive hearing loss, but it is typically not associated with pulsatile tinnitus and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: What is the amount of milk given to a term baby in the first 24 hours after delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 60ml/kg

In the first 24 hours after delivery, a term baby is typically given around 60ml of milk per kilogram of body weight. This amount is carefully calculated to:

  • Account for the newborn's small stomach size
  • Allow for the gradual increase in milk intake as the baby's digestive system continues to develop

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient is presented, as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mucormycosis

Explanation:

  • The image, coupled with the clinical context of an elderly diabetic female, strongly suggests Mucormycosis as the most probable diagnosis.
  • The image shows black necrotic tissue near the orbit, which is characteristic of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis.

 

Mucormycosis
  • It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus

Absidia

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained)

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. 

 b.

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b.Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

 

Aspergillosis (Option A):

  • is a fungal infection affecting the nasal cavity, sinuses, and lungs.
  • In the nasal cavity, it may appear as a white, fluffy, or mold-like growth on the mucosal lining.
  • In the sinuses, it may cause thick mucus or pus-like discharge
  • in the lungs, it can cause fungal balls in pre-existing cavitary lesions.

Foreign body (Option C): A foreign body in the nose may present as unilateral nasal discharge, foul odor, and occasionally epistaxis (nosebleed). On physical examination, the foreign body may be visible in the nasal cavity and appear as small objects or debris.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D): is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by a parasite, Rhinosporidium seeberi. It typically presents as a pedunculated or sessile polypoidal mass arising from the nasal mucosa. The mass is usually pink or red in color and may bleed on manipulation.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a neonate presenting with frothing from the mouth and respiratory distress, with the X-ray provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula

  • The clinical manifestations indicate esophageal atresia with tracheo-esophageal fistula (TEF). The diagnosis is supported by the characteristic presentation of frothiness from the mouth and respiratory distress, along with the pathognomonic X-ray finding of a coiled tube in the upper esophagus.
  • This condition results from disrupted embryonic development of the trachea and esophagus.
  • TEF commonly presents with frothing and bubbling at the mouth and nose, coughing, cyanosis, and respiratory distress that worsens with feeding. The condition is often associated with VACTERL anomalies.

Tracheoesophageal fistula

Causes
  • Embryology: Disruption during embryonic development of the trachea and oesophagus.
  • Genetic Factors: Associated with syndromes like Feingold syndrome, CHARGE syndrome, and anophthalmia-esophageal-genital syndrome.
  • Unknown Etiology: Factors such as advanced maternal age, ethnicity, obesity, low socioeconomic status, and smoking may be involved.

Types of TEF
  • Type A: Isolated oesophagal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type B: Esophageal atresia with proximal tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type C: Proximal oesophagal atresia with distal tracheoesophageal fistula
  • Type D: Esophageal atresia with both proximal and distal tracheoesophageal fistulas
  • Type E: Isolated tracheoesophageal fistula without associated oesophagal atresia

Presentation
  • Classic Symptoms: Frothing and bubbling at the mouth and nose, coughing, cyanosis, respiratory distress exacerbated by feeding.
  • Aspiration Pneumonia: More severe with distal fistula.
  • H-Type Fistula: Chronic respiratory issues, bronchospasm, recurrent pneumonia in isolated cases.

Diagnosis
  • Esophagogram
  • Chest X-ray shows a gas-filled or gasless abdomen and a coiled tube in the upper oesophagus.

Management
  • Immediate Care: Maintain airway patency, prevent aspiration, and use antibiotics.
  • Surgical Repair: Standard involves ligation of TEF and primary end-to-end anastomosis.
  • Alternative Approaches: Delayed primary closure, fistula ligation, gastrostomy tube placement, or using gastric, jejunal, or colonic segments if the gap >3-4 cm.

Complications
  • Respiratory Complications: Risk of aspiration pneumonia.
  • Esophageal Complications: Feeding difficulties, failure to thrive.
  • Associated Anomalies: Often part of VACTERL association (vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, limb).

Prognosis
  • Improved Outcomes: Better survival rates due to advancements in care.
  • Long-Term Complications: Potential issues include feeding difficulties, esophageal strictures, and respiratory problems.

Transient tachypnea of newborn (Option A) presents with mild respiratory distress that improves within 24-72 hours after birth. The X-ray shows normally inflated or hyperinflated lungs with streaky perihilar markings and a shaggy heart border with clear lung periphery. This condition is self-limiting and typically resolves spontaneously.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (Option B) demonstrates characteristic X-ray findings of cyst-like structures (bowel loops) in the left hemithorax with mediastinal shift to the right and a relatively gasless abdomen. This condition results from a developmental defect in the diaphragm allowing abdominal contents to enter the thoracic cavity.

Respiratory distress syndrome (Option D) typically affects premature infants and develops within 24 hours of birth. The X-ray shows hypoaeration with bilateral fine granular opacities and prominent air bronchograms. This condition is caused by surfactant deficiency and primarily affects premature infants.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms does a patient with Reinke's edema classically present with?

choices.text: Dysphagia of liquids more than solids
Dysphagia of solids more than liquids

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Dysphonia

Explanation:

 

 

Dysphonia (altered voice quality) is the hallmark presentation of Reinke's edema

  • Patients often have a deep, husky, or rough voice due to the edema affecting the vibration of the vocal cords.

Reinke's Edema

  • Causes:
    • Chronic vocal cord irritation (voice misuse, heavy smoking). Aka smokers larynx
    • Chronic sinusitis, laryngopharyngeal reflux.
    • Myxoedema
    • More common in middle-aged men and women.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Hoarseness or husky voice.
    • Use of false vocal cords for voice production, leading to a low-pitched, rough voice.
  • Examination:
    • Laryngoscopy: Fusiform swelling of vocal cords with a pale, translucent appearance.
    • Ventricular bands may be hyperaemic and hypertrophic, obscuring true cords.
  • Treatment:
    • Decortication of vocal cords: Removal of a strip of epithelium, first on one side, then the other after 3-4 weeks.
    • Voice rest
    • Speech therapy: To improve proper voice production.

Diplophonia (Option A): A condition where two different pitches are heard simultaneously during phonation. It's more specific to vocal fold lesions but not classically seen in Reinke's edema.

Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option C): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema,

Dysphagia of liquids or solids (Option D): is not a symptom associated with Reinke's edema

questions.text: What kind of family would the surveyor categorize the household as, considering it consists of a 35-year-old man, his 6-week pregnant wife, a 3-year old child, and the temporary presence of the man's brother and his wife during their winter vacation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nuclear family

Explanation:

  • A nuclear family consists of parents and their children living together in the same household. In this scenario, the 35-year-old man, his 6-week pregnant wife, and their 3-year-old child form the core of the family, which is characteristic of a nuclear family.
  • Although the man's brother and his wife are temporarily staying with them, their presence is temporary and does not alter the classification of the family type.

 

Joint family (Option A): is incorrect because a joint family typically includes multiple generations (e.g., grandparents, uncles, aunts) living together. In this case, only the nuclear family members are mentioned, and the brother's presence is temporary.

Extended family (Option C): is incorrect because an extended family usually refers to a family structure that includes additional relatives beyond the nuclear family, such as uncles, aunts, grandparents, and cousins, either living together or in close proximity. The brother's presence is temporary and does not fit this definition.

Third generation family (Option D): is incorrect because this term generally refers to families that consist of the grandparents, parents, and children living together. There is no indication in the scenario that grandparents are involved, so it does not fit the description.

questions.text: What is the fluid of choice for shock in a child with severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose

  • The clinical scenario indicates the need for appropriate fluid management in severe acute malnutrition (SAM) with shock.
  • WHO recommends Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose as the fluid of choice for treating shock in SAM. This combination addresses both the need for electrolyte replacement and glucose supplementation, which are crucial in managing shock in malnourished children.

Management of Severe Acute Malnutrition

Step

Diagnosis

Initial Management

Monitoring

1. Treat/Prevent Hypoglycemia

Blood glucose <54 mg/dL (3 mmol/L)

Asymptomatic:

  • 50 mL of 10% glucose/sucrose orally/NG
  • Follow with first feed
  • F-75 starter diet every 2 hours

Symptomatic:

  • 10% dextrose IV 5 mL/kg
  • Follow with 50 mL 10% glucose via NG tube
  • Start antibiotics immediately
  • Blood glucose every 30 minutes until stable
  • Level of consciousness
  • Vital signs every 2 hours
  • Feed intake volume
  • Signs of deterioration

2. Treat/Prevent Hypothermia

Temperature <35.5°C (rectal) or <35°C (axillary)

Immediate interventions:

  • Warm clothing with head cover
  • Skin-to-skin contact with mother
  • Warm room (25-30°C)
  • Warm feeds
  • Overhead warmer/heat convector

Avoid:

  • Rapid rewarming
  • Direct heat sources
  • Prolonged exposure
  • Temperature every 30 minutes until >36.5°C
  • Then every 2 hours until >37.5°C
  • Watch for overheating
  • Monitor blood glucose
  • Check for infection signs

3. Treat/Prevent Dehydration

Clinical signs:

  • Thirst
  • Sunken eyes
  • Reduced skin turgor
  • Weak pulses
  • Cold extremities

ReSoMal administration:

  • 5-10 mL/kg/hour for first 12 hours
  • Maximum 12 hours for rehydration
  • Replace ongoing losses

If shock present:

  • Ringer's lactate with 5% dextrose
  • 15 mL/kg over first hour
  • Reassess and repeat if needed

Every 30 minutes for first 2 hours:

  • Pulse rate
  • Respiratory rate
  • Urine output
  • Stool frequency
  • Signs of overhydration
  • Mental status

4. Correct Electrolyte Imbalance

Common abnormalities:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Excess total body sodium
  • Metabolic acidosis

Potassium supplementation:

  • 3-4 mEq/kg/day
  • Continue for 2 weeks

Magnesium:

  • Day 1: 0.3 mL/kg IM (max 2 mL)
  • Then 0.8-1.2 mEq/kg/day oral

Restrict sodium intake
  • Daily electrolytes
  • ECG if severe hypokalemia
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Urine output
  • Mental status changes

5. Treat/Prevent Infection

Screen for:

  • Sepsis
  • Pneumonia
  • UTI
  • TB
  • HIV
  • Malaria in endemic areas

First-line antibiotics:

  • Ampicillin 50 mg/kg 6 hourly
  • Gentamicin 7.5 mg/kg daily

If no improvement in 48h:

  • Cefotaxime 100-150 mg/kg/day
  • or Ceftriaxone 50-75 mg/kg/day
  • Temperature
  • Respiratory rate
  • Heart rate
  • Clinical response
  • Culture results
  • Inflammatory markers

6. Micronutrient Supplementation

Common deficiencies:

  • Vitamin A
  • Zinc
  • Iron
  • Folic acid
  • Copper
  • Other vitamins/minerals

Vitamin A (Day 1):

  • 6-12 months: 100,000 IU
  • >12 months: 200,000 IU

Daily supplements:

  • Folic acid 1mg/day
  • Zinc 2mg/kg/day
  • Copper 0.2-0.3 mg/kg/day
  • Iron 3mg/kg/day (after stabilization)
  • Clinical signs of deficiency
  • Response to therapy
  • Weight gain
  • Appetite improvement
  • Complications

7. Initiate Feeding

Assessment:

  • Appetite
  • Ability to feed
  • Complications
  • Metabolic status

Initial feeding:

  • F-75 formula (75 kcal/100 mL)
  • Start 80 kcal/kg/day
  • Increase to 100 kcal/kg/day
  • 2-hourly feeds initially

Volume per feed:

11 mL/kg/feed initially
  • Feed tolerance
  • Volume consumed
  • Weight changes
  • Edema
  • Vomiting/diarrhea
  • Refeeding syndrome

8. Catch-up Growth

Indicators for transition:

  • Return of appetite
  • Reduced/resolved edema
  • Metabolic stability
  • Infection control

Transition to F-100:

  • Increase to 150-200 kcal/kg/day
  • Protein 4-6 g/kg/day
  • 6 feeds per day
  • Gradual volume increase

Target weight gain: >10 g/kg/day
  • Daily weight
  • Height weekly
  • MUAC weekly
  • Appetite
  • Clinical status
  • Feed intake

9. Sensory Stimulation

Assess:

  • Developmental status
  • Interaction level
  • Physical capabilities
  • Emotional state

Daily activities:

  • Structured play 15-30 min
  • Physical activity as tolerated
  • Emotional support
  • Mother-child bonding
  • Age-appropriate stimulation
  • Development progress
  • Activity level
  • Social interaction
  • Emotional response
  • Motor skills

10. Prepare for Follow-up

Discharge criteria:

  • No edema x 2 weeks
  • Weight-for-height > -2 SD
  • Good appetite
  • Clinically well
  • Completed immunizations

Discharge planning:

  • Family education
  • Follow-up schedule
  • Community health worker linkage
  • Emergency care plan
  • Nutrition counseling

Post-discharge:

  • Weekly follow-up initially
  • Monthly weight checks
  • Growth monitoring
  • Development assessment
  • Immunization status

Normal saline (Option A) provides only sodium chloride without any glucose component. In SAM, hypoglycemia is a common complication, and using normal saline alone fails to address it. Additionally, the high chloride content may worsen metabolic acidosis.

Ringer lactate (Option B) alone, while providing better electrolyte balance than normal saline, does not address the hypoglycemia. These children have depleted glycogen stores and require glucose supplementation.

10% dextrose (Option C) provides only glucose without addressing the electrolyte requirements crucial in shock management. Using pure dextrose solution can worsen electrolyte imbalances and fail to provide adequate volume resuscitation needed in shock.

questions.text: Which government program aims to provide health checkups and services for children aged 0-18, including a focus on those not attending school?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram

Explanation:

  • The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakaram (RBSK) is a government initiative aimed at providing health checkups and services to children aged 0-18 years, including those who are not attending school. The program focuses on identifying and addressing health issues, such as congenital abnormalities, disabilities, and malnutrition, ensuring early intervention and appropriate treatment.

 

Janani Suraksha Yojna (Option B): is incorrect because Janani Suraksha Yojna primarily focuses on providing safe motherhood, promoting institutional deliveries, and reducing maternal and neonatal mortality, rather than addressing the health needs of children aged 0-18 years.

Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (Option C): is incorrect because Navjaat Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram focuses on ensuring newborn survival by providing immediate care at the time of birth and focusing on newborn health rather than a comprehensive child health program for the 0-18 age group.

Mid Day Meal Program (Option D): is incorrect because the Mid Day Meal Program focuses on providing nutritious meals to children in schools, particularly to promote enrollment and retention, and does not cover comprehensive health checkups and services for children outside of school.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match for ABCD according to pediatric advanced life support?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Dehydration

  • Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS) uses the ABCD approach to manage pediatric emergencies.

ABCD stands for:

  • A = Airway (Option A)
  • B = Breathing (Option B)
  • C = Circulation (Option C)
  • D = Disability

Dehydration is not part of the ABCD approach in PALS, although it can be a concern in pediatric emergencies.

Components of PALS Assessment:

  • Airway: Assess airway patency (open/patent, unobstructed/obstructed) and determine if the patient will need assistance maintaining their airway
  • Breathing: Assess respiratory rate, respiratory effort, lung sounds, airway sounds, chest movement, and oxygen saturation via pulse oximetry
  • Circulation: Assess heart rate, heart rhythm, pulses, skin color, skin temperature, capillary refill time, and blood pressure
  • Disability: Assess neurological function with the AVPU pediatric response scale (alert, voice, painful, unresponsive), pediatric Glasgow Coma Scale (eye opening, motor response, verbal response), pupil response to light (normal, pinpoint, dilated, unilateral dilated), and blood glucose test (hypoglycemia can cause altered mental status)
  • Exposure: Assess temperature, signs of trauma (cuts, bleeding, bruises, burns, etc.), and skin (petechiae, purpura, etc.)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a 5-year-old girl presented to the clinic with symptoms of fever, cough, red eyes, running nose, and rash, as depicted in the image of the child's appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Measles

  • The patient's presentation with fever, cough, red eyes, and running nose with the image showing Koplik spots on buccal mucosa is suggestive of measles.

Measles

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

 

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

Mumps (Option A) primarily presents with parotid gland swelling and does not have the characteristic progression of respiratory symptoms and rash seen in this case. The absence of parotid involvement makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Chickenpox (Option C) typically presents with vesicular lesions in different stages of development and does not have the prodromal respiratory symptoms or Koplik spots. The rash in chickenpox is characteristically pruritic and appears in crops.

Erythema infectiosum (Option D) presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" appearance and lace-like rash on the trunk, without the prodromal symptoms or Koplik spots seen in this case. The absence of the typical facial rash pattern rules out this condition.

questions.text: A child presents with the findings shown in the image below. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Kwashiorkor due to protein malnutrition

The image showing a swollen abdomen and a dull-looking face is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

  • Kwashiorkor is a type of protein-energy malnutrition that can occur in children with inadequate protein intake
  • The disease is characterized by a swollen belly, a dull face, and edema in the limbs
  • Low serum protein and albumin levels can lead to edema in Kwashiorkor

Comparison between Kwashiorkor and Marasmus:

Kwashiorkor

Marasmus

Pitting Edema: Characterized by swelling, often starting in the legs and feet, leaving a persistent indentation when pressed.

Severe Wasting: The child appears extremely thin, with prominent bones and little body fat.

Sugar Baby Appearance: The child may look deceptively healthy due to oedema, despite being malnourished.

Monkey Facies: A sunken appearance of the cheeks due to loss of fat, giving an aged look.

Muscle Wasting: Despite the swollen appearance, muscle loss is present, leading to weakness and hypotonia.

Baggy Pants Appearance: Loose, sagging skin around the buttocks caused by significant muscle and fat loss.

Mental and Neurological Symptoms: The child is apathetic, irritable, and may have feeding difficulties.

Alertness: Children with marasmus remain mentally alert.

Hair Changes: Hair may lose colour, become thin, and show alternating bands of colour ("flag sign").

Absence of Edema: Unlike kwashiorkor, marasmus does not involve swelling or oedema.

Skin Changes: Includes hyperpigmentation, peeling skin ("flaky paint" appearance), and colour changes, particularly in the buttocks, perineum, and thighs.

Hypoglycemia Risk: The liver's reduced capacity to produce glucose increases the risk of low blood sugar.

Gastrointestinal Issues: Anorexia, vomiting, and abdominal distension. Anaemia is present due to nutritional deficiencies.

Hypothermia Risk: The child may struggle to maintain body temperature due to energy depletion.

 

Kwashiorkor due to calorie malnutrition (Option B) is incorrect as kwashiorkor is primarily a protein deficiency condition, though calories may also be deficient. The characteristic edema is linked to hypoalbuminemia rather than caloric deficiency.

Marasmus (Option C & D) does not match the presentation as marasmus presents with severe wasting, "monkey facies", baggy pants appearance and absence of edema. These children typically appear extremely thin with prominent bones. The presence of edema and swollen abdomen rules out this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought for evaluation of short stature. His height is comparable with his parent’s height and his bone age corresponds to his chronological age. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Familial short stature

  • The clinical presentation indicates familial short stature, which is characterized by height below the 3rd percentile for age and sex but is normal according to the child's genetic potential, as determined by parental heights.
  • Key features supporting this diagnosis include bone age matching chronological age and height being consistent with parental heights, suggesting genetic rather than pathological short stature.

Characteristics of Familial Short Stature:

  • Child's height is <3rd percentile of expected according to age & sex, but is normal as per his target height
  • Child has normal puberty
  • Family history of short stature
  • Bone age = chronological age

Constitutional delay (Option B): In constitutional growth delay, the child presents with delayed bone age and delayed puberty, unlike this case where bone age matches chronological age. Most of these children tend to eventually grow to approximately the same height as their parents.

Undernutrition (Option C): Undernutrition shows evidence of poor weight gain and delayed bone age, which are absent in this case. Nutritional deficiency would affect both growth and skeletal maturation, leading to discrepancy between bone age and chronological age.

Growth hormone deficiency (Option D): Growth hormone deficiency, also known as dwarfism or pituitary dwarfism, typically presents with severe growth failure, delayed bone age, and height that is significantly below parental heights.

questions.text: What is the interpretation of the given pedigree chart?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Autosomal dominant

Explanation:

  • The interpretation of the pedigree chart given reveals Autosomal dominant inheritance, which means that an individual only needs one copy of the mutated gene to express the condition.
  • Affected individuals appear in every generation, as one parent passes on the mutated gene to their offspring.
  • Both males and females can be affected equally because the gene is located on one of the autosomes.
  • If an affected person has children, there is a 50% chance that each child will inherit the mutated gene and be affected.


Autosomal Recessive (Option B) inheritance is where the Individuals usually do not express the trait unless they inherit two copies of the mutation. This inheritance pattern typically has horizontal transmission and skip generations in between.

 

X-linked recessive (Option C) disorders affect males more than females because males have only one X chromosome. Females need two copies of the mutation to be affected. Additionally, X-linked recessive disorders often show a pattern where affected males pass the mutated gene to all their daughters but none of their sons.

X-linked dominant (Option D) inheritance means an affected female can pass the condition to both sons and daughters, while an affected male passes it to all daughters but none of his sons. The question contradicts this pattern, so X-linked dominant is not the correct answer.

questions.text: In order to investigate the dietary habits of the diverse population residing in the urban region of Delhi, a research study is being conducted. Which of the following methods can be utilized to acquire a representative sample for the study?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stratified random sampling

Explanation:

  • In a diverse population, such as the one in urban Delhi, stratified random sampling is an effective method to ensure that different subgroups (or strata) of the population are represented in the sample.
  • In this case, the population can be divided into subgroups based on factors like socioeconomic status, age, dietary preferences, or geographic location within the urban region.
  • After dividing the population into strata, random samples are then taken from each group, ensuring that the sample is representative of the entire population.

 

Cluster random sampling (Option A): is incorrect because cluster sampling is used when the population is divided into clusters, often geographically, and entire clusters are randomly selected. While this can be used in large-scale studies, it doesn't specifically ensure representation of the diverse subgroups within the population as well as stratified sampling.

Simple random sampling (Option C): is incorrect because simple random sampling involves selecting individuals from the entire population randomly without considering any subgroups. While it may still give a sample, it may not adequately represent the diverse dietary habits of the population in urban Delhi.

Systematic random sampling (Option D): is incorrect because systematic random sampling involves selecting every nth individual from a list or a sequence of individuals. While it's easier to implement, it doesn't ensure that different groups within the population are represented as effectively as stratified sampling.

questions.text: Giving class in a village for wound care after a dog bite by enacting it is which mode of health communication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Demonstration

Explanation:

  • Demonstration involves showing or enacting a process, technique, or skill in a visual and practical manner to the audience. In this case, by enacting wound care for a dog bite, the instructor is visually demonstrating the proper technique to the participants, making it an effective mode of communication.

 

Lecture (Option A): is incorrect because a lecture involves verbally delivering information to an audience, typically in a one-way communication format, without the hands-on, visual demonstration of the technique.

Group discussion (Option B): is incorrect because group discussion involves interactive exchange of ideas among participants, rather than a direct demonstration of a technique.

Flash cards (Option C): is incorrect because flashcards are visual aids that are typically used to present information in a simplified manner, but they don't involve enacting or demonstrating a process like wound care.

questions.text: Gonadal growth corresponds with _____.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Skeletal system

  • Gonadal growth corresponds with skeletal growth, particularly during puberty
  • Estrogen in females and testosterone in males play a significant role in developing secondary sexual characteristics and contribute to the growth and maturation of the skeleton
  • This hormonal influence leads to changes in bone structure and overall height

Brain (Option A) growth follows a different pattern, with rapid growth occurring primarily in early childhood and reaching almost adult size by age 6 years. This pattern differs significantly from gonadal development.

Lymphoid growth (Option C) follows a unique pattern with peak development occurring before puberty and then involuting, unlike gonadal growth which accelerates during puberty. Lymphoid tissue reaches 200% of adult size during childhood.

Dental growth (Option D) follows its own distinct timeline with two separate periods of development - primary and permanent dentition. This pattern does not correspond with gonadal development patterns.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with a headache and thick nasal discharge, and upon examination, shows hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate with a mulberry appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypertrophic rhinitis

Explanation:

  • Hypertrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by inflammation and thickening of the nasal mucosa, often due to prolonged irritation (e.g., allergies, infection, or pollutants).
  • The mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate is a hallmark of hypertrophic rhinitis, caused by nodular swellings on the turbinates.
  • Symptoms like headache and thick nasal discharge are common due to nasal obstruction and secondary infections.

 

Hypertrophic Rhinitis

  • Cause: Progression from untreated chronic simple rhinitis, leading to repeated infections and submucosal fibrosis, causing turbinate hypertrophy.
  • Commonly Affected Turbinate:
    • Inferior turbinate – develops a mulberry appearance.
  • Primary Symptom:
    • Nasal obstruction (due to fibrosis).
