  • Management: Nasal obstruction due to fibrosis requires turbinate size reduction via partial or total turbinectomy.
    • Turbinectomy (partial or total): To reduce the size of hypertrophied turbinates.
    • Methods include:
      • Laser surgery.
      • Cryosurgery.
      • Diathermy.
      • Radiofrequency ablation.
      • Surgical submucous resection of turbinate.

 

Atrophic rhinitis (Option A): is a condition in which the nasal mucosa thins and dries out, leading to foul-smelling nasal discharge, crusting, and obstruction. The symptoms are not consistent with those seen in the patient.

Common cold (Option B): Is a viral infection that affects the upper respiratory tract. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, runny nose, and sore throat.

Nasal polyp (Option D):

  • are benign growths that arise from the lining of the nose or sinuses.
  • They can lead to symptoms such as nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, and reduced sense of smell.
  • While they may cause nasal discharge, the mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate is not a feature of nasal polyps.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman who has the thalassemia trait visits the clinic for genetic counselling. Her husband is also confirmed to have the thalassemia trait. Considering their genetic background, what is the likelihood of their next offspring having thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 25%

Explanation:

  • There is a 25% chance that their child will inherit the genotype β⁰/β⁰, corresponding to β-thalassemia major.
  • Mother's Genotype: β/β⁰ (carrier for β-thalassemia)
  • Father's Genotype: β/β⁰ (carrier for β-thalassemia)

Punnett Square Analysis
 

β

β⁰

β

β/β

β/β⁰

β⁰

β/β⁰

β⁰/β⁰
  • Possible Outcomes:
    1. β/β (Normal): 25%
    2. β/β⁰ (Carrier): 50%
    3. β⁰/β⁰ (β-thalassemia major): 25%

questions.text: According to the neonatal resuscitation protocol, below what heart rate are chest compressions initiated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 60

  • According to the Neonatal Resuscitation Program (NRP) protocol, chest compressions should be initiated when the heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute despite adequate ventilation.

NRP Neonatal Chest Compressions Guidelines

Indications
  • Heart rate below 60/min despite 30 seconds of PPV
  • Continue until heart rate is 60/min or more

Technique
  • Two-thumb technique is preferred
  • Thumbs depress lower third of sternum
  • Hands encircle torso with fingers supporting back
  • Avoid using xiphisternum
  • Thumbs remain in contact during compression and release

Depth & Rate
  • Compress chest three times
  • One breath for ventilation
  • Use 3:1 ratio (compression:ventilation)
  • Complete cycle in 2 minutes
  • Check femoral or carotid pulse periodically

Evaluation
  • Check heart rate after 60 seconds of CC
  • HR below 60: Continue CC with PPV and medications
  • HR 60 or above: Stop CC, continue PPV until HR >100 and spontaneous breathing

Important Considerations
  • Must always accompany with BMV (bag-mask ventilation)
  • Only oxygenated blood should be circulated
  • Ventilate between compressions
  • Positive breath should follow every third CC

Complications
  • Broken ribs
  • Liver laceration
  • Pneumothorax

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the effect of the mutation causing sickle cell anaemia?

choices.text: Glutamate by valine at the 6th position
Valine by glutamate at the 6th position
Glutamate by valine at the 5th position
Valine by glutamate at the 5th position

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Glutamate by valine at the 6th position

Explanation:

  • Sickle cell anaemia is caused by a point mutation that involves substituting adenine for thymine at the sixth codon of the β-globin gene (GAG to GTG), replacing glutamic acid (glutamate) with valine in the β-globin chain of haemoglobin.
  • This single nucleotide change results in the formation of abnormal haemoglobin molecules (HbS).
  • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
  • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocytes, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sensitive and specific marker of intestinal inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fecal lactoferrin

Explanation:

  • Faecal lactoferrin is a sensitive and specific marker for intestinal inflammation, particularly in conditions like inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD).
  • It is a glycoprotein released by the neutrophils.
  • Fecal calprotectin and Fecal lactoferrin are both non-invasive biomarkers used to assess intestinal inflammation.
  • They are particularly useful in the diagnosis and monitoring of IBD and in identifying and separating between inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and non-inflammatory conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Incorrect Options:

Procalcitonin (Option A) is a biomarker produced in response to bacterial infections, particularly sepsis. It's used to monitor bacterial infections and guide antibiotic therapy. It is not specific for intestinal inflammation.

Tissue transglutaminase IgA (Option C) is an antibody commonly used in the diagnosis of celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to intestinal damage. It is not a marker for general intestinal inflammation.

High-sensitivity C-reactive protein (Option D) is a more sensitive version of CRP, often used to assess the risk of coronary artery disease. It increases in response to generalised inflammation and does not specifically pinpoint conditions like IBD.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with CSF otorrhea?

choices.text: Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane
Fracture of the roof of the nose

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Battle sign

Explanation:

  • CSF otorrhea is a condition where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks out of the skull through the ear.
  • Battle sign is a physical finding that occurs with CSF leakage into the mastoid air cells from a fracture of the temporal bone.
  • Battle sign is bruising over the mastoid process, which is generally brought on by head trauma.

CSF Rhinorrhea

  • Leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) into the nose.
  • Can present as clear fluid or mixed with blood, especially in acute head injuries.

Common Sites of CSF Rhinorrhea

Anterior cranial fossa

Middle cranial fossa

Temporal bone fracture
  • Cribriform plate(most common)
  • Roof of ethmoid air cells
  • Frontal sinus

Sphenoid sinus(following trauma)

CSF reaches the middle ear, escaping through the eustachian tube into the nose(CSF otorhinorrhea)

Aetiology

  • Trauma(Most common): Accidental or surgical (e.g., sinus surgery, nasal polypectomy, skull base surgery).
  • Inflammations: Mucocoeles, fungal infections, osteomyelitis, sinus polyposis.
  • Neoplasms: Benign and malignant tumours invading the skull base.
  • Congenital: Meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, gliomas with skull base defects.
  • Idiopathic: Spontaneous leaks with no known cause.

Investigations for CSF Rhinorrhea

  • Handkerchief test (Halo sign): Simple bedside test; CSF forms clear halo around blood spot.
  • Beta-2 transferrin: Gold standard biochemical test; highly specific for CSF.
  • High-Resolution CT (HRCT): Identifies bony defects in skull base.
  • CT Cisternography: Contrast-enhanced; precise localization of active CSF leaks.
  • MRI Cisternography: Non-invasive; useful for identifying meningoceles/encephaloceles.
  • Fluorescein Test: Intrathecal dye injection; helps in intraoperative leak localization.

Traumatic rupture of the tympanic membrane, Penetrating injury to the eye, and Fracture of the roof of the nose (Options B, C, and D): are not typically associated with CSF otorrhea.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the clinic by her mother with reduced hearing for the past 2-3 months. The otoscopy finding is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hemorrhagic Myringitis bullosa

Explanation:

  • Hemorrhagic bullae (fluid-filled blisters with blood) on the tympanic membrane (as seen in the otoscopy image) are characteristic of Myringitis bullosa.
  • The cause is a viral or bacterial infection.
  • Symptoms commonly include sudden otalgia (ear pain), reduced hearing, and sometimes bloody otorrhea if the blisters rupture.

 

 

Otitis Externa Haemorrhagica/Bullous Myringitis/Myringitis Bullosa

  • Cause:
    • Most common: Streptococcus pneumoniae
    • Others: Influenza virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Clinical Features:
    • Severe otalgia (ear pain)
    • Ear discharge
    • Hemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane (TM) and deep external auditory meatus
  • Management:
    • Systemic antibiotics
    • Antibiotic ear drops

 

Serous otitis media (Option B): is a condition where fluid accumulates in the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can cause mild to moderate hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

Acute otitis media (Option C): is an infection of the middle ear that causes ear pain, fever, and sometimes discharge from the ear.

Myringitis granulosa (Option D): is a condition where there are multiple small nodules or granulations on the tympanic membrane, causing hearing loss and pain. It is a rare condition and is often associated with other ear disorders, such as chronic otitis media.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis, and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed, which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained, and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aschoff’s bodies

Explanation:

  • This patient's symptoms of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur (mitral regurgitation), and Aschoff bodies on biopsy are indicative of rheumatic fever, a complication of Group A Streptococcus throat infection.

Histopathological features of RHD:

  • Aschoff bodies are focal areas of inflammation with infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells and activated macrophages or histiocytes. An endomyocardial biopsy showing Aschoff's bodies helps in confirming the diagnosis of RHD.
  • Anitschkow cells or Caterpillar cells are activated macrophages with elongated and wavy nuclei commonly found within Aschoff bodies.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in areas of the valves affected by inflammation.

Note: Granulation tissue is seen in cases of repair. It comprises proliferating blood vessels, inflammatory cells and fibroblasts.

Incorrect Options:

Epithelioid granuloma (Option B) is typically seen in granulomatous conditions like tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. The clinical presentation given does not align with these conditions.

Granulomatous vasculitis (Option C) refers to inflammation of blood vessels with granuloma formation, often seen in diseases like Wegener’s granulomatosis, but again, the clinical signs do not point to these disorders.

Granuloma inguinale (Option D), also called Donovanosis, is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis and typically presents with genital ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects the truth about health propaganda?

choices.text: It aids in developing a reflective behaviour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It appeals to emotions

Explanation:

  • Health propaganda is designed to influence or persuade people’s attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors regarding health-related issues. It typically appeals to emotions rather than logic, aiming to evoke strong feelings to drive action, such as fear, empathy, or excitement.

 

It is actively acquired (Option A): is incorrect because health propaganda is often passively received through media, advertisements, and campaigns, rather than being actively sought out by the audience.

It is behavior centered (Option C): is incorrect because health propaganda doesn’t primarily focus on modifying behavior directly but rather on altering perceptions or attitudes through emotional appeal.

It aids in developing a reflective behavior (Option D): is incorrect because health propaganda tends to focus on immediate emotional responses rather than encouraging reflective, thoughtful behavior change that requires deeper cognitive engagement.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about inverted papilloma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Benign and invasive

Explanation:

  • Inverted papilloma is the most common benign tumor of the nasal cavity.
  • Although it is a benign tumor, it is locally invasive.
  • It has a high rate of recurrence.
  • The tumor grows inward from the lining of the nose and sinuses and can invade the underlying bone and surrounding structures, hence the term "inverted."

 

Inverted papilloma: is a benign tumor arising from the nasal epithelium, often associated with the paranasal sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus. It typically presents in older adults and is more common in males.

Risk Factors: The history of smoking is a notable risk factor for the development of inverted papilloma

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • The patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a sensation of pressure, which are common symptoms associated with inverted papilloma.

 

Examination: The presence of a fleshy, lobulated mass on the lateral wall of the nasal cavity is characteristic of inverted papilloma.

Histopathology: Invagination of the superficial epithelium into the underlying stroma. The epithelium may be of the keratinized squamous, respiratory or transitional types which may coexist in varying proportions.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old was brought to the emergency department with difficulty swallowing for the last few hours. The X-ray is given below. Which is the next best step to manage this patient?

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophagoscopy

Explanation:

  • The X-ray shows a radiopaque foreign body in the esophagus, which is a common foreign body ingestion in children.
  • Esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both diagnosing and safely removing the foreign body.
  • The esophagus is the likely location when the object’s flat surface is seen on the anteroposterior (AP) X-ray because coins align flatly in the esophagus, unlike in the trachea, where the edge appears in the AP view.

 

 

Foreign body in esophagus:

Category

Indications

Management
Emergency
  • Esophageal obstruction (inability to handle oral secretions)
  • Disk batteries
  • Sharp-pointed objects
 Immediate endoscopic removal
Urgent
  • Blunt objects
  • Incomplete obstruction
  • Multiple magnets (or single magnet plus another ferromagnetic object within endoscopic reach)
  • Coins

Endoscopic removal within 12 to 24 hours

Non Urgent
  • Objects in stomach >2.5cm diameter
  • Disc battery in the stomach for up to 48 hrs if asymptomatic
  • Blunt objects that fail to pass the stomach in 3-4 weeks
 Observation

Bronchoscopy (Option A): is not appropriate as the foreign body is in the esophagus and not the airway.

Tracheostomy (Option C): is not necessary as the airway is not obstructed.

Heimlich's maneuver (Option D): may be appropriate for foreign bodies in the trachea and choking due to food or other material.

questions.text: What is the number of the deliveries performed by Type-A PHC in a month?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Less than 20

Explanation:

  • Type-A Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are typically small, rural healthcare facilities that are designed to serve a population in a limited geographical area. These centers typically handle fewer deliveries per month compared to higher-tier healthcare facilities. The number of deliveries is generally less than 20 per month at a Type-A PHC.

 

20 or above (Option B): is incorrect because Type-A PHCs usually manage fewer deliveries, with the number generally being less than 20 per month.

Less than 30 (Option C): is incorrect because the Type-A PHC usually handles fewer than 20 deliveries, so 30 deliveries would typically be beyond its capacity.

30 or above (Option D): is incorrect because the capacity of a Type-A PHC is unlikely to handle 30 or more deliveries per month, which is more typical of larger health centers or hospitals.

questions.text: At which of the following centers are the records of eligible couples maintained?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sub-centre

Explanation:

  • In the context of family planning and reproductive health services, sub-centres are responsible for maintaining records of eligible couples (those who are eligible for family planning services).
  • The sub-centre is the lowest level of healthcare delivery and plays a key role in providing basic health services, including maternal and child health services, and managing family planning records.

 

PHC (Option A): is incorrect because while PHCs provide a broader range of services than sub-centres, they do not typically maintain detailed records of eligible couples at the ground level.

CHC (Option B): is incorrect because CHCs provide more specialized care and cover a larger area, but the maintenance of records for eligible couples is primarily managed at the sub-centre.

District hospital (Option D): is incorrect because district hospitals focus on providing higher-level medical care and are not primarily responsible for maintaining family planning records for eligible couples, which is the role of sub-centres.

questions.text: Which diagnosis is most likely for a patient experiencing painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane, along with facial nerve palsy? Furthermore, which specific site is affected in this case?

choices.text: Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion
Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ramsay Hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

Explanation:

  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome (RHS) is caused by the reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the geniculate ganglion, a sensory ganglion of the facial nerve located in the temporal bone.
  • It commonly presents with painful vesicles in the external auditory meatus and over the tympanic membrane, as well as ipsilateral facial nerve palsy.

 

Ramsay Hunt Syndrome ( Herpes Zoster Oticus):

  • Caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus, it presents with facial nerve palsy, a painful vesicular rash around the external auditory canal and pinna.

 

 

  • There may be anaesthesia of face, giddiness and hearing impairment due to involvement of V th and VIII th nerve.

 

Treatment:

Medical management

 

Steroids:

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice (1 mg/kg/day).
  • Steroids can be combined with Acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus.
  • Dosage: If reported within 1 week, administer for 5 days and taper off by the 10th day. If paralysis persists, continue the same dose for 10 more days.

 

Surgical Treatment

  • Nerve Decompression: Relieves pressure on nerve fibers, improving microcirculation.

 

Ramsay Hunt syndrome and basal ganglion (Option A): Incorrect because the basal ganglia are part of the central nervous system and unrelated to the facial nerve or VZV reactivation.

Melkersson syndrome and trigeminal ganglion (Option C): Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome involves recurrent facial swelling, facial palsy, and fissured tongue. It is not associated with vesicles or VZV infection.

Melkersson syndrome and otic ganglion (Option D): Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome does not involve the otic ganglion, and otic ganglion lesions do not cause these symptoms.

questions.text: You are administering vitamin A supplements to an 8-month-old infant for two consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 100,000 IU

Explanation:

  • For infants 6-11 months old, the recommended dose of Vitamin A supplementation is 100,000 IU for two consecutive days.
  • This is part of national immunization programs aimed at preventing Vitamin A deficiency, which can cause blindness and increase the risk of other infections.

 

25,000 IU (Option A): is incorrect because 25,000 IU is the recommended dose for children aged 12-59 months, not for infants under one year.

50,000 IU (Option B): is incorrect because 50,000 IU is not the standard dose for infants under 1 year. The appropriate dose for infants aged 6-11 months is 100,000 IU.

200,000 IU (Option D): is incorrect because this dose is generally used for children aged 1-5 years, and is too high for an infant aged 6-11 months.

questions.text: What vitamin deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, a condition characterized by dryness of the eyes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

  • Vitamin A deficiency is the primary cause of xerophthalmia, a condition that includes dry eyes and can progress to night blindness and corneal damage if untreated. Vitamin A plays a crucial role in maintaining the health of the cornea.

 

Vitamin B (Option B): is incorrect because vitamin B deficiencies, like B1, B6, or B12, do not cause xerophthalmia. These deficiencies are linked to neurological and hematological issues, not eye-related conditions.

Vitamin C (Option C): is incorrect because vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and skin problems, but not xerophthalmia.

Vitamin D (Option D): is incorrect because vitamin D deficiency primarily leads to rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults, conditions that affect bone health, not the eyes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man dies due to a myocardial infarction. Which stains can be used to see the infarct in the heart while conducting an autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride

Explanation:

  • Triphenyl tetrazolium chloride (TTC) is a stain commonly used in autopsies to identify myocardial infarction (MI).
  • In myocardial infarction (MI), within the first 4 hours, gross examination may not show any visible infarcted area.
  • However, immersion of tissue slices in TTC solution can highlight the necrotic area.
  • This histochemical stain imparts a brick-red colour to intact, non-infarcted myocardium with preserved lactate dehydrogenase activity.
  • Conversely, infarcted tissue appears as an unstained pale zone because of leakage of dehydrogenases through the damaged membranes of dead cells.

Incorrect Options:

Oil Red O (Option A) stain optimally detects lipids in frozen sections by staining them bright red and is commonly used to detect fat accumulation or atherosclerotic plaques, but it is not used for identifying infarcts in myocardial tissue.

Sudan black B (Option C) is a lipid-specific stain primarily used to identify lipid-rich substances by staining them black, but it does not detect myocardial infarction.

Masson's trichrome (Option D) stain is used to differentiate collagen fibres (stain blue) from other tissue components. It is not specific for visualising glycogen.

questions.text: The duration for which copper T 380 A remains effective is referred to as its shelf life.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 10 years

Explanation:

  • Copper T 380 A is a long-term contraceptive device that remains effective for up to 10 years after insertion, making it a widely used option for long-term family planning.

 

3 years (Option A): is incorrect because copper T 380 A is designed for long-term contraception, far exceeding a 3-year effectiveness duration.

5 years (Option B): is incorrect because copper T 380 A provides contraceptive protection well beyond five years, although some other intrauterine devices have a 5-year lifespan.

7 years (Option C): is incorrect because copper T 380 A's effective duration is specifically rated for up to 10 years by manufacturers and health guidelines.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is confidentiality upheld?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Counselling

Explanation:

  • In counselling, confidentiality is a fundamental principle where personal information shared by the client is kept private, fostering trust and open communication. Exceptions apply only in situations involving harm or legal requirements.

 

Group discussion (Option A): is incorrect because group discussions involve multiple participants sharing information openly, making confidentiality difficult to maintain.

Panel discussion (Option C): is incorrect because panel discussions are typically public forums where multiple speakers discuss a topic openly in front of an audience.

Seminar (Option D): is incorrect because seminars are educational or informational gatherings where confidentiality is not inherently protected as discussions occur publicly.

questions.text: A young person with recurrent seasonal conjunctivitis presents with itchiness and eye-watering. What is the most likely cell involved in the immediate phase of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mast cells

Explanation:

  • The condition described is allergic conjunctivitis, where the immediate phase involves an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, with mast cells playing a central role in the response.
  • Type I Hypersensitivity (early) is an immediate IgE-mediated reaction where mast cells release histamine and other mediators upon allergen exposure, causing itching, eye-watering, redness, and swelling.
  • There are two phases in Type I hypersensitivity: the immediate and late-phase responses.

Type I hypersensitivity reaction phases and its features

Phase

Timing

Mechanism

Immediate Phase

Seconds to minutes

Mast cell/basophil degranulation: IgE cross-linking leads to the release of histamine and other mediators.

Late Phase

4-12 hours, peaks at 24-48 hours, lasting up to days

Inflammatory cell recruitment: Cytokines/chemokines attract eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, causing sustained inflammation. (Options A & C ruled out)

Lymphocytes (Option D), especially T-helper cells, play a role in delayed hypersensitivity (Type IV hypersensitivity), but they are not the primary cells involved in the immediate response.

questions.text: A patient who is a teacher by profession presents to the clinic with hoarseness of voice. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vocal nodule

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice is vocal nodule.
  • This is because vocal nodules are the most common benign vocal fold lesions in individuals who use their voice extensively, such as teachers, singers, and actors.
  • Vocal nodules are caused by vocal abuse or misuse, resulting in repeated trauma to the vocal folds, leading to the formation of small, benign growths.
  • Symptoms of vocal nodules include hoarseness, voice fatigue, and difficulty hitting high notes.

 

Vocal nodule and Vocal polyp

 

 

Vocal Nodule (Singer or screamer's nodule)

Vocal Polyp

(Option A)

 

Cause

Chronic vocal abuse (teachers, actors, vendors or pop singers.)
  • Sudden Vocal abuse like shouting (Men in the age group of 30-50 years).
  • Heavy smoking

Laterality

Bilateral or symmetrical

Unilateral

Location

 

 

Free edge of vocal cord at the junction of anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd. This

is the area of maximum vibration of the vocal cord.

Same as vocal nodules.

Appearance

 

Sessile , Reddish in the early stage and white in the chronic stage

Smooth and pedunculated.

Symptoms

Hoarseness, vocal fatigue and neck pain on prolonged phonation.
  • Hoarseness of voice and diplophonia (double voice due to different vibrating frequencies of two vocal cords)
  • Large polyps- dyspnea, stridor, choking.

Treatment

 

 
  • Initially, voice rest.
  • If it fails -
  • microscopic excision without injuring the vocal ligament
  • Speech therapy
  • Microscopic excision
  • Speech therapy

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Vocal cysts (Option B): are fluid-filled sacs that can form on the vocal folds and are usually caused by a blocked mucous gland.

Reinke's oedema (Option D):

  • is a condition in which the vocal folds become swollen and fluid-filled due to chronic exposure to irritants such as smoking or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Although Reinke's oedema can cause hoarseness, it is less likely to be the cause in a patient who is a teacher and presents with hoarseness of voice.

questions.text: A 10-year-old school-going girl came for a health checkup. Her Hb is 9 g/dL. Which of the following government programs is likely to provide significant benefit to her health?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK)

Explanation:

  • RBSK is a comprehensive program under the National Health Mission that focuses on early identification and intervention for children aged 0-18 years, targeting deficiencies such as anemia, developmental delays, and diseases. It supports the health and well-being of school-going children like the one described.

Janani Suraksha Yojana (Option B): is incorrect because this scheme focuses on promoting institutional deliveries and maternal health benefits rather than addressing child health and anemia in school-going children.

Pradhan Mantri Matru Vandana Yojana (Option C): is incorrect because it primarily provides financial support to pregnant and lactating mothers for better nutrition and postnatal care, not directly targeting school children.

Navjat Shishu Karyakram Yojana (Option D): is incorrect because it emphasizes newborn care and resuscitation in healthcare settings, not for health checkups of school-going children.

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Autoimmunity

Explanation:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues.
  • The pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) begins with antigenic exposure in genetically predisposed individuals, leading to the activation of CD4+ T-cells.
  • These T-cells release inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6, and interferon-γ, which activate endothelial cells, B lymphocytes, and macrophages.
  • This cascade of immune activation leads to chronic inflammation, joint damage, and deformities that characterise RA.

Rheumatoid arthritis

Epidemiology

  • Male to female ratio - 1:3.
  • Peaks between 25 and 55 years.
  • Remains constant between 55 and 75.

Genetics

  • Strongly associated with the HLA-DRβ1 gene.
  • Higher concordance in monozygotic twins.

Triggers and suppressors

  • Cigarette smoking and infections can trigger RA in genetically predisposed individuals by citrullination of proteins.
  • RA may remit during pregnancy and can first appear postpartum due to immune suppression and hormonal changes.

Pathogenesis

Incorrect Options:

IgE-mediated (Option A) immune response is primarily seen in allergic reactions, not in rheumatoid arthritis.

Defective cellular and humoral immunity (Option B): While immune dysfunction plays a role in RA, the specific issue is not a general defect in immunity but rather an autoimmune response where the immune system attacks its own tissues.

Chronic microbial infections (Option D) can trigger or exacerbate autoimmune diseases, but they are not the direct cause of RA. However, certain infections may contribute to disease flares or trigger the initial immune response.

questions.text: A doctor is consulted by a woman who is 8 weeks pregnant and employed in an industry. As per the ESI act, what is the length of maternity leave she is entitled to?

choices.text: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

Explanation:

  • As per the ESI Act and Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017, eligible women are entitled to 26 weeks of paid maternity leave, starting from 8 weeks before the expected delivery date for their first two children.

 

4 months (Option A): is incorrect because the ESI Act provides maternity leave benefits up to 26 weeks, not 4 months, and the 28-week clause is not applicable.

28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery (Option C): is incorrect because maternity leave typically starts before delivery, not just after delivery, and the duration stated exceeds the legal limit.

9 months (Option D): is incorrect because the ESI Act does not grant maternity leave for such a long duration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman takes aspirin for a headache, later presented with wheezing and breathlessness. Along with these two symptoms, what other clinical findings are likely to be found in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Nasal polyp

Explanation:

  • The woman likely developed aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), which is also known as Samter's triad.
  • Samter's Triad includes asthma, sinusitis with recurrent nasal polyps, and sensitivity to aspirin and other NSAIDs.

 

Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD):

  • also known as Samter's Triad, is a chronic medical condition characterized by the triad of asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and hypersensitivity reactions to aspirin and other(NSAIDs).
  • Symptoms: The symptoms of AERD can vary in severity and may include:
    • Recurrent episodes of asthma
    • Chronic rhinosinusitis
    • Nasal polyps, which are small growths in the lining of the nose that can obstruct the airway and cause breathing difficulties
    • Hypersensitivity reactions to aspirin and other NSAIDs, which can cause severe respiratory symptoms, hives, swelling, and even anaphylaxis.

 

Eosinophilia (Option A): Eosinophilia is a feature of allergic conditions but is not significantly associated with AERD.

Extrinsic asthma (Option C): In Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), the asthma component is considered a type of non-allergic or intrinsic asthma rather than extrinsic asthma.

Drug interaction (Option D): NSAIDs can worsen asthma symptoms in patients with the condition, but there is no drug-drug interaction causing AERD.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngeal cancer stage T1bNOMO?

choices.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis
One vocal cord involved and metastasis
One vocal cord involved, and mobile

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Both vocal cords involved, and no metastasis

Explanation:

  • The T1bN0M0 stage of laryngeal cancer indicates that the tumor is confined to both vocal cords, and is not metastatized

 

Laryngeal ca-TNM classification:

Supraglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.

T2

Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a

Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

 

Glottis

T1

Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility.

T1a

Tumor is limited to one vocal cord.

T1b

Tumor involves both vocal cords.

T2

Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion.

T4a

Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Subglottis

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis.

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility.

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation.

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

 

Regional lymph nodes (N)

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

 

Distant metastasis

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following is the least probable cause of mucormycosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Broad spectrum antibiotics
 

Explanation:

  • Mucormycosis is caused by molds, mainly Rhizopus.
  • Neutropenia, uncontrolled diabetes without DKA, and prolonged use of steroids are all risk factors for developing mucormycosis.
  • However, broad-spectrum antibiotics are not directly associated with the development of mucormycosis.

 

Risk Factors for Mucormycosis:

  1. Diabetes Mellitus: (Option C)
    • Uncontrolled diabetes.
    • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) – the most significant metabolic risk factor.
  2. Immunosuppression:
    • High-dose steroids (e.g., in COVID-19 or autoimmune conditions). (Option D)
    • Organ transplantation (e.g., liver, kidney) and immunosuppressive medications:
      • Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus, cyclosporine.
    • HIV/AIDS – advanced disease with low CD4 count.
  3. Neutropenia: (Option A)
    • Absolute neutrophil count (ANC) < 1500.
    • Common in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
  4. Iron Overload:
    • Use of Deferoxamine or other iron-chelating agents.
  5. Mechanical Ventilation:
    • Prolonged mechanical ventilation increases the risk of fungal infections.
  6. Autoimmune Disorders:
    • Diseases requiring immunosuppressive therapy.
  7. Other Causes:
    • Malnutrition.
    • Trauma or burns.
    • Prolonged antibiotic use (disrupts normal flora).

questions.text: Asbestos exposure may be associated with which of the following malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mesothelioma

Explanation:

  • Asbestos exposure is most strongly associated with mesothelioma

Mesothelioma
  • A rare cancer arising from mesothelial cells that most commonly affects the pleura.
  • It can also affect the peritoneum, pericardium and tunica vaginalis.

Aetiology

  • Asbestos: Mesothelioma is the most specific asbestos-associated cancer
  • It is not associated with smoking

Pathology

  • Advanced pleural mesothelioma can cause extensive pleural fibrosis and thickening, making the affected side rigid and immobile.
  • Later stages fix the mediastinum in place due to pleural thickening and fibrosis.
  • The mediastinal shift is not a characteristic feature of mesothelioma.
  • M/C cytogenetic abnormality in mesothelioma: Homozygous deletion of chromosome 9p, leading to loss of tumour suppressor gene - CDKN2A.

Clinical features

  • Progressive dyspnea, chest pain, weight loss, chronic cough, hemoptysis.
  • Decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion (due to pleural effusion or thickening).

Diagnosis

  • CT scan: Pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax (not causing a mediastinal shift in the presence of effusion)
  • Confirmed by biopsy:
    • Epithelioid mesothelioma shows tubules, nests, or papillary structures with uniform round to oval nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm.
    • Sarcomatoid mesothelioma consists of spindle-shaped cells resembling fibrosarcoma.
    • Biphasic mesothelioma displays a mixture of both patterns.
  • Specific markers for mesothelioma:
    • Calretinin
    • Epithelial membrane antigen
    • Cytokeratin
    • Mesothelin

Prognosis

Poor (median survival of 9-21 months).

Mesothelioma- Gross

Mesothelioma- H & E stain

Mesothelioma- Calretinin stain


Incorrect Options:

Acute myeloid leukaemia (Option B): While there are some associations between certain environmental toxins and leukaemia, asbestos is not a significant cause of AML. Other agents like benzene are more strongly linked with leukaemia.

Hepatic angiosarcoma (Option C) is primarily associated with exposure to vinyl chloride and arsenic, not asbestos.

Skin carcinoma (Option D), particularly basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma, is largely linked to UV radiation. Asbestos exposure is not a major risk factor for skin carcinoma.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness and walking difficulties. On examination, pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles was noted. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent dystrophin

Explanation:

  • The patient described is likely suffering from Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD), a genetic disorder characterised by progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the lower limbs, with pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles.
  • This condition is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, resulting in the absence or severe deficiency of dystrophin, a protein that helps anchor the muscle cell membrane.

Aspect

Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD)

Type of Mutation

Frameshift mutations lead to a disrupted reading frame

Dystrophin Protein
  • Dystrophin deficient
  • Truncated and unstable (< 3% of normal)

Clinical Severity

Severe, early onset, rapid progression

Inheritance Pattern

X-linked recessive.

Age of onset

Early childhood (Before 5 years)


Incorrect Options:

Abnormal collagen (Option A) would be more consistent with conditions like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or osteogenesis imperfecta, which involve defective collagen synthesis. Dystrophinopathies, like DMD, do not primarily involve collagen.

Expansion of CAG triplet repeats (Option C) can cause Huntington's disease or fragile X syndrome, but DMD is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene, not CAG repeats.

Defective fibrillin (Option D) is the cause of Marfan syndrome, which affects connective tissue and is characterized by features like tall stature, long limbs, and aortic dissection, but it is not involved in muscle degeneration like DMD.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of hemolytic anaemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Decreased haptoglobin

Explanation:

  • Decreased haptoglobin is a hallmark of hemolytic anaemia and helps distinguish it from other types of anaemia.
  • In hemolytic anaemia, the destruction of RBCs increases the amount of free haemoglobin in the blood, which binds to haptoglobin.

 

  • Other conditions where haptoglobin is reduced are (intravascular hemolysis):
    • Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
    • Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemia (MAHA)- HUS, TTP, DIC
    • Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria/Cold hemolysin type AIHA
    • G6PD deficiency

Neutropenia (Option B) refers to a low number of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell, which is not directly associated with hemolytic anaemia. Hemolytic anaemia primarily involves RBC destruction, not neutrophil abnormalities.

Reticulocytopenia (Option C): In hemolytic anaemia, the body responds to RBC destruction by producing more reticulocytes (immature red blood cells) as part of the compensatory mechanism. Thus, you would typically see reticulocytosis, not reticulocytopenia.

questions.text: What is the function of utricle and saccule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Linear acceleration and deceleration

Explanation:

  • The utricle and saccule are parts of the vestibular system in the inner ear.
  • The sensory epithelium of the utricle and sacula is called the macula which is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration
  • They contain specialized sensory hair cells that respond to movement and acceleration of the head in different directions, sending signals to the brain to help maintain balance and spatial orientation.

 

Parts of the Inner Ear

The inner ear, or labyrinth, is essential for hearing and balance and is located within the temporal bone. It consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth.

Bony Labyrinth

A rigid structure filled with perilymph (a sodium-rich fluid), it has three main parts:

  1. Vestibule: Central part connecting to the cochlea and semicircular canals.
    • Bony Recesses in the vestibule contains the utricle and saccule (part of the membranous labyrinth).
      • Spherical Recess: Contains the saccule, a membranous sac involved in detecting linear acceleration and deceleration.
      • Elliptical Recess: Contains the utricle, which works with the saccule to aid in balance and spatial orientation.
    • Oval Window: Located on the vestibule’s lateral wall, it connects to the middle ear.
    • Openings of the Semicircular Canals: The three semicircular canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) have five openings into the vestibule, enabling detection of head rotations.
    • Opening of the Vestibular Aqueduct: Positioned below the elliptical recess, it allows the passage of the endolymphatic duct, which carries endolymph within the membranous labyrinth.
  2. Semicircular Canals: Three canals (lateral, posterior, and superior) positioned at right angles to detect rotational head movement. Each has an ampulla containing the crista ampullaris for sensory function.
  3. Cochlea: A spiral structure essential for hearing, divided into three chambers (scala vestibuli, scala tympani, and scala media). The scala vestibuli and tympani contain perilymph and communicate via the helicotrema, while the scala media houses the organ of Corti, which converts sound vibrations into electrical signals.

 

Membranous Labyrinth

 

A delicate system within the bony labyrinth, filled with potassium-rich endolymph, it includes:

  1. Cochlear Duct (Scala Media): Inside the cochlea, it separates the scala vestibuli and scala tympani and contains the organ of Corti for hearing.
  2. Utricle and Saccule: Membranous sacs in the vestibule responsible for detecting linear acceleration and balance. They are connected via the utriculosaccular duct.
  3. Semicircular Ducts: Membranous ducts within the bony semicircular canals, contributing to balance.
  4. Endolymphatic Duct and Sac: Extending from the utricle and saccule, the duct ends in the endolymphatic sac, important in surgical treatments for conditions like Ménière's disease.

 

Hearing high-frequency sounds (Option A): This is the function of the cochlea, which is another part of the inner ear responsible for hearing.

Angular acceleration (Option C): This is detected by the semicircular canals, which are also part of the vestibular system but are responsible for detecting rotational movements of the head.

Hearing low-frequency sounds (Option D): This is the function of the cochlea.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with altered sensation in the extremities, difficulty with coordination, and speech problems. On examination, it is noted that the pupillary light reaction is absent, but the accommodation reaction is present. Which condition is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neurosyphilis

 

Explanation:

Neurosyphilis is a complication of syphilis that affects the nervous system. It occurs in the tertiary stage of syphilis, typically years after the initial infection. The condition can present with a variety of neurological symptoms, including altered sensation, coordination difficulties, and speech problems, as seen in the patient. Specific features of this case, including absent pupillary light reaction with intact accommodation, are highly suggestive of Argyll Robertson pupils, which is a classic sign of neurosyphilis.

 

Neurosyphilis and Argyll Robertson Pupils:

  1. Pupillary Light Reflex Absent: The pupillary light reflex is mediated by the optic nerve (CN II) and oculomotor nerve (CN III). In neurosyphilis, the optic nerve is often involved, leading to loss of the pupillary light reflex.
  2. Accommodation Reflex Present: Despite the absence of the light reflex, the accommodation reflex (the ability of the pupil to constrict when focusing on a near object) remains intact, which is typical in Argyll Robertson pupils. This occurs because the pathways responsible for accommodation (afferent via the optic nerve and efferent via the oculomotor nerve) are not usually affected in neurosyphilis.
  3. Other Symptoms: The patient may also present with neurological symptoms such as sensory disturbances, motor coordination problems (ataxia), and speech difficulties, all of which can be part of neurosyphilis.

 

Spirochetal uveitis:

  • Organism: Treponema pallidum
  • Anterior uveitis:
    • It can present as granulomatous or non-granulomatous iritis typically in the secondary syphilis stage
    • Iris roseola - dilated iris vessels that develop into nodules
    • ‘Plastic’ iritis occurs in congenital syphilis and Jarisch–Herxheimer reaction
  • Posterior uveitis:
    • It occurs as disseminated, peripheral, or diffuse choroiditis.
  • Treatment: Systemic penicillin

Horner's Syndrome (Option B): This condition is caused by disruption of the sympathetic pathway to the eye and presents with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis. It does not cause absent pupillary light reflex or preserved accommodation reflex.

Papilledema (Option C): Papilledema is swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure, which can affect vision but would not explain the absence of the light reflex with preserved accommodation. It also doesn't account for the coordination and speech problems.

Optic Neuritis (Option D): Optic neuritis involves inflammation of the optic nerve, which can cause vision changes, but it does not typically cause the combination of absent light reflex with intact accommodation. Also, optic neuritis usually doesn't present with the full range of neurological symptoms seen here.

questions.text: Tamm-Horsfall protein is a major component of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Renal casts

Explanation:

  • Tamm-Horsfall protein, produced in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle, is the most abundant protein in normal urine and serves as a marker of tubular function.
  • It plays a key role in preventing urinary tract infections and is the primary component of hyaline casts, the most common type of urinary casts.

Incorrect Options:

Mural thrombi (Option A) are blood clots that stick to the walls of blood vessels or the heart. They are not related to the Tamm-Horsfall protein, which is specific to renal tubular function and not involved in thrombus formation.

Curschmann spirals (Option B) are mucus plugs found in the sputum of patients with asthma or other obstructive pulmonary diseases.

Bence-Jones proteins (Option D) are free immunoglobulin light chains found in urine and are linked to multiple myeloma. Unlike the Tamm-Horsfall protein, which is a normal renal protein involved in renal casts, Bence-Jones proteins are abnormal products resulting from plasma cell malignancies.

questions.text: Which drug is commonly used for refraction in a child with accommodative squint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 1% Atropine

  • Cycloplegics are drugs that temporarily paralyze the ciliary muscle to prevent accommodation, making it easier to measure refractive errors (especially in children).
  • Atropine (1%) is commonly used in children under 5 years of age for cycloplegia during refraction, particularly in cases of accommodative squint, as it effectively prevents the eye from focusing and allows for accurate measurement of refractive error.

Cycloplegics:

  • Cycloplegics can be used in any age group if active accommodation is present.
  • Commonly used cycloplegics:
    • Atropine: used in < 5 years age
    • Homatropine: 5-25 years (Option D ruled out)
    • Phenylephrine (Mydriatic) in elderly

Cyclopentolate (Option B): Often used in children for cycloplegia but is not as commonly used as atropine for long-term treatment or in younger children.

Tropicamide (Option C): A shorter-acting agent, used primarily for pupil dilation rather than cycloplegia.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is typically prescribed as the initial treatment for tuberculosis during the first 2 months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ethambutol

Explanation:

  • The initial 2-month phase (intensive phase) of tuberculosis treatment typically includes a combination of Isoniazid, Rifampicin, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol (HRZE). Ethambutol is crucial in preventing drug resistance and enhancing treatment efficacy.

 

Streptomycin (Option A): is incorrect because while it was previously used as a first-line drug, it is now rarely included in the initial treatment due to the rise in drug-resistant TB and toxicity concerns.

Linezolid (Option C): is incorrect because it is a second-line drug reserved for multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) cases, not for initial treatment.

Levofloxacin (Option D): is incorrect because it is also a second-line drug used in drug-resistant TB rather than the initial phase of standard treatment.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the process that occurs in an oxidation pond?

choices.text: Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night
Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night

Explanation:

  • In oxidation ponds, aerobic conditions prevail during the day due to oxygen production by algae, while anaerobic conditions may develop at night due to the cessation of photosynthesis and continued oxygen consumption by microorganisms. This dynamic balance aids in the effective breakdown of organic matter.

 

Always aerobic (Option A): is incorrect because oxygen levels in oxidation ponds fluctuate, and anaerobic conditions can develop at night due to reduced photosynthesis.

Always anaerobic (Option B): is incorrect because during the day, algae in the pond produce oxygen through photosynthesis, creating aerobic conditions.

Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night (Option D): is incorrect because photosynthesis occurs during the day, promoting aerobic conditions, while anaerobic conditions typically develop at night.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the urban health care delivery system?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Subcenter

Explanation:

  • Sub-centers are primarily designed for rural healthcare delivery and are typically not part of the formal urban health infrastructure. Urban areas rely more on primary health centers (UPHCs) and Swasthya Chowkis instead.

 

PHC (Option A): is incorrect because Primary Health Centers are part of the urban health care delivery system in certain cities for providing outpatient care and preventive services.

CHC (Option B): is incorrect because Community Health Centers, although predominantly in rural areas, can also be established in semi-urban regions for specialty care.

Swasthya chowki (Option C): is incorrect because these are urban healthcare units that play a role in healthcare delivery for densely populated urban slums.

questions.text: The given inclusion bodies are characteristic of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

  • The presence of inclusion bodies, which gives the characteristic “Owl-eye appearance,” suggests Cytomegalovirus.

CMV infection

Modes of transmission
  • Oral route, respiratory & body secretions (most common)
  • Vertical transmission
  • Sexual transmission
  • Organ transplantation
  • Blood transfusion

Investigations

Peripheral smear

Owl’s eye appearance of inclusion bodies

Virus isolation

It is done by

  • Human fibroblast cell line culture
  • Shell vial culture

Antigen detected

PP65

Antibody detection

It is done by ELISA, and the antibodies detected are

  • CMV IgM antibodies.
  • CMV IgG antibodies.
  • Against PP150 and PP65.
  • Against the PP52.

PCR
  • Used in detecting CMV DNA.
  • Quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) by PCR is the most sensitive and specific testing.

Treatment
  • Ganciclovir (drug of choice)
  • Foscarnet (in Ganciclovir resistance)
  • CMV immunoglobulins and Ganciclovir are given to bone marrow transplant patients.

Incorrect Options:

Human papillomavirus (Option A) is a sexually transmitted virus, including low-risk strains 6 & 11, causing benign genital warts, and high-risk strains 16 & 18, linked to cervical carcinoma, vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) and vulvar carcinoma. It is characterised by the presence of enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei with perinuclear halos (koilocytes) in the superficial layers of the epithelium.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option C) is primarily associated with infectious mononucleosis and certain lymphoproliferative disorders. It is characterised by ‘Downey cells’, i.e. atypical lymphocytes (large, vacuolated) and Ballerina skirt appearance.

Herpes simplex virus (Option D) causes vesicular lesions and is characterised by intranuclear inclusion bodies in infected cells. It is characterised by multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground-glass' chromatin (Tzanck cells) in the Tzanck smear and the formation of Lipschutz bodies (Cowdry type A).

questions.text: What are the yoke muscles for Levodepression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - RSO and LIR

  • The Right Superior Oblique (RSO) and the Left Inferior Rectus (LIR) are the yoke muscles involved in levodepression (the downward movement of both eyes when the gaze is directed to the left).
  • Right Superior Oblique (RSO): The superior oblique muscle in the right eye helps depress the eye when it is abducted (pushed outward).
  • Left Inferior Rectus (LIR): The inferior rectus muscle in the left eye helps depress the eye.
  • These two muscles coordinate to cause the downward movement of the eyes when looking to the left.

Yoke muscles

  • Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles, one in each eye, that work together to ensure coordinated eye movements in the same direction.
  • These muscles function according to Hering's Law of Equal Innervation, which ensures that corresponding muscles in both eyes receive equal neural impulses for synchronised movement.
  • Hering’s Law of Equal Innervation would mean that the right lateral rectus (yoke muscle) should be balanced with the left medial rectus (vs Sherrington’s law: This law about reciprocal innervation states that increased innervation and contraction of a muscle is automatically associated with reciprocal decrease in innervation and contraction of its antagonist).
  • The yoke muscle pairs facilitate various eye movements:

 

 

  • Horizontal Gaze (Left or Right):
    • Leftward Gaze (Levoversion):
      • Left Lateral Rectus (abducts the left eye)
      • Right Medial Rectus (adducts the right eye)
    • Rightward Gaze (Dextroversion):
      • Right Lateral Rectus (abducts the right eye)
      • Left Medial Rectus (adducts the left eye)
  • Vertical Gaze (Up or Down):
    • Upward Gaze (Elevation):
      • Right and Left Superior Rectus (elevate the eyes)
      • Right and Left Inferior Oblique (assist in elevation)
    • Downward Gaze (Depression):
      • Right and Left Inferior Rectus (depress the eyes)
      • Right and Left Superior Oblique (assist in depression)
  • Inward Gaze (Convergence):
    • Both Medial Rectus muscles contract to bring the eyes inward (toward the nose) during near-vision tasks, such as reading.

LSO and RIR (Option A): Incorrect because LSO (Left Superior Oblique) helps in depression but not for levodepression. RIR (Right Inferior Rectus) is also involved in depression but doesn't pair with LSO for this movement.

RIO and LIR (Option C): RIO (Right Inferior Oblique) assists with elevation, not depression. LIR does help in depression, but they don't work together for levodepression.

LIO and RIR (Option D): LIO (Left Inferior Oblique) assists with elevation, not depression. RIR does help in depression, but this pair is not correct for levodepression.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the single exposure point source epidemic?

choices.text: Has more than one incubation period

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Explosive in nature

Explanation:

  • A single exposure point source epidemic is characterized by a sudden and simultaneous exposure to an infectious agent, leading to an explosive increase in cases within a short time frame, typically seen in foodborne or waterborne outbreaks.

 

Has more than one incubation period (Option A): is incorrect because a single exposure point source epidemic typically results from a single exposure event, leading to cases clustering around a single incubation period.

Has multiple peaks (Option B): is incorrect because a single exposure outbreak usually shows a single sharp peak, not multiple peaks.

Slow rise and fall (Option D): is incorrect because a single exposure point source epidemic exhibits a rapid onset and decline in cases rather than a gradual change.

questions.text: Sickness absenteeism of workers in the industry is used to evaluate
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Health of the worker

Explanation:

  • Sickness absenteeism refers to workers being absent from work due to health-related issues.
  • It is a direct indicator of the health status of the worker and helps to evaluate patterns of illness and health hazards faced by workers in an industry.
  • This metric is commonly used in occupational health studies.

 

Health of the family (Option B): is incorrect because sickness absenteeism measures individual worker absenteeism and does not directly assess the health status of their family members.

Industrial environment (Option C): is incorrect because, although poor industrial environments may contribute to absenteeism, the metric specifically evaluates the health of the worker rather than environmental conditions.

Community health (Option D): is incorrect because absenteeism in an industrial setting is specific to workers and does not provide a comprehensive measure of overall community health.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male comes with complaints of hip pain. An X-ray of the hip shows lytic lesions and elevated serum calcium levels. Bone marrow plasma cells are 42%, and the cells seen are given in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Multiple myeloma

Explanation:

  • Multiple myeloma is characterised by malignant plasma cell proliferation in the bone marrow, leading to lytic bone lesions and elevated serum calcium levels (due to bone resorption). The presence of plasma cells further supports the diagnosis.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings of Multiple Myeloma:

  • Increased number of plasma cells in the marrow, often >30% of cellularity.
  • Plasma cells may infiltrate the interstitium subtly or completely replace normal elements.
  • HPE:
    • Eccentric nucleus with perinuclear clearing (prominent Golgi) and abundant basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Normal-appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.
  • Other Cytologic Variants (due to dysregulated Ig synthesis and secretion):
    • Flame cells: Fiery red cytoplasm.
    • Mott cells: Contain multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets.
  • Inclusions:
    • Russell bodies: Globular cytoplasmic inclusions.
    • Dutcher bodies: Globular nuclear inclusions.


Incorrect Options:

CLL (Option B) is a malignancy of mature B-cells, not associated with lytic bone lesions or elevated calcium. It shows Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cells) due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation and convent girl appearance (a lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm).

ALL (Option C) affects immature lymphocytes and typically presents with other hematologic symptoms, not lytic bone lesions and elevated calcium. It shows Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%, Cytoplasmic vacuolations, fat (Oil Red O Positive) and hand mirror-shaped cells.

CML (Option D) is a myeloproliferative disorder that primarily affects granulocytes and is not associated with plasma cells or lytic bone lesions. It presents with Leukocytosis with cell types including Neutrophils (multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)

  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chronic dacryocystitis. She complains of recurrent tearing, discharge, and mild swelling in the inner corner of the eye. The clinical findings and history are consistent with chronic dacryocystitis. What should be the treatment of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dacryocystorhinostomy

  • Chronic dacryocystitis is a condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the lacrimal sac, typically due to a blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. The patient’s symptoms of recurrent tearing, discharge, and mild swelling in the inner corner of the eye are classic signs of this condition.
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is the definitive surgical procedure designed to create a new drainage pathway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, thus resolving the obstruction and restoring proper tear drainage. This approach addresses the underlying blockage and prevents recurrence.

Aspect

Acute Dacryocystitis

Chronic Dacryocystitis

Aetiology
  • Acute exacerbation of chronic dacryocystitis
  • Spread from neighbouring infected structures (e.g., sinuses, bones, dental abscess)
  • Causative organisms: Streptococcus haemolyticus, Pneumococcus, Staphylococcus
  • Stasis and mild infection of long duration
  • Common in women aged 40-60
  • Causes: anatomical factors (narrow bony canal), nasal diseases, foreign bodies, infection.

Clinical Features/ Sequelae
  1. Stage of cellulitis: Painful swelling at the lacrimal sac, epiphora, fever, redness, and oedema.
  2. Lacrimal abscess: Pus-filled sac, fluctuant swelling, may rupture forming an abscess.
  3. Fistula formation: Untreated abscess leads to spontaneous discharge, forming a fistula.
  1. Stage of chronic catarrhal dacryocystitis: Watering eye, mild redness, NLD block
  2. Lacrimal mucocele: Swelling below inner canthus, mucoid fluid regurgitation.
  3. Chronic suppurative dacryocystitis: Purulent discharge (d/t infection), recurrent conjunctivitis.
  4. Chronic fibrotic sac: Thickened mucosa, persistent epiphora, irregular folds.

Image

 

Complications

Conjunctivitis, corneal ulcer, lid abscess, orbital cellulitis, facial cellulitis, rarely cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Conjunctivitis, ectropion of lower lid, risk of corneal ulcers.

Treatment
  • Cellulitis: Systemic antibiotics, anti-inflammatory drugs, hot fomentation.
  • Lacrimal abscess: Drainage with incision, antibiotics, possible DCT or DCR later.
  • External fistula: Fistulectomy with DCT or DCR after controlling infection.
  • Conservative: Probing and syringing (early stages).
  • Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): Preferred surgery to re-establish lacrimal drainage.
  • Dacryocystectomy (DCT): Indicated if DCR is contraindicated or in cases of fibrosis, infection, or old age.

Lacrimal sac massage (Option A): This is a conservative approach often recommended for mild or early cases of nasolacrimal duct obstruction, especially in infants. It helps express the accumulated tears and debris in the lacrimal sac. However, in chronic dacryocystitis in adults, this approach is typically insufficient and would not resolve the underlying obstruction.

Syringing (Option C) (irrigation of the lacrimal system) can help clear the obstruction in some cases and is often used diagnostically to confirm the presence of a blockage. However, it does not provide a long-term solution and is typically not effective for treating chronic dacryocystitis in adults, particularly when there is significant structural obstruction.

Probing (Option D) is a procedure used primarily in young children with congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction. It is typically not appropriate for adults with chronic dacryocystitis, especially in cases where there is long-standing obstruction or scarring of the nasolacrimal duct.

questions.text: Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to _____weeks of gestational age.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 20

Explanation:

  • Immediately post-delivery, the uterus corresponds to 20 weeks of gestational age.
     

Involution of uterus in puerperium :

  • Fundal height decreases by 1 finger breath per day (1 cm per day), i.e., 2 finger breaths below the umbilicus after 2 days.
  • Involution occurs due to the reduction in size of uterine muscle fibers.
Time after delivery Fundal height/Position of uterus Weight of uterus Corresponding GA (Approx.)
Immediately after delivery At or just below the level of the umbilicus ~1000 g ~20 weeks
1 week postpartum Midway between umbilicus & symphysis pubis

~500 g

 ~12 weeks
2 weeks postpartum Not palpable abdominally (pelvic organ) ~300 g <12 weeks
4 weeks postpartum Fully involuted, small pelvic organ ~100 g -

questions.text: The following picture shows a lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hodgkin disease

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings suggest a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, and the HPE reveals the presence of characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma typically spreads in an orderly, contiguous manner from one lymph node group to the next adjacent group without skipping areas.

Histopathological variants of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma

1. Mononuclear cells
  • Single nucleus with a large, inclusion-like nucleolus with abundant cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma

2. Popcorn cells
  • Cells with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Nodular lymphocyte - Predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

3. Reed-sternberg cell

It is characterised by two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm and is typically surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

4. Lacunar cells
  • Typically found in the nodular sclerosis subtype.
  • Nuclei are more delicate, folded, or multilobate.
  • Abundant pale cytoplasm often gets disrupted during sectioning, creating an appearance where the nucleus sits in an empty space (lacuna).

 

Incorrect Options:

Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) (Option A) is a type of cancer characterized by the rapid proliferation of abnormal myeloid blasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood and is characterised by the presence of blasts ≥ 20% and myeloblasts with Auer rods.

Human papillomavirus (HPV) (Option C) is a sexually transmitted virus, including low-risk strains 6 & 11, causing benign genital warts, and high-risk strains 16 & 18, linked to cervical carcinoma, vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), and vulvar carcinoma. It is characterised by the presence of enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei with perinuclear halos (koilocytes) in the superficial layers of the epithelium.

Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) (Option D) is a malignancy of mature B-cells not associated with lytic bone lesions or elevated calcium. It shows Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cells) due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation and convent girl appearance (a lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm).

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with the given visual field effect. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 3

  • Site of Lesion: Optic Chiasma.
  • Effect on Visual Field: Bitemporal Hemianopia (Heteronymous Hemianopia). This means the patient will have loss of vision in the outer (temporal) fields of both eyes, which is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasma where the nasal fibers from both eyes cross.

Visual Pathway:

  • Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

(Option B ruled out)

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Anopia

Optic Chiasma

(Option A)

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia)
  • Optic Tract (Option C ruled out)
  • Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion)
  • Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Right Homonymous Hemianopia

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Post. Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia

 

Aspect

Inferior Optic Radiations (Meyer’s Loop)

Superior Optic Radiations (Baum’s Loop)

Location of Lesion

Temporal lobe

Parietal lobe (Option D ruled out)

Affected Visual Field

Superior quadrants of the contralateral visual field

Inferior quadrants of the contralateral visual field

Visual Defect

Superior homonymous quadrantanopia

Inferior homonymous quadrantanopia

Associated Symptoms
  • Memory loss
  • Hearing loss
  • Auditory hallucinations
  • Contralateral hemiplegia
  • Hemianesthesia
  • Optokinetic nystagmus
 

1 (Option B)- Optic Nerve: Causes complete blindness in one eye, not a bitemporal hemianopia.

4 (Option C)- Optic Tract: Causes homonymous hemianopia, but not bitemporal hemianopia.

6 (Option D)- Visual Cortex: Typically causes homonymous hemianopia with possible macular sparing, not bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. The investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumour. Which of the following histological findings correlates with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumour cells

Explanation:

  • The patient’s presentation of a dural-based tumour with raised intracranial pressure suggests a diagnosis of meningioma, and the histological feature of psammoma bodies with whorling of tumour cells is a characteristic finding.
  • They originate from meningothelial cells of the arachnoid layer and are typically connected to the dura mater.
  • More common in women and has increased risk with pregnancy, exposure to radiation and NF2 gene mutation.
  • Tumours typically exhibit a rubbery dural mass, compressing the brain, yet easily separable.
  • Histopathologically, they present with a whorled pattern of cells and psammoma bodies and are progesterone receptor-positive.

Incorrect Options:

Fried-egg appearance (Option A) is characteristic of oligodendrogliomas along with chicken wire vessels, calcification and perineuronal satellitosis.

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (Option B) are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells and are seen in retinoblastomas, along with Homer-Wright rosettes, undifferentiated tumour cells and areas of necrosis and calcification.


Homer-Wright rosettes (Option D) are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes. They are commonly seen in neuroblastomas.

questions.text: Which of the following cells plays a key role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Kupffer cells

Explanation:

  • Kupffer cells are specialised macrophages found in sinusoids of the liver and play a key role in phagocytosis and chronic inflammation.
  • They are responsible for clearing pathogens, debris, and old red blood cells from the blood as it passes through the liver.


Incorrect Options:

Hepatocytes (Option A) are vital liver cells responsible for various metabolic functions but are not directly responsible for phagocytosis.

Ito cells (Option B), also called Hepatic stellate cells, are pericytes located in the space of Disse, between hepatocytes and sinusoidal endothelial cells in the liver that store vitamin A and regulate sinusoidal blood flow. Upon liver injury, they activate into myofibroblast-like cells, releasing TGFβ and promoting fibrosis through excessive collagen production.

Sinusoidal endothelial cells (Option C) line the liver's sinusoids and facilitate material exchange between blood and liver cells. While they are not primarily involved in phagocytosis, their unique fenestrated structure enables them to filter blood and regulate molecule movement.

questions.text: The image below displays the findings of a fundoscopy. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - CRAO

  • Fundoscopy shows the typical features of pale retina and cherry-red spot, and CRAO is the most likely diagnosis in this case. CRAO often presents with sudden, painless, unilateral vision loss, and it is considered an ophthalmologic emergency because of the potential for permanent vision loss.

Risk factors:

  • Atherosclerosis

  • Age

  • Hypertension

  • Cardiac Diseases

    • Atrial fibrillation: promotes blood clot formation, increasing CRAO risk

    • Mitral valve prolapse: this can lead to blood flow abnormalities and clot formation

    • Bacterial endocarditis: causes vegetation that can travel and occlude the retinal artery

  • Thrombophilic disorders

    • Hyperhomocysteinemia: elevated homocysteine levels increase clot formation risk

    • Antiphospholipid syndrome: an autoimmune disorder causing increased clot formation risk
