    • Inherited anticoagulant defects: genetic conditions disrupting natural blood clotting regulation

  • Giant cell arteritis (GCA)

    • Inflammatory condition affecting blood vessels, often with severe visual loss

  • Other factors

    • Smoking

    • Diabetes mellitus

    • Oral contraceptive pills

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden, painless, profound vision loss

  • Painless, except in GCA: GCA-associated CRAO may present with headache, jaw claudication, scalp tenderness, and/or pain around the temple

Clinical Signs:

  • Visual Acuity (VA): severely reduced, often to counting fingers or worse

  • Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD): Profound and sometimes total (amaurotic pupil)

Fundus Examination:

  • Retinal Whitening: Pale and opaque retina, particularly in the posterior pole

  • Cherry-Red Spot: Bright red area at the fovea due to the contrast between pale retina and underlying choroidal circulation

  • Cattle truck appearance: Due to segmentation of blood column in retinal veins

  • Attenuated Arteries: Narrowed and segmented retinal arterioles

  • Optic Disc Changes: Pale optic disc over time due to optic atrophy from prolonged ischemia is seen in chronic cases.

Fluorescein Angiography (FA)

  • Arterial Filling: Delayed

  • Masking of Background Fluorescence: Edematous retina blocks normal fluorescence from the choroid

  • Patent Cilioretinal Artery: Area of normal perfusion if a cilioretinal artery supplies the fovea, potentially preserving central vision

Other Diagnostic Tests

Reveals retinal edema, structural changes, and possibly an embolic plaque within the retinal artery and other systemic causes.

  • Cranial MRI or CT

  • Carotid duplex scanning

  • Echocardiography

  • Thrombophilia screening

CRVO (Option B) (Central Retinal Vein Occlusion): Fundoscopic findings- Diffuse retinal hemorrhages (often in all quadrants), venous dilation, and cotton wool spots. The optic disc may be swollen, and there may be blood and thunder appearance. This is different from CRAO, where the retina is pale and a cherry-red spot is seen.

Diabetic Retinopathy (Option C): Fundoscopic findings- Microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and hard exudates. These findings reflect chronic vascular changes in diabetes and are distinct from the acute ischemic signs seen in CRAO, which involve retinal pallor and cherry-red spots.

Cystoid Macular Edema (Option D) (CME): Fundoscopic findings- Cystic spaces in the macula, often with focal macular edema. This causes central vision blurring, but unlike CRAO, it doesn’t show retinal pallor or cherry-red spots. CME is more related to macular dysfunction rather than ischemia.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Internal Capsule

Explanation:

Internal Capsule:

  • The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that separates the caudate nucleus (medially) from the putamen and globus pallidus (laterally).
  • It contains major ascending and descending tracts, including corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions.
  • In the given image, the structure appears as a dense white matter band in the coronal plane, consistent with the location of the internal capsule.

 

External capsule (option A): Incorrect because the external capsule is a thin white matter layer located lateral to the putamen, separating it from the claustrum. It is not the structure shown in this image.

Caudate nucleus (option C): Incorrect because the caudate nucleus is located medial to the internal capsule, near the lateral ventricles. It appears as a grey matter structure and is not consistent with the marked region.

Putamen (option D): Incorrect because the putamen is located lateral to the internal capsule and is part of the basal ganglia. It appears as a grey matter structure and does not match the highlighted structure.

questions.text: Please identify the rib that is shown in the X-ray.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 3rd rib posterior part

Explanation:

3rd rib posterior part:

  • The posterior part of the rib is typically identified by its position relative to the spine and the more horizontal orientation in an X-ray, especially when taken from a lateral view.
  • The posterior part of the rib will be closer to the vertebrae and typically appears more curved and parallel to the spine on the X-ray.
  • The highlighted structure in the image is consistent with this description, which is why the 3rd rib posterior part is the correct answer.

 

3rd rib anterior part (option A): Incorrect because the anterior part of the 3rd rib would be closer to the sternum, with a more forward and downward orientation on an X-ray. The posterior part is more visible in this case.

4th rib anterior part (option C): Incorrect because the 4th rib would be located further down than the 3rd rib, and its anterior part would be closer to the sternum. This option doesn't match the positioning seen in the image.

1st rib anterior part (option D): Incorrect because the 1st rib is positioned more superiorly, closer to the clavicle. Its anterior part would be located near the sternum, and this is not consistent with the rib shown in the image.

questions.text: A child with elevated liver enzymes presented to the OPD with the following eye finding on gonioscopy. It is associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Copper

  • Wilson Disease is characterized by abnormal copper deposition in tissues, caused by a deficiency of caeruloplasmin.
  • Eye Finding: The child has a Kayser-Fleischer ring, a brownish-yellow copper deposit in the Descemet membrane of the cornea, which is visible on gonioscopy. This is a hallmark sign of Wilson disease.

Wilson’s disease

  • Deficiency of caeruloplasmin, leading to abnormal copper deposition in tissues.
  • Symptoms:
    • Liver disease
    • Basal ganglia dysfunction (movement disorders)
    • Psychiatric disturbances
  • Ocular Signs:
    • Kayser-Fleischer ring: Brownish-yellow copper deposits in the corneal Descemet membrane, visible on gonioscopy.
    • Sunflower cataract: Anterior capsular cataract in some patients.
  • Diagnosis: Kayser-Fleischer rings detected on gonioscopy.
  • Treatment: Penicillamine therapy can reduce copper deposits and improve symptoms.

Zinc (Option B), selenium (Option C), and iron (Option D) are not associated with the Kayser-Fleischer ring or the specific symptoms of Wilson disease.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with pain and redness in the right eye following an injury during welding. On examination, the image as seen below is observed. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Removal by 26G needle

  • In managing a patient with pain and redness in the right eye following a welding injury, the most appropriate next step is removal by a 26G needle. This approach is typically indicated when there is a foreign body present in the eye, which is common in welding injuries due to flying debris.
  • This method is effective for extracting superficial foreign bodies from the cornea. It allows for direct access to remove small metallic fragments or other debris that can cause significant irritation and potential damage to the eye.

Steroids and antibiotics (Option A): While these medications can be useful for treating inflammation and preventing infection, they are not the first-line treatment for immediate foreign body removal.

Surgical exploration (Option B): This option may be considered for more complex injuries or if there are complications, but it is not the first step in straightforward foreign body cases.

Keratoplasty (Option C): This surgical procedure is reserved for severe corneal damage or scarring and is not appropriate immediately after an injury

questions.text: What is the probable medical condition for a 70-year-old individual who has relied on presbyopia glasses but can now comfortably read the newspaper without them?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Index myopia:

  • Myopia=shortsightedness- refractive error where parallel rays of light from distant objects focus in front of the retina when the eye's accommodation is relaxed.
  • Index myopia is a condition that often occurs in older individuals, typically associated with age-related changes in the lens. As we age, the lens of the eye becomes denser and less flexible, which can lead to myopia (nearsightedness) in some cases.
  • In index myopia, the refractive index of the lens increases, causing a shift in the focal point of the eye, making it easier for a person to focus on nearby objects, like reading a newspaper, without the aid of reading glasses. This would explain why the 70-year-old patient, who had been using presbyopia glasses (for near vision), is now able to read comfortably without them.

Type of Myopia

Cause

Axial Myopia

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball (most common form).

Curvatural Myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both.

Positional Myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye.

Index Myopia

Increase in the refractive index of the crystalline lens, often due to nuclear sclerosis.

Myopia due to Excessive Accommodation

Caused by spasm of accommodation, leading to excessive focusing power.

 

Clinical features

  • Asthenopic symptoms
  • Half-shutting of eyes for better clarity
  • Prominent eyeball.
  • Prominent, large, and somewhat sluggishly reacting pupils.
  • Slightly deeper anterior chamber.
  • Normal fundus; rarely a temporal myopic crescent may be seen.
  
 

Treatment
  • Prescription of appropriate concave lenses
  • Surgical Treatment
  

Index hypermetropia (Option B): This would cause the opposite effect of index myopia. In this condition, the lens of the eye becomes more hypermetropic (farsighted), making near objects harder to focus on, which would make reading more difficult, not easier. Therefore, this is not consistent with the patient's improvement in near vision.

Presbyopia (Option C): This condition is a normal aging process that causes the loss of accommodation (the ability to focus on near objects). Presbyopia usually results in difficulty reading without corrective lenses (reading glasses). If the patient no longer needs glasses for reading, it is unlikely that they simply have presbyopia. The improvement in near vision suggests a different mechanism, such as index myopia.

None of the above (Option D): This option is incorrect because index myopia is a plausible explanation for the patient's improvement in near vision.

questions.text: In a three-year-old boy, his parents have noticed a progressive decline in coordination over the last six months. During a physical examination, a growth resembling a cauliflower is observed in the left eye, along with leukocoria and the absence of a red reflex. Microscopic analysis of the sample reveals the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which gene is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Rb gene

The findings of leukocoria, a cauliflower-like growth, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology strongly suggest retinoblastoma, which is associated with mutations in the Rb gene.

The question describes a classic presentation of retinoblastoma, which is the MC primary intraocular malignancy in children.

The key features pointing to this diagnosis are:

  1. Age of presentation: Retinoblastoma typically occurs in young children, usually before 5 years of age.
  2. Leukocoria: This is the most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma, often described as a white pupillary reflex.
  3. Fundus examination: A white, elevated mass in the retina is characteristic of retinoblastoma.

Most specific histopathological feature of retinoblastoma is Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, which are rosettes with a central lumen as shown in the diagram below.

Histopathology and Diagnostic modalities for Retinoblastoma

Histopathology
  • Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific)- These are composed of an ‘empty’ lumen surrounded by columnar cells
  • Homer-Wright rosettes - These are pseudo-rosettes and consist of cells surrounding a central lumen made up of their processes
  • Undifferentiated tumor cells
  • Areas of necrosis and calcification

Clinical Presentation
  • Leukocoria (60%)
  • Strabismus (20%)
  • Painful red eye (7%)
  • Poor vision (5%)
  • Asymptomatic (3%)

Fundus Examination
  • White, elevated mass in the retina
  • Can be endophytic, exophytic, or mixed growth

Imaging
  • CT scan: Calcification in 90% of cases
  • MRI: Better for evaluating optic nerve and extraocular extension
  • Ultrasound: Useful for initial screening

Genetic Testing
  • RB1 gene mutation on chromosome 13q14

ATP 7B gene (Option B): Mutations in the ATP7B gene are associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism, leading to copper buildup in various organs, including the liver and brain. It does not cause retinoblastoma.

Rhodopsin gene (Option C): The rhodopsin gene is associated with retinitis pigmentosa, a genetic condition causing progressive vision loss, but not with retinoblastoma.

FBN1 gene (Option D): Mutations in the FBN1 gene are responsible for Marfan syndrome, a connective tissue disorder affecting the heart, eyes, and bones, but not retinoblastoma.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia in the right eye?

choices.text: Spectacles or refraction with a near addition

questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Occlusion Therapy

  • Amblyopia (lazy eye) is treated by forcing the amblyopic eye (the weaker eye) to work, and the most common method is occlusion therapy, where the normal eye is covered (occluded) to stimulate the weaker eye.

Treatment of Amblyopia (aka Lazy eye)

  • Early treatment is essential for better visual outcomes.
  • Occlusion of Normal Eye (Occlusion Therapy)
    • Mainstay treatment involves occluding the normal eye to force the amblyopic eye to work.
    • Full-time occlusion: All waking hours or all but one hour. Schedule by Age:
      • Up to 2 years: 2:1 (2 days occluded, 1 day not)
      • 3 years: 3:1
      • 4 years: 4:1
      • 5 years: 5:1
      • 6 years and older: 6:1
    • Part-time occlusion: 4-6 hours/day, as shown by Amblyopia Treatment Study (ATS), and is as effective as full-time occlusion.
    • Maintenance occlusion: After vision equalization, part-time occlusion continues until at least 8 years of age.
    • Ensure no media opacity or refractive errors before starting occlusion therapy.
  • Other Methods
    • Penalization: Blurring vision in the sound eye with atropine or over-plus lenses.
    • Computerized Home Vision Therapy: Uses specially designed software as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
  • Pharmacologic Manipulation
    • Levodopa/Carbidopa: Studied as an adjunct to occlusion therapy.
    • Other agents: Citicoline and omega fatty acids
  • Pleoptics: Pleoptic exercises are done to improve foveal fixation, though less commonly used now.

Observation (Option A): Passive observation is not effective for amblyopia, as early intervention is key to improving visual outcomes.

Spectacles or refraction with a near addition (Option B): These are useful for refractive errors (e.g., hyperopia) but do not directly address amblyopia unless coupled with occlusion therapy.

Radial keratotomy (Option D): This is an outdated surgical procedure for correcting refractive errors, not for treating amblyopia.

questions.text: Which muscle serves as the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Left medial rectus

  • Yoke muscles are pairs of muscles that work together to coordinate eye movements in the same direction.
  • According to Hering's Law, for a right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye), the corresponding yoke muscle is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye) to maintain synchronized movement during horizontal gaze.

Yoke muscles

  • Yoke muscles are pairs of extraocular muscles, one in each eye, that work together to ensure coordinated eye movements in the same direction.
  • These muscles function according to Hering's Law of Equal Innervation, which ensures that corresponding muscles in both eyes receive equal neural impulses for synchronised movement.
  • Hering’s Law of Equal Innervation would mean that the right lateral rectus (yoke muscle) should be balanced with the left medial rectus (vs Sherrington’s law: This law about reciprocal innervation states that increased innervation and contraction of a muscle is automatically associated with reciprocal decrease in innervation and contraction of its antagonist).
  • The yoke muscle pairs facilitate various eye movements:

  • Horizontal Gaze (Left or Right):
    • Leftward Gaze (Levoversion):
      • Left Lateral Rectus (abducts the left eye)
      • Right Medial Rectus (adducts the right eye)
    • Rightward Gaze (Dextroversion):
      • Right Lateral Rectus (abducts the right eye)
      • Left Medial Rectus (adducts the left eye)
  • Vertical Gaze (Up or Down):
    • Upward Gaze (Elevation):
      • Right and Left Superior Rectus (elevate the eyes)
      • Right and Left Inferior Oblique (assist in elevation)
    • Downward Gaze (Depression):
      • Right and Left Inferior Rectus (depress the eyes)
      • Right and Left Superior Oblique (assist in depression)
  • Inward Gaze (Convergence):
    • Both Medial Rectus muscles contract to bring the eyes inward (toward the nose) during near-vision tasks, such as reading.

Right superior oblique (Option A): Helps with vertical and torsional eye movement, not horizontal.

Left lateral rectus (Option C): Moves the left eye outward, opposite to what’s needed for the right lateral rectus.

Right medial rectus (Option D): Moves the right eye inward, opposite of what is needed for the right lateral rectus.

questions.text: What substance is responsible for the development of a diabetic cataract in a 68-year-old female patient, which has been present for 3 months?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Sorbitol

  • In diabetic patients, sorbitol accumulation in the lens plays a critical role in the development of diabetic cataracts. This process is primarily mediated by the polyol pathway, where glucose is converted to sorbitol via the enzyme aldose reductase. Sorbitol accumulates in the lens because it is poorly permeable across the lens membrane, leading to osmotic stress and cellular damage, which promotes cataract formation.

Glucose Metabolism in the Lens:

The lens uses glucose through several metabolic pathways:

  1. Glycolytic pathway: This is the primary pathway where about 80% of glucose is metabolized anaerobically.

  2. Pentose Phosphate pathway (HMP shunt): Responsible for metabolizing 15% of glucose.

  3. Kreb's citric acid cycle: A small proportion of glucose is metabolized through this oxidative pathway.

  4. Sorbitol pathway: In healthy individuals, this pathway is minimally active. However, in diabetic and galactosemic patients, excess glucose is converted into sorbitol by aldose reductase. The accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic imbalance, which causes lens fiber swelling and opacity, resulting in cataracts.

Glucose (Option A): Although glucose is involved in cataract formation, it is not directly responsible for the development of diabetic cataracts. In the lens, glucose is metabolized via several pathways, but it is the conversion of glucose to sorbitol (via the polyol pathway) that leads to osmotic stress and cataract formation in diabetes.

Fructose (Option B): Fructose does not significantly contribute to diabetic cataracts. While fructose is metabolized in the body, it is not the primary substance implicated in lens opacity in diabetic patients. The key factor in diabetic cataracts is sorbitol accumulation.

Lactose + Glucose (Option C): Lactose is not involved in the formation of diabetic cataracts. Although glucose plays a role in cataract formation, lactose is more relevant in galactosemic cataracts and not in diabetes-induced cataracts.

questions.text: What kind of laser can be utilized to treat posterior capsular opacification, which is observed during an examination of a patient who has reported decreased visual acuity following cataract surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nd YAG laser

  • Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is a common complication following cataract surgery, often referred to as a "secondary cataract." It occurs when the posterior capsule of the eye becomes cloudy after cataract extraction, leading to decreased visual acuity.
  • The treatment for PCO is laser capsulotomy, which involves using a laser to create an opening in the cloudy posterior capsule to restore vision. The Neodymium YAG (Nd YAG) laser is the standard laser used to treat posterior capsular opacification.

After cataract = Secondary cataract:

Definition
  • M/C postoperative complication following extracapsular lens extraction.

Clinical Types
  • Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO): Common form of after cataract.
  • Dense Membranous After Cataract: Thick membrane formation.
  • Soemmering's Ring: Thick ring behind the iris, enclosed between capsule layers.

 

  • Elschnig's Pearls: Clustered, vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells along the posterior capsule.

Treatment
  • ND YAG laser posterior capsulotomy

Femto laser (Option A): The femtosecond laser is used in cataract surgery for making precise incisions and can be used for corneal surgery, but it is not used for treating posterior capsular opacification.

Argon fluoride (Option C): This laser is primarily used for retinal treatments, such as for retinal photocoagulation, and is not suitable for posterior capsular opacification.

Argon laser (Option D): The argon laser is used for retinal procedures (like retinal photocoagulation) and does not have the specific characteristics needed to treat PCO effectively.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 32 weeks, presented with severe abdominal pain, bleeding per vagina, and loss of fetal movements. On examination, her uterus is tender. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Abruptio placenta

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario with severe abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, loss of fetal movements, and uterine tenderness points towards diagnosis of Abruptio placenta.


Abruptio Placenta:

  • Refers to the early partial/total separation of the placenta from the uterine lining before the completion of the second stage of labor.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Health History:
      • Smoking, cocaine use during pregnancy, maternal age >35 years, hypertension, and a history of placental abruption in prior pregnancies.
    • Current Pregnancy:
      • Multiple gestations, polyhydramnios, preeclampsia, sudden uterine decompression, and short umbilical cord.
    • Trauma:
      • Abdominal trauma from a motor vehicle collision, fall, or violence can lead to placental abruption.
  • Classification of Placental Abruption:
    • Class 0 (Asymptomatic): Discovery of a blood clot on the maternal side of a delivered placenta, diagnosed retrospectively.
    • Class 1 (Mild): No or small vaginal bleeding, slight uterine tenderness, normal maternal vital signs, and no fetal distress.
    • Class 2 (Moderate): Moderate vaginal bleeding, significant uterine tenderness, changes in vital signs (tachycardia, orthostatic hypotension), evidence of fetal distress, and clotting abnormalities.
    • Class 3 (Severe): Heavy vaginal bleeding, tetanic uterus, maternal shock, coagulopathy, and fetal death.
       

 

Placenta previa (Option B) occurs when the placenta is positioned in the lower uterine segment, covering part or all of the cervical os, leading to painless vaginal bleeding, but it does not usually cause severe abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, or loss of fetal movements as seen in this scenario.

Polyhydramnios (Option C) is characterized by excessive amniotic fluid, typically does not cause severe abdominal pain or vaginal bleeding. It may lead to discomfort or premature labor, but these are not the primary symptoms in this case.

Preterm labor (Option D) involves contractions and cervical changes, but it usually does not result in significant bleeding, abdominal pain, uterine tenderness, or loss of fetal movements, which are key features in this scenario.

questions.text: Which among the following is an outlet forceps?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wrigley forceps

Explanation: Wrigley forceps is an outlet forceps.

Wrigley's Forceps:

  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

Criteria for Outlet forceps Delivery:

  • Scalp is visible at the introitus without separating the labia
  • Fetal skull has reached pelvic floor
  • Fetal head is at or on perineum
  • Head is occipitoanterior or occipitoposterior or
  • Head is right or left occipitoanterior or occipitoposterior position but rotation ≤45 degrees

 

Piper’s forceps (Option A) have a distinct perineal curve and are specifically designed for use in breech deliveries, particularly for assisting the after-coming head.

 

Das forceps (Option C) are a lighter and shorter variant of long curved obstetric forceps. They are designed for use in deliveries where the mother has a narrower pelvis and the newborn has a lower birth weight. This design facilitates easier delivery in mid-cavity cases.

 

Kielland forceps (Option D) have a long, almost straight design and are primarily used for rotational delivery. They have an adjustable pivot and are designed to help rotate the fetal head, especially in occiput transverse positions or when there is asynclitism (tilted head).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hyper-estrogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Low BMI

Explanation:

  • Low BMI is not a hyper-estrogenic condition.

Causes of Hyperestrogenism:

  • Ovarian Tumors: Granulosa cell tumors and thecomas. (Option B)
  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): Long-term or high-dose estrogen therapy can lead to hyperestrogenism.
  • Obesity: Increased fat tissue can lead to higher estrogen levels, as adipose tissue converts androgens into estrogens.
  • Adrenal Tumors or Hyperadrenocorticism: Excess production of adrenal hormones, including estrogen, due to conditions like Cushing's syndrome.
  • Medications: Tamoxifen or estrogen-containing contraceptives (Option D)
  • Endometriosis: Estrogen stimulates the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, leading to hyperestrogenism. (Option C)
  • Liver Disease: Reduce the metabolism of estrogen, leading to its accumulation.
  • Early Puberty or Precocious Puberty: Lead to elevated estrogen production in younger girls due to premature ovarian or adrenal activity.
  • Excessive Alcohol Consumption: Chronic alcohol intake can affect liver function and estrogen metabolism, leading to hyperestrogenism.

questions.text: A female undergoes a methylene blue 3 swab test and the middle swab is stained with blue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Vesicovaginal Fistula

Explanation:

  • The middle swab being stained blue indicates a communication between the bladder and vagina, suggesting a vesicovaginal fistula.

Vesicovaginal fistula (VVF):

  • An abnormal opening between the bladder and the vagina, resulting in continuous urinary incontinence.
  • Symptoms: Constant dribbling of urine (true incontinence), genital area excoriation, depression, secondary amenorrhoea, and bladder stones.
  • Classification of VVFs:
    • Simple Fistulas:
      • Small in size (≤0.5 cm).
      • Present as single, non-radiated fistulas.
    • Complex Fistulas:
      • Large in size (≥2.5 cm).
      • Often result from chronic diseases or radiotherapy.
      • May include previously failed fistula repairs.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Methylene Blue - Three-swab Test: A catheter is inserted into the bladder through the urethra, and the vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile swabs. Dilute methylene blue dye (50-100 ml) is injected into the bladder.
      • Uppermost swab gets wet but not stained: The leak is from the ureter, indicating a ureterovaginal fistula.(Option D)
      • Middle swab gets stained: The leak is from the bladder, indicating a vesicovaginal fistula.
      • Lowermost swab gets stained: The leak is from the urethra, indicating a urethrovaginal fistula.(Option A)

    • Urine culture, cystoscopy, intravenous pyelography (IVP), ureteric catheterization, and sonography.
  • Management:
    • Conservative: Indwelling catheter and antibiotics for 3-4 weeks, followed by waiting 3 months for tissue healing before surgery.
    • Surgical Repair:
      • Vaginal repair (Latzko procedure, Chassar Moir technique) for most cases.
      • For large fistulas or failed repairs, abdominal approach may be required.
    • In cases of extensive bladder loss or failed repairs, urinary diversion techniques (e.g., sigmoid colon, ileal loop bladder) may be needed.

Vesicouterine Fistulas (Option C) are rare connections between the uterus and bladder, often after cesarean sections. Symptoms include urinary incontinence, hematuria. Diagnosis is made through cystoscopy or by injecting methylene blue into the bladder, with dye exiting the uterine cervix confirming the fistula.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones are secreted by sertoli cells and Leydig cells respectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inhibin and testosterone

Explanation:

  • Inhibin and testosterone are secreted by sertoli cells and Leydig cells respectively.

Leydig Cells:

  • These interstitial cells are responsible for androgen biosynthesis, primarily testosterone and androstenedione, regulating secondary sex characteristics.
  • Involved in testicular descent, development of the prostate, scrotum, penis, and differentiation of the Wolffian duct, forming the epididymides, vasa deferentia, and seminal vesicles.

Sertoli Cells:

  • Also known as sustentacular cells, they are pyramid-shaped cells within the seminiferous epithelium, with their bases against the basement membrane and tips toward the lumen.
  • Sertoli cells nurture and provide structural support for spermatogenic cells, accommodating their movement as they mature from the base to the lumen of seminiferous tubules.
  • Sertoli cells secrete androgen-binding protein, inhibin, and anti-Müllerian hormone (in the fetus). They also convert testosterone to estrogen and DHT.
     

Option A & C: DHA (Docosahexaenoic acid) is an omega-3 fatty acid and not a hormone. It is important for brain and eye health.

questions.text: A woman requests for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP). The doctor decides to perform a suction evacuation. Till when can this be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 12 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • Suction evacuation for medical termination of pregnancy can typically be performed up to 12 weeks of gestation.

Methods of Termination of Pregnancy:

Gestational Age

Abortive method

Up to 7 weeks

Medical Abortion (99% success rate if done before 7 weeks)

Up to 9 weeks

Up to 10 weeks
  • Medical Abortion
  • Suction evacuation

Up to 12 weeks
  • Suction evacuation
  • Dilatation and Curettage (D&C)

12-20 weeks (Option B & C)

Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)

20-24 weeks (Option D)
  • Dilatation and Evacuation (D&E)
  • Prostaglandin Induction.

>24 weeks

Hysterotomy

 

Medical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Regimen

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Best method with a high success rate.

 

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

Used when Mifepristone is not available.

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

Less commonly used.

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline.

Longer induction duration is rarely used.

 

Surgical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Procedure

Description

Image

1st

Manual Vacuum Aspiration (MVA)
  • MVA is an outpatient surgical abortion procedure used up to 12 weeks of gestation.
  • The procedure involves dilating the cervix and inserting a cannula attached to a manual vacuum aspirator or a 60-mL syringe.
  • The cannula is used to remove retained tissue from the uterus.
  • The approximate pressure is around - 610 mmHg.

 

Electric Vacuum Aspiration (EVA)
  • EVA is similar to MVA.
  • Instead of a manual syringe, it uses an electric pump to generate suction to remove retained products of conception.

 

Dilation and Curettage (D&C)

 
  • D&C is performed up to 12 weeks of gestation by dilating the cervix and using instruments like curettes and suction cannula.
  • MVA and EVA are preferred over sharp D&C for being safer and more efficient.

Karman’s cannula

 

Hegar’s dilator

 

Uterine curette

2nd

Dilation and Evacuation (D&E)

  • D&E is a 2nd-trimester abortion method involving cervical dilation using osmotic dilators. Ovum forceps are then used to remove the pregnancy tissue.
  • Draining amniotic fluid before removing the fetus is crucial to minimize the risk of amniotic fluid embolism during the procedure.

Ovum forceps

Hysterotomy

  • A hysterotomy is a surgical procedure where the uterus is incised to remove the fetus.
  • Reserved for 2nd-trimester abortions where other methods are not feasible or have failed.

questions.text: Please determine the segment of the liver that is highlighted in red in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) V

Explanation:

Segment V:

  • The segment highlighted in red is segment V, which is a part of the liver. In liver segmental anatomy, segment V corresponds to the anterior inferior segment of the right lobe.
  • This segment is situated near the right hepatic vein and is typically visualized on imaging studies like CT or MRI scans.

 

IVa (option B): Incorrect because segment IVa is part of the left lobe of the liver, specifically the anteromedial portion. It is not located in the area highlighted in red in the image.

VII (option C): Incorrect because segment VII is located in the posterior part of the right lobe of the liver, typically near the right hepatic vein but further back compared to segment V.

III (option D): Incorrect because segment III is part of the left lobe of the liver and located in the posterior part of the left lobe, closer to the left hepatic vein, which does not match the highlighted segment.

questions.text: What is the name of the radiotherapy treatment given to a cancer patient that involves administering a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy once daily for 5 days per week over a period of 6 to 8 weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Regular Fractionated radiotherapy

Explanation:

Regular Fractionated Radiotherapy:

  • This is the standard treatment regimen in radiotherapy for many cancers.
  • The patient receives a dose of 1.8 to 2 Gy per day, typically administered once daily for 5 days a week (Monday to Friday), with a total treatment course lasting between 6 to 8 weeks.
  • This approach allows for normal tissue recovery while delivering effective doses to the cancerous tissue.

Fractionated Radiotherapy

Definition: Treatment in multiple smaller doses (fractions) to enhance tumor control and protect normal tissue.

Key Principles

  • Therapeutic Window: Balances damage to tumor vs. normal tissue using the "5 Rs of Radiobiology":
    • Radiosensitivity: Tumor cells are more sensitive to radiation.
    • Repair: Normal tissue repairs better between treatments.
    • Reoxygenation: Hypoxic tumor cells reoxygenate, increasing sensitivity.
    • Redistribution: Cells cycle through phases of varying sensitivity.
    • Repopulation: Normal tissue regeneration, affecting treatment outcomes.
  • Fraction Size and Dose: Standard doses are 1.8-2 Gy per session, totaling 50-66 Gy over weeks.

Advances in Fractionation

Technique

Key Features

Spatially Fractionated Radiation Therapy (SFRT)

Delivers heterogeneous doses to spare normal tissue, effective in bulky tumors.

Hyperfractionation

More frequent, smaller doses to enhance local control.

Accelerated Fractionation

Shortens overall treatment time, maintaining or enhancing efficacy.

 

Challenges

  • Radioresistance: Tumors may develop resistance, requiring careful dose planning.
  • Scheduling: Ideal fractionation depends on tumor type, size, and location; research is ongoing

 

 

Hyper fractionated Radiotherapy (option B): Incorrect because in hyperfractionated radiotherapy, smaller doses of radiation (usually 1.2 to 1.5 Gy) are given multiple times a day (typically twice), rather than once daily.

Accelerated Fractionation Radiotherapy (option C): Incorrect because accelerated fractionation involves delivering radiation doses more frequently, often with a shorter overall treatment duration (e.g., increasing the daily dose or increasing the frequency of radiation delivery within a shorter period).

Brachytherapy (option D): Incorrect because brachytherapy is a type of radiotherapy where a radioactive source is placed directly inside or very close to the tumor. It is typically used for specific cancers (e.g., prostate, cervical) rather than the fractionated external beam therapy described in the question.

questions.text: Please identify the section of the intestine shown in the barium study provided.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Jejunum

Explanation:

The jejunum is the second part of the small intestine, following the duodenum and preceding the ileum. It is typically characterized by:

  • A thicker, more vascular wall compared to the ileum.
  • Plicae circulares (circular folds) are prominent in the jejunum, and the mucosal surface appears folded in the barium study.
  • The barium study would show coarse, dense mucosal folds which is a distinctive feature of the jejunum.

Various Bubble signs of the abdomen:

Condition

Radiological Sign

Explanation

Normal Abdomen

Single bubble in the stomach

A single air bubble seen in the left upper quadrant corresponds to the fundus of the stomach. A large single bubble is seen in cases of pyloric atresia, GOO.

Pyloric Atresia

"Single bubble" sign

A single distended stomach with no air in the small bowel or beyond, caused by obstruction at the pylorus.

 

Duodenal Atresia

"Double bubble" sign

Distended stomach and proximal duodenum; no distal bowel gas due to obstruction at the duodenum.

Jejunal Atresia

"Triple bubble" sign

Three distended loops of bowel (stomach, duodenum, proximal jejunum) with no distal gas.

Ileal Atresia

Multiple air-fluid levels

Dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels and no gas in the large intestine, more distal than jejunal atresia.

 

Ileum (option A): Incorrect because the ileum is the third and longest part of the small intestine. It is often characterized by fewer, less prominent folds compared to the jejunum and a thinner wall. In a barium study, it would show less dense mucosal folds than the jejunum.

Transverse colon (option B): Incorrect because the transverse colon is part of the large intestine, which would appear with a wider lumen and less defined folds compared to the small intestine. The characteristic features of the transverse colon would not match the dense folds of the jejunum seen in the barium study.

Splenic flexure (option D): Incorrect because the splenic flexure is the bend between the ascending colon and the descending colon, located near the spleen. It has a much larger and less folded appearance compared to the jejunum in a barium study.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Postpartum blues

Explanation:

  • The woman's symptoms of tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia 5 days postpartum are most consistent with Postpartum blues.

Disorder

Postpartum Blues (Option B)

Postpartum Depression (Option A)

Postpartum Psychosis (Option C)

Onset

4-5 days after delivery, lasts a few days

Gradual onset over 4-6 months following delivery or abortion

Sudden, typically within 4-6 weeks after delivery

Duration

Transient, lasts for a few days

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Can persist beyond postpartum period

Symptoms
  • Depression
  • Anxiety
  • Tearfulness
  • Insomnia
  • Negative feelings
  • Mood swings
  • Loss of energy and appetite
  • Insomnia
  • Social withdrawal
  • Irritability
  • Suicidal attitude
  • Fear
  • Restlessness
  • Hallucinations
  • Delusions
  • Disorientation
  • Suicidal and infantile impulses

Treatment
  • Reassurance
  • psychological support
  • CBT
  • SSRIs, estrogen Patch later.
  • Urgent psychiatric consultation, hospitalization.
  • Chlorpromazine, sublingual estradiol, lithium, ECT (if necessary)

Prognosis

Good

Good with treatment

High risk of recurrence

Breastfeeding

Generally safe

Safe with SSRIs

Contraindicated with some medications (Lithium)

Postpartum anxiety (Option D is defined by excessive or severe worry after childbirth and may include somatic symptoms, but the described symptoms are more consistent with postpartum blues. The DSM-5 offers no standardized criteria for perinatal anxiety.

questions.text: A primigravida woman gives birth to a baby with the following defect. Identify the anomaly.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Craniorachischisis

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a severe neural tube defect with exposure of both the brain and spinal cord, which is characteristic of craniorachischisis.

Craniorachischisis:

  • A severe neural tube defect where the closure defect of the neural tube extends from the cephalic region (anencephaly) into the spinal cord.
  • Features:
    • Anencephaly is present, with a large defect involving the spine.
    • The vault of the skull and parts of the vertebral column are absent.
  • Polyhydramnios occurs due to the absence of the swallowing reflex.

Spina Bifida:

  • A general term for neural tube defects (NTDs) affecting the spinal region, where the vertebral arches split.
  • Types of spina bifida:
    • Spina Bifida Occulta:
      • A defect in the vertebral arches covered by skin, typically in the sacral region (S1-S2).
      • Does not usually involve neural tissue and is often asymptomatic.
      • May be marked by a patch of hair over the affected region but typically does not cause disability.
    • Meningocele:
      • A severe NTD where only the meninges (fluid-filled sacs) protrude through the defect.
    • Myelomeningocele/Meningomyelocele: (Option A & C)
      • A severe NTD where both meninges and neural tissue protrude through the defect, resulting in neurological deficits.
      • Often found in the lumbosacral region.

 

Rachischisis (Myeloschisis): (Option D)

  • A severe form of spina bifida that involves significant neural tissue malformation.
  • Occurs when the neural folds fail to elevate, leaving a flattened mass of neural tissue.
  • This defect can occur in either the spinal cord or brain region.
  • The exposed neural tissue becomes necrotic and deteriorates.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Condyloma accuminata

Explanation:

  • The image shown indicates Condylomata acuminata.

Condylomata Acuminata (Anogenital Warts):

  • Caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV), primarily strains 6 and 11.
  • Mainly transmitted through sexual contact.
  • Risk Factors: Age, lifestyle, and sexual practices influence susceptibility.
  • Diagnosed clinically, but histopathological examination reveals acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and koilocytes (large keratinocytes with pyknotic nuclei).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Usually asymptomatic, though they may cause bleeding, pruritus, and pain.
    • Typically appear as raised, skin-colored, fleshy papules.
    • Size ranges from one to five millimeters in diameter.
    • Can be broad and flat, pedunculated (on a stalk), or occasionally have a cauliflower-like appearance.
    • Lesions are commonly found in multiples and may coalesce.
    • Present in the anogenital region or, less frequently, the oral cavity.
  • Management:
    • Treatment is typically not required for lesions that resolve spontaneously.
    • Persistent or symptomatic lesions: Topical therapies (e.g., podophyllotoxin, imiquimod), cryotherapy, TCA application, or surgical excision.
    • Surgical methods like electrosurgery and laser therapy are effective for refractory cases.

 

Condyloma lata (Option A) is associated with secondary syphilis and typically presents as flat, broad, wart-like lesions. These lesions are painless and have a moist appearance, often occurring in the genital area.

 

Molluscum contagiosum (Option B) is caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus and results in small, dome-shaped papules or nodules with a central depression. These lesions are typically painless and can be found on various areas of the body.

 

None of the Above (Option D): This option is not correct in this context because the image does indeed resemble a specific skin condition, and that condition is Condyloma acuminata, not ‘None of the Above’.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department with chills and rigors. She has acute pain in the right flank region. The imaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Emphysematous pyelonephritis

Explanation:

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis:

  • This is a severe, necrotizing infection of the kidney, typically caused by gas-producing organisms (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella).
  • The hallmark imaging feature in CT scan would be the presence of gas in the renal parenchyma or renal collecting system.
  • Symptoms typically include flank pain, fever, chills, and rigors, and it is commonly seen in diabetic patients or those with immunocompromised states.
  • The radiological finding of gas within the renal parenchyma on the CT scan supports this diagnosis.

Acute Pyelonephritis

Xanthogranulomatous Pyelonephritis

Emphysematous Pyelonephritis

Ultrasound (USG): This may show kidney enlargement, reduced echogenicity, and dilated collecting systems.

 

 

 

Ultrasound (USG): Shows an enlarged kidney with echogenic staghorn calculi and hypoechoic masses replacing renal parenchyma.

 

 

Plain Abdominal X-ray: Detects gas in the kidney region in about 70% of cases.

 

 

Contrast-enhanced CT: Most sensitive, showing wedge-shaped hypodense areas, striated nephrograms, and pelvic wall thickening.

 

CT Scan reveals a non-functioning kidney, staghorn calculus, expanded calyces, and inflammatory changes. A characteristic bear paw sign is noted.

 

CT: Gold standard, reveals gas within the kidney, renal enlargement, perinephric stranding and abscesses. Helps classify into Type 1 (gas without fluid) or Type 2 (gas with fluid).

 

Acute infection of the kidney involving the renal parenchyma and collecting system is usually caused by ascending bacteria.
  • It is a chronic granulomatous response to recurrent renal infection - that leads to the destruction of renal parenchyma and its replacement by lipid-laden foamy macrophages.
  • Destruction spreads from the renal pelvis→medulla→ cortex.
  • Usually, staghorn calculus is present in the pelvis.

Severe necrotizing infection with gas accumulation in and around the kidney, primarily in diabetic patients.

 

Cholecystitis (option A): Incorrect because cholecystitis is an inflammation of the gallbladder, typically presenting with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The imaging would show gallstones and a thickened gallbladder wall rather than gas in the renal system.

Small bowel obstruction (option C): Incorrect because small bowel obstruction presents with symptoms of vomiting, abdominal distension, and failure to pass flatus or stool. Imaging would typically show dilated loops of bowel and air-fluid levels, not gas in the kidney or renal system.

Volvulus (option D): Incorrect because volvulus refers to the twisting of the bowel, leading to bowel obstruction. It would cause abdominal distension, pain, and vomiting, with imaging showing distended loops of bowel and sometimes a twisted mesenteric root. There would be no gas in the kidney or renal parenchyma.

questions.text:
A pregnant woman presented with complaints of passing grape-like vesicles vaginally. A USG scan was done and is shown below. Which of the following hormone levels need to be checked in this patient?

hCG-Human Chorionic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) hCG

Explanation:

  • The presentation of grape-like vesicles and the ultrasound finding showing a snowstorm appearance strongly suggest a hydatidiform mole. The most appropriate hormone level to check in this patient is hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin).

Follow-up of Molar Pregnancy:

  • β-hCG Monitoring:
    • The initial test is within 48 hours post-evacuation for baseline.
    • Follow-up every 1-2 weeks until 3 consecutive normal values
    • Post-Normalization Testing: Monthly β-hCG tests for another 6 months.
  • Median Resolution Time for GTD :
    • Partial moles: 6 weeks.
    • Complete moles: 7 weeks.
  • Normalisation Timeline of beta HCG levels:
    • 95% by 14 weeks.
    • 99% by 25 weeks
  • Evaluation for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is required if β-hCG levels increase or plateau.

  • It is advised to avoid conception for up to 12 months. But If Pregnancy is desired, may conceive 6 months after serum beta HCG normalization.
  • Delay pregnancy for 1 year after gestational trophoblastic neoplasia and 2 years if metastasis is present.

questions.text: A young primigravida at 32 weeks gestation was admitted since her BP was 150/90 mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. On examination, she has pedal edema. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Preeclampsia

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with elevated blood pressure (150/90 mmHg), proteinuria (2+ on urine dipstick), and pedal edema, which are characteristic signs of Preeclampsia.

Preeclampsia:

  • Types of Preeclampsia:
    • Early-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at <34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Defective placenta due to altered trophoblast invasion and placental ischemia.
      • Features: Placental infarcts, arterial sclerosis, and hypoperfusion.
    • Late-Onset Preeclampsia:
      • Occurs at ≥34 weeks gestation.
      • Etiology: Healthy placenta interacting with maternal factors, causing microvascular damage and endothelial dysfunction.
      • Features: Maintained placental perfusion; managed expectantly until 37 weeks if stable.
  • Clinical Presentations:
    • New-onset headache unresponsive to medication.
    • Visual disturbances.
    • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain, often with nausea or vomiting.
    • Shortness of breath.
    • Worsened swelling beyond baseline pregnancy-related symptoms.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Elevated blood pressure:
      • SBP ≥140 mmHg or DBP ≥90 mmHg on two measurements at least 4 hours apart.
      • Severe hypertension: SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg.
    • Edema: Dependent (lower extremities) or independent (face, hands).
    • Lung examination for pulmonary disturbances.
    • Tenderness in the right upper quadrant or epigastric area.
  • Laboratory Tests:
    • Proteinuria: Urine dipstick ≥2+, 24-hour collection ≥300 mg, or protein/creatinine ratio ≥0.3.
    • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count <100 K/mm³.
    • Impaired Liver Function: Liver enzymes >2 times the upper limit of normal.
    • Renal Insufficiency: Serum creatinine ≥1.1 mg/dL or double baseline levels.
  • Management:
    • Antihypertensive Therapy:
      • For severe hypertension (SBP ≥160 mmHg or DBP ≥110 mmHg):
        • IV Medications: Labetalol, hydralazine.
        • Oral Medications: Immediate-release nifedipine.
      • For maintenance:
        • PO Medications: Labetalol, extended-release nifedipine, or clonidine.
    • Seizure Prophylaxis:
      • First-Line: IV magnesium sulfate.
      • Alternatives (if contraindicated): Levetiracetam or benzodiazepines for seizure treatment.
    • Definitive Treatment: Delivery of the fetus is the only definitive cure.
    • Delivery Timing:
      • Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia without Severe Features: Deliver at 37 weeks.
      • Severe Features at ≥34 weeks: Delivery after maternal stabilization.
      • Severe Features <34 weeks: Expectant management with close monitoring and antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturation if stable.

 

Placenta previa (Option A) is characterized by painless vaginal bleeding and the placenta covering the cervix, it does not typically present with high blood pressure, proteinuria, or pedal edema as seen in this case.

Placenta abruptio (Option B) typically presents with abdominal pain and painful vaginal bleeding due to placental detachment, whereas the patient’s signs of pedal edema and proteinuria are more suggestive of preeclampsia.

Spontaneous Abortion (Option C) occurs in the early stages of pregnancy and is associated with vaginal bleeding and cramping, not high blood pressure or proteinuria.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pneumomediastinum

Explanation:

Pneumomediastinum:

  • Hamman sign is a characteristic physical finding heard on auscultation. It is described as a crunching sound or synchronous clicking sound with the heartbeat, often heard in the precordial area.
  • It is typically associated with pneumomediastinum, where air is present in the mediastinal space, often due to esophageal rupture or trauma. The air in the mediastinum creates a distinctive sound when it moves with the heartbeats, producing the Hamman sign.

Pneumomediastinum:

  • Presence of free air around mediastinal structures.
  • Common Causes:
    • Blunt or penetrating trauma.
    • Esophageal perforation.
    • Recent interventions in the esophageal or tracheobronchial tree.
    • Pulmonary infections.
    • Gas-forming infections in the mediastinum.
    • Cocaine inhalation.
    • Extension of air from a pneumothorax.
  • Hamman's crunch sign: Unusual, adventitious sound heard on auscultation of the chest.
  • Radiographic Signs:
    • Ring around the artery sign: Air around the pulmonary artery (usually the right) outlining the artery.
  • Sail sign: Elevation of the thymus caused by air.
  • Continuous diaphragm sign: Air trapped posterior to the pericardium, appearing as a continuous air collection on an AP projection
  • Tubular artery sign: Air outlines the medial side of major aortic branches, with aerated lung outlining the lateral side.
  • Double bronchial wall sign: Air adjacent to the bronchus highlights the bronchial wall.
  • Naclerio V-sign: V-shaped air lucency in the left lower mediastinal area.

 

Pneumoperitoneum (option A): Incorrect because pneumoperitoneum refers to air in the peritoneal cavity, usually caused by gastrointestinal perforation. It does not typically produce the Hamman sign. Instead, it is more commonly detected through radiological imaging (e.g., abdominal X-ray) showing air under the diaphragm.

Pneumopericardium (option B): Incorrect because pneumopericardium is the presence of air in the pericardial sac around the heart, which may lead to cardiac tamponade. While it can cause a clinical presentation of chest pain or dyspnoea, it is not typically associated with the Hamman sign.

Hydropneumothorax (option D): Incorrect because hydropneumothorax refers to the accumulation of both air and fluid in the pleural cavity, commonly due to trauma or infection. While it may cause dyspnoea and chest pain, it does not produce the characteristic Hamman sign.

questions.text: A girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth.USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum testosterone

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario with irregular periods, acne, increased facial hair growth, and multiple ovarian follicles on ultrasound point towards diagnosis of Polycystic Ovary

Syndrome (PCOS). In PCOS, serum tests typically show elevated serum testosterone levels.

Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), also known as Stein-Leventhal syndrome, is a heterogeneous, multisystem endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age with ovarian expression of various metabolic disturbances.

Components of PCOS:

  • Increased androgens
  • Ovulatory dysfunction
  • Polycystic ovaries

Clinical features:

  • Usually present in young women
  • Central obesity (BMI > 30kg/cm2), waistline> 88cm.
  • Oligomenorrhea, amenorrhoea
  • Infertility
  • Hirsutism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance

Endocrinological changes in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS):

  • Oestrone/Estrone levels rise.
  • Luteinizing hormone (LH) levels are elevated (>10 IU/mL).
  • FSH levels remain normal (Option C), but the FSH/LH ratio decreases. (Option D)
  • Sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) levels fall due to hyperandrogenism. (Option A)
  • Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels increase.
  • Fasting blood glucose and insulin levels suggest insulin resistance, with fasting insulin levels >10 mIU/L in 50-70% of cases.
  • Triglyceride levels rise (>150 mg/dL), indicating hyperlipidemia, and HDL (High-Density Lipoprotein) is low (<50 mg/dL).
  • Testosterone levels may exceed 2 ng/mL, with free testosterone >2.2 pg/mL (normal range: 0.2-0.8 ng/mL).
  • Androstenedione levels are typically normal.
  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) levels are raised.
  • Prolactin may be mildly elevated in 15% of cases.
  • Thyroid function tests can be abnormal, with a tendency toward hypothyroidism.
  • Urinary cortisol levels are low (<50 µg/24 hours).

Rotterdam Criteria for diagnosing PCOS: Two of the following three criteria must be present:

  • Increased androgen levels: Leading to symptoms like hirsutism or acne, or biochemical findings such as high testosterone.
  • Ovulatory dysfunction: Irregular or absent menstrual cycles (oligomenorrhea/ amenorrhea) due to ovulatory dysfunction.
  • Ultrasound findings: Ovaries with >12 follicles (2-9mm) and/or ovarian volume ≥10 cm³, showing a "necklace pattern" of cysts arranged peripherally with excessive stromal tissue in the centre producing androgens.

Management:

  • Lifestyle Modifications:
    • Weight Loss: Improves hormonal balance and reduces testosterone and insulin levels.
    • Lifestyle Changes: Smoking cessation.
  • Pharmacologic Treatment:
    • OCPs: Regulate menstruation, treat hirsutism, and improve acne.
    • Anti-androgens: Spironolactone and ketoconazole reduce testosterone.
    • Metformin: Improves fertility and lowers insulin and testosterone levels.
    • Dexamethasone: Reduces androgen production.
  • Infertility Treatment:
    • Clomiphene Citrate: For ovulation induction.
    • Letrozole: For clomiphene-resistant cases.
  • Surgical Treatment:
    • Laparoscopic Ovarian Drilling: For infertility or hyperstimulation despite medical therapy.
    • Surgery is indicated if:
      • Medical therapy fails
      • Hyperstimulation occurs
      • Infertility persists
      • There are previous pregnancy losses

questions.text: A male was referred to the urology OPD for evaluation of infertility. Karyotyping analysis revealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about the condition?

choices.text: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

Explanation:

  • A male presenting with infertility was found to have an XXY karyotype, consistent with a diagnosis of Klinefelter syndrome. Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are elevated, not reduced, in this condition.

Klinefelter Syndrome:

  • Male hypogonadism caused by an extra X chromosome (e.g., 47,XXY).
  • Most common sex chromosome disorder (1 in 5000 male births).
  • Clinical Features:
    • Body Habit: Elongated body, eunuchoid habitus, abnormally long legs.
    • Hypogonadism: Small testes, small penis, and absent secondary male characteristics (deep voice, beard, male pubic hair). (Option B & D)
    • Cognitive Impact: Average to below-average intelligence; deficits in verbal and language skills.
    • Gynecomastia
    • Increased Comorbidities: Type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, mitral valve prolapse (50%), congenital heart defects, osteoporosis, extragonadal germ cell tumors, breast cancer, and autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus).
  • Genetic and Pathological Findings:
    • Karyotype:
      • Classic: 47,XXY (90% of cases).
      • Mosaic patterns: e.g., 46,XY/47,XXY (15%).
    • Sex Chromatin: Positive, like females, due to the extra X chromosome.
    • Testicular Biopsy:
      • Hyaline degeneration of seminiferous tubules.
      • Prominent Leydig cells due to gonadotropin elevation.
    • Hormonal Changes:
      • Elevated FSH and LH
      • Reduced testosterone
      • Increased estradiol (Option C)

questions.text: In a 35-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation, which of the following conditions is oxytocin contraindicated for?

choices.text: Induction of labor in post-term pregnancy
Augmentation of labor in case of slow progress
Preterm labor with cervical dilation of 3 cm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Placenta covering internal os

Explanation:

  • Placenta previa, where the placenta partially or completely covers the internal os, is a contraindication for oxytocin use. In this condition, inducing or augmenting labor with oxytocin can lead to severe bleeding.

Oxytocin:

  • Indications:
    • Antepartum Indications (FDA-approved):
      • For mothers with preeclampsia, maternal diabetes, or premature rupture of membranes.
      • For mothers with an inactive uterus requiring stimulation to start labor.
      • For inevitable or incomplete abortions in the second trimester.
    • Postpartum Indications (FDA-approved):
      • To help deliver the placenta during the third stage of labor.
      • To control postpartum hemorrhage.
    • Non-FDA-approved Indications:
      • Treatment of delayed orgasm.
      • Inducing sexual arousal.
      • Treatment of autism (potential role in improving social skills but requires further studies).
  • Contraindications:
    • Hypersensitivity
    • Contraindications for Vaginal Deliveries:
      • Active genital herpes infection.
      • Vasa previa (blood vessels in the membranes).
      • Placenta previa.
      • Invasive cervical cancer.
      • Prolapse or presentation of the umbilical cord.
    • Fetal Abnormalities:
      • Fetus in an abnormal position, such as transverse lie.
      • Fetal distress when delivery is not imminent.
    • Pelvic and Uterine Issues:
      • Inadequate pelvic size for vaginal delivery.
      • Hyperactive or hypertonic uterus.
         

Induction of labor in post-term pregnancy (Option B): Oxytocin is commonly used for labor induction in post-term pregnancies (beyond 40 weeks). It helps initiate contractions and progress labor safely, making it an appropriate choice in this scenario.

Augmentation of labor in case of slow progress (Option C): Oxytocin is frequently used to augment labor when progress is slow. By strengthening contractions, it helps move labor forward effectively. Unless contraindications like placenta previa or fetal distress are present, this is a standard and appropriate use of oxytocin.

Preterm labor with cervical dilation of 3 cm (Option D): In cases of preterm labor, oxytocin may be used to enhance contractions and ensure labor progresses safely, especially when delivery is inevitable. A cervical dilation of 3 cm indicates that labor has started, and oxytocin could be considered for augmentation if deemed safe by the healthcare provider.

questions.text: Whole-body CT scan protocol for a trauma patient includes all, except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT Limbs

Explanation:

  • Whole-body CT protocols for trauma patients are designed to assess life-threatening injuries quickly. They focus on critical areas such as the head, cervical spine, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. CT scans of the limbs are not routinely included unless there is specific clinical suspicion of significant limb injuries.

 

CT Head (option A): This is included to detect traumatic brain injuries, fractures, or haemorrhages, which are common in major trauma cases.

CT Cervical spine (option B): This is included to evaluate for cervical spine fractures or ligamentous injuries, which are critical in trauma patients with suspected spinal injuries.

CT Abdomen (option D): This is included to identify abdominal organ injuries, bleeding, or free fluid, which are crucial to diagnose promptly in trauma management.

questions.text: What is the dose of Misoprostol in medical abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 800 micrograms

Explanation:

  • The standard and widely accepted dose of misoprostol for medical abortion (up to 10 weeks gestation) is 800 micrograms.

Medical Methods of MTP:

Trimester

Regimen

Indication

Notes

1st

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 800 mcg vaginally after 24 hours

Medical abortion; Miscarriage.

Best method with a high success rate.

 

2nd

Mifepristone 200 mg orally, followed by Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Hygroscopic dilators (e.g., laminaria) may be used before administration for cervical ripening.

Misoprostol 400 mcg every 3 hours for up to 5 doses

MTP

Used when Mifepristone is not available.

Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal every 4 hours.

MTP

Less commonly used.

High-dose intravenous Oxytocin in saline.

MTP

Longer induction duration is rarely used.
  • Complications: Bleeding, Cramping, incomplete abortion.
  • Rh D-negative women should receive anti-D immunoglobulin to prevent Rh alloimmunization.
  • Counselling and provision of post-abortion contraception are essential, as ovulation can occur as early as eight days after an abortion.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is correct in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Serum creatinine decrease

Explanation: Serum creatinine decreases during pregnancy.

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) During Pregnancy: (Option A)

  • Increases by 25% by the second week of pregnancy and by 50% in the first trimester.
  • Elevated GFR persists until term despite a decline in renal plasma flow in late pregnancy.

Serum Creatinine During Pregnancy:

  • Normal nonpregnant level: ~0.7 mg/dL.
  • Declines to ~0.5 mg/dL during pregnancy.
  • Values >0.9 mg/dL may indicate renal disease.

Platelet Count During Pregnancy:

  • Average platelet count decreases throughout pregnancy. (Option B & D)
  • Returns to nonpregnant levels within 4 to 12 weeks postpartum.
  • Platelet counts are lower in twin pregnancies.

questions.text: McCall’s culdoplasty is done in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enterocele repair

Explanation:

  • McCall’s culdoplasty is done in Enterocele repair.

Enterocele:

  • Herniation of the pouch of Douglas into the rectovaginal septum, often associated with uterine prolapse.
  • Location:
    • Upper one-third of the posterior vaginal wall: Enterocele.
    • Lower two-thirds: Rectocele.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bowel incontinence
    • Constipation/diarrhea
    • Pelvic discomfort
    • Sexual dysfunction
    • Mass descending per vaginam
  • Surgical Procedures:
    • McCall Culdoplasty: Fixes the uterosacral and Mackenrodt's ligaments to the vaginal vault and peritoneum of the pouch of Douglas.
    • Moschcowitz Repair: Obliterates the cul-de-sac of the pouch of Douglas via several purse-string sutures, often during abdominal surgery.
    • Halban’s Procedure: Obliterates the peritoneal sac using vertical sutures, transvaginal or abdominal route.

questions.text: Galactokinesis is governed by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oxytocin

Explanation:

  • Oxytocin is the most powerful galactokinetic hormone, triggering milk extrusion from the mammary gland.

Hormones Involved in Breast Milk Production:

questions.text: Sperm count on a seminormal is 16 million/ml, with 40% motility and <1% of sperm with normal morphology. What is the term for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)Teratospermia

Explanation:

  • The sperm count of 16 million/ml and 40% motility are borderline normal, but less than 1% normal morphology is abnormal, indicating Teratospermia.

Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more


Reproductive Terms Related to Semen Analysis:

  • Normospermia: Normal sperm count, motility, and morphology. (Option B)
  • Aspermia: Complete absence of semen.
  • Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in the semen.
  • Oligospermia: Low sperm count. (Option A)
  • Asthenospermia: Reduced or absent motility of sperm. (Option C)
  • Necrospermia: Presence of dead sperm.
  • Teratospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female presented with a history of vaginal delivery 2 days ago and complained of pain and sensory loss in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. Which of the following nerves is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

Explanation:

  • The involved nerve is the Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, which can be compressed during labor, leading to pain and sensory loss in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh, often resulting in meralgia paresthetica.

Obstetrical Neuropathies:

  • Lateral femoral cutaneous neuropathy (24%) is the most common, followed by femoral neuropathy (14%), particularly after vaginal delivery.
  • Compression of Lumbosacral Nerve Plexus:
    • Occurs during labor due to fetal head descent or use of forceps.
    • Can result in neuralgia, cramp-like pains, sensory loss, or muscle paralysis.
    • Possible foot drop from injury to the lumbosacral plexus, sciatic nerve, or common fibular (peroneal) nerve.
  • Common Fibular Nerve Compression:
    • Caused by prolonged positioning in stirrups during second-stage labor.
  • Nerve Injuries with Cesarean Delivery:
    • Iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerve damage.
  • Rare Complications:
    • Lumbar arachnoiditis following epidural analgesia, leading to severe bilateral neuropathic pain.


Sciatic nerve (Option A) innervates the posterior thigh and lower leg, not the anterolateral thigh. Symptoms from sciatic nerve injury typically include pain, numbness, and weakness along the back of the thigh, leg, and foot, not the anterolateral thigh.

Obturator nerve (Option B) supplies the medial thigh muscles and provides sensation to the medial aspect of the thigh, not the anterolateral thigh. Injury to this nerve would cause symptoms in the medial thigh, not the anterolateral region.

Ilioinguinal nerve (Option C) provides sensory innervation to the upper groin, mons pubis, and labia majora, but it does not affect the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. It is not responsible for the sensory loss described in this case.

questions.text: A male patient presented for the evaluation of infertility. He has been having recurrent hospitalization for infections, since 2 years of age. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary ciliary dyskinesia

Explanation:

  • A male patient with infertility and a history of recurrent lung infections since childhood is most likely to have Primary ciliary dyskinesia.

Primary Ciliary Dyskinesia (PCD):

  • A genetically heterogeneous recessive disorder of motile cilia causing oto-sino-pulmonary diseases and organ laterality defects in 50% of cases.
  • Respiratory Distress in Term Neonates: Over 80% of full-term neonates with PCD have respiratory distress, often misdiagnosed as transient tachypnea or pneumonia.
  • Oto-Sino-Pulmonary Manifestations:
    • Early signs: nasal congestion, wet cough, chronic otitis media, recurrent sinus infections, and bronchiectasis.
    • Diagnosis may be missed due to symptom overlap with other respiratory conditions.
  • Lung Diseases:
    • Persistent wet cough and chronic infections lead to bronchiectasis.
    • Lung function may deteriorate early, with worsening spirometry over time.
  • Nonpulmonary Manifestations:
    • Situs Inversus: Seen in 60% of pediatric patients, linked to cilia dysfunction.
    • Congenital Heart Disease: More common in those with situs ambiguus.
    • Fertility: Male infertility due to sperm motility issues; women may have reduced fertility or ectopic pregnancies.
    • Pectus Excavatum and Scoliosis: Found in 10% and 5–10% of patients, respectively.

 

Celiac disease (Option A) is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten consumption, leading to malabsorption with symptoms like diarrhea, abdominal pain, and weight loss, which are absent in this case. It primarily affects the gastrointestinal system, not the respiratory system, making it unlikely in this scenario.

Cystic fibrosis (Option B) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene. Diagnostic criteria for cystic fibrosis:

  • One of:
    • Sweat chloride concentration > 60 mmol/l on at least two occasions
    • Two CF-causing mutations
    • Abnormal chloride transport (nasal PD)

                                         and

  • One of:
    • Clinical characteristics, typical for CF
    • Sibling with CF
    • Positive newborn screening

COPD (Option D) (Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) is a chronic respiratory condition typically seen in adults, often related to smoking or environmental exposure. It presents with symptoms like chronic cough, sputum production, and dyspnea on exertion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bacterial vaginosis

Explanation:

  • A female with profuse vaginal discharge and a fishy odor, along with clue cells on microscopy, is most likely to have Bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV):

  • A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora.
  • Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.
    • Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis.
    • Not sexually transmitted.
  • Symptoms:
    • 50% are asymptomatic.
    • Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent.
    • Minimal vulval irritation.
  • Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features):
    • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
    • Discharge with pH >4.5.
    • Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test).
    • Presence of clue cells on wet mount.
  • Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria.
  • Complications:
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
    • Preterm labor
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole (DOC):
      • 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%).
      • Single 1 g dose cures only 45%.
    • Clindamycin:
      • 2% cream locally (85% effective).
      • Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days.
    • Alternatives:
      • Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, tinidazole or sulfa drugs.

 

Herpes (Option A) typically presents with painful blisters or ulcers on the genital area, not with profuse vaginal discharge or clue cells.

Candida albicans (Option B) causes thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge, itching, and presents with pseudohyphae and yeast cells on KOH mount, but not a fishy odor or clue cells on wet mount.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option C) causes frothy, greenish-yellow discharge with itching, burning, and motile trichomonas on wet mount, but lacks a fishy odor and it doesn't cause clue cells.

questions.text: Which of the following can not be used for emergency contraception?

choices.text: LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours

Explanation:

  • LNG 0.75 mg single dose in 72 hours is not to be used for emergency contraception.

Emergency Contraceptives (EC):

  • Prevents unintended pregnancy after unprotected or inadequately protected intercourse.
  • It includes both emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs) and the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD):
  • Emergency Contraceptive Pills (ECPs):
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG): (Option A)
      • Available as a single 1.5 mg pill.
      • Most effective within 72 hours but can be used up to 120 hours.
      • Commonly available in India.
    • Ulipristal Acetate (UPA):
      • Single-dose pill containing 30 mg of ulipristal acetate. (Option D)
      • Effective for up to 120 hours (5 days) post-intercourse.
      • Approved by US-FDA and European medicine agencies.
      • Not available in India.
    • Combined Hormonal Regimens (Yuzpe Method):
      • Involves taking 2 doses, 12 hours apart.
      • Each dose contains at least 100 micrograms of ethinyl estradiol and 500 micrograms of levonorgestrel.
    • Centchroman:
      • Two 60 mg tablets, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours. (Option B)
      • Effective only if taken within 24 hours post-intercourse.
      • Requires adequate trials to establish its effectiveness as emergency contraception.
  • Intrauterine Device (IUD):
    • Copper IUD:
      • Most effective form of EC.
      • It can be inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct cause of maternal death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Eclampsia

Explanation:

  • Eclampsia is a direct cause of maternal death, while other options are indirect causes of maternal death.
  • Maternal deaths and late maternal deaths are combined in the 11th revision of the ICD under the grouping of ‘comprehensive maternal deaths’.
  • Direct Obstetric Deaths:
    • Result from obstetric complications during pregnancy, labor, or puerperium.
    • Examples:
      • Obstetric hemorrhage.
      • Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy.
      • Obstructed labor.
      • Complications from interventions like anesthesia or cesarean section.
