  • Indirect Obstetric Deaths:
    • Result from pre-existing diseases or diseases developed during pregnancy.
    • Aggravated by the physiological effects of pregnancy.
    • Examples:
      • Aggravation of cardiac or renal disease due to pregnancy. (Option C)
      • Anemia (Option A)
      • Malaria (Option B)

questions.text: The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 24-28 weeks of gestation

Explanation:

  • The screening method for GDM recommended in India is done between 24-28 weeks of gestation.

One-step approach recommended by WHO and IAD PSG (International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Group):

  • It is done in all pregnant females at 24-28 weeks.
  • It is used both for screening and diagnostic purposes.
  • The patient is advised to have an unrestricted diet for 72 hours, followed by overnight fasting, and then 75 gm of glucose is given.
  • A total of 3 samples are taken:
    • 1st sample: Fasting sample.
    • 2nd sample: After 1 hour of 75 gm of glucose.
    • 3rd sample: After 2 hours of 75 gm of glucose.
  • Interpretation: If any 1 value is abnormal, the patient is considered as having gestational diabetes.

 

mg/dL

mmol/litre

Fasting

≤ 92

5.1

1 hour

≤ 180

10.1

2 hours

≤ 153

8.5

The two-step approach advocated by ACOG is not recommended due to its two-step process:

  • Oral glucose challenge test: Performed by giving 50 gm of glucose irrespective of previous meals and no fasting required.
  • Glucose tolerance test: Confirmatory test is done using 100 gm of glucose after overnight fasting of 8 hours.

questions.text: In which trimester is the quadruple test performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2nd trimester

Explanation:

  • Quadruple test is performed during 2nd trimester (15-22 weeks).

Prenatal Genetic Screening:

 

First trimester

Second trimester

Timing

11 - 14 weeks

15 - 22 weeks

Screening test

 
  • Dual Test:
    • PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein-A)
    • Beta-hCG
  • Can be combined with ultrasound measurement of - Nuchal translucency (NT) and nasal bone If NT is ≥ 3 mm in the first trimester
  • Triple Test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Beta hCG

OR

  • Quadruple Test:
    • Maternal Serum Alpha Fetoprotein (MSAFP)
    • Unconjugated estriol (uE3)
    • Beta hCG
    • Dimeric inhibin-A

questions.text: A female patient with postpartum hemorrhage has been given ergometrine and oxytocin. The bleeding still continues. Which prostaglandin derivative can be given in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Carboprost

Explanation:

  • The prostaglandin derivative effective for refractory postpartum hemorrhage after oxytocin and ergometrine is Carboprost.

Uterotonic Agents for Postpartum Hemorrhage (PPH) Management:

  • First-Line Agent:
    • Oxytocin:
      • WHO recommends first-line prophylaxis.
      • Dosage: 20 units in 1000 mL crystalloid IV at 10 mL/min (200 mU/min).
      • IM administration is an alternative if IV access is unavailable.
      • Used for continued or initiation of uterine atony.
      • Contraindications: Avoid undiluted bolus IV due to risks of hypotension or cardiac arrhythmias.
  • Second-Line Agents:
    • Ergot Alkaloids:
      • Examples: Ergonovine, Methylergonovine (Methergine).
      • Usage:
        • Rapid tetanic uterine contractions (last ~45 minutes).
        • Dosage: 0.2 mg IM, repeatable every 2-4 hours.
      • Contraindications:
      • Hypertension, preeclampsia, or concomitant HIV protease inhibitors.
    • Prostaglandins:
      • Carboprost Tromethamine (Hemabate):
        • Dosage: 250 µg IM, repeatable at 15-90 min intervals (max 8 doses).
        • Side Effects: Diarrhea, hypertension, vomiting, fever, flushing, tachycardia, pulmonary constriction.
        • Contraindications: Asthma, pulmonary hypertension, renal/liver/cardiac disease, suspected amniotic fluid embolism.
      • Misoprostol:
        • Synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue.
        • Dosage: 600-1000 µg rectally, orally, or sublingually.
        • No added effect compared to oxytocin or ergometrine for treatment of uterine atony. (Option B)
      • Dinoprostone (Prostaglandin E2):
        • Off-label use: 20 mg rectally/vaginally every 2 hours.
        • Side Effects: Diarrhea, hypotension.
        • Due to hypotension, it is contraindicated in some cases and not used for hemorrhage management in certain centers. (Option A)
           

Latanoprost (Option C): A prostaglandin F2α analogue, designed for ophthalmic use to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma. It has no role in managing postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be given in bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Erythromycin

Explanation:

  • Erythromycin is not commonly used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial Vaginosis (BV):

  • A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora.
  • Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid.
  • Pathogenesis:
    • Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria.
    • Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis.
    • Not sexually transmitted.
  • Symptoms:
    • 50% are asymptomatic.
    • Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent.
    • Minimal vulval irritation.
  • Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features):
    • White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
    • Discharge with pH >4.5.
    • Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test).
    • Presence of clue cells on wet mount.
  • Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria.
  • Complications:
    • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM)
    • Preterm labor
  • Treatment:
    • Metronidazole (DOC): (Option C)
      • 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%).
      • Single 1 g dose cures only 45%.
    • Clindamycin: (Option A)
      • 2% cream locally (85% effective).
      • Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days.
    • Alternatives: Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, tinidazole or sulfa drugs. (Option D)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Dermatomyositis

  • The patient's presentation of proximal muscle weakness (difficulty with stairs, rising from chair, and hair combing) along with the pathognomonic violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids (heliotrope rash) suggest Dermatomyositis . This inflammatory myopathy typically affects middle-aged individuals and has a combination of muscle and skin involvement.

Dermatomyositis

Definition

Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age.

 

Clinical features

Clinical features

  • It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal)
  • Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease.

  • Gottron’s sign: Symmetric, confluent, violaceous macular erythema (CMVE) on the back of fingers, on the extensor surfaces of joints of the elbows, knees, or ankles
  • CMVE is seen over other sites too, and is named accordingly.
    • Heliotrope rash: CMVE over the periorbital skin

    • V-Sign: CMVE over the anterior aspect of the neck

    • Shawl sign: Involvement of upper back

    • Holster sign: Rash over the lateral aspect of the thigh

    • Mechanic’s hand: Hyperkeratosis and fissuring on the edges of the fingers

Inclusion body myositis (Option A) primarily affects older people and typically presents with distal muscle weakness and asymmetric involvement. Unlike dermatomyositis, it does not have associated skin manifestations and tends to affect finger flexors and quadriceps preferentially.

Polymyositis (Option C) is an autoimmune inflammatory muscle disease that presents with symmetric proximal muscle weakness. However, it lacks the characteristic skin manifestations seen in dermatomyositis, particularly the heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules.

Scleroderma (Option D) is a connective tissue disorder primarily affecting the skin and internal organs. While it can cause muscle weakness, its hallmark features are skin thickening and fibrosis, not the violaceous rash characteristic of dermatomyositis. It also presents with Raynaud's phenomenon and internal organ involvement.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Myasthenia gravis

  • The diagnosis for Myasthenia gravis is supported by the classic presentation of fatigable muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day (diurnal variation), ptosis, and positive response to neostigmine. The improvement with neostigmine, an Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor which increases acetylcholine availability at the neuromuscular junction, is particularly diagnostic of myasthenia gravis.

Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Myasthenia Gravis

Clinical Features
  • Diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, dysphagia
  • Weakness in oculomotor, pharyngeal, limb, neck extensors
  • Fluctuation and fatigue worse with activity, improved by rest
  • Fatiguability increases as the day passes (diurnal variation)
  • Initial symptoms frequently ocular (diplopia/ptosis)
  • Facial weakness produces "snarling" expression

Physical Examination
  • Eye movements and ptosis
  • Assessment of muscle strength in neck and extremities
  • Weakness following repetitive muscle activation
  • Normal deep tendon reflexes
  • No sensory abnormalities
  • Symptoms relieved by Anticholinesterases

Diagnostic Tests
  • Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% generalized MG)
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies (in ~40% of AChR-negative cases)
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation
  • Single-fiber EMG
  • CT or MRI of chest (to evaluate thymus)

Clinical Tests
  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: 2mg + 8mg IV
  • Ice pack test for ptosis
  • Fatigue testing (repeated muscle activation)

Huntington chorea (Option B) is a genetic condition characterized by involuntary movements, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms. It does not present with ptosis or show diurnal variation, nor does it respond to neostigmine.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (Option C) presents with progressive muscle weakness, but lacks the characteristic diurnal variation seen in myasthenia gravis. ALS does not typically begin with ptosis and shows no improvement with neostigmine.

External ophthalmoplegia (Option D) can cause ptosis but does not demonstrate the distinctive pattern of fatigue and improvement with rest. Additionally, external ophthalmoplegia does not respond to neostigmine and lacks the diurnal variation characteristic of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves:

choices.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face
Ipsilateral lower half of the face
Contralateral lower half of the face

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face

  • Bell's palsy is an acute peripheral facial nerve (CN VII) palsy and typically presents with unilateral facial weakness or paralysis, affecting both the upper and lower portions of the face on the same (ipsilateral) side.

Bell’s Palsy

Causes
  • Inflammation of facial nerve
  • HSV-1 reactivation- Common cause
  • VZV reactivation in Ramsay Hunt
  • Edema within facial canal

Clinical Features
  • Acute onset (24-72 hours)
  • Complete unilateral facial paralysis
  • Loss of taste anterior 2/3 tongue
  • Hyperacusis (stapedius paralysis)
  • Decreased tear production
  • Bell's phenomenon present

Diagnostic Approach
  • Clinical diagnosis primary
  • EMG/NCS if no improvement
  • MRI if atypical features
  • CSF analysis if indicated
  • Lyme titers in endemic areas

Treatment & Prognosis
  • Prednisone 60-80mg × 5 days
  • Valacyclovir 1000mg TID × 5-7 days
  • Eye protection crucial
  • 80% recovery rate
  • Axonal degeneration = worse prognosis
  • Incomplete paralysis in 1st week = best prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Metoprolol

  • The clinical evidence indicates that beta-blockers like metoprolol significantly reduce mortality in heart failure patients. Beta-blockers work by blocking the effects of chronic sympathetic activation in heart failure.
  • Metoprolol, specifically, has been proven to reduce the ill-effects of chronic sympathetic activation in heart failure, improve left ventricular function, reduce mortality and decrease hospitalizations. Metoprolol, along with ACE inhibitors, demonstrate mortality benefits in heart failure patients.

First-line drugs used in the treatment of Chronic CHF (mortality-reducing)

ARBs/ACE-inhibitors/ARNI
  • Either of these can be started as initial therapy.
  • ACE-inhibitors: Captopril, Enalapril
  • ARBs: Telmisartan, Olmesartan
  • ARNI: ARB+Neprilysin inhibitor - Valsartan-Sacubitril (most preferred 1st line drug)
  • ADR: Cough, angioedema

Beta-blockers
  • Cardioselective (2nd gen): Metoprolol, Bisoprolol
  • 3rd gen: Carvedilol (both α- & β- blocking action) - Best beta blocker for heart failure
  • ADR: Bradycardia, Hypotension

SGLT-2 Inhibitors
  • Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin
  • ADR: UTI, Forunier gangrene, Euglycemic DKA

Aldosterone antagonists
  • Spironolactone
  • ADR: Gynaecomastia

Furosemide (Option B): While furosemide is commonly used in heart failure for symptom relief and fluid management, it has not been shown to reduce mortality in heart failure patients. It primarily helps manage congestion and improve symptoms but does not affect the underlying disease progression or survival.

Prazosin (Option C): Although prazosin is an alpha-blocker that can reduce afterload, clinical trials have not demonstrated mortality benefit in heart failure patients. In fact, alpha-blockers may increase the risk of heart failure worsening due to their vasodilatory effects and reflex sympathetic activation.

Torsemide (Option D): Similar to furosemide, torsemide is a loop diuretic that helps manage fluid overload and symptoms in heart failure but has not been proven to reduce mortality. While it may have better bioavailability than furosemide, neither medication has shown a survival benefit in clinical trials.
